"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adaptive radiation</span>"	Period of evolutionary change in which groups of organisms form many new species whose adaptations allow them to fill vacant ecological roles in their communities.
Period of evolutionary change in which groups of organisms form many new species whose adaptations allow them to fill vacant ecological roles in their communities.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adaptive radiation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ATP (adenosine triphosphate)</span>"	An adenine-containing nucleoside triphosphate that releases free energy when its phosphate bonds are hydrolyzed. This energy is used to drive endergonic reactions in cells.
An adenine-containing nucleoside triphosphate that releases free energy when its phosphate bonds are hydrolyzed. This energy is used to drive endergonic reactions in cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ATP (adenosine triphosphate)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Archaea</span>"	One of two prokaryotic domains, the other being Bacteria.
One of two prokaryotic domains, the other being Bacteria.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Archaea</span>"

Member of the prokaryotic domain Archaea.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">archaean</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bioinformatics</span>"	The use of computers, software, and mathematical models to process and integrate biological information from large data sets.
The use of computers, software, and mathematical models to process and integrate biological information from large data sets.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bioinformatics</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">controlled experiment</span>"	An experiment in which an experimental group is compared with a control group that varies only in the factor being tested.
An experiment in which an experimental group is compared with a control group that varies only in the factor being tested.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">controlled experiment</span>"

A type of logic in which specific results are predicted from a general premise.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">deductive reasoning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)</span>"	A double-stranded, helical nucleic acid molecule consisting of nucleotide monomers with a deoxyribose sugar and the nitrogenous bases adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T); capable of replicating and determining the inherited structure of a cell’s proteins.
A double-stranded, helical nucleic acid molecule consisting of nucleotide monomers with a deoxyribose sugar and the nitrogenous bases adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T); capable of replicating and determining the inherited structure of a cell’s proteins.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)</span>"

The process of scientific inquiry that focuses on describing nature.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">discovery science</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">emergent properties</span>"	New properties that arise with each step upward in the hierarchy of life, owing to the arrangement and interactions of parts as complexity increases.
New properties that arise with each step upward in the hierarchy of life, owing to the arrangement and interactions of parts as complexity increases.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">emergent properties</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eukaryotic cell</span>"	A type of cell with a membrane-enclosed nucleus and membrane-enclosed organelles. Organisms with [these] (protists, plants, fungi, and animals) are called eukaryotes.
A type of cell with a membrane-enclosed nucleus and membrane-enclosed organelles. Organisms with [these] (protists, plants, fungi, and animals) are called eukaryotes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eukaryotic cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evolution</span>"	Descent with modification; the idea that living species are descendants of ancestral species that were different from the present-day ones; also defined more narrowly as the change in the genetic composition of a population from generation to generation.
Descent with modification; the idea that living species are descendants of ancestral species that were different from the present-day ones; also defined more narrowly as the change in the genetic composition of a population from generation to generation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evolution</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genome</span>"	The genetic material of an organism or virus; the complete complement of an organism’s or virus’s genes along with its noncoding nucleic acid sequences.
The genetic material of an organism or virus; the complete complement of an organism’s or virus’s genes along with its noncoding nucleic acid sequences.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genome</span>"

A tentative answer to a well-framed question, narrower in scope than a theory and subject to testing.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hypothesis</span>"

A type of logic in which generalizations are based on a large number of specific observations.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inductive reasoning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inquiry</span>"	The search for information and explanation, often focused by specific questions.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">negative feedback</span>"	A primary mechanism of homeostasis, whereby a change in a physiological variable triggers a response that counteracts the initial change.
A primary mechanism of homeostasis, whereby a change in a physiological variable triggers a response that counteracts the initial change.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">negative feedback</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">order</span>"	In classification, the taxonomic category above the level of family.
In classification, the taxonomic category above the level of family.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">order</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">positive feedback</span>"	A physiological control mechanism in which a change in a variable triggers mechanisms that amplify the change.
A physiological control mechanism in which a change in a variable triggers mechanisms that amplify the change.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">positive feedback</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prokaryotic cell</span>"	A type of cell lacking a membrane-enclosed nucleus and membrane-enclosed organelles. Organisms with [these] (bacteria and archaea) are called prokaryotes.
A type of cell lacking a membrane-enclosed nucleus and membrane-enclosed organelles. Organisms with [these] (bacteria and archaea) are called prokaryotes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prokaryotic cell</span>"

The application of scientific knowledge for a specific purpose, often involving industry or commerce but also including uses in basic research.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">technology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ammonia</span>"	A small, very toxic molecule (NH3) produced by nitrogen fixation or as a metabolic waste product of protein and nucleic acid metabolism.
A small, very toxic molecule (NH3) produced by nitrogen fixation or as a metabolic waste product of protein and nucleic acid metabolism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ammonia</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anion</span>"	A negatively charged ion.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atom</span>"	The smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.
The smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atom</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atomic mass</span>"	The total mass of an atom, which is the mass in grams of 1 mole of the atom.
The total mass of an atom, which is the mass in grams of 1 mole of the atom.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atomic mass</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atomic nucleus</span>"	An atom’s dense central core, containing protons and neutrons.
An atom’s dense central core, containing protons and neutrons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atomic nucleus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atomic number</span>"	The number of protons in the nucleus of an atom, unique for each element and designated by a subscript to the left of the elemental symbol.
The number of protons in the nucleus of an atom, unique for each element and designated by a subscript to the left of the elemental symbol.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atomic number</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cation</span>"	A positively charged ion.
A positively charged ion.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemical bond</span>"	An attraction between two atoms, resulting from a sharing of outer-shell electrons or the presence of opposite charges on the atoms. The bonded atoms gain complete outer electron shells.
An attraction between two atoms, resulting from a sharing of outer-shell electrons or the presence of opposite charges on the atoms. The bonded atoms gain complete outer electron shells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemical bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemical equilibrium</span>"	In a chemical reaction, the state in which the rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the reverse reaction, so that the relative concentrations of the reactants and products do not change with time.
In a chemical reaction, the state in which the rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the reverse reaction, so that the relative concentrations of the reactants and products do not change with time.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemical equilibrium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemical reaction</span>"	The making and breaking of chemical bonds, leading to changes in the composition of matter.
The making and breaking of chemical bonds, leading to changes in the composition of matter.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemical reaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">compound</span>"	A substance consisting of two or more different elements combined in a fixed ratio.
A substance consisting of two or more different elements combined in a fixed ratio.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">compound</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">covalent bond</span>"	A type of strong chemical bond in which two atoms share one or more pairs of valence electrons.
A type of strong chemical bond in which two atoms share one or more pairs of valence electrons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">covalent bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dalton</span>"	A measure of mass for atoms and subatomic particles; the same as the atomic mass unit, or amu.
A measure of mass for atoms and subatomic particles; the same as the atomic mass unit, or amu.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dalton</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">double bond</span>"	The sharing of two pairs of valence electrons by two atoms.
The sharing of two pairs of valence electrons by two atoms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">double bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electron</span>"	A subatomic particle with a single negative electrical charge and a mass about 1/2,000 that of a neutron or proton. One or more [these] move around the nucleus of an atom.
A subatomic particle with a single negative electrical charge and a mass about 1/2,000 that of a neutron or proton. One or more [these] move around the nucleus of an atom.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electron shell</span>"	An energy level of electrons at a characteristic average distance from the nucleus of an atom.
An energy level of electrons at a characteristic average distance from the nucleus of an atom.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electron shell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electronegativity</span>"	The attraction of a given atom for the electrons of a covalent bond.
The attraction of a given atom for the electrons of a covalent bond.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electronegativity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">element</span>"	Any substance that cannot be broken down to any other substance by chemical reactions.
Any substance that cannot be broken down to any other substance by chemical reactions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">element</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">energy</span>"	The capacity to cause change, especially to do work (to move matter against an opposing force).
The capacity to cause change, especially to do work (to move matter against an opposing force).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">energy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrogen bond</span>"	A type of weak chemical bond that is formed when the slightly positive hydrogen atom of a polar covalent bond in one molecule is attracted to the slightly negative atom of a polar covalent bond in another molecule.
A type of weak chemical bond that is formed when the slightly positive hydrogen atom of a polar covalent bond in one molecule is attracted to the slightly negative atom of a polar covalent bond in another molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrogen bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ion</span>"	An atom or group of atoms that has gained or lost one or more electrons, thus acquiring a charge.
An atom or group of atoms that has gained or lost one or more electrons, thus acquiring a charge.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ionic bond</span>"	A chemical bond resulting from the attraction between oppositely charged ions.
A chemical bond resulting from the attraction between oppositely charged ions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ionic bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ionic compound</span>"	A compound resulting from the formation of an ionic bond; also called a salt.
A compound resulting from the formation of an ionic bond; also called a salt.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ionic compound</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">isotope</span>"	One of several atomic forms of an element, each with the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons, thus differing in atomic mass.
One of several atomic forms of an element, each with the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons, thus differing in atomic mass.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">isotope</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mass number</span>"	The sum of the number of protons and neutrons in an atom’s nucleus.
The sum of the number of protons and neutrons in an atom’s nucleus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mass number</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">matter</span>"	Anything that takes up space and has mass.
Anything that takes up space and has mass.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">matter</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecular formula</span>"	A type of molecular notation representing the quantity of constituent atoms, but not the nature of the bonds that join them.
A type of molecular notation representing the quantity of constituent atoms, but not the nature of the bonds that join them.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecular formula</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecule</span>"	Two or more atoms held together by covalent bonds.
Two or more atoms held together by covalent bonds.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neutron</span>"	A subatomic particle having no electrical charge (electrically neutral), with a mass of about 1.7 × 10-24 g, found in the nucleus of an atom.
A subatomic particle having no electrical charge (electrically neutral), with a mass of about 1.7 × 10-24 g, found in the nucleus of an atom.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neutron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nonpolar covalent bond</span>"	A type of covalent bond in which electrons are shared equally between two atoms of similar electronegativity.
A type of covalent bond in which electrons are shared equally between two atoms of similar electronegativity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nonpolar covalent bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleus</span>"	(1) An atom’s central core, containing protons and neutrons. (2) The chromosome-containing organelle of a eukaryotic cell. (3) A cluster of neurons.
(1) An atom’s central core, containing protons and neutrons. (2) The chromosome-containing organelle of a eukaryotic cell. (3) A cluster of neurons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">orbital</span>"	The three-dimensional space where an electron is found 90% of the time.
The three-dimensional space where an electron is found 90% of the time.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">orbital</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polar covalent bond</span>"	A covalent bond between atoms that differ in electronegativity. The shared electrons are pulled closer to the more electronegative atom, making it slightly negative and the other atom slightly positive.
A covalent bond between atoms that differ in electronegativity. The shared electrons are pulled closer to the more electronegative atom, making it slightly negative and the other atom slightly positive.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polar covalent bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">potential energy</span>"	The energy that matter possesses as a result of its location or spatial arrangement (structure).
The energy that matter possesses as a result of its location or spatial arrangement (structure).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">potential energy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">product</span>"	A material resulting from a chemical reaction.
A material resulting from a chemical reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">product</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proton</span>"	A subatomic particle with a single positive electrical charge, with a mass of about 1.7 × 10-24 g, found in the nucleus of an atom.
A subatomic particle with a single positive electrical charge, with a mass of about 1.7 × 10-24 g, found in the nucleus of an atom.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proton</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radioactive isotope</span>"	An isotope (an atomic form of a chemical element) that is unstable; the nucleus decays spontaneously, giving off detectable particles and energy.
An isotope (an atomic form of a chemical element) that is unstable; the nucleus decays spontaneously, giving off detectable particles and energy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radioactive isotope</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reactant</span>"	A starting material in a chemical reaction.
A starting material in a chemical reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reactant</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">salt</span>"	A compound resulting from the formation of an ionic bond; also called an ionic compound.
A compound resulting from the formation of an ionic bond; also called an ionic compound.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">salt</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">single bond</span>"	The sharing of one pair of valence electrons by two atoms.
The sharing of one pair of valence electrons by two atoms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">single bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">structural formula</span>"	A type of molecular notation in which the constituent atoms are joined by lines representing covalent bonds.
A type of molecular notation in which the constituent atoms are joined by lines representing covalent bonds.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">structural formula</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">theory</span>"	An explanation that is broad in scope, generates new hypotheses, and is supported by a large body of evidence.
An explanation that is broad in scope, generates new hypotheses, and is supported by a large body of evidence.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">theory</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trace element</span>"	An element indispensable for life but required in extremely minute amounts.
An element indispensable for life but required in extremely minute amounts.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trace element</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">valence</span>"	The bonding capacity of a given atom; usually equals the number of unpaired electrons required to complete the atom’s outermost shell.
The bonding capacity of a given atom; usually equals the number of unpaired electrons required to complete the atom’s outermost shell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">valence</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">valence electron</span>"	An electron in the outermost electron shell.
An electron in the outermost electron shell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">valence electron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">valence shell</span>"	The outermost energy shell of an atom, containing the valence electrons involved in the chemical reactions of that atom.
The outermost energy shell of an atom, containing the valence electrons involved in the chemical reactions of that atom.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">valence shell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">van der Waals interactions</span>"	Weak attractions between molecules or parts of molecules that result from localized charge fluctuations.
Weak attractions between molecules or parts of molecules that result from localized charge fluctuations.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">van der Waals interactions</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acid</span>"	A substance that increases the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution.
A substance that increases the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acid precipitation</span>"	Rain, snow, or fog that is more acidic than pH 5.2.
Rain, snow, or fog that is more acidic than pH 5.2.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acid precipitation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adhesion</span>"	The attraction between different kinds of molecules.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">base</span>"	A substance that reduces the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">buffer</span>"	A substance that consists of acid and base forms in a solution and that minimizes changes in pH when extraneous acids or bases are added to the solution.
A substance that consists of acid and base forms in a solution and that minimizes changes in pH when extraneous acids or bases are added to the solution.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">buffer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">calorie (cal)</span>"	The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of 1 g of water by 1°C; also the amount of heat energy that 1 g of water releases when it cools by 1°C. [This] (with a capital [T]), usually used to indicate the energy content of food, is a kilocalorie.
The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of 1 g of water by 1°C; also the amount of heat energy that 1 g of water releases when it cools by 1°C. [This] (with a capital [T]), usually used to indicate the energy content of food, is a kilocalorie.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">calorie (cal)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Celsius scale</span>"	A temperature scale (°C) equal to 5/9(°F – 32) that measures the freezing point of water at 0°C and the boiling point of water at 100°C.
A temperature scale (°C) equal to 5/9(°F – 32) that measures the freezing point of water at 0°C and the boiling point of water at 100°C.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Celsius scale</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cohesion</span>"	The binding together of like molecules, often by hydrogen bonds.
The binding together of like molecules, often by hydrogen bonds.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cohesion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">colloid</span>"	A mixture made up of a liquid and particles that (because of their large size) remain suspended rather than dissolved in that liquid.
A mixture made up of a liquid and particles that (because of their large size) remain suspended rather than dissolved in that liquid.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">colloid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evaporation</span>"	The process by which a liquid changes to a gas.
The process by which a liquid changes to a gas.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evaporation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evaporative cooling</span>"	The process in which the surface of an object becomes cooler during evaporation, owing to a change of the molecules with the greatest kinetic energy from the liquid to the gaseous state.
The process in which the surface of an object becomes cooler during evaporation, owing to a change of the molecules with the greatest kinetic energy from the liquid to the gaseous state.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evaporative cooling</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heat</span>"	The total amount of kinetic energy due to the random motion of atoms or molecules in a body of matter; also called thermal energy. [This] is energy in its most random form.
The total amount of kinetic energy due to the random motion of atoms or molecules in a body of matter; also called thermal energy. [This] is energy in its most random form.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heat</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heat of vaporization</span>"	The quantity of heat a liquid must absorb for 1 g of it to be converted from the liquid to the gaseous state.
The quantity of heat a liquid must absorb for 1 g of it to be converted from the liquid to the gaseous state.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heat of vaporization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydration shell</span>"	The sphere of water molecules around a dissolved ion.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrogen ion</span>"	A single proton with a charge of 1+. The dissociation of a water molecule (H2O) leads to the generation of a hydroxide ion (OH–) and a [this] (H+).
A single proton with a charge of 1+. The dissociation of a water molecule (H2O) leads to the generation of a hydroxide ion (OH–) and a [this] (H+).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrogen ion</span>"

A water molecule that has an extra proton bound to it; H3O+.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydronium ion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrophilic</span>"	Having an affinity for water.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">joule (J)</span>"	A unit of energy: 1 [this] = 0.239 cal; 1 cal = 4.184 [this].
A unit of energy: 1 [this] = 0.239 cal; 1 cal = 4.184 [this].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">joule (J)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kilocalorie (kcal)</span>"	A thousand calories; the amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water by 1°C.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kinetic energy</span>"	The energy associated with the relative motion of objects. Moving matter can perform work by imparting motion to other matter.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molarity</span>"	A common measure of solute concentration, referring to the number of moles of solute per liter of solution.
A common measure of solute concentration, referring to the number of moles of solute per liter of solution.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molarity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mole (mol)</span>"	The number of grams of a substance that equals its molecular weight in daltons and contains Avogadro’s number of molecules.
The number of grams of a substance that equals its molecular weight in daltons and contains Avogadro’s number of molecules.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mole (mol)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecular mass</span>"	The sum of the masses of all the atoms in a molecule; sometimes called molecular weight.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pH</span>"	A measure of hydrogen ion concentration equal to –log [H+] and ranging in value from 0 to 14.
A measure of hydrogen ion concentration equal to –log [H+] and ranging in value from 0 to 14.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pH</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polar molecule</span>"	A molecule (such as water) with opposite charges on different ends of the molecule.
A molecule (such as water) with opposite charges on different ends of the molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polar molecule</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">solution</span>"	A liquid that is a homogeneous mixture of two or more substances.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">specific heat</span>"	The amount of heat that must be absorbed or lost for 1 g of a substance to change its temperature by 1°C.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amino group</span>"	A chemical group consisting of a nitrogen atom bonded to two hydrogen atoms; can act as a base in solution, accepting a hydrogen ion and acquiring a charge of 1+.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">urea</span>"	A soluble nitrogenous waste produced in the liver by a metabolic cycle that combines ammonia with carbon dioxide.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alpha (α) helix</span>"	A spiral shape constituting one form of the secondary structure of proteins, arising from a specific pattern of hydrogen bonding.
A spiral shape constituting one form of the secondary structure of proteins, arising from a specific pattern of hydrogen bonding.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alpha (α) helix</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atherosclerosis</span>"	A cardiovascular disease in which fatty deposits called plaques develop in the inner walls of the arteries, obstructing the arteries and causing them to harden.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">beta (β) pleated sheet</span>"	One form of the secondary structure of proteins in which the polypeptide chain folds back and forth. Two regions of the chain lie parallel to each other and are held together by hydrogen bonds.
One form of the secondary structure of proteins in which the polypeptide chain folds back and forth. Two regions of the chain lie parallel to each other and are held together by hydrogen bonds.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">beta (β) pleated sheet</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carbohydrate</span>"	A sugar (monosaccharide) or one of its dimers (disaccharides) or polymers (polysaccharides).
A sugar (monosaccharide) or one of its dimers (disaccharides) or polymers (polysaccharides).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carbohydrate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">catalyst</span>"	A chemical agent that increases the rate of a reaction without being consumed by the reaction.
A chemical agent that increases the rate of a reaction without being consumed by the reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">catalyst</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cellulose</span>"	A structural polysaccharide of plant cell walls, consisting of glucose monomers joined by β glycosidic linkages.
A structural polysaccharide of plant cell walls, consisting of glucose monomers joined by β glycosidic linkages.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cellulose</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chaperonin</span>"	A protein molecule that assists in the proper folding of other proteins.
A protein molecule that assists in the proper folding of other proteins.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chaperonin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chitin</span>"	A structural polysaccharide, consisting of amino sugar monomers, found in many fungal cell walls and in the exoskeletons of all arthropods.
A structural polysaccharide, consisting of amino sugar monomers, found in many fungal cell walls and in the exoskeletons of all arthropods.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chitin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cholesterol</span>"	A steroid that forms an essential component of animal cell membranes and acts as a precursor molecule for the synthesis of other biologically important steroids, such as hormones.
A steroid that forms an essential component of animal cell membranes and acts as a precursor molecule for the synthesis of other biologically important steroids, such as hormones.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cholesterol</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">collagen</span>"	A glycoprotein in the extracellular matrix of animal cells that forms strong fibers, found extensively in connective tissue and bone; the most abundant protein in the animal kingdom.
A glycoprotein in the extracellular matrix of animal cells that forms strong fibers, found extensively in connective tissue and bone; the most abundant protein in the animal kingdom.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">collagen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">condensation reaction</span>"	A reaction in which two molecules become covalently bonded to each other through the loss of a small molecule, usually water, in which case it is also called a dehydration reaction.
A reaction in which two molecules become covalently bonded to each other through the loss of a small molecule, usually water, in which case it is also called a dehydration reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">condensation reaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dehydration reaction</span>"	A chemical reaction in which two molecules covalently bond to each other with the removal of a water molecule.
A chemical reaction in which two molecules covalently bond to each other with the removal of a water molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dehydration reaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">deoxyribose</span>"	The sugar component of DNA nucleotides, having one fewer hydroxyl group than ribose, the sugar component of RNA nucleotides.
The sugar component of DNA nucleotides, having one fewer hydroxyl group than ribose, the sugar component of RNA nucleotides.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">deoxyribose</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">disaccharide</span>"	A double sugar, consisting of two monosaccharides joined by a glycosidic linkage formed during dehydration synthesis.
A double sugar, consisting of two monosaccharides joined by a glycosidic linkage formed during dehydration synthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">disaccharide</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">disulfide bridge</span>"	A strong covalent bond formed when the sulfur of one cysteine monomer bonds to the sulfur of another cysteine monomer.
A strong covalent bond formed when the sulfur of one cysteine monomer bonds to the sulfur of another cysteine monomer.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">disulfide bridge</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">double helix</span>"	The form of native DNA, referring to its two adjacent antiparallel polynucleotide strands wound around an imaginary axis into a spiral shape.
The form of native DNA, referring to its two adjacent antiparallel polynucleotide strands wound around an imaginary axis into a spiral shape.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">double helix</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endorphin</span>"	Any of several hormones produced in the brain and anterior pituitary that inhibits pain perception.
Any of several hormones produced in the brain and anterior pituitary that inhibits pain perception.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endorphin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">enzyme</span>"	A macromolecule serving as a catalyst, a chemical agent that changes the rate of a reaction without being consumed by the reaction.
A macromolecule serving as a catalyst, a chemical agent that changes the rate of a reaction without being consumed by the reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">enzyme</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fat</span>"	A lipid consisting of three fatty acids linked to one glycerol molecule; also called a triacylglycerol or triglyceride.
A lipid consisting of three fatty acids linked to one glycerol molecule; also called a triacylglycerol or triglyceride.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fat</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fatty acid</span>"	A long carbon chain carboxylic acid. [These] vary in length and in the number and location of double bonds; three [these] linked to a glycerol molecule form a fat molecule, also known as a triacylglycerol or triglyceride.
A long carbon chain carboxylic acid. [These] vary in length and in the number and location of double bonds; three [these] linked to a glycerol molecule form a fat molecule, also known as a triacylglycerol or triglyceride.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fatty acid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene</span>"	A discrete unit of hereditary information consisting of a specific nucleotide sequence in DNA (or RNA, in some viruses).
A discrete unit of hereditary information consisting of a specific nucleotide sequence in DNA (or RNA, in some viruses).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycosidic linkage</span>"	A covalent bond formed between two monosaccharides by a dehydration reaction.
A covalent bond formed between two monosaccharides by a dehydration reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycosidic linkage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrolysis</span>"	A chemical process that lyses, or splits, molecules by the addition of water, functioning in disassembly of polymers to monomers.
A chemical process that lyses, or splits, molecules by the addition of water, functioning in disassembly of polymers to monomers.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrolysis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrophobic interaction</span>"	A type of weak chemical bond formed when molecules that do not mix with water coalesce to exclude water.
A type of weak chemical bond formed when molecules that do not mix with water coalesce to exclude water.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrophobic interaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">insulin</span>"	A hormone secreted by pancreatic beta cells that lowers blood glucose levels. It promotes the uptake of glucose by most body cells and the synthesis and storage of glycogen in the liver and also stimulates protein and fat synthesis.
A hormone secreted by pancreatic beta cells that lowers blood glucose levels. It promotes the uptake of glucose by most body cells and the synthesis and storage of glycogen in the liver and also stimulates protein and fat synthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">insulin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lipid</span>"	One of a group of compounds, including fats, phospholipids, and steroids, that mix poorly, if at all, with water.
One of a group of compounds, including fats, phospholipids, and steroids, that mix poorly, if at all, with water.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lipid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">messenger RNA (mRNA)</span>"	A type of RNA, synthesized using a DNA template, that attaches to ribosomes in the cytoplasm and specifies the primary structure of a protein.
A type of RNA, synthesized using a DNA template, that attaches to ribosomes in the cytoplasm and specifies the primary structure of a protein.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">messenger RNA (mRNA)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monomer</span>"	The subunit that serves as the building block of a polymer.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monosaccharide</span>"	The simplest carbohydrate, active alone or serving as a monomer for disaccharides and polysaccharides. Also known as simple sugars, [these] have molecular formulas that are generally some multiple of CH2O.
The simplest carbohydrate, active alone or serving as a monomer for disaccharides and polysaccharides. Also known as simple sugars, [these] have molecular formulas that are generally some multiple of CH2O.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monosaccharide</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleic acid</span>"	A polymer (polynucleotide) consisting of many nucleotide monomers; serves as a blueprint for proteins and, through the actions of proteins, for all cellular activities. The two types are DNA and RNA.
A polymer (polynucleotide) consisting of many nucleotide monomers; serves as a blueprint for proteins and, through the actions of proteins, for all cellular activities. The two types are DNA and RNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleic acid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleotide</span>"	The building block of a nucleic acid, consisting of a five-carbon sugar covalently bonded to a nitrogenous base and a phosphate group.
The building block of a nucleic acid, consisting of a five-carbon sugar covalently bonded to a nitrogenous base and a phosphate group.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleotide</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peptide bond</span>"	The covalent bond between the carboxyl group on one amino acid and the amino group on another, formed by a dehydration reaction.
The covalent bond between the carboxyl group on one amino acid and the amino group on another, formed by a dehydration reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peptide bond</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phospholipid</span>"	A lipid made up of glycerol joined to two fatty acids and a phosphate group. The hydrocarbon chains of the fatty acids act as nonpolar, hydrophobic tails, while the rest of the molecule acts as a polar, hydrophilic head. [These] form bilayers that function as biological membranes.
A lipid made up of glycerol joined to two fatty acids and a phosphate group. The hydrocarbon chains of the fatty acids act as nonpolar, hydrophobic tails, while the rest of the molecule acts as a polar, hydrophilic head. [These] form bilayers that function as biological membranes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phospholipid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polymer</span>"	A long molecule consisting of many similar or identical monomers linked together.
A long molecule consisting of many similar or identical monomers linked together.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polymer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polypeptide</span>"	A polymer (chain) of many amino acids linked together by peptide bonds.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polysaccharide</span>"	A polymer of many monosaccharides, formed by dehydration reactions.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary structure</span>"	The level of protein structure referring to the specific sequence of amino acids.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protein</span>"	A functional biological molecule consisting of one or more polypeptides folded and coiled into a specific three-dimensional structure.
A functional biological molecule consisting of one or more polypeptides folded and coiled into a specific three-dimensional structure.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protein kinase</span>"	An enzyme that transfers phosphate groups from ATP to a protein, thus phosphorylating the protein.
An enzyme that transfers phosphate groups from ATP to a protein, thus phosphorylating the protein.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protein kinase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">purine</span>"	One of two types of nitrogenous bases found in nucleotides, characterized by a six-membered ring fused to a five-membered ring. Adenine (A) and guanine (G) are [these].
One of two types of nitrogenous bases found in nucleotides, characterized by a six-membered ring fused to a five-membered ring. Adenine (A) and guanine (G) are [these].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">purine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pyrimidine</span>"	One of two types of nitrogenous bases found in nucleotides, characterized by a six-membered ring. Cytosine (C), thymine (T), and uracil (U) are [these].
One of two types of nitrogenous bases found in nucleotides, characterized by a six-membered ring. Cytosine (C), thymine (T), and uracil (U) are [these].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pyrimidine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">quaternary structure</span>"	The particular shape of a complex, aggregate protein, defined by the characteristic three-dimensional arrangement of its constituent subunits, each a polypeptide.
The particular shape of a complex, aggregate protein, defined by the characteristic three-dimensional arrangement of its constituent subunits, each a polypeptide.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">quaternary structure</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ribonucleic acid (RNA)</span>"	A type of nucleic acid consisting of nucleotide monomers with a ribose sugar and the nitrogenous bases adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and uracil (U); usually single-stranded; functions in protein synthesis, gene regulation, and as the genome of some viruses.
A type of nucleic acid consisting of nucleotide monomers with a ribose sugar and the nitrogenous bases adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and uracil (U); usually single-stranded; functions in protein synthesis, gene regulation, and as the genome of some viruses. "<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">saturated fatty acid</span>"	A fatty acid in which all carbons in the hydrocarbon tail are connected by single bonds, thus maximizing the number of hydrogen atoms that are attached to the carbon skeleton.
A fatty acid in which all carbons in the hydrocarbon tail are connected by single bonds, thus maximizing the number of hydrogen atoms that are attached to the carbon skeleton.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">saturated fatty acid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary structure</span>"	The localized, repetitive coiling or folding of the polypeptide backbone of a protein due to hydrogen bond formation between constituents of the backbone.
The localized, repetitive coiling or folding of the polypeptide backbone of a protein due to hydrogen bond formation between constituents of the backbone.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary structure</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">starch</span>"	A storage polysaccharide in plants, consisting entirely of glucose monomers joined by a glycosidic linkages.
A storage polysaccharide in plants, consisting entirely of glucose monomers joined by a glycosidic linkages.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">starch</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">steroid</span>"	A type of lipid characterized by a carbon skeleton consisting of four rings with various chemical groups attached.
A type of lipid characterized by a carbon skeleton consisting of four rings with various chemical groups attached.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">steroid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tertiary structure</span>"	Irregular contortions of a protein molecule due to interactions of side chains involved in hydrophobic interactions, ionic bonds, hydrogen bonds, and disulfide bridges.
Irregular contortions of a protein molecule due to interactions of side chains involved in hydrophobic interactions, ionic bonds, hydrogen bonds, and disulfide bridges.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tertiary structure</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trans fat</span>"	An unsaturated fat containing one or more trans double bonds.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">triacylglycerol</span>"	Three fatty acids linked to one glycerol molecule; also called a fat or a triglyceride.
Three fatty acids linked to one glycerol molecule; also called a fat or a triglyceride.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">triacylglycerol</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">unsaturated fatty acid</span>"	A fatty acid possessing one or more double bonds between the carbons in the hydrocarbon tail. Such bonding reduces the number of hydrogen atoms attached to the carbon skeleton.
A fatty acid possessing one or more double bonds between the carbons in the hydrocarbon tail. Such bonding reduces the number of hydrogen atoms attached to the carbon skeleton.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">unsaturated fatty acid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">X-ray crystallography</span>"	A technique that depends on the diffraction of an X-ray beam by the individual atoms of a crystallized molecule to study the three-dimensional structure of the molecule.
A technique that depends on the diffraction of an X-ray beam by the individual atoms of a crystallized molecule to study the three-dimensional structure of the molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">X-ray crystallography</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polynucleotide</span>"	A polymer consisting of many nucleotide monomers in a chain; nucleotides can be those of DNA or RNA.
A polymer consisting of many nucleotide monomers in a chain; nucleotides can be those of DNA or RNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polynucleotide</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">activation energy</span>"	The amount of energy that reactants must absorb before a chemical reaction will start; also called free energy of activation.
The amount of energy that reactants must absorb before a chemical reaction will start; also called free energy of activation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">activation energy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">active site</span>"	The specific portion of an enzyme that binds the substrate by means of multiple weak interactions and that forms the pocket in which catalysis occurs.
The specific portion of an enzyme that binds the substrate by means of multiple weak interactions and that forms the pocket in which catalysis occurs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">active site</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">allosteric regulation</span>"	The binding of a regulatory molecule to a protein at one site that affects the function of the protein at a different site.
The binding of a regulatory molecule to a protein at one site that affects the function of the protein at a different site.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">allosteric regulation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anabolic pathway</span>"	A metabolic pathway that consumes energy to synthesize a complex molecule from simpler compounds.
A metabolic pathway that consumes energy to synthesize a complex molecule from simpler compounds.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anabolic pathway</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bioenergetics</span>"	(1) The overall flow and transformation of energy in an organism. (2) The study of how energy flows through organisms.
(1) The overall flow and transformation of energy in an organism. (2) The study of how energy flows through organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bioenergetics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">catabolic pathway</span>"	A metabolic pathway that releases energy by breaking down complex molecules to simpler compounds.
A metabolic pathway that releases energy by breaking down complex molecules to simpler compounds.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">catabolic pathway</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemical energy</span>"	Energy available in molecules for release in a chemical reaction; a form of potential energy.
Energy available in molecules for release in a chemical reaction; a form of potential energy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemical energy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">coenzyme</span>"	An organic molecule serving as a cofactor. Most vitamins function as [these] in metabolic reactions.
An organic molecule serving as a cofactor. Most vitamins function as [these] in metabolic reactions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">coenzyme</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cofactor</span>"	Any nonprotein molecule or ion that is required for the proper functioning of an enzyme. [These] can be permanently bound to the active site or may bind loosely with the substrate during catalysis.
Any nonprotein molecule or ion that is required for the proper functioning of an enzyme. [These] can be permanently bound to the active site or may bind loosely with the substrate during catalysis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cofactor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">competitive inhibitor</span>"	A substance that reduces the activity of an enzyme by entering the active site in place of the substrate whose structure it mimics.
A substance that reduces the activity of an enzyme by entering the active site in place of the substrate whose structure it mimics.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">competitive inhibitor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cooperativity</span>"	A kind of allosteric regulation whereby a shape change in one subunit of a protein caused by substrate binding is transmitted to all the others, facilitating binding of subsequent substrate molecules.
A kind of allosteric regulation whereby a shape change in one subunit of a protein caused by substrate binding is transmitted to all the others, facilitating binding of subsequent substrate molecules.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cooperativity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endergonic reaction</span>"	A nonspontaneous chemical reaction, in which free energy is absorbed from the surroundings.
A nonspontaneous chemical reaction, in which free energy is absorbed from the surroundings.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endergonic reaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">energy coupling</span>"	In cellular metabolism, the use of energy released from an exergonic reaction to drive an endergonic reaction.
In cellular metabolism, the use of energy released from an exergonic reaction to drive an endergonic reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">energy coupling</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">entropy</span>"	A measure of disorder, or randomness.
A measure of disorder, or randomness.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">entropy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">enzyme-substrate complex</span>"	A temporary complex formed when an enzyme binds to its substrate molecule(s).
A temporary complex formed when an enzyme binds to its substrate molecule(s).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">enzyme-substrate complex</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exergonic reaction</span>"	A spontaneous chemical reaction, in which there is a net release of free energy.
A spontaneous chemical reaction, in which there is a net release of free energy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exergonic reaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">feedback inhibition</span>"	A method of metabolic control in which the end product of a metabolic pathway acts as an inhibitor of an enzyme within that pathway.
A method of metabolic control in which the end product of a metabolic pathway acts as an inhibitor of an enzyme within that pathway.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">feedback inhibition</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">first law of thermodynamics</span>"	The principle of conservation of energy: Energy can be transferred and transformed, but it cannot be created or destroyed.
The principle of conservation of energy: Energy can be transferred and transformed, but it cannot be created or destroyed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">first law of thermodynamics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">free energy</span>"	The portion of a biological system’s energy that can perform work when temperature and pressure are uniform throughout the system. (The change in [this] of a system is calculated by the equation ΔG = ΔH – TΔS, where H is enthalpy [in biological systems, equivalent to total energy], T is absolute temperature, and S is entropy.)
The portion of a biological system’s energy that can perform work when temperature and pressure are uniform throughout the system. (The change in [this] of a system is calculated by the equation ΔG = ΔH – TΔS, where H is enthalpy [in biological systems, equivalent to total energy], T is absolute temperature, and S is entropy.)	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">free energy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hemoglobin</span>"	An iron-containing protein in red blood cells that reversibly binds oxygen.
An iron-containing protein in red blood cells that reversibly binds oxygen.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hemoglobin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">induced fit</span>"	Induced by entry of the substrate, the change in shape of the active site of an enzyme so that it binds more snugly to the substrate.
Induced by entry of the substrate, the change in shape of the active site of an enzyme so that it binds more snugly to the substrate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">induced fit</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metabolic pathway</span>"	A series of chemical reactions that either builds a complex molecule (anabolic pathway) or breaks down a complex molecule into simpler compounds (catabolic pathway).
A series of chemical reactions that either builds a complex molecule (anabolic pathway) or breaks down a complex molecule into simpler compounds (catabolic pathway).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metabolic pathway</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metabolism</span>"	The totality of an organism’s chemical reactions, consisting of catabolic and anabolic pathways, which manage the material and energy resources of the organism.
The totality of an organism’s chemical reactions, consisting of catabolic and anabolic pathways, which manage the material and energy resources of the organism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metabolism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">noncompetitive inhibitor</span>"	A substance that reduces the activity of an enzyme by binding to a location remote from the active site, changing the enzyme’s shape so that the active site no longer functions effectively.
A substance that reduces the activity of an enzyme by binding to a location remote from the active site, changing the enzyme’s shape so that the active site no longer functions effectively.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">noncompetitive inhibitor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phosphorylated</span>"	Referring to a molecule that is covalently bonded to a phosphate group.
Referring to a molecule that is covalently bonded to a phosphate group.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phosphorylated</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">second law of thermodynamics</span>"	The principle stating that every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe. Ordered forms of energy are at least partly converted to heat.
The principle stating that every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe. Ordered forms of energy are at least partly converted to heat.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">second law of thermodynamics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">substrate</span>"	The reactant on which an enzyme works.
The reactant on which an enzyme works.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">substrate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thermal energy</span>"	The total amount of kinetic energy due to the random motion of atoms or molecules in a body of matter; also called heat. [This] is energy in its most random form.
The total amount of kinetic energy due to the random motion of atoms or molecules in a body of matter; also called heat. [This] is energy in its most random form.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thermal energy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thermodynamics</span>"	The study of energy transformations that occur in a collection of matter. See first law of [this]; second law of [this].
The study of energy transformations that occur in a collection of matter. See first law of [this]; second law of [this].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thermodynamics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">actin</span>"	A globular protein that links into chains, two of which twist helically about each other, forming microfilaments in muscle and other kinds of cells.
A globular protein that links into chains, two of which twist helically about each other, forming microfilaments in muscle and other kinds of cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">actin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">basal body</span>"	A eukaryotic cell structure consisting of a 9 + 0 arrangement of microtubule triplets. [This] may organize the microtubule assembly of a cilium or flagellum and is structurally very similar to a centriole.
A eukaryotic cell structure consisting of a 9 + 0 arrangement of microtubule triplets. [This] may organize the microtubule assembly of a cilium or flagellum and is structurally very similar to a centriole.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">basal body</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">capsule</span>"	(1) A sticky layer that surrounds the cell wall of some prokaryotes, protecting the cell surface and sometimes helping to glue the cell to surfaces. (2) The sporangium of a bryophyte (moss, liverwort, or hornwort).
(1) A sticky layer that surrounds the cell wall of some prokaryotes, protecting the cell surface and sometimes helping to glue the cell to surfaces. (2) The sporangium of a bryophyte (moss, liverwort, or hornwort).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">capsule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell fractionation</span>"	The disruption of a cell and separation of its parts by centrifugation.
The disruption of a cell and separation of its parts by centrifugation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell fractionation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">central vacuole</span>"	A membranous sac in a mature plant cell with diverse roles in reproduction, growth, and development.
A membranous sac in a mature plant cell with diverse roles in reproduction, growth, and development.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">central vacuole</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">centriole</span>"	A structure in the centrosome of an animal cell composed of a cylinder of microtubule triplets arranged in a 9 + 0 pattern. A centrosome has a pair of [these].
A structure in the centrosome of an animal cell composed of a cylinder of microtubule triplets arranged in a 9 + 0 pattern. A centrosome has a pair of [these].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">centriole</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">centrosome</span>"	Structure present in the cytoplasm of animal cells, important during cell division; functions as a microtubule-organizing center. [This] has two centrioles.
Structure present in the cytoplasm of animal cells, important during cell division; functions as a microtubule-organizing center. [This] has two centrioles.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">centrosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chloroplast</span>"	An organelle found in plants and photosynthetic protists that absorbs sunlight and uses it to drive the synthesis of organic compounds from carbon dioxide and water.
An organelle found in plants and photosynthetic protists that absorbs sunlight and uses it to drive the synthesis of organic compounds from carbon dioxide and water.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chloroplast</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chromatin</span>"	The complex of DNA and proteins that makes up a eukaryotic chromosome. When the cell is not dividing, [this] exists in its dispersed form, as a mass of very long, thin fibers that are not visible with a light microscope.
The complex of DNA and proteins that makes up a eukaryotic chromosome. When the cell is not dividing, [this] exists in its dispersed form, as a mass of very long, thin fibers that are not visible with a light microscope.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chromatin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chromosome</span>"	A cellular structure carrying genetic material, found in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. Each [this] consists of one very long DNA molecule and associated proteins. (A bacterial [this] usually consists of a single circular DNA molecule and associated proteins. It is found in the nucleoid region, which is not membrane bounded.) 
A cellular structure carrying genetic material, found in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. Each [this] consists of one very long DNA molecule and associated proteins. (A bacterial [this] usually consists of a single circular DNA molecule and associated proteins. It is found in the nucleoid region, which is not membrane bounded.) 	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chromosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cilium</span>"	A short cellular appendage containing microtubules. A motile [this] is specialized for locomotion and is formed from a core of nine outer doublet microtubules and two inner single microtubules (the “9 + 2” arrangement) ensheathed in an extension of the plasma membrane. A primary [this] is usually nonmotile and plays a sensory and signaling role; it lacks the two inner microtubules (the “9 + 0” arrangement).
A short cellular appendage containing microtubules. A motile [this] is specialized for locomotion and is formed from a core of nine outer doublet microtubules and two inner single microtubules (the “9 + 2” arrangement) ensheathed in an extension of the plasma membrane. A primary [this] is usually nonmotile and plays a sensory and signaling role; it lacks the two inner microtubules (the “9 + 0” arrangement).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cilium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">contractile vacuole</span>"	A membranous sac that helps move excess water out of certain freshwater protists.
A membranous sac that helps move excess water out of certain freshwater protists.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">contractile vacuole</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">crista</span>"	An infolding of the inner membrane of a mitochondrion that houses electron transport chains and molecules of the enzyme catalyzing the synthesis of ATP (ATP synthase).
An infolding of the inner membrane of a mitochondrion that houses electron transport chains and molecules of the enzyme catalyzing the synthesis of ATP (ATP synthase).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">crista</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytoplasm</span>"	The contents of the cell, exclusive of the nucleus and bounded by the plasma membrane.
The contents of the cell, exclusive of the nucleus and bounded by the plasma membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytoplasm</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytoplasmic streaming</span>"	A circular flow of cytoplasm, involving myosin and actin filaments, that speeds the distribution of materials within cells.
A circular flow of cytoplasm, involving myosin and actin filaments, that speeds the distribution of materials within cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytoplasmic streaming</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytoskeleton</span>"	A network of microtubules, microfilaments, and intermediate filaments that branch throughout the cytoplasm and serve a variety of mechanical, transport, and signaling functions.
A network of microtubules, microfilaments, and intermediate filaments that branch throughout the cytoplasm and serve a variety of mechanical, transport, and signaling functions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytoskeleton</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytosol</span>"	The semifluid portion of the cytoplasm.
The semifluid portion of the cytoplasm.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytosol</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">desmosome</span>"	A type of intercellular junction in animal cells that functions as a rivet.
A type of intercellular junction in animal cells that functions as a rivet.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">desmosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dynein</span>"	In cilia and flagella, a large contractile protein extending from one microtubule doublet to the adjacent doublet. ATP hydrolysis drives changes in the shape of [this] that lead to bending of cilia and flagella.
In cilia and flagella, a large contractile protein extending from one microtubule doublet to the adjacent doublet. ATP hydrolysis drives changes in the shape of [this] that lead to bending of cilia and flagella.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dynein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electron microscope (EM)</span>"	A microscope that uses magnets to focus an electron beam on or through a specimen, resulting in resolving power a thousandfold greater than that of a light microscope. A transmission electron microscope (TEM) is used to study the internal structure of thin sections of cells. A scanning electron microscope (SEM) is used to study the fine details of cell surfaces.
A microscope that uses magnets to focus an electron beam on or through a specimen, resulting in resolving power a thousandfold greater than that of a light microscope. A transmission electron microscope (TEM) is used to study the internal structure of thin sections of cells. A scanning electron microscope (SEM) is used to study the fine details of cell surfaces.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electron microscope (EM)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endomembrane system</span>"	The collection of membranes inside and around a eukaryotic cell, related either through direct physical contact or by the transfer of membranous vesicles; includes the smooth and rough endoplasmic reticulum, the Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, and vacuoles.
The collection of membranes inside and around a eukaryotic cell, related either through direct physical contact or by the transfer of membranous vesicles; includes the smooth and rough endoplasmic reticulum, the Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, and vacuoles.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endomembrane system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endoplasmic reticulum (ER)</span>"	An extensive membranous network in eukaryotic cells, continuous with the outer nuclear membrane and composed of ribosome-studded (rough) and ribosome-free (smooth) regions.
An extensive membranous network in eukaryotic cells, continuous with the outer nuclear membrane and composed of ribosome-studded (rough) and ribosome-free (smooth) regions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endoplasmic reticulum (ER)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extracellular matrix (ECM)</span>"	The substance in which animal cells are embedded, consisting of protein and polysaccharides synthesized and secreted by cells.
The substance in which animal cells are embedded, consisting of protein and polysaccharides synthesized and secreted by cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extracellular matrix (ECM)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fibronectin</span>"	A glycoprotein that helps animal cells attach to the extracellular matrix.
A glycoprotein that helps animal cells attach to the extracellular matrix.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fibronectin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">flagellum</span>"	A long cellular appendage specialized for locomotion. Like motile cilia, eukaryotic [these] have a core with nine outer doublet microtubules and two inner single microtubules ensheathed in an extension of the plasma membrane. Prokaryotic [these] have a different structure.
A long cellular appendage specialized for locomotion. Like motile cilia, eukaryotic [these] have a core with nine outer doublet microtubules and two inner single microtubules ensheathed in an extension of the plasma membrane. Prokaryotic [these] have a different structure.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">flagellum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">food vacuole</span>"	A membranous sac formed by phagocytosis of microorganisms or particles to be used as food by the cell.
A membranous sac formed by phagocytosis of microorganisms or particles to be used as food by the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">food vacuole</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gap junction</span>"	A type of intercellular junction in animals that allows the passage of materials between cells.
A type of intercellular junction in animals that allows the passage of materials between cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gap junction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycoprotein</span>"	A protein with one or more carbohydrates covalently attached to it.
A protein with one or more carbohydrates covalently attached to it.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycoprotein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Golgi apparatus</span>"	An organelle in eukaryotic cells consisting of stacks of flat membranous sacs that modify, store, and route products of the endoplasmic reticulum and synthesize some products, notably noncellulose carbohydrates.
An organelle in eukaryotic cells consisting of stacks of flat membranous sacs that modify, store, and route products of the endoplasmic reticulum and synthesize some products, notably noncellulose carbohydrates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Golgi apparatus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">granum</span>"	A stack of membrane-bounded thylakoids in the chloroplast. [These] function in the light reactions of photosynthesis.
A stack of membrane-bounded thylakoids in the chloroplast. [These] function in the light reactions of photosynthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">granum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">integrin</span>"	In animal cells, a transmembrane receptor protein that interconnects the extracellular matrix and the cytoskeleton.
In animal cells, a transmembrane receptor protein that interconnects the extracellular matrix and the cytoskeleton.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">integrin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intermediate filament</span>"	A component of the cytoskeleton that includes filaments intermediate in size between microtubules and microfilaments.
A component of the cytoskeleton that includes filaments intermediate in size between microtubules and microfilaments.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intermediate filament</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">light microscope (LM)</span>"	An optical instrument with lenses that refract (bend) visible light to magnify images of specimens.
An optical instrument with lenses that refract (bend) visible light to magnify images of specimens.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">light microscope (LM)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lysosome</span>"	A membrane-enclosed sac of hydrolytic enzymes found in the cytoplasm of animal cells and some protists.
A membrane-enclosed sac of hydrolytic enzymes found in the cytoplasm of animal cells and some protists.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lysosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microfilament</span>"	A cable composed of actin proteins in the cytoplasm of almost every eukaryotic cell, making up part of the cytoskeleton and acting alone or with myosin to cause cell contraction; also known as an actin filament.
A cable composed of actin proteins in the cytoplasm of almost every eukaryotic cell, making up part of the cytoskeleton and acting alone or with myosin to cause cell contraction; also known as an actin filament.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microfilament</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microtubule</span>"	A hollow rod composed of tubulin proteins that make up part of the cytoskeleton in all eukaryotic cells and is found in cilia and flagella.
A hollow rod composed of tubulin proteins that make up part of the cytoskeleton in all eukaryotic cells and is found in cilia and flagella.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microtubule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">middle lamella</span>"	In plants, a thin layer of adhesive extracellular material, primarily pectins, found between the primary walls of adjacent young cells.
In plants, a thin layer of adhesive extracellular material, primarily pectins, found between the primary walls of adjacent young cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">middle lamella</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitochondrial matrix</span>"	The compartment of the mitochondrion enclosed by the inner membrane and containing enzymes and substrates for the citric acid cycle.
The compartment of the mitochondrion enclosed by the inner membrane and containing enzymes and substrates for the citric acid cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitochondrial matrix</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitochondrion</span>"	An organelle in eukaryotic cells that serves as the site of cellular respiration.
An organelle in eukaryotic cells that serves as the site of cellular respiration.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitochondrion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">motor protein</span>"	A protein that interacts with cytoskeletal elements and other cell components, producing movement of the whole cell or parts of the cell.
A protein that interacts with cytoskeletal elements and other cell components, producing movement of the whole cell or parts of the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">motor protein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nuclear envelope</span>"	The double membrane in a eukaryotic cell that encloses the nucleus, separating it from the cytoplasm.
The double membrane in a eukaryotic cell that encloses the nucleus, separating it from the cytoplasm.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nuclear envelope</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nuclear lamina</span>"	A netlike array of protein filaments lining the inner surface of the nuclear envelope; it helps maintain the shape of the nucleus.
A netlike array of protein filaments lining the inner surface of the nuclear envelope; it helps maintain the shape of the nucleus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nuclear lamina</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleoid</span>"	A dense region of DNA in a prokaryotic cell.
A dense region of DNA in a prokaryotic cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleoid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleolus</span>"	A specialized structure in the nucleus, consisting of chromatin regions containing ribosomal RNA genes along with ribosomal proteins imported from the cytoplasmic site of rRNA synthesis and ribosomal subunit assembly.
A specialized structure in the nucleus, consisting of chromatin regions containing ribosomal RNA genes along with ribosomal proteins imported from the cytoplasmic site of rRNA synthesis and ribosomal subunit assembly.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleolus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organelle</span>"	Any of several membrane-enclosed structures with specialized functions, suspended in the cytosol of eukaryotic cells.
Any of several membrane-enclosed structures with specialized functions, suspended in the cytosol of eukaryotic cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organelle</span>"
