"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peroxisome</span>"	An organelle containing enzymes that transfer hydrogen (H2) from various substrates to oxygen (O2), producing and then degrading hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
An organelle containing enzymes that transfer hydrogen (H2) from various substrates to oxygen (O2), producing and then degrading hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peroxisome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phagocytosis</span>"	A type of endocytosis in which large particulate substances are taken up by a cell. It is carried out by some protists and by certain immune cells of animals (in mammals, mainly macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells).
A type of endocytosis in which large particulate substances are taken up by a cell. It is carried out by some protists and by certain immune cells of animals (in mammals, mainly macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phagocytosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasma membrane</span>"	The membrane at the boundary of every cell that acts as a selective barrier, regulating the cell’s chemical composition.
The membrane at the boundary of every cell that acts as a selective barrier, regulating the cell’s chemical composition.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasma membrane</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmodesma</span>"	An open channel in the cell wall of a plant through which strands of cytosol connect from an adjacent cell.
An open channel in the cell wall of a plant through which strands of cytosol connect from an adjacent cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmodesma</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plastid</span>"	One of a family of closely related organelles that includes chloroplasts, chromoplasts, and amyloplasts (leucoplasts). [These] are found in cells of photosynthetic organisms.
One of a family of closely related organelles that includes chloroplasts, chromoplasts, and amyloplasts (leucoplasts). [These] are found in cells of photosynthetic organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plastid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary cell wall</span>"	In plants, a relatively thin and flexible layer first secreted by a young cell.
In plants, a relatively thin and flexible layer first secreted by a young cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary cell wall</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proteoglycan</span>"	A glycoprotein consisting of a small core protein with many carbohydrate chains attached, found in the extracellular matrix of animal cells. [This] may consist of up to 95% carbohydrate.
A glycoprotein consisting of a small core protein with many carbohydrate chains attached, found in the extracellular matrix of animal cells. [This] may consist of up to 95% carbohydrate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proteoglycan</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pseudopodium</span>"	A cellular extension of amoeboid cells used in moving and feeding.
A cellular extension of amoeboid cells used in moving and feeding.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pseudopodium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ribosomal RNA (rRNA)</span>"	The most abundant type of RNA, which together with proteins makes up ribosomes.
The most abundant type of RNA, which together with proteins makes up ribosomes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ribosomal RNA (rRNA)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ribosome</span>"	A complex of rRNA and protein molecules that functions as a site of protein synthesis in the cytoplasm; consists of a large and a small subunit. In eukaryotic cells, each subunit is assembled in the nucleolus.
A complex of rRNA and protein molecules that functions as a site of protein synthesis in the cytoplasm; consists of a large and a small subunit. In eukaryotic cells, each subunit is assembled in the nucleolus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ribosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">rough ER</span>"	That portion of the endoplasmic reticulum studded with ribosomes.
That portion of the endoplasmic reticulum studded with ribosomes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">rough ER</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">scanning electron microscope (SEM)</span>"	A microscope that uses an electron beam to scan the surface of a sample to study details of its topography.
A microscope that uses an electron beam to scan the surface of a sample to study details of its topography.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">scanning electron microscope (SEM)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary cell wall</span>"	In plants, a strong and durable matrix often deposited in several laminated layers for cell protection and support.
In plants, a strong and durable matrix often deposited in several laminated layers for cell protection and support.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary cell wall</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">smooth ER</span>"	That portion of the endoplasmic reticulum that is free of ribosomes.
That portion of the endoplasmic reticulum that is free of ribosomes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">smooth ER</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stroma</span>"	Within the chloroplast, the dense fluid of the chloroplast surrounding the thylakoid membrane; involved in the synthesis of organic molecules from carbon dioxide and water.
Within the chloroplast, the dense fluid of the chloroplast surrounding the thylakoid membrane; involved in the synthesis of organic molecules from carbon dioxide and water.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stroma</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thylakoid</span>"	A flattened membranous sac inside a chloroplast. [These] exist in an interconnected system in the chloroplast and contain the molecular “machinery” used to convert light energy to chemical energy.
A flattened membranous sac inside a chloroplast. [These] exist in an interconnected system in the chloroplast and contain the molecular “machinery” used to convert light energy to chemical energy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thylakoid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tight junction</span>"	A type of intercellular junction in animal cells that prevents the leakage of material between cells.
A type of intercellular junction in animal cells that prevents the leakage of material between cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tight junction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transmission electron microscope (TEM)</span>"	A microscope that passes an electron beam through very thin sections and is primarily used to study the internal ultrastructure of cells.
A microscope that passes an electron beam through very thin sections and is primarily used to study the internal ultrastructure of cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transmission electron microscope (TEM)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transport vesicle</span>"	A tiny membranous sac in a cell’s cytoplasm carrying molecules produced by the cell.
A tiny membranous sac in a cell’s cytoplasm carrying molecules produced by the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transport vesicle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vacuole</span>"	A membrane-bounded vesicle whose function varies in different kinds of cells.
A membrane-bounded vesicle whose function varies in different kinds of cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vacuole</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vesicle</span>"	A sac made of membrane in the cytoplasm.
A sac made of membrane in the cytoplasm.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vesicle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">active transport</span>"	The movement of a substance across a cell membrane, with an expenditure of energy, against its concentration or electrochemical gradient; mediated by specific transport proteins.
The movement of a substance across a cell membrane, with an expenditure of energy, against its concentration or electrochemical gradient; mediated by specific transport proteins.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">active transport</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amphipathic</span>"	Having both a hydrophilic region and a hydrophobic region.
Having both a hydrophilic region and a hydrophobic region.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amphipathic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aquaporin</span>"	A channel protein in the plasma membrane of a plant, animal, or microorganism cell that specifically facilitates osmosis, the diffusion of water across the membrane.
A channel protein in the plasma membrane of a plant, animal, or microorganism cell that specifically facilitates osmosis, the diffusion of water across the membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aquaporin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">concentration gradient</span>"	A region along which the density of a chemical substance increases or decreases.
A region along which the density of a chemical substance increases or decreases.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">concentration gradient</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diffusion</span>"	The spontaneous movement of a substance down its concentration gradient, from a region where it is more concentrated to a region where it is less concentrated.
The spontaneous movement of a substance down its concentration gradient, from a region where it is more concentrated to a region where it is less concentrated.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diffusion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electrochemical gradient</span>"	The diffusion gradient of an ion, which is affected by both the concentration difference of the ion across a membrane (a chemical force) and the ion's tendency to move relative to the membrane potential (an electrical force).
The diffusion gradient of an ion, which is affected by both the concentration difference of the ion across a membrane (a chemical force) and the ion's tendency to move relative to the membrane potential (an electrical force).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electrochemical gradient</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electrogenic pump</span>"	An ion transport protein that generates voltage across a membrane.
An ion transport protein that generates voltage across a membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electrogenic pump</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endocytosis</span>"	Cellular uptake of biological molecules and particulate matter via formation of new vesicles from the plasma membrane.
Cellular uptake of biological molecules and particulate matter via formation of new vesicles from the plasma membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endocytosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exocytosis</span>"	The cellular secretion of biological molecules by the fusion of vesicles containing them with the plasma membrane.
The cellular secretion of biological molecules by the fusion of vesicles containing them with the plasma membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exocytosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">facilitated diffusion</span>"	The spontaneous passage of molecules or ions across a biological membrane with the assistance of specific transmembrane transport proteins.
The spontaneous passage of molecules or ions across a biological membrane with the assistance of specific transmembrane transport proteins.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">facilitated diffusion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">flaccid</span>"	Limp. Lacking in stiffness or firmness, as in a plant cell in surroundings where there is no tendency for water to enter the cell.
Limp. Lacking in stiffness or firmness, as in a plant cell in surroundings where there is no tendency for water to enter the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">flaccid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gated channel</span>"	A transmembrane protein channel that opens or closes in response to a particular stimulus.
A transmembrane protein channel that opens or closes in response to a particular stimulus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gated channel</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycogen</span>"	An extensively branched glucose storage polysaccharide found in the liver and muscle of animals; the animal equivalent of starch.
An extensively branched glucose storage polysaccharide found in the liver and muscle of animals; the animal equivalent of starch.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycogen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycolipid</span>"	A lipid with covalently attached carbohydrate(s).
A lipid with covalently attached carbohydrate(s).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycolipid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hypertonic</span>"	Referring to a solution that, when surrounding a cell, will cause the cell to lose water.
Referring to a solution that, when surrounding a cell, will cause the cell to lose water.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hypertonic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hypotonic</span>"	Referring to a solution that, when surrounding a cell, will cause the cell to take up water.
Referring to a solution that, when surrounding a cell, will cause the cell to take up water.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hypotonic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">integral protein</span>"	Typically a transmembrane protein with hydrophobic regions that extend into and often completely span the hydrophobic interior of the membrane and with hydrophilic regions in contact with the aqueous solution on either side of the membrane (or lining the channel in the case of a channel protein).
Typically a transmembrane protein with hydrophobic regions that extend into and often completely span the hydrophobic interior of the membrane and with hydrophilic regions in contact with the aqueous solution on either side of the membrane (or lining the channel in the case of a channel protein).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">integral protein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ion channel</span>"	A transmembrane protein channel that allows a specific ion to flow across the membrane down its concentration gradient.
A transmembrane protein channel that allows a specific ion to flow across the membrane down its concentration gradient.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ion channel</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">isotonic</span>"	Referring to a solution that, when surrounding a cell, has no effect on the passage of water into or out of the cell.
Referring to a solution that, when surrounding a cell, has no effect on the passage of water into or out of the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">isotonic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ligand</span>"	A molecule that binds specifically to another molecule, usually a larger one.
A molecule that binds specifically to another molecule, usually a larger one.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ligand</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">low-density lipoprotein (LDL)</span>"	A particle in the blood made up of cholesterol and other lipids surrounded by a single layer of phospholipids in which proteins are embedded. [This] carries more cholesterol than a related lipoprotein, HDL, and high [this] levels in the blood correlate with a tendency to develop blocked blood vessels and heart disease.
A particle in the blood made up of cholesterol and other lipids surrounded by a single layer of phospholipids in which proteins are embedded. [This] carries more cholesterol than a related lipoprotein, HDL, and high [this] levels in the blood correlate with a tendency to develop blocked blood vessels and heart disease.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">low-density lipoprotein (LDL)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">membrane potential</span>"	The difference in electrical charge (voltage) across a cell's plasma membrane due to the differential distribution of ions. [This] affects the activity of excitable cells and the transmembrane movement of all charged substances.
The difference in electrical charge (voltage) across a cell's plasma membrane due to the differential distribution of ions. [This] affects the activity of excitable cells and the transmembrane movement of all charged substances.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">membrane potential</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">myosin</span>"	A type of protein filament that acts as a motor protein with actin filaments to cause cell contraction.
A type of protein filament that acts as a motor protein with actin filaments to cause cell contraction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">myosin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">osmoregulation</span>"	Regulation of solute concentrations and water balance by a cell or organism.
Regulation of solute concentrations and water balance by a cell or organism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">osmoregulation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">osmosis</span>"	The diffusion of water across a selectively permeable membrane.
The diffusion of water across a selectively permeable membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">osmosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">passive transport</span>"	The diffusion of a substance across a biological membrane with no expenditure of energy.
The diffusion of a substance across a biological membrane with no expenditure of energy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">passive transport</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peripheral protein</span>"	A protein loosely bound to the surface of a membrane or to part of an integral protein and not embedded in the lipid bilayer.
A protein loosely bound to the surface of a membrane or to part of an integral protein and not embedded in the lipid bilayer.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peripheral protein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pinocytosis</span>"	A type of endocytosis in which the cell ingests extracellular fluid and its dissolved solutes.
A type of endocytosis in which the cell ingests extracellular fluid and its dissolved solutes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pinocytosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmolysis</span>"	A phenomenon in walled cells in which the cytoplasm shrivels and the plasma membrane pulls away from the cell wall; occurs when the cell loses water to a hypertonic environment.
A phenomenon in walled cells in which the cytoplasm shrivels and the plasma membrane pulls away from the cell wall; occurs when the cell loses water to a hypertonic environment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmolysis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proton pump</span>"	An active transport protein in a cell membrane that uses ATP to transport hydrogen ions out of a cell against their concentration gradient, generating a membrane potential in the process.
An active transport protein in a cell membrane that uses ATP to transport hydrogen ions out of a cell against their concentration gradient, generating a membrane potential in the process.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proton pump</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">receptor-mediated endocytosis</span>"	The movement of specific molecules into a cell by the inward budding of membranous vesicles containing proteins with receptor sites specific to the molecules being taken in; enables a cell to acquire bulk quantities of specific substances.
The movement of specific molecules into a cell by the inward budding of membranous vesicles containing proteins with receptor sites specific to the molecules being taken in; enables a cell to acquire bulk quantities of specific substances.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">receptor-mediated endocytosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">selective permeability</span>"	A property of biological membranes that allows them to regulate the passage of substances.
A property of biological membranes that allows them to regulate the passage of substances.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">selective permeability</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sodium-potassium pump</span>"	A transport protein in the plasma membrane of animal cells that actively transports sodium out of the cell and potassium into the cell.
A transport protein in the plasma membrane of animal cells that actively transports sodium out of the cell and potassium into the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sodium-potassium pump</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tonicity</span>"	The ability of a solution surrounding a cell to cause that cell to gain or lose water.
The ability of a solution surrounding a cell to cause that cell to gain or lose water.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tonicity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transport protein</span>"	A transmembrane protein that helps a certain substance or class of closely related substances to cross the membrane.
A transmembrane protein that helps a certain substance or class of closely related substances to cross the membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transport protein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">turgid</span>"	Swollen or distended, as in plant cells. (A walled cell becomes [this] if it has a greater solute concentration than its surroundings, resulting in entry of water.)
Swollen or distended, as in plant cells. (A walled cell becomes [this] if it has a greater solute concentration than its surroundings, resulting in entry of water.)	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">turgid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acetyl CoA (acetyl coenzyme A)</span>"	The entry compound for the citric acid cycle in cellular respiration, formed from a fragment of pyruvate attached to a coenzyme.
The entry compound for the citric acid cycle in cellular respiration, formed from a fragment of pyruvate attached to a coenzyme.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acetyl CoA (acetyl coenzyme A)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aerobic respiration</span>"	A catabolic pathway that consumes oxygen (O2) and organic molecules, producing ATP. This is the most efficient catabolic pathway and is carried out in most eukaryotic cells and many prokaryotic organisms.
A catabolic pathway that consumes oxygen (O2) and organic molecules, producing ATP. This is the most efficient catabolic pathway and is carried out in most eukaryotic cells and many prokaryotic organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aerobic respiration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alcohol fermentation</span>"	Glycolysis followed by the conversion of pyruvate to carbon dioxide and ethyl alcohol.
Glycolysis followed by the conversion of pyruvate to carbon dioxide and ethyl alcohol.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alcohol fermentation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anaerobic respiration</span>"	The use of inorganic molecules other than oxygen to accept electrons at the “downhill” end of electron transport chains.
The use of inorganic molecules other than oxygen to accept electrons at the “downhill” end of electron transport chains.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anaerobic respiration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ATP synthase</span>"	A complex of several membrane proteins that provide a port through which protons diffuse. This complex functions in chemiosmosis with adjacent electron transport chains, using the energy of a hydrogen ion (proton) concentration gradient to make ATP.&nbsp;&nbsp;[These] are found in the inner mitochondrial membrane of eukaryotic cells and in the plasma membrane of prokaryotes.
A complex of several membrane proteins that provide a port through which protons diffuse. This complex functions in chemiosmosis with adjacent electron transport chains, using the energy of a hydrogen ion (proton) concentration gradient to make ATP.&nbsp;&nbsp;[These] are found in the inner mitochondrial membrane of eukaryotic cells and in the plasma membrane of prokaryotes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ATP synthase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">beta oxidation</span>"	A metabolic sequence that breaks fatty acids down to two-carbon fragments that enter the citric acid cycle as acetyl CoA.
A metabolic sequence that breaks fatty acids down to two-carbon fragments that enter the citric acid cycle as acetyl CoA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">beta oxidation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cellular respiration</span>"	The catabolic pathways of aerobic and anaerobic respiration, which break down organic molecules for the production of ATP.
The catabolic pathways of aerobic and anaerobic respiration, which break down organic molecules for the production of ATP.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cellular respiration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemiosmosis</span>"	An energy-coupling mechanism that uses energy stored in the form of a hydrogen ion gradient across a membrane to drive cellular work, such as the synthesis of ATP. Most ATP synthesis in cells occurs by [this].
An energy-coupling mechanism that uses energy stored in the form of a hydrogen ion gradient across a membrane to drive cellular work, such as the synthesis of ATP. Most ATP synthesis in cells occurs by [this].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemiosmosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">citric acid cycle</span>"	A chemical cycle involving eight steps that completes the metabolic breakdown of glucose molecules begun in glycolysis by oxidizing pyruvate to carbon dioxide; occurs within the mitochondrion in eukaryotic cells and in the cytosol of prokaryotes; the second major stage in cellular respiration.
A chemical cycle involving eight steps that completes the metabolic breakdown of glucose molecules begun in glycolysis by oxidizing pyruvate to carbon dioxide; occurs within the mitochondrion in eukaryotic cells and in the cytosol of prokaryotes; the second major stage in cellular respiration.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">citric acid cycle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytochrome</span>"	An iron-containing protein that is a component of electron transport chains in the mitochondria and chloroplasts of eukaryotic cells and the plasma membranes of prokaryotic cells.
An iron-containing protein that is a component of electron transport chains in the mitochondria and chloroplasts of eukaryotic cells and the plasma membranes of prokaryotic cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytochrome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electron transport chain</span>"	A sequence of electron carrier molecules (membrane proteins) that shuttle electrons during the redox reactions that release energy used to make ATP.
A sequence of electron carrier molecules (membrane proteins) that shuttle electrons during the redox reactions that release energy used to make ATP.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electron transport chain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">facultative anaerobe</span>"	An organism that makes ATP by aerobic respiration if oxygen is present but that switches to anaerobic respiration or fermentation if oxygen is not present.
An organism that makes ATP by aerobic respiration if oxygen is present but that switches to anaerobic respiration or fermentation if oxygen is not present.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">facultative anaerobe</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fermentation</span>"	A catabolic process that makes a limited amount of ATP from glucose without an electron transport chain and that produces a characteristic end product, such as ethyl alcohol or lactic acid.
A catabolic process that makes a limited amount of ATP from glucose without an electron transport chain and that produces a characteristic end product, such as ethyl alcohol or lactic acid.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fermentation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycolysis</span>"	The splitting of glucose into pyruvate. [This] occurs in almost all living cells, serving as the starting point for fermentation or cellular respiration.
The splitting of glucose into pyruvate. [This] occurs in almost all living cells, serving as the starting point for fermentation or cellular respiration.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glycolysis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lactic acid fermentation</span>"	Glycolysis followed by the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, with no release of carbon dioxide.
Glycolysis followed by the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, with no release of carbon dioxide.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lactic acid fermentation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide)</span>"	A coenzyme that can accept an electron and acts as an electron carrier in the electron transport chain.
A coenzyme that can accept an electron and acts as an electron carrier in the electron transport chain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">obligate anaerobe</span>"	An organism that only carries out fermentation or anaerobic respiration. Such organisms cannot use oxygen and in fact may be poisoned by it.
An organism that only carries out fermentation or anaerobic respiration. Such organisms cannot use oxygen and in fact may be poisoned by it.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">obligate anaerobe</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oxidation</span>"	The loss of electrons from a substance involved in a redox reaction.
The loss of electrons from a substance involved in a redox reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oxidation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oxidative phosphorylation</span>"	The production of ATP using energy derived from the redox reactions of an electron transport chain; the third major stage of cellular respiration.
The production of ATP using energy derived from the redox reactions of an electron transport chain; the third major stage of cellular respiration.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oxidative phosphorylation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oxidizing agent</span>"	The electron acceptor in a redox reaction.
The electron acceptor in a redox reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oxidizing agent</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proton-motive force</span>"	The potential energy stored in the form of an electrochemical gradient, generated by the pumping of hydrogen ions across a biological membrane during chemiosmosis.
The potential energy stored in the form of an electrochemical gradient, generated by the pumping of hydrogen ions across a biological membrane during chemiosmosis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proton-motive force</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reducing agent</span>"	The electron donor in a redox reaction.
The electron donor in a redox reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reducing agent</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reduction</span>"	The addition of electrons to a substance involved in a redox reaction.
The addition of electrons to a substance involved in a redox reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reduction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">substrate-level phosphorylation</span>"	The formation of ATP by an enzyme directly transferring a phosphate group to ADP from an intermediate substrate in catabolism.
The formation of ATP by an enzyme directly transferring a phosphate group to ADP from an intermediate substrate in catabolism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">substrate-level phosphorylation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">absorption spectrum</span>"	The range of a pigment’s ability to absorb various wavelengths of light; also a graph of such a range.
The range of a pigment’s ability to absorb various wavelengths of light; also a graph of such a range.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">absorption spectrum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">action spectrum</span>"	A graph that profiles the relative effectiveness of different wavelengths of radiation in driving a particular process.
A graph that profiles the relative effectiveness of different wavelengths of radiation in driving a particular process.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">action spectrum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autotroph</span>"	An organism that obtains organic food molecules without eating other organisms or substances derived from other organisms. [These] use energy from the sun or from the oxidation of inorganic substances to make organic molecules from inorganic ones.
An organism that obtains organic food molecules without eating other organisms or substances derived from other organisms. [These] use energy from the sun or from the oxidation of inorganic substances to make organic molecules from inorganic ones.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autotroph</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bundle-sheath cell</span>"	In C4 plants, a type of photosynthetic cell arranged into tightly packed sheaths around the veins of a leaf.
In C4 plants, a type of photosynthetic cell arranged into tightly packed sheaths around the veins of a leaf.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bundle-sheath cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">C3 plant</span>"	A plant that uses the Calvin cycle for the initial steps that incorporate CO2 into organic material, forming a three-carbon compound as the first stable intermediate.
A plant that uses the Calvin cycle for the initial steps that incorporate CO2 into organic material, forming a three-carbon compound as the first stable intermediate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">C3 plant</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">C4 plant</span>"	A plant in which the Calvin cycle is preceded by reactions that incorporate CO2 into a four-carbon compound, the end product of which supplies CO2 for the Calvin cycle.
A plant in which the Calvin cycle is preceded by reactions that incorporate CO2 into a four-carbon compound, the end product of which supplies CO2 for the Calvin cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">C4 plant</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Calvin cycle</span>"	The second of two major stages in photosynthesis (following the light reactions), involving fixation of atmospheric CO2 and reduction of the fixed carbon into carbohydrate.
The second of two major stages in photosynthesis (following the light reactions), involving fixation of atmospheric CO2 and reduction of the fixed carbon into carbohydrate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Calvin cycle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">CAM plant</span>"	A plant that uses crassulacean acid metabolism, an adaptation for photosynthesis in arid conditions. In this process, carbon dioxide entering open stomata during the night is converted to organic acids, which release CO2 for the Calvin cycle during the day, when stomata are closed.
A plant that uses crassulacean acid metabolism, an adaptation for photosynthesis in arid conditions. In this process, carbon dioxide entering open stomata during the night is converted to organic acids, which release CO2 for the Calvin cycle during the day, when stomata are closed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">CAM plant</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carbon fixation</span>"	The initial incorporation of carbon from CO2 into an organic compound by an autotrophic organism (a plant, another photosynthetic organism, or a chemoautotrophic prokaryote).
The initial incorporation of carbon from CO2 into an organic compound by an autotrophic organism (a plant, another photosynthetic organism, or a chemoautotrophic prokaryote).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carbon fixation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carotenoid</span>"	An accessory pigment, either yellow or orange, in the chloroplasts of plants and in some prokaryotes. By absorbing wavelengths of light that chlorophyll cannot, [these] broaden the spectrum of colors that can drive photosynthesis.
An accessory pigment, either yellow or orange, in the chloroplasts of plants and in some prokaryotes. By absorbing wavelengths of light that chlorophyll cannot, [these] broaden the spectrum of colors that can drive photosynthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carotenoid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chlorophyll</span>"	A green pigment located within the chloroplasts of plants and algae and in the membranes of certain prokaryotes. [This] a participates directly in the light reactions, which convert solar energy to chemical energy.
A green pigment located within the chloroplasts of plants and algae and in the membranes of certain prokaryotes. [This] a participates directly in the light reactions, which convert solar energy to chemical energy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chlorophyll</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chlorophyll a</span>"	A photosynthetic pigment that participates directly in the light reactions, which convert solar energy to chemical energy.
A photosynthetic pigment that participates directly in the light reactions, which convert solar energy to chemical energy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chlorophyll a</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chlorophyll b</span>"	An accessory photosynthetic pigment that transfers energy to chlorophyll a.
An accessory photosynthetic pigment that transfers energy to chlorophyll a.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chlorophyll b</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM)</span>"	An adaptation for photosynthesis in arid conditions, first discovered in the family Crassulaceae. In this process, a plant takes up CO2 and incorporates it into a variety of organic acids at night; during the day, CO2 is released from organic acids for use in the Calvin cycle.
An adaptation for photosynthesis in arid conditions, first discovered in the family Crassulaceae. In this process, a plant takes up CO2 and incorporates it into a variety of organic acids at night; during the day, CO2 is released from organic acids for use in the Calvin cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cyclic electron flow</span>"	A route of electron flow during the light reactions of photosynthesis that involves only photosystem I and that produces ATP but not NADPH or O2.
A route of electron flow during the light reactions of photosynthesis that involves only photosystem I and that produces ATP but not NADPH or O2.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cyclic electron flow</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electromagnetic spectrum</span>"	The entire spectrum of electromagnetic radiation ranging in wavelength from less than a nanometer to more than a kilometer.
The entire spectrum of electromagnetic radiation ranging in wavelength from less than a nanometer to more than a kilometer.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electromagnetic spectrum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (G3P)</span>"	A three-carbon carbohydrate that is the direct product of the Calvin cycle; it is also an intermediate in glycolysis.
A three-carbon carbohydrate that is the direct product of the Calvin cycle; it is also an intermediate in glycolysis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (G3P)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterotroph</span>"	An organism that obtains organic food molecules by eating other organisms or substances derived from them.
An organism that obtains organic food molecules by eating other organisms or substances derived from them.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterotroph</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">leaf</span>"	The main photosynthetic organ of vascular plants.
The main photosynthetic organ of vascular plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">leaf</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">light reactions</span>"	The first of two major stages in photosynthesis (preceding the Calvin cycle). These reactions, which occur on the thylakoid membranes of the chloroplast or on membranes of certain prokaryotes, convert solar energy to the chemical energy of ATP and NADPH, releasing oxygen in the process.
The first of two major stages in photosynthesis (preceding the Calvin cycle). These reactions, which occur on the thylakoid membranes of the chloroplast or on membranes of certain prokaryotes, convert solar energy to the chemical energy of ATP and NADPH, releasing oxygen in the process.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">light reactions</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">light-harvesting complex</span>"	A complex of proteins associated with pigment molecules (including chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, and carotenoids) that captures light energy and transfers it to reaction-center pigments in a photosystem.
A complex of proteins associated with pigment molecules (including chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, and carotenoids) that captures light energy and transfers it to reaction-center pigments in a photosystem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">light-harvesting complex</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">linear electron flow</span>"	A route of electron flow during the light reactions of photosynthesis that involves both photosystems (I and II) and produces ATP, NADPH, and O2. The net electron flow is from H2O to NADP+.
A route of electron flow during the light reactions of photosynthesis that involves both photosystems (I and II) and produces ATP, NADPH, and O2. The net electron flow is from H2O to NADP+.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">linear electron flow</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mesophyll</span>"	The ground tissue of a leaf, sandwiched between the upper and lower epidermis and specialized for photosynthesis.
The ground tissue of a leaf, sandwiched between the upper and lower epidermis and specialized for photosynthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mesophyll</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mesophyll cell</span>"	In C4 plants, a type of loosely arranged photosynthetic cell located between the bundle sheath and the leaf surface.
In C4 plants, a type of loosely arranged photosynthetic cell located between the bundle sheath and the leaf surface.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mesophyll cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">NADP+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate)</span>"	An electron acceptor that, as NADPH, temporarily stores energized electrons produced during the light reactions.
An electron acceptor that, as NADPH, temporarily stores energized electrons produced during the light reactions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">NADP+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">PEP carboxylase</span>"	An enzyme that adds CO2 to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to form oxaloacetate in C4 plants. It acts prior to photosynthesis.
An enzyme that adds CO2 to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to form oxaloacetate in C4 plants. It acts prior to photosynthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">PEP carboxylase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photoautotroph</span>"	An organism that harnesses light energy to drive the synthesis of organic compounds from carbon dioxide.
An organism that harnesses light energy to drive the synthesis of organic compounds from carbon dioxide.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photoautotroph</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photon</span>"	A quantum, or discrete quantity, of light energy that behaves as if it were a particle.
A quantum, or discrete quantity, of light energy that behaves as if it were a particle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photophosphorylation</span>"	The process of generating ATP from ADP and phosphate by means of a proton-motive force generated across the thylakoid membrane of the chloroplast or the membrane of certain prokaryotes during the light reactions of photosynthesis.
The process of generating ATP from ADP and phosphate by means of a proton-motive force generated across the thylakoid membrane of the chloroplast or the membrane of certain prokaryotes during the light reactions of photosynthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photophosphorylation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photorespiration</span>"	A metabolic pathway that consumes oxygen and ATP, releases carbon dioxide, and decreases photosynthetic output. [This] generally occurs on hot, dry, bright days, when stomata close and the oxygen concentration in the leaf exceeds that of carbon dioxide.
A metabolic pathway that consumes oxygen and ATP, releases carbon dioxide, and decreases photosynthetic output. [This] generally occurs on hot, dry, bright days, when stomata close and the oxygen concentration in the leaf exceeds that of carbon dioxide.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photorespiration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photosynthesis</span>"	The conversion of light energy to chemical energy that is stored in sugars or other organic compounds; occurs in plants, algae, and certain prokaryotes.
The conversion of light energy to chemical energy that is stored in sugars or other organic compounds; occurs in plants, algae, and certain prokaryotes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photosynthesis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photosystem</span>"	A light-capturing unit located in the thylakoid membrane of the chloroplast or in the membrane of some prokaryotes, consisting of a reaction-center complex surrounded by numerous light-harvesting complexes. There are two types of [these], I and II; they absorb light best at different wavelengths.
A light-capturing unit located in the thylakoid membrane of the chloroplast or in the membrane of some prokaryotes, consisting of a reaction-center complex surrounded by numerous light-harvesting complexes. There are two types of [these], I and II; they absorb light best at different wavelengths.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photosystem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photosystem I (PS I)</span>"	One of two light-capturing units in a chloroplast’s thylakoid membrane or in the membrane of some prokaryotes; it has two molecules of P700 chlorophyll a at its reaction center.
One of two light-capturing units in a chloroplast’s thylakoid membrane or in the membrane of some prokaryotes; it has two molecules of P700 chlorophyll a at its reaction center.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photosystem I (PS I)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photosystem II (PS II)</span>"	One of two light-capturing units in a chloroplast’s thylakoid membrane or in the membrane of some prokaryotes; it has two molecules of P680 chlorophyll a at its reaction center.
One of two light-capturing units in a chloroplast’s thylakoid membrane or in the membrane of some prokaryotes; it has two molecules of P680 chlorophyll a at its reaction center.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photosystem II (PS II)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary electron acceptor</span>"	In the thylakoid membrane of a chloroplast or in the membrane of some prokaryotes, a specialized molecule that shares the reaction-center complex with a pair of chlorophyll a molecules and that accepts an electron from them.
In the thylakoid membrane of a chloroplast or in the membrane of some prokaryotes, a specialized molecule that shares the reaction-center complex with a pair of chlorophyll a molecules and that accepts an electron from them.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary electron acceptor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">producer</span>"	An organism that produces organic compounds from CO2 by harnessing light energy (in photosynthesis) or by oxidizing inorganic chemicals (in chemosynthetic reactions carried out by some prokaryotes).
An organism that produces organic compounds from CO2 by harnessing light energy (in photosynthesis) or by oxidizing inorganic chemicals (in chemosynthetic reactions carried out by some prokaryotes).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">producer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reaction-center complex</span>"	A complex of proteins associated with a special pair of chlorophyll a molecules and a primary electron acceptor. Located centrally in a photosystem, this complex triggers the light reactions of photosynthesis. Excited by light energy, the pair of chlorophylls donates an electron to the primary electron acceptor, which passes an electron to an electron transport chain.
A complex of proteins associated with a special pair of chlorophyll a molecules and a primary electron acceptor. Located centrally in a photosystem, this complex triggers the light reactions of photosynthesis. Excited by light energy, the pair of chlorophylls donates an electron to the primary electron acceptor, which passes an electron to an electron transport chain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reaction-center complex</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">rubisco (ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP) carboxylase)</span>"	The enzyme that catalyzes the first step of the Calvin cycle (the addition of CO2 to RuBP).
The enzyme that catalyzes the first step of the Calvin cycle (the addition of CO2 to RuBP).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">rubisco (ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP) carboxylase)</span>"

An instrument that measures the proportions of light of different wavelengths absorbed and transmitted by a pigment solution.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spectrophotometer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stoma</span>"	A microscopic pore surrounded by guard cells in the epidermis of leaves and stems that allows gas exchange between the environment and the interior of the plant.
A microscopic pore surrounded by guard cells in the epidermis of leaves and stems that allows gas exchange between the environment and the interior of the plant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stoma</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">visible light</span>"	That portion of the electromagnetic spectrum that can be detected as various colors by the human eye, ranging in wavelength from about 380 nm to about 750 nm.
That portion of the electromagnetic spectrum that can be detected as various colors by the human eye, ranging in wavelength from about 380 nm to about 750 nm.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">visible light</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amplification</span>"	The strengthening of stimulus energy during transduction.
The strengthening of stimulus energy during transduction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amplification</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apoptosis</span>"	A program of controlled cell suicide, which is brought about by signals that trigger the activation of a cascade of suicide proteins in the cell destined to die.
A program of controlled cell suicide, which is brought about by signals that trigger the activation of a cascade of suicide proteins in the cell destined to die.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apoptosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biofilm</span>"	A surface-coating colony of one or more species of prokaryotes that engage in metabolic cooperation.
A surface-coating colony of one or more species of prokaryotes that engage in metabolic cooperation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biofilm</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)</span>"	A ring-shaped molecule made from ATP that is a common intracellular signaling molecule (second messenger) in eukaryotic cells. It is also a regulator of some bacterial operons.
A ring-shaped molecule made from ATP that is a common intracellular signaling molecule (second messenger) in eukaryotic cells. It is also a regulator of some bacterial operons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diacylglycerol (DAG)</span>"	A second messenger produced by the cleavage of a certain kind of phospholipid in the plasma membrane.
A second messenger produced by the cleavage of a certain kind of phospholipid in the plasma membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diacylglycerol (DAG)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epinephrine</span>"	A catecholamine that, when secreted as a hormone by the adrenal medulla, mediates “fight-or-flight” responses to short-term stresses; also released by some neurons as a neurotransmitter; also known as adrenaline.
A catecholamine that, when secreted as a hormone by the adrenal medulla, mediates “fight-or-flight” responses to short-term stresses; also released by some neurons as a neurotransmitter; also known as adrenaline.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epinephrine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G protein</span>"	A GTP-binding protein that relays signals from a plasma membrane signal receptor, known as a [this]-coupled receptor, to other signal transduction proteins inside the cell.
A GTP-binding protein that relays signals from a plasma membrane signal receptor, known as a [this]-coupled receptor, to other signal transduction proteins inside the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G protein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">growth factor</span>"	(1) A protein that must be present in the extracellular environment (culture medium or animal body) for the growth and normal development of certain types of cells. (2) A local regulator that acts on nearby cells to stimulate cell proliferation and differentiation.
(1) A protein that must be present in the extracellular environment (culture medium or animal body) for the growth and normal development of certain types of cells. (2) A local regulator that acts on nearby cells to stimulate cell proliferation and differentiation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">growth factor</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protein phosphatase</span>"	An enzyme that removes phosphate groups from (dephosphorylates) proteins, often functioning to reverse the effect of a protein kinase.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">receptor tyrosine kinase</span>"	A receptor protein in the plasma membrane, the cytoplasmic (intracellular) part of which can catalyze the transfer of a phosphate group from ATP to a tyrosine on another protein. [These] often respond to the binding of a signaling molecule by dimerizing and then phosphorylating a tyrosine on the cytoplasmic portion of the other receptor in the dimer. The phosphorylated tyrosines on the receptors then activate other signal transduction proteins within the cell.
A receptor protein in the plasma membrane, the cytoplasmic (intracellular) part of which can catalyze the transfer of a phosphate group from ATP to a tyrosine on another protein. [These] often respond to the binding of a signaling molecule by dimerizing and then phosphorylating a tyrosine on the cytoplasmic portion of the other receptor in the dimer. The phosphorylated tyrosines on the receptors then activate other signal transduction proteins within the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">receptor tyrosine kinase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">scaffolding protein</span>"	A type of large relay protein to which several other relay proteins are simultaneously attached, increasing the efficiency of signal transduction.
A type of large relay protein to which several other relay proteins are simultaneously attached, increasing the efficiency of signal transduction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">scaffolding protein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">second messenger</span>"	A small, nonprotein, water-soluble molecule or ion, such as a calcium ion (Ca2+) or cyclic AMP, that relays a signal to a cell’s interior in response to a signaling molecule bound by a signal receptor protein.
A small, nonprotein, water-soluble molecule or ion, such as a calcium ion (Ca2+) or cyclic AMP, that relays a signal to a cell’s interior in response to a signaling molecule bound by a signal receptor protein.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">second messenger</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">testosterone</span>"	A steroid hormone required for development of the male reproductive system, spermatogenesis, and male secondary sex characteristics; the major androgen in mammals.

(2) In cellular communication, the conversion of a signal from outside the cell to a form that can bring about a specific cellular response.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">yeast</span>"	Single-celled fungus that reproduces asexually by binary fission or by the pinching of small buds off a parent cell; some species exhibit cell fusion between different mating types.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">allele</span>"	Any of the alternative versions of a gene that produce distinguishable phenotypic effects.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amniocentesis</span>"	A technique of prenatal diagnosis in which amniotic fluid, obtained by aspiration from a needle inserted into the uterus, is analyzed to detect certain genetic and congenital defects in the fetus.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carrier</span>"	In genetics, an individual who is heterozygous at a given genetic locus, with one normal allele and one recessive allele. The heterozygote is phenotypically dominant for the character determined by the gene but can pass on the recessive allele to offspring.
In genetics, an individual who is heterozygous at a given genetic locus, with one normal allele and one recessive allele. The heterozygote is phenotypically dominant for the character determined by the gene but can pass on the recessive allele to offspring.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carrier</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">character</span>"	An observable heritable feature.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chorionic villus sampling (CVS)</span>"	A technique of prenatal diagnosis in which a small sample of the fetal portion of the placenta is removed and analyzed to detect certain genetic and congenital defects in the fetus.
A technique of prenatal diagnosis in which a small sample of the fetal portion of the placenta is removed and analyzed to detect certain genetic and congenital defects in the fetus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chorionic villus sampling (CVS)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">codominance</span>"	The situation in which the phenotypes of both alleles are exhibited in the heterozygote because both alleles affect the phenotype in separate, distinguishable ways.
The situation in which the phenotypes of both alleles are exhibited in the heterozygote because both alleles affect the phenotype in separate, distinguishable ways.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">codominance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">complete dominance</span>"	The situation in which the phenotypes of the heterozygote and dominant homozygote are indistinguishable.
The situation in which the phenotypes of the heterozygote and dominant homozygote are indistinguishable.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">complete dominance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cystic fibrosis</span>"	A human genetic disorder caused by a recessive allele for a chloride channel protein; characterized by an excessive secretion of mucus and consequent vulnerability to infection; fatal if untreated.
A human genetic disorder caused by a recessive allele for a chloride channel protein; characterized by an excessive secretion of mucus and consequent vulnerability to infection; fatal if untreated.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cystic fibrosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dihybrid</span>"	An organism that is heterozygous with respect to two genes of interest. All the offspring from a cross between parents doubly homozygous for different alleles are [these]. For example, parents of genotypes AABB and aabb produce a [this] of genotype AaBb.
An organism that is heterozygous with respect to two genes of interest. All the offspring from a cross between parents doubly homozygous for different alleles are [these]. For example, parents of genotypes AABB and aabb produce a [this] of genotype AaBb.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dihybrid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dominant allele</span>"	An allele that is fully expressed in the phenotype of a heterozygote.
An allele that is fully expressed in the phenotype of a heterozygote.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dominant allele</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epistasis</span>"	A type of gene interaction in which one gene alters the phenotypic effects of another gene that is independently inherited.
A type of gene interaction in which one gene alters the phenotypic effects of another gene that is independently inherited.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epistasis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">F1 generation</span>"	The first filial, or hybrid, offspring in a series of genetic crosses.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">F2 generation</span>"	Offspring resulting from interbreeding of the hybrid F1 generation.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Huntington’s disease</span>"	A human genetic disease caused by a dominant allele; characterized by uncontrollable body movements and degeneration of the nervous system; usually fatal 10 to 20 years after the onset of symptoms.
A human genetic disease caused by a dominant allele; characterized by uncontrollable body movements and degeneration of the nervous system; usually fatal 10 to 20 years after the onset of symptoms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Huntington’s disease</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">incomplete dominance</span>"	The situation in which the phenotype of heterozygotes is intermediate between the phenotypes of individuals homozygous for either allele.
The situation in which the phenotype of heterozygotes is intermediate between the phenotypes of individuals homozygous for either allele.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">incomplete dominance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">law of independent assortment</span>"	Mendel’s second law, stating that each pair of alleles segregates independently of each other pair during gamete formation; applies when genes for two characters are located on different pairs of homologous chromosomes.
Mendel’s second law, stating that each pair of alleles segregates independently of each other pair during gamete formation; applies when genes for two characters are located on different pairs of homologous chromosomes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">law of independent assortment</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">law of segregation</span>"	Mendel’s first law, stating that the two alleles in a pair separate into different gametes during gamete formation.
Mendel’s first law, stating that the two alleles in a pair separate into different gametes during gamete formation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">law of segregation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monohybrid</span>"	An organism that is heterozygous with respect to a single gene of interest. All the offspring from a cross between parents homozygous for different alleles are [these]. For example, parents of genotypes AA and aa produce a [this] of genotype Aa.
An organism that is heterozygous with respect to a single gene of interest. All the offspring from a cross between parents homozygous for different alleles are [these]. For example, parents of genotypes AA and aa produce a [this] of genotype Aa.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monohybrid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">multifactorial</span>"	Referring to a phenotypic character that is influenced by multiple genes and environmental factors.
Referring to a phenotypic character that is influenced by multiple genes and environmental factors.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">multifactorial</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">norm of reaction</span>"	The range of phenotypes produced by a single genotype, due to environmental influences.
The range of phenotypes produced by a single genotype, due to environmental influences.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">norm of reaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">P generation</span>"	The parent individuals from which offspring are derived in studies of inheritance; [T] stands for “parental.”
The parent individuals from which offspring are derived in studies of inheritance; [T] stands for “parental.”	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">P generation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pedigree</span>"	A diagram of a family tree showing the occurrence of heritable characters in parents and offspring over multiple generations.
A diagram of a family tree showing the occurrence of heritable characters in parents and offspring over multiple generations.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pedigree</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phenotype</span>"	The physical and physiological traits of an organism, which are determined by its genetic makeup.
The physical and physiological traits of an organism, which are determined by its genetic makeup.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phenotype</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pleiotropy</span>"	The ability of a single gene to have multiple effects.
The ability of a single gene to have multiple effects.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pleiotropy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polygenic inheritance</span>"	An additive effect of two or more genes on a single phenotypic character.
An additive effect of two or more genes on a single phenotypic character.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polygenic inheritance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Punnett square</span>"	A diagram used in the study of inheritance to show the predicted results of random fertilization in genetic crosses.
A diagram used in the study of inheritance to show the predicted results of random fertilization in genetic crosses.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Punnett square</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">quantitative character</span>"	A heritable feature that varies continuously over a range rather than in an either-or fashion.
A heritable feature that varies continuously over a range rather than in an either-or fashion.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">quantitative character</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">recessive allele</span>"	An allele whose phenotypic effect is not observed in a heterozygote.
An allele whose phenotypic effect is not observed in a heterozygote.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">recessive allele</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sickle-cell disease</span>"	A human genetic disease caused by a recessive allele that results in the substitution of a single amino acid in a globin polypeptide that is part of the hemoglobin protein; characterized by deformed red blood cells (due to protein aggregation) that can lead to numerous symptoms.
A human genetic disease caused by a recessive allele that results in the substitution of a single amino acid in a globin polypeptide that is part of the hemoglobin protein; characterized by deformed red blood cells (due to protein aggregation) that can lead to numerous symptoms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sickle-cell disease</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Tay-Sachs disease</span>"	A human genetic disease caused by a recessive allele for a dysfunctional enzyme, leading to accumulation of certain lipids in the brain. Seizures, blindness, and degeneration of motor and mental performance usually become manifest a few months after birth, followed by death within a few years.
A human genetic disease caused by a recessive allele for a dysfunctional enzyme, leading to accumulation of certain lipids in the brain. Seizures, blindness, and degeneration of motor and mental performance usually become manifest a few months after birth, followed by death within a few years.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Tay-Sachs disease</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">testcross</span>"	Breeding an organism of unknown genotype with a homozygous recessive individual to determine the unknown genotype. The ratio of phenotypes in the offspring reveals the unknown genotype.
Breeding an organism of unknown genotype with a homozygous recessive individual to determine the unknown genotype. The ratio of phenotypes in the offspring reveals the unknown genotype.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">testcross</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trait</span>"	Any detectable variant in a genetic character.
Any detectable variant in a genetic character.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trait</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">true-breeding</span>"	Referring to plants that produce offspring of the same variety when they self-pollinate.
Referring to plants that produce offspring of the same variety when they self-pollinate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">true-breeding</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aneuploidy</span>"	A chromosomal aberration in which one or more chromosomes are present in extra copies or are deficient in number.
A chromosomal aberration in which one or more chromosomes are present in extra copies or are deficient in number.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aneuploidy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Barr body</span>"	A dense object lying along the inside of the nuclear envelope in cells of female mammals, representing a highly condensed, inactivated X chromosome.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chromosome theory of inheritance</span>"	A basic principle in biology stating that genes are located on chromosomes and that the behavior of chromosomes during meiosis accounts for inheritance patterns.
A basic principle in biology stating that genes are located on chromosomes and that the behavior of chromosomes during meiosis accounts for inheritance patterns.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chromosome theory of inheritance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">crossing over</span>"	The reciprocal exchange of genetic material between nonsister chromatids during prophase I of meiosis.
The reciprocal exchange of genetic material between nonsister chromatids during prophase I of meiosis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">crossing over</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytogenetic map</span>"	A chart of a chromosome that locates genes with respect to chromosomal features distinguishable in a microscope.
A chart of a chromosome that locates genes with respect to chromosomal features distinguishable in a microscope.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytogenetic map</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dendrite</span>"	One of usually numerous, short, highly branched extensions of a neuron that receive signals from other neurons.
One of usually numerous, short, highly branched extensions of a neuron that receive signals from other neurons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dendrite</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Down syndrome</span>"	A human genetic disease caused by the presence of an extra chromosome 21; characterized by mental retardation and heart and respiratory defects.
A human genetic disease caused by the presence of an extra chromosome 21; characterized by mental retardation and heart and respiratory defects.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Down syndrome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Duchenne muscular dystrophy</span>"	A human genetic disease caused by a sex-linked recessive allele; characterized by progressive weakening and a loss of muscle tissue.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">duplication</span>"	An aberration in chromosome structure due to fusion with a fragment from a homologous chromosome, such that a portion of a chromosome is duplicated.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetic recombination</span>"	General term for the production of offspring with combinations of traits that differ from those found in either parent.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genomic imprinting</span>"	A phenomenon in which expression of an allele in offspring depends on whether the allele is inherited from the male or female parent.
A phenomenon in which expression of an allele in offspring depends on whether the allele is inherited from the male or female parent.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genomic imprinting</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hemophilia</span>"	A human genetic disease caused by a sex-linked recessive allele resulting in the absence of one or more blood-clotting proteins; characterized by excessive bleeding following injury.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">linked genes</span>"	Genes located close enough together on a chromosome that they tend to be inherited together.
Genes located close enough together on a chromosome that they tend to be inherited together.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">linked genes</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">map unit</span>"	A unit of measurement of the distance between genes. One [this] is equivalent to a 1% recombination frequency.
A unit of measurement of the distance between genes. One [this] is equivalent to a 1% recombination frequency.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">map unit</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monosomic</span>"	Referring to a cell that has only one copy of a particular chromosome instead of the normal two.
Referring to a cell that has only one copy of a particular chromosome instead of the normal two.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monosomic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nondisjunction</span>"	An error in meiosis or mitosis in which members of a pair of homologous chromosomes or a pair of sister chromatids fail to separate properly from each other.
An error in meiosis or mitosis in which members of a pair of homologous chromosomes or a pair of sister chromatids fail to separate properly from each other.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nondisjunction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parental type</span>"	An offspring with a phenotype that matches one of the parental phenotypes; also refers to the phenotype itself.
An offspring with a phenotype that matches one of the parental phenotypes; also refers to the phenotype itself.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parental type</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyploidy</span>"	A chromosomal alteration in which the organism possesses more than two complete chromosome sets. It is the result of an accident of cell division.
A chromosomal alteration in which the organism possesses more than two complete chromosome sets. It is the result of an accident of cell division.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyploidy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sex-linked gene</span>"	A gene located on a sex chromosome (usually the X chromosome), resulting in a distinctive pattern of inheritance.
A gene located on a sex chromosome (usually the X chromosome), resulting in a distinctive pattern of inheritance.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sex-linked gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">translocation</span>"	(1) An aberration in chromosome structure resulting from attachment of a chromosomal fragment to a nonhomologous chromosome. (2) During protein synthesis, the third stage in the elongation cycle when the RNA carrying the growing polypeptide moves from the A site to the P site on the ribosome. (3) The transport of organic nutrients in the phloem of vascular plants.

(2) During protein synthesis, the third stage in the elongation cycle when the RNA carrying the growing polypeptide moves from the A site to the P site on the ribosome. "<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trisomic</span>"	Referring to a diploid cell that has three copies of a particular chromosome instead of the normal two.
Referring to a diploid cell that has three copies of a particular chromosome instead of the normal two.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trisomic</span>"

A method of asexual reproduction by “division in half.” In prokaryotes, [this] does not involve mitosis; but in single-celled eukaryotes that undergo [this], mitosis is part of the process.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">binary fission</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell cycle</span>"	An ordered sequence of events in the life of a cell, from its origin in the division of a parent cell until its own division into two; the eukaryotic [this] is composed of interphase (including G1, S, and G2 subphases) and M phase (including mitosis and cytokinesis).
An ordered sequence of events in the life of a cell, from its origin in the division of a parent cell until its own division into two; the eukaryotic [this] is composed of interphase (including G1, S, and G2 subphases) and M phase (including mitosis and cytokinesis). "<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell cycle control system</span>"	A cyclically operating set of molecules in the eukaryotic cell that both triggers and coordinates key events in the cell cycle.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cleavage</span>"	(1) The process of cytokinesis in animal cells, characterized by pinching of the plasma membrane. (2) The succession of rapid cell divisions without significant growth during early embryonic development that converts the zygote to a ball of cells.
(1) The process of cytokinesis in animal cells, characterized by pinching of the plasma membrane. (2) The succession of rapid cell divisions without significant growth during early embryonic development that converts the zygote to a ball of cells. "<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cyclin</span>"	A cellular protein that occurs in a cyclically fluctuating concentration and that plays an important role in regulating the cell cycle.
A cellular protein that occurs in a cyclically fluctuating concentration and that plays an important role in regulating the cell cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cyclin</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytokinesis</span>"	The division of the cytoplasm to form two separate daughter cells immediately after mitosis, meiosis I, or meiosis II.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">density-dependent inhibition</span>"	The phenomenon observed in normal animal cells that causes them to stop dividing when they come into contact with one another.
The phenomenon observed in normal animal cells that causes them to stop dividing when they come into contact with one another.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">density-dependent inhibition</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G0 phase</span>"	A nondividing state occupied by cells that have left the cell cycle.
A nondividing state occupied by cells that have left the cell cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G0 phase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G1 phase</span>"	The first gap, or growth phase, of the cell cycle, consisting of the portion of interphase before DNA synthesis begins.
The first gap, or growth phase, of the cell cycle, consisting of the portion of interphase before DNA synthesis begins.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G1 phase</span>"
