"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G2 phase</span>"	The second gap, or growth phase, of the cell cycle, consisting of the portion of interphase after DNA synthesis occurs.
The second gap, or growth phase, of the cell cycle, consisting of the portion of interphase after DNA synthesis occurs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G2 phase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gamete</span>"	A haploid reproductive cell, such as an egg or sperm. [These] unite during sexual reproduction to produce a diploid zygote.
A haploid reproductive cell, such as an egg or sperm. [These] unite during sexual reproduction to produce a diploid zygote.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gamete</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interphase</span>"	The period in the cell cycle when the cell is not dividing. During [this], cellular metabolic activity is high, chromosomes and organelles are duplicated, and cell size may increase. [This] accounts for 90% of the cell cycle.
The period in the cell cycle when the cell is not dividing. During [this], cellular metabolic activity is high, chromosomes and organelles are duplicated, and cell size may increase. [This] accounts for 90% of the cell cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interphase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kinetochore</span>"	A structure of proteins attached to the centromere that links each sister chromatid to the mitotic spindle.
A structure of proteins attached to the centromere that links each sister chromatid to the mitotic spindle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kinetochore</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">malignant tumor</span>"	A cancerous tumor that is invasive enough to impair the functions of one or more organs.
A cancerous tumor that is invasive enough to impair the functions of one or more organs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">malignant tumor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metaphase</span>"	The third stage of mitosis, in which the spindle is complete and the chromosomes, attached to microtubules at their kinetochores, are all aligned at the metaphase plate.
The third stage of mitosis, in which the spindle is complete and the chromosomes, attached to microtubules at their kinetochores, are all aligned at the metaphase plate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metaphase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metaphase plate</span>"	An imaginary plane midway between the two poles of a cell in metaphase on which the centromeres of all the duplicated chromosomes are located.
An imaginary plane midway between the two poles of a cell in metaphase on which the centromeres of all the duplicated chromosomes are located.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metaphase plate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metastasis</span>"	The spread of cancer cells to locations distant from their original site.
The spread of cancer cells to locations distant from their original site.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metastasis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitosis</span>"	A process of nuclear division in eukaryotic cells conventionally divided into five stages: prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. [This] conserves chromosome number by allocating replicated chromosomes equally to each of the daughter nuclei.
A process of nuclear division in eukaryotic cells conventionally divided into five stages: prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. [This] conserves chromosome number by allocating replicated chromosomes equally to each of the daughter nuclei.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitotic (M) phase</span>"	The phase of the cell cycle that includes mitosis and cytokinesis.
The phase of the cell cycle that includes mitosis and cytokinesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitotic (M) phase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitotic spindle</span>"	An assemblage of microtubules and associated proteins that is involved in the movements of chromosomes during mitosis.
An assemblage of microtubules and associated proteins that is involved in the movements of chromosomes during mitosis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mitotic spindle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">origin of replication</span>"	Site where the replication of a DNA molecule begins, consisting of a specific sequence of nucleotides.
Site where the replication of a DNA molecule begins, consisting of a specific sequence of nucleotides.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">origin of replication</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prometaphase</span>"	The second stage of mitosis, in which discrete chromosomes consisting of identical sister chromatids appear, the nuclear envelope fragments, and the spindle microtubules attach to the kinetochores of the chromosomes.
The second stage of mitosis, in which discrete chromosomes consisting of identical sister chromatids appear, the nuclear envelope fragments, and the spindle microtubules attach to the kinetochores of the chromosomes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prometaphase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prophase</span>"	The first stage of mitosis, in which the chromatin condenses, the mitotic spindle begins to form, and the nucleolus disappears, but the nucleus remains intact.
The first stage of mitosis, in which the chromatin condenses, the mitotic spindle begins to form, and the nucleolus disappears, but the nucleus remains intact.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prophase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">S phase</span>"	The synthesis phase of the cell cycle; the portion of interphase during which DNA is replicated.
The synthesis phase of the cell cycle; the portion of interphase during which DNA is replicated.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">S phase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sister chromatid</span>"	Either of two copies of a duplicated chromosome attached to each other by proteins at the centromere and, sometimes, along the arms. While joined, two [these] make up one chromosome; [these] are eventually separated during mitosis or meiosis II.
Either of two copies of a duplicated chromosome attached to each other by proteins at the centromere and, sometimes, along the arms. While joined, two [these] make up one chromosome; [these] are eventually separated during mitosis or meiosis II.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sister chromatid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">somatic cell</span>"	Any cell in a multicellular organism except a sperm or egg.
Any cell in a multicellular organism except a sperm or egg.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">somatic cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">telophase</span>"	The fifth and final stage of mitosis, in which daughter nuclei are forming and cytokinesis has typically begun.
The fifth and final stage of mitosis, in which daughter nuclei are forming and cytokinesis has typically begun.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">telophase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transformation</span>"	(1) The conversion of a normal animal cell to a cancerous cell. (2) A change in genotype and phenotype due to the assimilation of external DNA by a cell.
(1) The conversion of a normal animal cell to a cancerous cell. (2) A change in genotype and phenotype due to the assimilation of external DNA by a cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transformation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alternation of generations</span>"	A life cycle in which there is both a multicellular diploid form, the sporophyte, and a multicellular haploid form, the gametophyte; characteristic of plants and some algae.
A life cycle in which there is both a multicellular diploid form, the sporophyte, and a multicellular haploid form, the gametophyte; characteristic of plants and some algae.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alternation of generations</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">asexual reproduction</span>"	The generation of offspring from a single parent that occurs without the fusion of gametes (by budding, division of a single cell, or division of the entire organism into two or more parts). In most cases, the offspring are genetically identical to the parent.
The generation of offspring from a single parent that occurs without the fusion of gametes (by budding, division of a single cell, or division of the entire organism into two or more parts). In most cases, the offspring are genetically identical to the parent.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">asexual reproduction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autosome</span>"	A chromosome that is not directly involved in determining sex; not a sex chromosome.
A chromosome that is not directly involved in determining sex; not a sex chromosome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chiasma</span>"	The X-shaped, microscopically visible region where homologous nonsister chromatids have exchanged genetic material through crossing over during meiosis, the two homologs remaining associated due to sister chromatid cohesion.
The X-shaped, microscopically visible region where homologous nonsister chromatids have exchanged genetic material through crossing over during meiosis, the two homologs remaining associated due to sister chromatid cohesion.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chiasma</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">clone</span>"	(1) A lineage of genetically identical individuals or cells. (2) In popular usage, a single individual organism that is genetically identical to another individual. (3) As a verb, to make one or more genetic replicas of an individual or cell. See also gene cloning.
(1) A lineage of genetically identical individuals or cells. (2) In popular usage, a single individual organism that is genetically identical to another individual. (3) As a verb, to make one or more genetic replicas of an individual or cell. See also gene cloning.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">clone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diploid cell</span>"	A cell containing two sets of chromosomes (2n), one set inherited from each parent.
A cell containing two sets of chromosomes (2n), one set inherited from each parent.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diploid cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gametophyte</span>"	In organisms (plants and some algae) that have alternation of generations, the multicellular haploid form that produces haploid gametes by mitosis. The haploid gametes unite and develop into sporophytes.
In organisms (plants and some algae) that have alternation of generations, the multicellular haploid form that produces haploid gametes by mitosis. The haploid gametes unite and develop into sporophytes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gametophyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetics</span>"	The scientific study of heredity and hereditary variation.
The scientific study of heredity and hereditary variation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">haploid cell</span>"	A cell containing only one set of chromosomes (n).
A cell containing only one set of chromosomes (n).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">haploid cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heredity</span>"	The transmission of traits from one generation to the next.
The transmission of traits from one generation to the next.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heredity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homologous chromosomes</span>"	A pair of chromosomes of the same length, centromere position, and staining pattern that possess genes for the same characters at corresponding loci. One [this] is inherited from the organism’s father, the other from the mother.
A pair of chromosomes of the same length, centromere position, and staining pattern that possess genes for the same characters at corresponding loci. One [this] is inherited from the organism’s father, the other from the mother.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homologous chromosomes</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">karyotype</span>"	A display of the chromosome pairs of a cell arranged by size and shape.
A display of the chromosome pairs of a cell arranged by size and shape.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">karyotype</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">life cycle</span>"	The generation-to-generation sequence of stages in the reproductive history of an organism.
The generation-to-generation sequence of stages in the reproductive history of an organism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">life cycle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">locus</span>"	A specific place along the length of a chromosome where a given gene is located.
A specific place along the length of a chromosome where a given gene is located.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">locus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meiosis</span>"	A modified type of cell division in sexually reproducing organisms consisting of two rounds of cell division but only one round of DNA replication. It results in cells with half the number of chromosome sets as the original cell.
A modified type of cell division in sexually reproducing organisms consisting of two rounds of cell division but only one round of DNA replication. It results in cells with half the number of chromosome sets as the original cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meiosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meiosis I</span>"	The first division of a two-stage process of cell division in sexually reproducing organisms that results in cells with half the number of chromosome sets as the original cell.
The first division of a two-stage process of cell division in sexually reproducing organisms that results in cells with half the number of chromosome sets as the original cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meiosis I</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meiosis II</span>"	The second division of a two-stage process of cell division in sexually reproducing organisms that results in cells with half the number of chromosome sets as the original cell.
The second division of a two-stage process of cell division in sexually reproducing organisms that results in cells with half the number of chromosome sets as the original cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meiosis II</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">recombinant chromosome</span>"	A chromosome created when crossing over combines the DNA from two parents into a single chromosome.
A chromosome created when crossing over combines the DNA from two parents into a single chromosome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">recombinant chromosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sex chromosome</span>"	A chromosome responsible for determining the sex of an individual.
A chromosome responsible for determining the sex of an individual.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sex chromosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sexual reproduction</span>"	A type of reproduction in which two parents give rise to offspring that have unique combinations of genes inherited from the gametes of the parents.
A type of reproduction in which two parents give rise to offspring that have unique combinations of genes inherited from the gametes of the parents.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sexual reproduction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spore</span>"	(1) In the life cycle of a plant or alga undergoing alternation of generations, a haploid cell produced in the sporophyte by meiosis. A [this] can divide by mitosis to develop into a multicellular haploid individual, the gametophyte, without fusing with another cell. (2) In fungi, a haploid cell, produced either sexually or asexually, that produces a mycelium after germination.
(1) In the life cycle of a plant or alga undergoing alternation of generations, a haploid cell produced in the sporophyte by meiosis. A [this] can divide by mitosis to develop into a multicellular haploid individual, the gametophyte, without fusing with another cell. (2) In fungi, a haploid cell, produced either sexually or asexually, that produces a mycelium after germination.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spore</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporophyte</span>"	In organisms (plants and some algae) that have alternation of generations, the multicellular diploid form that results from the union of gametes. [This] produces haploid spores by meiosis that develop into gametophytes.
In organisms (plants and some algae) that have alternation of generations, the multicellular diploid form that results from the union of gametes. [This] produces haploid spores by meiosis that develop into gametophytes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporophyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synapsis</span>"	The pairing and physical connection of replicated homologous chromosomes during prophase I of meiosis.
The pairing and physical connection of replicated homologous chromosomes during prophase I of meiosis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synapsis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">variation</span>"	Differences between members of the same species.
Differences between members of the same species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">variation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">zygote</span>"	The diploid product of the union of haploid gametes during fertilization; a fertilized egg.
The diploid product of the union of haploid gametes during fertilization; a fertilized egg.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">zygote</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bacteriophage</span>"	A virus that infects bacteria; also called a phage.
A virus that infects bacteria; also called a phage.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bacteriophage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bacterium</span>"	Member of the prokaryotic domain Bacteria.
Member of the prokaryotic domain Bacteria.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bacterium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">DNA ligase</span>"	A linking enzyme essential for DNA replication; catalyzes the covalent bonding of the 3' end of one DNA fragment (such as an Okazaki fragment) to the 5' end of another DNA fragment (such as a growing DNA chain).
A linking enzyme essential for DNA replication; catalyzes the covalent bonding of the 3' end of one DNA fragment (such as an Okazaki fragment) to the 5' end of another DNA fragment (such as a growing DNA chain).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">DNA ligase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">DNA polymerase</span>"	An enzyme that catalyzes the elongation of new DNA (for example, at a replication fork) by the addition of nucleotides to the 3' end of an existing chain. There are several [these]; [this] III and [this] I play major roles in DNA replication in prokaryotes.
An enzyme that catalyzes the elongation of new DNA (for example, at a replication fork) by the addition of nucleotides to the 3' end of an existing chain. There are several [these]; [this] III and [this] I play major roles in DNA replication in prokaryotes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">DNA polymerase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">euchromatin</span>"	The less condensed form of eukaryotic chromatin that is available for transcription.
The less condensed form of eukaryotic chromatin that is available for transcription.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">euchromatin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">helicase</span>"	An enzyme that untwists the double helix of DNA at the replication forks, separating the two strands and making them available as template strands.
An enzyme that untwists the double helix of DNA at the replication forks, separating the two strands and making them available as template strands.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">helicase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterochromatin</span>"	Eukaryotic chromatin that remains highly compacted during interphase and is generally not transcribed.
Eukaryotic chromatin that remains highly compacted during interphase and is generally not transcribed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterochromatin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">histone</span>"	A small protein with a high proportion of positively charged amino acids that binds to the negatively charged DNA and plays a key role in chromatin structure.
A small protein with a high proportion of positively charged amino acids that binds to the negatively charged DNA and plays a key role in chromatin structure.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">histone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lagging strand</span>"	A discontinuously synthesized DNA strand that elongates by means of Okazaki fragments, each synthesized in a 5'→3' direction away from the replication fork.
A discontinuously synthesized DNA strand that elongates by means of Okazaki fragments, each synthesized in a 5'→3' direction away from the replication fork.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lagging strand</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">leading strand</span>"	The new complementary DNA strand synthesized continuously along the template strand toward the replication fork in the mandatory 5'→3' direction.
The new complementary DNA strand synthesized continuously along the template strand toward the replication fork in the mandatory 5'→3' direction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">leading strand</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mismatch repair</span>"	The cellular process that uses specific enzymes to remove and replace incorrectly paired nucleotides.
The cellular process that uses specific enzymes to remove and replace incorrectly paired nucleotides.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mismatch repair</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nuclease</span>"	An enzyme that cuts DNA or RNA, either removing one or a few bases or hydrolyzing the DNA or RNA completely into its component nucleotides.
An enzyme that cuts DNA or RNA, either removing one or a few bases or hydrolyzing the DNA or RNA completely into its component nucleotides.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nuclease</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleosome</span>"	The basic, bead-like unit of DNA packing in eukaryotes, consisting of a segment of DNA wound around a protein core composed of two copies of each of four types of histone.
The basic, bead-like unit of DNA packing in eukaryotes, consisting of a segment of DNA wound around a protein core composed of two copies of each of four types of histone.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleotide excision repair</span>"	A repair system that removes and then correctly replaces a damaged segment of DNA using the undamaged strand as a guide.
A repair system that removes and then correctly replaces a damaged segment of DNA using the undamaged strand as a guide.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleotide excision repair</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Okazaki fragment</span>"	A short segment of DNA synthesized away from the replication fork on a template strand during DNA replication, many of which are joined together to make up the lagging strand of newly synthesized DNA.
A short segment of DNA synthesized away from the replication fork on a template strand during DNA replication, many of which are joined together to make up the lagging strand of newly synthesized DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Okazaki fragment</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phage</span>"	A virus that infects bacteria; also called a bacteriophage.
A virus that infects bacteria; also called a bacteriophage.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primase</span>"	An enzyme that joins RNA nucleotides to make the primer using the parental DNA strand as a template.
An enzyme that joins RNA nucleotides to make the primer using the parental DNA strand as a template.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primer</span>"	A short stretch of RNA with a free 3' end, bound by complementary base pairing to the template strand, that is elongated with DNA nucleotides during DNA replication.
A short stretch of RNA with a free 3' end, bound by complementary base pairing to the template strand, that is elongated with DNA nucleotides during DNA replication.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">repetitive DNA</span>"	Nucleotide sequences, usually noncoding, that are present in many copies in a eukaryotic genome. The repeated units may be short and arranged tandemly (in series) or long and dispersed in the genome.
Nucleotide sequences, usually noncoding, that are present in many copies in a eukaryotic genome. The repeated units may be short and arranged tandemly (in series) or long and dispersed in the genome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">repetitive DNA</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">replication fork</span>"	A Y-shaped region on a replicating DNA molecule where the parental strands are being unwound and new strands are growing.
A Y-shaped region on a replicating DNA molecule where the parental strands are being unwound and new strands are growing.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">replication fork</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">semiconservative model</span>"	Type of DNA replication in which the replicated double helix consists of one old strand, derived from the old molecule, and one newly made strand.
Type of DNA replication in which the replicated double helix consists of one old strand, derived from the old molecule, and one newly made strand.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">semiconservative model</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">single-strand binding protein</span>"	A protein that binds to the unpaired DNA strands during DNA replication, stabilizing them and holding them apart while they serve as templates for the synthesis of complementary strands of DNA.
A protein that binds to the unpaired DNA strands during DNA replication, stabilizing them and holding them apart while they serve as templates for the synthesis of complementary strands of DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">single-strand binding protein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">telomerase</span>"	An enzyme that catalyzes the lengthening of telomeres in eukaryotic germ cells.
An enzyme that catalyzes the lengthening of telomeres in eukaryotic germ cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">telomerase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">telomere</span>"	The tandemly repetitive DNA at the end of a eukaryotic chromosome’s DNA molecule that protects the organism’s genes from being eroded during successive rounds of replication. See also repetitive DNA.
The tandemly repetitive DNA at the end of a eukaryotic chromosome’s DNA molecule that protects the organism’s genes from being eroded during successive rounds of replication. See also repetitive DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">telomere</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">template strand</span>"	The DNA strand that provides the pattern, or template, for ordering the sequence of nucleotides in an RNA transcript.
The DNA strand that provides the pattern, or template, for ordering the sequence of nucleotides in an RNA transcript.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">template strand</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">topoisomerase</span>"	A protein that breaks, swivels, and rejoins DNA strands. During DNA replication, [this] helps to relieve strain in the double helix ahead of the replication fork.
A protein that breaks, swivels, and rejoins DNA strands. During DNA replication, [this] helps to relieve strain in the double helix ahead of the replication fork.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">topoisomerase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">5' cap</span>"	A modified form of guanine nucleotide added onto the nucleotide at the 5' end of a pre-mRNA molecule.
A modified form of guanine nucleotide added onto the nucleotide at the 5' end of a pre-mRNA molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">5' cap</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">A site</span>"	One of a ribosome’s three binding sites for tRNA during translation. The [this] holds the tRNA carrying the next amino acid to be added to the polypeptide chain. ([T] stands for aminoacyl tRNA.)
One of a ribosome’s three binding sites for tRNA during translation. The [this] holds the tRNA carrying the next amino acid to be added to the polypeptide chain. ([T] stands for aminoacyl tRNA.)	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">A site</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alternative RNA splicing</span>"	A type of eukaryotic gene regulation at the RNA-processing level in which different mRNA molecules are produced from the same primary transcript, depending on which RNA segments are treated as exons and which as introns.
A type of eukaryotic gene regulation at the RNA-processing level in which different mRNA molecules are produced from the same primary transcript, depending on which RNA segments are treated as exons and which as introns.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alternative RNA splicing</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase</span>"	An enzyme that joins each amino acid to the appropriate tRNA.
An enzyme that joins each amino acid to the appropriate tRNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anticodon</span>"	A nucleotide triplet at one end of a tRNA molecule that recognizes a particular complementary codon on an mRNA molecule.
A nucleotide triplet at one end of a tRNA molecule that recognizes a particular complementary codon on an mRNA molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anticodon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">base-pair substitution</span>"	A type of point mutation; the replacement of one nucleotide and its partner in the complementary DNA strand by another pair of nucleotides.
A type of point mutation; the replacement of one nucleotide and its partner in the complementary DNA strand by another pair of nucleotides.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">base-pair substitution</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">codon</span>"	A three-nucleotide sequence of DNA or mRNA that specifies a particular amino acid or termination signal; the basic unit of the genetic code.
A three-nucleotide sequence of DNA or mRNA that specifies a particular amino acid or termination signal; the basic unit of the genetic code.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">codon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">domain</span>"	(1) A taxonomic category above the kingdom level. The three [these] are Archaea, Bacteria, and Eukarya. (2) An independently folding part of a protein.
(1) A taxonomic category above the kingdom level. The three [these] are Archaea, Bacteria, and Eukarya. (2) An independently folding part of a protein.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">domain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">E site</span>"	One of a ribosome’s three binding sites for tRNA during translation. The [this] is the place where discharged tRNAs leave the ribosome. ([T] stands for exit.)
One of a ribosome’s three binding sites for tRNA during translation. The [this] is the place where discharged tRNAs leave the ribosome. ([T] stands for exit.)	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">E site</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exon</span>"	A sequence within a primary transcript that remains in the RNA after RNA processing; also refers to the region of DNA from which this sequence was transcribed.
A sequence within a primary transcript that remains in the RNA after RNA processing; also refers to the region of DNA from which this sequence was transcribed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">frameshift mutation</span>"	A mutation occurring when the number of nucleotides inserted or deleted is not a multiple of three, resulting in the improper grouping of the subsequent nucleotides into codons.
A mutation occurring when the number of nucleotides inserted or deleted is not a multiple of three, resulting in the improper grouping of the subsequent nucleotides into codons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">frameshift mutation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene expression</span>"	The process by which DNA directs the synthesis of proteins or, in some cases, just RNAs.
The process by which DNA directs the synthesis of proteins or, in some cases, just RNAs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene expression</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">insertion</span>"	A mutation involving the addition of one or more nucleotide pairs to a gene.
A mutation involving the addition of one or more nucleotide pairs to a gene.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">insertion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intron</span>"	A noncoding, intervening sequence within a primary transcript that is removed from the transcript during RNA processing; also refers to the region of DNA from which this sequence was transcribed.
A noncoding, intervening sequence within a primary transcript that is removed from the transcript during RNA processing; also refers to the region of DNA from which this sequence was transcribed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">missense mutation</span>"	A base-pair substitution that results in a codon that codes for a different amino acid.
A base-pair substitution that results in a codon that codes for a different amino acid.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">missense mutation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mutagen</span>"	A chemical or physical agent that interacts with DNA and causes a mutation.
A chemical or physical agent that interacts with DNA and causes a mutation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mutagen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mutation</span>"	A change in the nucleotide sequence of an organism’s DNA, ultimately creating genetic diversity. [These] also can occur in the DNA or RNA of a virus.
A change in the nucleotide sequence of an organism’s DNA, ultimately creating genetic diversity. [These] also can occur in the DNA or RNA of a virus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mutation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nonsense mutation</span>"	A mutation that changes an amino acid codon to one of the three stop codons, resulting in a shorter and usually nonfunctional protein.
A mutation that changes an amino acid codon to one of the three stop codons, resulting in a shorter and usually nonfunctional protein.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nonsense mutation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">P site</span>"	One of a ribosome’s three binding sites for tRNA during translation. The [this] holds the tRNA carrying the growing polypeptide chain. ([T] stands for peptidyl tRNA.)
One of a ribosome’s three binding sites for tRNA during translation. The [this] holds the tRNA carrying the growing polypeptide chain. ([T] stands for peptidyl tRNA.)	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">P site</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">point mutation</span>"	A change in a gene at a single nucleotide pair.
A change in a gene at a single nucleotide pair.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">point mutation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">poly-A tail</span>"	A sequence of 50 to 250 adenine nucleotides added onto the 3' end of a pre-mRNA molecule.
A sequence of 50 to 250 adenine nucleotides added onto the 3' end of a pre-mRNA molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">poly-A tail</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyribosome (polysome)</span>"	A group of several ribosomes attached to, and translating, the same messenger RNA molecule.
A group of several ribosomes attached to, and translating, the same messenger RNA molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyribosome (polysome)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary transcript</span>"	An initial RNA transcript; also called pre-mRNA when transcribed from a protein-coding gene.
An initial RNA transcript; also called pre-mRNA when transcribed from a protein-coding gene.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary transcript</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">promoter</span>"	A specific nucleotide sequence in DNA that binds RNA polymerase, positioning it to start transcribing RNA at the appropriate place.
A specific nucleotide sequence in DNA that binds RNA polymerase, positioning it to start transcribing RNA at the appropriate place.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">promoter</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radiation</span>"	The emission of electromagnetic waves by all objects warmer than absolute zero.
The emission of electromagnetic waves by all objects warmer than absolute zero.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radiation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reading frame</span>"	On an mRNA, the triplet grouping of ribonucleotides used by the translation machinery during polypeptide synthesis.
On an mRNA, the triplet grouping of ribonucleotides used by the translation machinery during polypeptide synthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reading frame</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ribozyme</span>"	An RNA molecule that functions as an enzyme, catalyzing reactions during RNA splicing.
An RNA molecule that functions as an enzyme, catalyzing reactions during RNA splicing.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ribozyme</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">RNA polymerase</span>"	An enzyme that links ribonucleotides into a growing RNA chain during transcription.
An enzyme that links ribonucleotides into a growing RNA chain during transcription.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">RNA polymerase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">RNA processing</span>"	Modification of RNA transcripts, including splicing out of introns, joining together of exons, and alteration of the 5' and 3' ends.
Modification of RNA transcripts, including splicing out of introns, joining together of exons, and alteration of the 5' and 3' ends.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">RNA processing</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">RNA splicing</span>"	After synthesis of a eukaryotic primary RNA transcript, the removal of portions (introns) of the transcript that will not be included in the mRNA.
After synthesis of a eukaryotic primary RNA transcript, the removal of portions (introns) of the transcript that will not be included in the mRNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">RNA splicing</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">signal peptide</span>"	A sequence of about 20 amino acids at or near the leading (amino) end of a polypeptide that targets it to the endoplasmic reticulum or other organelles in a eukaryotic cell.
A sequence of about 20 amino acids at or near the leading (amino) end of a polypeptide that targets it to the endoplasmic reticulum or other organelles in a eukaryotic cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">signal peptide</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">signal-recognition particle (SRP)</span>"	A protein-RNA complex that recognizes a signal peptide as it emerges from a ribosome and helps direct the ribosome to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) by binding to a receptor protein on the ER.
A protein-RNA complex that recognizes a signal peptide as it emerges from a ribosome and helps direct the ribosome to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) by binding to a receptor protein on the ER.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">signal-recognition particle (SRP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spliceosome</span>"	A large complex made up of proteins and RNA molecules that splices RNA by interacting with the ends of an RNA intron, releasing the intron and joining the two adjacent exons.
A large complex made up of proteins and RNA molecules that splices RNA by interacting with the ends of an RNA intron, releasing the intron and joining the two adjacent exons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spliceosome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">TATA box</span>"	A DNA sequence in eukaryotic promoters crucial in forming the transcription initiation complex.
A DNA sequence in eukaryotic promoters crucial in forming the transcription initiation complex.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">TATA box</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">terminator</span>"	In bacteria, a sequence of nucleotides in DNA that marks the end of a gene and signals RNA polymerase to release the newly made RNA molecule and detach from the DNA.
In bacteria, a sequence of nucleotides in DNA that marks the end of a gene and signals RNA polymerase to release the newly made RNA molecule and detach from the DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">terminator</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transcription</span>"	The synthesis of RNA using a DNA template.
The synthesis of RNA using a DNA template.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transcription</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transcription initiation complex</span>"	The completed assembly of transcription factors and RNA polymerase bound to a promoter.
The completed assembly of transcription factors and RNA polymerase bound to a promoter.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transcription initiation complex</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transcription unit</span>"	A region of DNA that is transcribed into an RNA molecule.
A region of DNA that is transcribed into an RNA molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transcription unit</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transfer RNA (tRNA)</span>"	An RNA molecule that functions as an interpreter between nucleic acid and protein language by picking up specific amino acids and recognizing the appropriate codons in the mRNA.
An RNA molecule that functions as an interpreter between nucleic acid and protein language by picking up specific amino acids and recognizing the appropriate codons in the mRNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transfer RNA (tRNA)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">translation</span>"	The synthesis of a polypeptide using the genetic information encoded in an mRNA molecule. There is a change of “language” from nucleotides to amino acids.
The synthesis of a polypeptide using the genetic information encoded in an mRNA molecule. There is a change of “language” from nucleotides to amino acids.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">translation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">triplet code</span>"	A set of three-nucleotide-long words that specify the amino acids for polypeptide chains.
A set of three-nucleotide-long words that specify the amino acids for polypeptide chains.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">triplet code</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">wobble</span>"	Flexibility in the base-pairing rules in which the nucleotide at the 5' end of a tRNA anticodon can form hydrogen bonds with more than one kind of base in the third position (3' end) of a codon.
Flexibility in the base-pairing rules in which the nucleotide at the 5' end of a tRNA anticodon can form hydrogen bonds with more than one kind of base in the third position (3' end) of a codon.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">wobble</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">activator</span>"	A protein that binds to DNA and stimulates gene transcription. In prokaryotes, [these] bind in or near the promoter; in eukaryotes, [these] bind to control elements in enhancers.
A protein that binds to DNA and stimulates gene transcription. In prokaryotes, [these] bind in or near the promoter; in eukaryotes, [these] bind to control elements in enhancers.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">activator</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bicoid</span>"	A maternal effect gene that codes for a protein responsible for specifying the anterior end in Drosophila.
A maternal effect gene that codes for a protein responsible for specifying the anterior end in Drosophila.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bicoid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell differentiation</span>"	The structural and functional divergence of cells as they become specialized during a multicellular organism’s development. [This] depends on the control of gene expression.
The structural and functional divergence of cells as they become specialized during a multicellular organism’s development. [This] depends on the control of gene expression.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell differentiation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">control element</span>"	A segment of noncoding DNA that helps regulate transcription of a gene by binding a transcription factor. Multiple [these] are present in a eukaryotic gene’s enhancer.
A segment of noncoding DNA that helps regulate transcription of a gene by binding a transcription factor. Multiple [these] are present in a eukaryotic gene’s enhancer.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">control element</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">corepressor</span>"	A small molecule that binds to a bacterial repressor protein and changes its shape, allowing it to switch an operon off.
A small molecule that binds to a bacterial repressor protein and changes its shape, allowing it to switch an operon off.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">corepressor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytoplasmic determinant</span>"	A maternal substance, such as a protein or RNA, placed into an egg that influences the course of early development by regulating the expression of genes that affect the developmental fate of cells.
A maternal substance, such as a protein or RNA, placed into an egg that influences the course of early development by regulating the expression of genes that affect the developmental fate of cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytoplasmic determinant</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">determination</span>"	The progressive restriction of developmental potential in which the possible fate of each cell becomes more limited as an embryo develops. At the end of [this], a cell is committed to its fate.
The progressive restriction of developmental potential in which the possible fate of each cell becomes more limited as an embryo develops. At the end of [this], a cell is committed to its fate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">determination</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">differential gene expression</span>"	The expression of different sets of genes by cells with the same genome.
The expression of different sets of genes by cells with the same genome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">differential gene expression</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">egg-polarity gene</span>"	A gene that helps control the orientation (polarity) of the egg; also called a maternal effect gene.
A gene that helps control the orientation (polarity) of the egg; also called a maternal effect gene.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">egg-polarity gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">embryonic lethal</span>"	A mutation with a phenotype leading to death of an embryo or larva.
A mutation with a phenotype leading to death of an embryo or larva.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">embryonic lethal</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">enhancer</span>"	A segment of eukaryotic DNA containing multiple control elements, usually located far from the gene whose transcription it regulates.
A segment of eukaryotic DNA containing multiple control elements, usually located far from the gene whose transcription it regulates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">enhancer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epigenetic inheritance</span>"	Inheritance of traits transmitted by mechanisms not directly involving the nucleotide sequence of a genome.
Inheritance of traits transmitted by mechanisms not directly involving the nucleotide sequence of a genome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epigenetic inheritance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">histone acetylation</span>"	The attachment of acetyl groups to certain amino acids of histone proteins.
The attachment of acetyl groups to certain amino acids of histone proteins.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">histone acetylation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homeotic gene</span>"	Any of the master regulatory genes that control placement and spatial organization of body parts in animals, plants, and fungi by controlling the developmental fate of groups of cells.
Any of the master regulatory genes that control placement and spatial organization of body parts in animals, plants, and fungi by controlling the developmental fate of groups of cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homeotic gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inducer</span>"	A specific small molecule that binds to a bacterial repressor protein and changes the repressor's shape so that it cannot bind to an operator, thus switching an operon on.
A specific small molecule that binds to a bacterial repressor protein and changes the repressor's shape so that it cannot bind to an operator, thus switching an operon on.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inducer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">induction</span>"	The process in which one group of embryonic cells influences the development of another, usually by causing changes in gene expression.
The process in which one group of embryonic cells influences the development of another, usually by causing changes in gene expression.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">induction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">maternal effect gene</span>"	A gene that, when mutant in the mother, results in a mutant phenotype in the offspring, regardless of the offspring’s genotype. [These] were first identified in Drosophila.
A gene that, when mutant in the mother, results in a mutant phenotype in the offspring, regardless of the offspring’s genotype. [These] were first identified in Drosophila.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">maternal effect gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microRNA (miRNA)</span>"	A small, single-stranded RNA molecule, generated from a hairpin structure on a precursor RNA transcribed from a particular gene. The [this] associates with one or more proteins in a complex that can degrade or prevent translation of an mRNA with a complementary sequence.
A small, single-stranded RNA molecule, generated from a hairpin structure on a precursor RNA transcribed from a particular gene. The [this] associates with one or more proteins in a complex that can degrade or prevent translation of an mRNA with a complementary sequence.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microRNA (miRNA)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">morphogen</span>"	A substance, such as bicoid protein in Drosophila, that provides positional information in the form of a concentration gradient along an embryonic axis.
A substance, such as bicoid protein in Drosophila, that provides positional information in the form of a concentration gradient along an embryonic axis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">morphogen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">morphogenesis</span>"	The development of body shape and organization.
The development of body shape and organization.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">morphogenesis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oncogene</span>"	A gene found in viral or cellular genomes that is involved in triggering molecular events that can lead to cancer.
A gene found in viral or cellular genomes that is involved in triggering molecular events that can lead to cancer.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oncogene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">operator</span>"	In bacterial DNA, a sequence of nucleotides near the start of an operon to which an active repressor can attach. The binding of the repressor prevents RNA polymerase from attaching to the promoter and transcribing the genes of the operon.
In bacterial DNA, a sequence of nucleotides near the start of an operon to which an active repressor can attach. The binding of the repressor prevents RNA polymerase from attaching to the promoter and transcribing the genes of the operon.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">operator</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">operon</span>"	A unit of genetic function found in bacteria and phages, consisting of a promoter, an operator, and a coordinately regulated cluster of genes whose products function in a common pathway.
A unit of genetic function found in bacteria and phages, consisting of a promoter, an operator, and a coordinately regulated cluster of genes whose products function in a common pathway.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">operon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">p53 gene</span>"	A tumor-suppressor gene that codes for a specific transcription factor that promotes the synthesis of cell cycle–inhibiting proteins.
A tumor-suppressor gene that codes for a specific transcription factor that promotes the synthesis of cell cycle–inhibiting proteins.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">p53 gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pattern formation</span>"	The development of a multicellular organism’s spatial organization, the arrangement of organs and tissues in their characteristic places in three-dimensional space.
The development of a multicellular organism’s spatial organization, the arrangement of organs and tissues in their characteristic places in three-dimensional space.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pattern formation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyp</span>"	(1) A small growth, typically benign and with a stalk, protruding from a mucous membrane.&nbsp;&nbsp;(2) The sessile variant of the cnidarian body plan. The alternate form is the medusa.
(1) A small growth, typically benign and with a stalk, protruding from a mucous membrane.&nbsp;&nbsp;(2) The sessile variant of the cnidarian body plan. The alternate form is the medusa.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyp</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">positional information</span>"	Molecular cues that control pattern formation in an animal or plant embryonic structure by indicating a cell’s location relative to the organism’s body axes. These cues elicit a response by genes that regulate development.
Molecular cues that control pattern formation in an animal or plant embryonic structure by indicating a cell’s location relative to the organism’s body axes. These cues elicit a response by genes that regulate development.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">positional information</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proteasome</span>"	A giant protein complex that recognizes and destroys proteins tagged for elimination by the small protein ubiquitin.
A giant protein complex that recognizes and destroys proteins tagged for elimination by the small protein ubiquitin.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proteasome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proto-oncogene</span>"	A normal cellular gene that has the potential to become an oncogene.
A normal cellular gene that has the potential to become an oncogene.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proto-oncogene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ras gene</span>"	A gene that codes for Ras, a G protein that relays a growth signal from a growth factor receptor on the plasma membrane to a cascade of protein kinases, ultimately resulting in stimulation of the cell cycle.
A gene that codes for Ras, a G protein that relays a growth signal from a growth factor receptor on the plasma membrane to a cascade of protein kinases, ultimately resulting in stimulation of the cell cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ras gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">regulatory gene</span>"	A gene that codes for a protein, such as a repressor, that controls the transcription of another gene or group of genes.
A gene that codes for a protein, such as a repressor, that controls the transcription of another gene or group of genes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">regulatory gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">repressor</span>"	A protein that inhibits gene transcription. In prokaryotes, [these] bind to the DNA in or near the promoter. In eukaryotes, [these] may bind to control elements within enhancers, to activators, or to other proteins in a way that blocks activators from binding to DNA.
A protein that inhibits gene transcription. In prokaryotes, [these] bind to the DNA in or near the promoter. In eukaryotes, [these] may bind to control elements within enhancers, to activators, or to other proteins in a way that blocks activators from binding to DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">repressor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">RNA interference (RNAi)</span>"	A technique used to silence the expression of selected genes. [This] uses synthetic double-stranded RNA molecules that match the sequence of a particular gene to trigger the breakdown of the gene’s messenger RNA.
A technique used to silence the expression of selected genes. [This] uses synthetic double-stranded RNA molecules that match the sequence of a particular gene to trigger the breakdown of the gene’s messenger RNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">RNA interference (RNAi)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">small interfering RNA (siRNA)</span>"	A small, single-stranded RNA molecule generated by cellular machinery from a long, double-stranded RNA molecule. The [this] associates with one or more proteins in a complex that can degrade or prevent translation of an mRNA with a complementary sequence. In some cases, [this] can also block transcription by promoting chromatin modification.
A small, single-stranded RNA molecule generated by cellular machinery from a long, double-stranded RNA molecule. The [this] associates with one or more proteins in a complex that can degrade or prevent translation of an mRNA with a complementary sequence. In some cases, [this] can also block transcription by promoting chromatin modification.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">small interfering RNA (siRNA)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tumor-suppressor gene</span>"	A gene whose protein product inhibits cell division, thereby preventing the uncontrolled cell growth that contributes to cancer.
A gene whose protein product inhibits cell division, thereby preventing the uncontrolled cell growth that contributes to cancer.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tumor-suppressor gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome)</span>"	The symptoms and signs present during the late stages of HIV infection, defined by a specified reduction in the number of T cells and the appearance of characteristic secondary infections.
The symptoms and signs present during the late stages of HIV infection, defined by a specified reduction in the number of T cells and the appearance of characteristic secondary infections.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">capsid</span>"	The protein shell that encloses a viral genome. It may be rod-shaped, polyhedral, or more complex in shape.
The protein shell that encloses a viral genome. It may be rod-shaped, polyhedral, or more complex in shape.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">capsid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">HIV (human immunodeficiency virus)</span>"	The infectious agent that causes AIDS.&nbsp;&nbsp;[This] is a retrovirus.
The infectious agent that causes AIDS.&nbsp;&nbsp;[This] is a retrovirus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">HIV (human immunodeficiency virus)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">host range</span>"	The limited range of host cells that each type of virus can infect.
The limited range of host cells that each type of virus can infect.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">host range</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lysogenic cycle</span>"	A type of phage reproductive cycle in which the viral genome becomes incorporated into the bacterial host chromosome as a prophage and does not kill the host.
A type of phage reproductive cycle in which the viral genome becomes incorporated into the bacterial host chromosome as a prophage and does not kill the host.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lysogenic cycle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lytic cycle</span>"	A type of phage reproductive cycle resulting in the release of new phages by lysis (and death) of the host cell.
A type of phage reproductive cycle resulting in the release of new phages by lysis (and death) of the host cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lytic cycle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pandemic</span>"	A global epidemic.
A global epidemic.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pandemic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prion</span>"	An infectious agent that is a misfolded version of a normal cellular protein. [These] appear to increase in number by converting correctly folded versions of the protein to more [these].
An infectious agent that is a misfolded version of a normal cellular protein. [These] appear to increase in number by converting correctly folded versions of the protein to more [these].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prophage</span>"	A phage genome that has been inserted into a specific site on a bacterial chromosome.
A phage genome that has been inserted into a specific site on a bacterial chromosome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prophage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">provirus</span>"	A viral genome that is permanently inserted into a host genome.
A viral genome that is permanently inserted into a host genome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">provirus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restriction enzyme</span>"	An endonuclease (type of enzyme) that recognizes and cuts DNA molecules foreign to a bacterium (such as phage genomes). The enzyme cuts at specific nucleotide sequences (restriction sites).
An endonuclease (type of enzyme) that recognizes and cuts DNA molecules foreign to a bacterium (such as phage genomes). The enzyme cuts at specific nucleotide sequences (restriction sites).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restriction enzyme</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">retrovirus</span>"	An RNA virus that reproduces by transcribing its RNA into DNA and then inserting the DNA into a cellular chromosome; an important class of cancer-causing viruses.
An RNA virus that reproduces by transcribing its RNA into DNA and then inserting the DNA into a cellular chromosome; an important class of cancer-causing viruses.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">retrovirus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reverse transcriptase</span>"	An enzyme encoded by certain viruses (retroviruses) that uses RNA as a template for DNA synthesis.
An enzyme encoded by certain viruses (retroviruses) that uses RNA as a template for DNA synthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reverse transcriptase</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">temperate phage</span>"	A phage that is capable of reproducing by either a lytic or lysogenic cycle.
A phage that is capable of reproducing by either a lytic or lysogenic cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">temperate phage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vaccine</span>"	A harmless variant or derivative of a pathogen that stimulates a host’s immune system to mount defenses against the pathogen.
A harmless variant or derivative of a pathogen that stimulates a host’s immune system to mount defenses against the pathogen.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vaccine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">viral envelope</span>"	A membrane that cloaks the capsid that in turn encloses a viral genome.
A membrane that cloaks the capsid that in turn encloses a viral genome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">viral envelope</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">viroid</span>"	A plant pathogen consisting of a molecule of naked, circular RNA a few hundred nucleotides long.
A plant pathogen consisting of a molecule of naked, circular RNA a few hundred nucleotides long.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">viroid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">virulent phage</span>"	A phage that reproduces only by a lytic cycle.
A phage that reproduces only by a lytic cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">virulent phage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC)</span>"	A large plasmid that acts as a bacterial chromosome and can carry inserts of 100,000 to 300,000 base pairs.
A large plasmid that acts as a bacterial chromosome and can carry inserts of 100,000 to 300,000 base pairs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biofuel</span>"	A fuel produced from dry organic matter or combustible oils produced by plants.
A fuel produced from dry organic matter or combustible oils produced by plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biofuel</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biotechnology</span>"	The manipulation of organisms or their components to produce useful products.
The manipulation of organisms or their components to produce useful products.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biotechnology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cDNA library</span>"	A gene library containing clones that carry complementary DNA (cDNA) inserts. The library includes only the genes that were transcribed in the cells whose mRNA was isolated to make the cDNA.
A gene library containing clones that carry complementary DNA (cDNA) inserts. The library includes only the genes that were transcribed in the cells whose mRNA was isolated to make the cDNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cDNA library</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cloning vector</span>"	In genetic engineering, a DNA molecule that can carry foreign DNA into a host cell and replicate there. [These] include plasmids that move recombinant DNA from a test tube back into a cell and viruses that transfer recombinant DNA by infection.
In genetic engineering, a DNA molecule that can carry foreign DNA into a host cell and replicate there. [These] include plasmids that move recombinant DNA from a test tube back into a cell and viruses that transfer recombinant DNA by infection.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cloning vector</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">complementary DNA (cDNA)</span>"	A double-stranded DNA molecule made in vitro using mRNA as a template and the enzymes reverse transcriptase and DNA polymerase. A [this] molecule corresponds to the exons of a gene.
A double-stranded DNA molecule made in vitro using mRNA as a template and the enzymes reverse transcriptase and DNA polymerase. A [this] molecule corresponds to the exons of a gene.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">complementary DNA (cDNA)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">DNA microarray assay</span>"	A method to detect and measure the expression of thousands of genes at one time. Tiny amounts of a large number of single-stranded DNA fragments representing different genes are fixed to a glass slide and tested for hybridization with samples of labeled cDNA.
A method to detect and measure the expression of thousands of genes at one time. Tiny amounts of a large number of single-stranded DNA fragments representing different genes are fixed to a glass slide and tested for hybridization with samples of labeled cDNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">DNA microarray assay</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electroporation</span>"	A technique to introduce recombinant DNA into cells by applying a brief electrical pulse to a solution containing the cells. The pulse creates temporary holes in the cells’ plasma membranes, through which DNA can enter.
A technique to introduce recombinant DNA into cells by applying a brief electrical pulse to a solution containing the cells. The pulse creates temporary holes in the cells’ plasma membranes, through which DNA can enter.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">electroporation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">expression vector</span>"	A cloning vector that contains the requisite bacterial promoter just upstream of a restriction site where a eukaryotic gene can be inserted, allowing the gene to be expressed in a bacterial cell.
A cloning vector that contains the requisite bacterial promoter just upstream of a restriction site where a eukaryotic gene can be inserted, allowing the gene to be expressed in a bacterial cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">expression vector</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gel electrophoresis</span>"	A technique for separating nucleic acids or proteins on the basis of their size and electrical charge, both of which affect their rate of movement through an electric field in a gel.
A technique for separating nucleic acids or proteins on the basis of their size and electrical charge, both of which affect their rate of movement through an electric field in a gel.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gel electrophoresis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene cloning</span>"	The production of multiple copies of a gene.
The production of multiple copies of a gene.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene cloning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene therapy</span>"	The introduction of genes into an afflicted individual for therapeutic purposes.
The introduction of genes into an afflicted individual for therapeutic purposes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene therapy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetic engineering</span>"	The direct manipulation of genes for practical purposes.
The direct manipulation of genes for practical purposes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetic engineering</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetic profile</span>"	An individual’s unique set of genetic markers, detected most often today by PCR or, previously, by electrophoresis and nucleic acid probes.
An individual’s unique set of genetic markers, detected most often today by PCR or, previously, by electrophoresis and nucleic acid probes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetic profile</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetically modified (GM) organism</span>"	An organism that has acquired one or more genes by artificial means; also known as a transgenic organism.
An organism that has acquired one or more genes by artificial means; also known as a transgenic organism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetically modified (GM) organism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genomic library</span>"	A set of cell clones containing all the DNA segments from a genome, each within a plasmid, phage, or other cloning vector.
A set of cell clones containing all the DNA segments from a genome, each within a plasmid, phage, or other cloning vector.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genomic library</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">in situ hybridization</span>"	A technique used to detect the location of a specific mRNA using nucleic acid hybridization with a labeled probe in an intact organism.
A technique used to detect the location of a specific mRNA using nucleic acid hybridization with a labeled probe in an intact organism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">in situ hybridization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">in vitro mutagenesis</span>"	A technique used to discover the function of a gene by cloning it, introducing specific changes into the cloned gene’s sequence, reinserting the mutated gene into a cell, and studying the phenotype of the mutant.
A technique used to discover the function of a gene by cloning it, introducing specific changes into the cloned gene’s sequence, reinserting the mutated gene into a cell, and studying the phenotype of the mutant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">in vitro mutagenesis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Northern blotting</span>"	A technique that enables specific nucleotide sequences to be detected in a sample of mRNA. It involves gel electrophoresis of RNA molecules and their transfer to a membrane (blotting), followed by nucleic acid hybridization with a labeled probe.
A technique that enables specific nucleotide sequences to be detected in a sample of mRNA. It involves gel electrophoresis of RNA molecules and their transfer to a membrane (blotting), followed by nucleic acid hybridization with a labeled probe.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Northern blotting</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleic acid hybridization</span>"	The process of base pairing between a gene and a complementary sequence on another nucleic acid molecule.
The process of base pairing between a gene and a complementary sequence on another nucleic acid molecule.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleic acid hybridization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleic acid probe</span>"	In DNA technology, a labeled single-stranded nucleic acid molecule used to locate a specific nucleotide sequence in a nucleic acid sample. Molecules of the [this] hydrogen-bond to the complementary sequence wherever it occurs; radioactive or other labeling of the [this] allows its location to be detected.
In DNA technology, a labeled single-stranded nucleic acid molecule used to locate a specific nucleotide sequence in a nucleic acid sample. Molecules of the [this] hydrogen-bond to the complementary sequence wherever it occurs; radioactive or other labeling of the [this] allows its location to be detected.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nucleic acid probe</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Parkinson’s disease</span>"	A progressive brain disease characterized by difficulty in initiating movements, slowness of movement, and rigidity.
A progressive brain disease characterized by difficulty in initiating movements, slowness of movement, and rigidity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Parkinson’s disease</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmid</span>"	A small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecule that carries accessory genes separate from those of a bacterial chromosome. [These] are also found in some eukaryotes, such as yeasts.
A small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecule that carries accessory genes separate from those of a bacterial chromosome. [These] are also found in some eukaryotes, such as yeasts.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pluripotent</span>"	Describing a cell that can give rise to many, but not all, parts of an organism.
Describing a cell that can give rise to many, but not all, parts of an organism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pluripotent</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polymerase chain reaction (PCR)</span>"	A technique for amplifying DNA in vitro by incubating it with specific primers, a heat-resistant DNA polymerase, and nucleotides.
A technique for amplifying DNA in vitro by incubating it with specific primers, a heat-resistant DNA polymerase, and nucleotides.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polymerase chain reaction (PCR)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">recombinant DNA</span>"	A DNA molecule made in vitro with segments from different sources.
A DNA molecule made in vitro with segments from different sources.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">recombinant DNA</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restriction fragment</span>"	A DNA segment that results from the cutting of DNA by a restriction enzyme.
A DNA segment that results from the cutting of DNA by a restriction enzyme.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restriction fragment</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP)</span>"	A single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) that exists in the restriction site for a particular enzyme, thus making the site unrecognizable by that enzyme and changing the lengths of the restriction fragments formed by digestion with that enzyme. A [this] can be in coding or noncoding DNA.
A single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) that exists in the restriction site for a particular enzyme, thus making the site unrecognizable by that enzyme and changing the lengths of the restriction fragments formed by digestion with that enzyme. A [this] can be in coding or noncoding DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restriction site</span>"	A specific sequence on a DNA strand that is recognized and cut by a restriction enzyme.
A specific sequence on a DNA strand that is recognized and cut by a restriction enzyme.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restriction site</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reverse transcriptase–polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)</span>"	A technique for determining expression of a particular gene. It uses reverse transcriptase and DNA polymerase to synthesize cDNA from all the mRNA in a sample and then subjects the cDNA to PCR amplification using primers specific for the gene of interest.
A technique for determining expression of a particular gene. It uses reverse transcriptase and DNA polymerase to synthesize cDNA from all the mRNA in a sample and then subjects the cDNA to PCR amplification using primers specific for the gene of interest.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reverse transcriptase–polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">short tandem repeat (STR)</span>"	Simple sequence DNA containing multiple tandemly repeated units of two to five nucleotides. Variations in [these] act as genetic markers in [this] analysis, used to prepare genetic profiles.
Simple sequence DNA containing multiple tandemly repeated units of two to five nucleotides. Variations in [these] act as genetic markers in [this] analysis, used to prepare genetic profiles.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">short tandem repeat (STR)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)</span>"	A single base-pair site in a genome where nucleotide variation is found in at least 1% of the population.
A single base-pair site in a genome where nucleotide variation is found in at least 1% of the population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Southern blotting</span>"	A technique that enables specific nucleotide sequences to be detected in a sample of DNA. It involves gel electrophoresis of DNA molecules and their transfer to a membrane (blotting), followed by nucleic acid hybridization with a labeled probe.
A technique that enables specific nucleotide sequences to be detected in a sample of DNA.
