It involves gel electrophoresis of DNA molecules and their transfer to a membrane (blotting), followed by nucleic acid hybridization with a labeled probe.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Southern blotting</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stem cell</span>"	Any relatively unspecialized cell that can produce, during a single division, one identical daughter cell and one more specialized daughter cell that can undergo further differentiation.
Any relatively unspecialized cell that can produce, during a single division, one identical daughter cell and one more specialized daughter cell that can undergo further differentiation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stem cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sticky end</span>"	A single-stranded end of a double-stranded restriction fragment.
A single-stranded end of a double-stranded restriction fragment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sticky end</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Ti plasmid</span>"	A plasmid of a tumor-inducing bacterium (the plant pathogen Agrobacterium) that integrates a segment of its DNA (T DNA) into a chromosome of a host plant. The [this] is frequently used as a vector for genetic engineering in plants.
A plasmid of a tumor-inducing bacterium (the plant pathogen Agrobacterium) that integrates a segment of its DNA (T DNA) into a chromosome of a host plant. The [this] is frequently used as a vector for genetic engineering in plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Ti plasmid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">yeast artificial chromosome (YAC)</span>"	A cloning vector that combines the essentials of a eukaryotic chromosome—an origin for DNA replication, a centromere, and two telomeres—with foreign DNA.
A cloning vector that combines the essentials of a eukaryotic chromosome—an origin for DNA replication, a centromere, and two telomeres—with foreign DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">yeast artificial chromosome (YAC)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evo-devo</span>"	Evolutionary developmental biology; a field of biology that compares developmental processes of different multicellular organisms to understand how these processes have evolved and how changes can modify existing organismal features or lead to new ones.
Evolutionary developmental biology; a field of biology that compares developmental processes of different multicellular organisms to understand how these processes have evolved and how changes can modify existing organismal features or lead to new ones.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evo-devo</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genomics</span>"	The study of whole sets of genes and their interactions.
The study of whole sets of genes and their interactions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genomics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homeobox</span>"	A 180-nucleotide sequence within homeotic genes and some other developmental genes that is widely conserved in animals. Related sequences occur in plants and yeasts.
A 180-nucleotide sequence within homeotic genes and some other developmental genes that is widely conserved in animals. Related sequences occur in plants and yeasts.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homeobox</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Human Genome Project</span>"	An international collaborative effort to map and sequence the DNA of the entire human genome.
An international collaborative effort to map and sequence the DNA of the entire human genome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Human Genome Project</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lysozyme</span>"	An enzyme that destroys bacterial cell walls; in mammals, found in sweat, tears, and saliva.
An enzyme that destroys bacterial cell walls; in mammals, found in sweat, tears, and saliva.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lysozyme</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">multigene family</span>"	A collection of genes with similar or identical sequences, presumably of common origin.
A collection of genes with similar or identical sequences, presumably of common origin.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">multigene family</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylogenetic tree</span>"	A branching diagram that represents a hypothesis about the evolutionary history of a group of organisms.
A branching diagram that represents a hypothesis about the evolutionary history of a group of organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylogenetic tree</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">physical map</span>"	A genetic map in which the actual physical distances between genes or other genetic markers are expressed, usually as the number of base pairs along the DNA.
A genetic map in which the actual physical distances between genes or other genetic markers are expressed, usually as the number of base pairs along the DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">physical map</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proteomics</span>"	The systematic study of the full protein sets (proteomes) encoded by genomes.
The systematic study of the full protein sets (proteomes) encoded by genomes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proteomics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pseudogene</span>"	A DNA segment very similar to a real gene but which does not yield a functional product; a DNA segment that formerly functioned as a gene but has become inactivated in a particular species because of mutation.
A DNA segment very similar to a real gene but which does not yield a functional product; a DNA segment that formerly functioned as a gene but has become inactivated in a particular species because of mutation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pseudogene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">retrotransposon</span>"	A transposable element that moves within a genome by means of an RNA intermediate, a transcript of the [this] DNA.
A transposable element that moves within a genome by means of an RNA intermediate, a transcript of the [this] DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">retrotransposon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">simple sequence DNA</span>"	A DNA sequence that contains many copies of tandemly repeated short sequences.
A DNA sequence that contains many copies of tandemly repeated short sequences.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">simple sequence DNA</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transposable element</span>"	A segment of DNA that can move within the genome of a cell by means of a DNA or RNA intermediate; also called a transposable genetic element.
A segment of DNA that can move within the genome of a cell by means of a DNA or RNA intermediate; also called a transposable genetic element.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transposable element</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transposon</span>"	A transposable element that moves within a genome by means of a DNA intermediate.
A transposable element that moves within a genome by means of a DNA intermediate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">transposon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adaptation</span>"	Inherited characteristic of an organism that enhances its survival and reproduction in specific environments.
Inherited characteristic of an organism that enhances its survival and reproduction in specific environments.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adaptation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">analogous</span>"	Having characteristics that are similar because of convergent evolution, not homology.
Having characteristics that are similar because of convergent evolution, not homology.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">analogous</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">artificial selection</span>"	The selective breeding of domesticated plants and animals to encourage the occurrence of desirable traits.
The selective breeding of domesticated plants and animals to encourage the occurrence of desirable traits.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">artificial selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biogeography</span>"	The study of the past and present distribution of species.
The study of the past and present distribution of species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biogeography</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">catastrophism</span>"	The principle that events in the past occurred suddenly and were caused by different mechanisms than those operating today. See uniformitarianism.
The principle that events in the past occurred suddenly and were caused by different mechanisms than those operating today. See uniformitarianism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">catastrophism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">continental drift</span>"	The slow movement of the continental plates across Earth’s surface.
The slow movement of the continental plates across Earth’s surface.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">continental drift</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">convergent evolution</span>"	The evolution of similar features in independent evolutionary lineages.
The evolution of similar features in independent evolutionary lineages.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">convergent evolution</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endemic</span>"	Referring to a species that is confined to a specific, relatively small geographic area.
Referring to a species that is confined to a specific, relatively small geographic area.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endemic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evolutionary tree</span>"	A branching diagram that reflects a hypothesis about evolutionary relationships among groups of organisms.
A branching diagram that reflects a hypothesis about evolutionary relationships among groups of organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evolutionary tree</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fossil</span>"	A preserved remnant or impression of an organism that lived in the past.
A preserved remnant or impression of an organism that lived in the past.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fossil</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homologous structures</span>"	Structures in different species that are similar because of common ancestry.
Structures in different species that are similar because of common ancestry.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homologous structures</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homology</span>"	Similarity in characteristics resulting from a shared ancestry.
Similarity in characteristics resulting from a shared ancestry.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">marsupial</span>"	A mammal, such as a koala, kangaroo, or opossum, whose young complete their embryonic development inside a maternal pouch called the marsupium.
A mammal, such as a koala, kangaroo, or opossum, whose young complete their embryonic development inside a maternal pouch called the marsupium.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">marsupial</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">natural selection</span>"	A process in which organisms with certain inherited characteristics are more likely to survive and reproduce than are organisms with other characteristics.
A process in which organisms with certain inherited characteristics are more likely to survive and reproduce than are organisms with other characteristics.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">natural selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paleontology</span>"	The scientific study of fossils.
The scientific study of fossils.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paleontology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Pangaea</span>"	The supercontinent that formed near the end of the Paleozoic era, when plate movements brought all the landmasses of Earth together.
The supercontinent that formed near the end of the Paleozoic era, when plate movements brought all the landmasses of Earth together.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Pangaea</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stratum</span>"	A rock layer formed when new layers of sediment cover older ones and compress them.
A rock layer formed when new layers of sediment cover older ones and compress them.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stratum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">uniformitarianism</span>"	The principle stating that mechanisms of change are constant over time. See catastrophism.
The principle stating that mechanisms of change are constant over time. See catastrophism.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">uniformitarianism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vestigial structure</span>"	A structure of marginal, if any, importance to an organism. [These] are historical remnants of structures that had important functions in ancestors.
A structure of marginal, if any, importance to an organism. [These] are historical remnants of structures that had important functions in ancestors.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vestigial structure</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">allopatric speciation</span>"	The formation of new species in populations that are geographically isolated from one another.
The formation of new species in populations that are geographically isolated from one another.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">allopatric speciation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">allopolyploid</span>"	A fertile individual that has more than two chromosome sets as a result of two different species interbreeding and combining their chromosomes.
A fertile individual that has more than two chromosome sets as a result of two different species interbreeding and combining their chromosomes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">allopolyploid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autopolyploid</span>"	An individual that has more than two chromosome sets that are all derived from a single species.
An individual that has more than two chromosome sets that are all derived from a single species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autopolyploid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biological species concept</span>"	Definition of a species as a population or group of populations whose members have the potential to interbreed in nature and produce viable, fertile offspring, but do not produce viable, fertile offspring with members of other such groups.
Definition of a species as a population or group of populations whose members have the potential to interbreed in nature and produce viable, fertile offspring, but do not produce viable, fertile offspring with members of other such groups.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biological species concept</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecological species concept</span>"	A definition of species in terms of ecological niche, the sum of how members of the species interact with the nonliving and living parts of their environment.
A definition of species in terms of ecological niche, the sum of how members of the species interact with the nonliving and living parts of their environment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecological species concept</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hybrid</span>"	Offspring that results from the mating of individuals from two different species or two true-breeding varieties of the same species.
Offspring that results from the mating of individuals from two different species or two true-breeding varieties of the same species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hybrid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hybrid zone</span>"	A geographic region in which members of different species meet and mate, producing at least some offspring of mixed ancestry.
A geographic region in which members of different species meet and mate, producing at least some offspring of mixed ancestry.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hybrid zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">macroevolution</span>"	Evolutionary change above the species level, including the origin of a new group of organisms or a shift in the broad pattern of evolutionary change over a long period of time. Examples of macroevolutionary change include the appearance of major new features of organisms and the impact of mass extinctions on the diversity of life and its subsequent recovery.
Evolutionary change above the species level, including the origin of a new group of organisms or a shift in the broad pattern of evolutionary change over a long period of time. Examples of macroevolutionary change include the appearance of major new features of organisms and the impact of mass extinctions on the diversity of life and its subsequent recovery.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">macroevolution</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">morphological species concept</span>"	A definition of species in terms of measurable anatomical criteria.
A definition of species in terms of measurable anatomical criteria.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">morphological species concept</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylogenetic species concept</span>"	A definition of species as the smallest group of individuals that share a common ancestor, forming one branch on the tree of life.
A definition of species as the smallest group of individuals that share a common ancestor, forming one branch on the tree of life.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylogenetic species concept</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">postzygotic barrier</span>"	A reproductive barrier that prevents hybrid zygotes produced by two different species from developing into viable, fertile adults.
A reproductive barrier that prevents hybrid zygotes produced by two different species from developing into viable, fertile adults.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">postzygotic barrier</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prezygotic barrier</span>"	A reproductive barrier that impedes mating between species or hinders fertilization if interspecific mating is attempted.
A reproductive barrier that impedes mating between species or hinders fertilization if interspecific mating is attempted.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prezygotic barrier</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">punctuated equilibria</span>"	In the fossil record, long periods of apparent stasis, in which a species undergoes little or no morphological change, interrupted by relatively brief periods of sudden change.
In the fossil record, long periods of apparent stasis, in which a species undergoes little or no morphological change, interrupted by relatively brief periods of sudden change.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">punctuated equilibria</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reinforcement</span>"	A process in which natural selection strengthens prezygotic barriers to reproduction, thus reducing the chances of hybrid formation. Such a process is likely to occur only if hybrid offspring are less fit than members of the parent species.
A process in which natural selection strengthens prezygotic barriers to reproduction, thus reducing the chances of hybrid formation. Such a process is likely to occur only if hybrid offspring are less fit than members of the parent species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reinforcement</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">speciation</span>"	An evolutionary process in which one species splits into two or more species.
An evolutionary process in which one species splits into two or more species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">speciation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">species</span>"	A population or group of populations whose members have the potential to interbreed in nature and produce viable, fertile offspring, but do not produce viable, fertile offspring with members of other such groups.
A population or group of populations whose members have the potential to interbreed in nature and produce viable, fertile offspring, but do not produce viable, fertile offspring with members of other such groups.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">species</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sympatric speciation</span>"	The formation of new species in populations that live in the same geographic area.
The formation of new species in populations that live in the same geographic area.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sympatric speciation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reproductive isolation</span>"	The existence of biological factors (barriers) that impede members of two species from producing viable, fertile offspring.
The existence of biological factors (barriers) that impede members of two species from producing viable, fertile offspring.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reproductive isolation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">average heterozygosity</span>"	The percent, on average, of a population’s loci that are heterozygous in members of the population.
The percent, on average, of a population’s loci that are heterozygous in members of the population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">average heterozygosity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">balancing selection</span>"	Natural selection that maintains two or more phenotypic forms in a population.
Natural selection that maintains two or more phenotypic forms in a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">balancing selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bottleneck effect</span>"	Genetic drift that occurs when the size of a population is reduced, as by a natural disaster or human actions. Typically, the surviving population is no longer genetically representative of the original population.
Genetic drift that occurs when the size of a population is reduced, as by a natural disaster or human actions. Typically, the surviving population is no longer genetically representative of the original population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bottleneck effect</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cline</span>"	A graded change in a character along a geographic axis.
A graded change in a character along a geographic axis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cline</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">directional selection</span>"	Natural selection in which individuals at one end of the phenotypic range survive or reproduce more successfully than do other individuals.
Natural selection in which individuals at one end of the phenotypic range survive or reproduce more successfully than do other individuals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">directional selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">disruptive selection</span>"	Natural selection in which individuals on both extremes of a phenotypic range survive or reproduce more successfully than do individuals with intermediate phenotypes.
Natural selection in which individuals on both extremes of a phenotypic range survive or reproduce more successfully than do individuals with intermediate phenotypes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">disruptive selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">founder effect</span>"	Genetic drift that occurs when a few individuals become isolated from a larger population and form a new population whose gene pool composition is not reflective of that of the original population.
Genetic drift that occurs when a few individuals become isolated from a larger population and form a new population whose gene pool composition is not reflective of that of the original population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">founder effect</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">frequency-dependent selection</span>"	A decline in the reproductive success of individuals that have a phenotype that has become too common in a population.
A decline in the reproductive success of individuals that have a phenotype that has become too common in a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">frequency-dependent selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene flow</span>"	The transfer of alleles from one population to another, resulting from the movement of fertile individuals or their gametes.
The transfer of alleles from one population to another, resulting from the movement of fertile individuals or their gametes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene flow</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene pool</span>"	The aggregate of all of the alleles for all of the loci in all individuals in a population. The term is also used in a more restricted sense as the aggregate of alleles for just one or a few loci in a population.
The aggregate of all of the alleles for all of the loci in all individuals in a population. The term is also used in a more restricted sense as the aggregate of alleles for just one or a few loci in a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gene pool</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetic drift</span>"	A process in which chance events cause unpredictable fluctuations in allele frequencies from one generation to the next. Effects of [this] are most pronounced in small populations.
A process in which chance events cause unpredictable fluctuations in allele frequencies from one generation to the next. Effects of [this] are most pronounced in small populations.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genetic drift</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">geographic variation</span>"	Differences between the gene pools of geographically separate populations or population subgroups.
Differences between the gene pools of geographically separate populations or population subgroups.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">geographic variation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium</span>"	The condition describing a nonevolving population (one that is in genetic equilibrium).
The condition describing a nonevolving population (one that is in genetic equilibrium).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Hardy-Weinberg principle</span>"	The principle that frequencies of alleles and genotypes in a population remain constant from generation to generation, provided that only Mendelian segregation and recombination of alleles are at work.
The principle that frequencies of alleles and genotypes in a population remain constant from generation to generation, provided that only Mendelian segregation and recombination of alleles are at work.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Hardy-Weinberg principle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterozygote advantage</span>"	Greater reproductive success of heterozygous individuals compared with homozygotes; tends to preserve variation in a gene pool.
Greater reproductive success of heterozygous individuals compared with homozygotes; tends to preserve variation in a gene pool.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterozygote advantage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intersexual selection</span>"	Selection whereby individuals of one sex (usually females) are choosy in selecting their mates from individuals of the other sex; also called mate choice.
Selection whereby individuals of one sex (usually females) are choosy in selecting their mates from individuals of the other sex; also called mate choice.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intersexual selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intrasexual selection</span>"	A direct competition among individuals of one sex (usually the males in vertebrates) for mates of the opposite sex.
A direct competition among individuals of one sex (usually the males in vertebrates) for mates of the opposite sex.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intrasexual selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microevolution</span>"	Evolutionary change below the species level; change in the allele frequencies in a population over generations.
Evolutionary change below the species level; change in the allele frequencies in a population over generations.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microevolution</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neutral variation</span>"	Genetic variation that does not appear to provide a selective advantage or disadvantage.
Genetic variation that does not appear to provide a selective advantage or disadvantage.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neutral variation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">population</span>"	A localized group of individuals of the same species that can interbreed, producing fertile offspring.
A localized group of individuals of the same species that can interbreed, producing fertile offspring.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">population</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">relative fitness</span>"	The contribution an individual makes to the gene pool of the next generation, relative to the contributions of other individuals in the population.
The contribution an individual makes to the gene pool of the next generation, relative to the contributions of other individuals in the population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">relative fitness</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sexual dimorphism</span>"	Marked differences between the secondary sex characteristics of males and females.
Marked differences between the secondary sex characteristics of males and females.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sexual dimorphism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sexual selection</span>"	A form of natural selection in which individuals with certain inherited characteristics are more likely than other individuals to obtain mates.
A form of natural selection in which individuals with certain inherited characteristics are more likely than other individuals to obtain mates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sexual selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stabilizing selection</span>"	Natural selection in which intermediate phenotypes survive or reproduce more successfully than do extreme phenotypes.
Natural selection in which intermediate phenotypes survive or reproduce more successfully than do extreme phenotypes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stabilizing selection</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acetylcholine</span>"	One of the most common neurotransmitters; functions by binding to receptors and altering the permeability of the postsynaptic membrane to specific ions, either depolarizing or hyperpolarizing the membrane.
One of the most common neurotransmitters; functions by binding to receptors and altering the permeability of the postsynaptic membrane to specific ions, either depolarizing or hyperpolarizing the membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acetylcholine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">axon</span>"	A typically long extension, or process, of a neuron that carries nerve impulses away from the cell body toward target cells.
A typically long extension, or process, of a neuron that carries nerve impulses away from the cell body toward target cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">axon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">axon hillock</span>"	The conical region of a neuron’s axon where it joins the cell body; typically the region where nerve impulses are generated.
The conical region of a neuron’s axon where it joins the cell body; typically the region where nerve impulses are generated.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">axon hillock</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biogenic amine</span>"	A neurotransmitter derived from an amino acid.
A neurotransmitter derived from an amino acid.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biogenic amine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">brain</span>"	Organ of the central nervous system where information is processed and integrated.
Organ of the central nervous system where information is processed and integrated.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">brain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell body</span>"	The part of a neuron that houses the nucleus and most other organelles.
The part of a neuron that houses the nucleus and most other organelles.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell body</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">depolarization</span>"	A change in a cell's membrane potential such that the inside of the membrane is made less negative relative to the outside. For example, a neuron membrane is depolarized if a stimulus decreases its voltage from the resting potential of –70 mV in the direction of zero voltage.
A change in a cell's membrane potential such that the inside of the membrane is made less negative relative to the outside. For example, a neuron membrane is depolarized if a stimulus decreases its voltage from the resting potential of –70 mV in the direction of zero voltage.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">depolarization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dopamine</span>"	A neurotransmitter that is a catecholamine, like epinephrine and norepinephrine.
A neurotransmitter that is a catecholamine, like epinephrine and norepinephrine.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dopamine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">equilibrium potential (Eion)</span>"	The magnitude of a cell’s membrane voltage at equilibrium; calculated using the Nernst equation.
The magnitude of a cell’s membrane voltage at equilibrium; calculated using the Nernst equation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">equilibrium potential (Eion)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP)</span>"	An electrical change (depolarization) in the membrane of a postsynaptic cell caused by the binding of an excitatory neurotransmitter from a presynaptic cell to a postsynaptic receptor; makes it more likely for a postsynaptic cell to generate an action potential.
An electrical change (depolarization) in the membrane of a postsynaptic cell caused by the binding of an excitatory neurotransmitter from a presynaptic cell to a postsynaptic receptor; makes it more likely for a postsynaptic cell to generate an action potential.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA)</span>"	An amino acid that functions as a CNS neurotransmitter in the central nervous system of vertebrates.
An amino acid that functions as a CNS neurotransmitter in the central nervous system of vertebrates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ganglion</span>"	A cluster (functional group) of nerve cell bodies in a centralized nervous system.
A cluster (functional group) of nerve cell bodies in a centralized nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ganglion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gated ion channel</span>"	A gated channel for a specific ion. The opening or closing of such channels may alter a cell's membrane potential.
A gated channel for a specific ion. The opening or closing of such channels may alter a cell's membrane potential.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gated ion channel</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glial cells (glia)</span>"	Supporting cells that are essential for the structural integrity of the nervous system and for the normal functioning of neurons.
Supporting cells that are essential for the structural integrity of the nervous system and for the normal functioning of neurons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glial cells (glia)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glutamate</span>"	An amino acid that functions as a neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.
An amino acid that functions as a neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glutamate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hyperpolarization</span>"	A change in a cell's membrane potential such that the inside of the membrane becomes more negative relative to the outside. [This] reduces the chance that a neuron will transmit a nerve impulse.
A change in a cell's membrane potential such that the inside of the membrane becomes more negative relative to the outside. [This] reduces the chance that a neuron will transmit a nerve impulse.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hyperpolarization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP)</span>"	An electrical change (usually hyperpolarization) in the membrane of a postsynaptic neuron caused by the binding of an inhibitory neurotransmitter from a presynaptic cell to a postsynaptic receptor; makes it more difficult for a postsynaptic neuron to generate an action potential.
An electrical change (usually hyperpolarization) in the membrane of a postsynaptic neuron caused by the binding of an inhibitory neurotransmitter from a presynaptic cell to a postsynaptic receptor; makes it more difficult for a postsynaptic neuron to generate an action potential.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interneuron</span>"	An association neuron; a nerve cell within the central nervous system that forms synapses with sensory and/or motor neurons and integrates sensory input and motor output.
An association neuron; a nerve cell within the central nervous system that forms synapses with sensory and/or motor neurons and integrates sensory input and motor output.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interneuron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">motor neuron</span>"	A nerve cell that transmits signals from the brain or spinal cord to muscles or glands.
A nerve cell that transmits signals from the brain or spinal cord to muscles or glands.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">motor neuron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">myelin sheath</span>"	Around the axon of a neuron, an insulating coat of cell membranes from Schwann cells or oligodendrocytes. It is interrupted by nodes of Ranvier, where action potentials are generated.
Around the axon of a neuron, an insulating coat of cell membranes from Schwann cells or oligodendrocytes. It is interrupted by nodes of Ranvier, where action potentials are generated.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">myelin sheath</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neuron</span>"	A nerve cell; the fundamental unit of the nervous system, having structure and properties that allow it to conduct signals by taking advantage of the electrical charge across its plasma membrane.
A nerve cell; the fundamental unit of the nervous system, having structure and properties that allow it to conduct signals by taking advantage of the electrical charge across its plasma membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neuron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neuropeptide</span>"	A relatively short chain of amino acids that serves as a neurotransmitter.
A relatively short chain of amino acids that serves as a neurotransmitter.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neuropeptide</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neurotransmitter</span>"	A molecule that is released from the synaptic terminal of a neuron at a chemical synapse, diffuses across the synaptic cleft, and binds to the postsynaptic cell, triggering a response.
A molecule that is released from the synaptic terminal of a neuron at a chemical synapse, diffuses across the synaptic cleft, and binds to the postsynaptic cell, triggering a response.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neurotransmitter</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">node of Ranvier</span>"	Gap in the myelin sheath of certain axons where an action potential may be generated. In saltatory conduction, an action potential is regenerated at each node, appearing to “jump” along the axon from node to node.
Gap in the myelin sheath of certain axons where an action potential may be generated. In saltatory conduction, an action potential is regenerated at each node, appearing to “jump” along the axon from node to node.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">node of Ranvier</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">norepinephrine</span>"	A catecholamine that is chemically and functionally similar to epinephrine and acts as a hormone or neurotransmitter; also known as noradrenaline.
A catecholamine that is chemically and functionally similar to epinephrine and acts as a hormone or neurotransmitter; also known as noradrenaline.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">norepinephrine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oligodendrocyte</span>"	A type of glial cell that forms insulating myelin sheaths around the axons of neurons in the central nervous system.
A type of glial cell that forms insulating myelin sheaths around the axons of neurons in the central nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oligodendrocyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">penis</span>"	The copulatory structure of male mammals.
The copulatory structure of male mammals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">penis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peripheral nervous system (PNS)</span>"	The sensory and motor neurons that connect to the central nervous system.
The sensory and motor neurons that connect to the central nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peripheral nervous system (PNS)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">postsynaptic cell</span>"	The target cell at a synapse.
The target cell at a synapse.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">postsynaptic cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">presynaptic cell</span>"	The transmitting cell at a synapse.
The transmitting cell at a synapse.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">presynaptic cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">refractory period</span>"	The short time immediately after an action potential in which the neuron cannot respond to another stimulus, owing to the inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels.
The short time immediately after an action potential in which the neuron cannot respond to another stimulus, owing to the inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">refractory period</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">resting potential</span>"	The membrane potential characteristic of a nonconducting excitable cell, with the inside of the cell more negative than the outside.
The membrane potential characteristic of a nonconducting excitable cell, with the inside of the cell more negative than the outside.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">resting potential</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">saltatory conduction</span>"	Rapid transmission of a nerve impulse along an axon, resulting from the action potential jumping from one node of Ranvier to another, skipping the myelin-sheathed regions of membrane.
Rapid transmission of a nerve impulse along an axon, resulting from the action potential jumping from one node of Ranvier to another, skipping the myelin-sheathed regions of membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">saltatory conduction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Schwann cell</span>"	A type of glial cell that forms insulating myelin sheaths around the axons of neurons in the peripheral nervous system.
A type of glial cell that forms insulating myelin sheaths around the axons of neurons in the peripheral nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Schwann cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sensory neuron</span>"	A nerve cell that receives information from the internal or external environment and transmits signals to the central nervous system.
A nerve cell that receives information from the internal or external environment and transmits signals to the central nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sensory neuron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">serotonin</span>"	A neurotransmitter, synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan, that functions in the central nervous system.
A neurotransmitter, synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan, that functions in the central nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">serotonin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spatial summation</span>"	A phenomenon of neural integration in which the membrane potential of the postsynaptic cell is determined by the combined effect of EPSPs or IPSPs produced nearly simultaneously by different synapses.
A phenomenon of neural integration in which the membrane potential of the postsynaptic cell is determined by the combined effect of EPSPs or IPSPs produced nearly simultaneously by different synapses.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spatial summation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">substance P</span>"	A neuropeptide that is a key excitatory neurotransmitter that mediates the perception of pain.
A neuropeptide that is a key excitatory neurotransmitter that mediates the perception of pain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">substance P</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synapse</span>"	The junction where one neuron communicates with another cell across a narrow gap. Neurotransmitter molecules released by the neuron diffuse across the [this], relaying messages to the other cell.
The junction where one neuron communicates with another cell across a narrow gap. Neurotransmitter molecules released by the neuron diffuse across the [this], relaying messages to the other cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synapse</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synaptic cleft</span>"	A narrow gap separating the synaptic terminal of a transmitting neuron from a receiving neuron or an effector cell.
A narrow gap separating the synaptic terminal of a transmitting neuron from a receiving neuron or an effector cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synaptic cleft</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synaptic terminal</span>"	A bulb at the end of an axon in which neurotransmitter molecules are stored and from which they are released.
A bulb at the end of an axon in which neurotransmitter molecules are stored and from which they are released.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synaptic terminal</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synaptic vesicle</span>"	Membranous sac containing neurotransmitter molecules at the tip of an axon.
Membranous sac containing neurotransmitter molecules at the tip of an axon.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">synaptic vesicle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">temporal summation</span>"	A phenomenon of neural integration in which the membrane potential of the postsynaptic cell in a chemical synapse is determined by the combined effect of EPSPs or IPSPs produced in rapid succession.
A phenomenon of neural integration in which the membrane potential of the postsynaptic cell in a chemical synapse is determined by the combined effect of EPSPs or IPSPs produced in rapid succession.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">temporal summation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">threshold</span>"	The potential that an excitable cell membrane must reach for an action potential to be initiated.
The potential that an excitable cell membrane must reach for an action potential to be initiated.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">threshold</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">voltage-gated ion channel</span>"	A specialized ion channel that opens or closes in response to changes in membrane potential.
A specialized ion channel that opens or closes in response to changes in membrane potential.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">voltage-gated ion channel</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adrenal gland</span>"	One of two endocrine glands located adjacent to the kidneys in mammals. Endocrine cells in the outer portion (cortex) respond to ACTH by secreting steroid hormones that help maintain homeostasis during long-term stress. Neurosecretory cells in the central portion (medulla) secrete epinephrine and norepinephrine in response to nervous inputs triggered by short-term stress.
One of two endocrine glands located adjacent to the kidneys in mammals. Endocrine cells in the outer portion (cortex) respond to ACTH by secreting steroid hormones that help maintain homeostasis during long-term stress. Neurosecretory cells in the central portion (medulla) secrete epinephrine and norepinephrine in response to nervous inputs triggered by short-term stress.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adrenal gland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)</span>"	A tropic hormone that is produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary and that stimulates the production and secretion of steroid hormones by the adrenal cortex.
A tropic hormone that is produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary and that stimulates the production and secretion of steroid hormones by the adrenal cortex.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">androgen</span>"	Any steroid hormone, such as testosterone, that stimulates the development and maintenance of the male reproductive system and secondary sex characteristics.
Any steroid hormone, such as testosterone, that stimulates the development and maintenance of the male reproductive system and secondary sex characteristics.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">androgen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anterior pituitary</span>"	Also called the adenohypophysis; portion of the pituitary that develops from nonneural tissue; consists of endocrine cells that synthesize and secrete several tropic and nontropic hormones.
Also called the adenohypophysis; portion of the pituitary that develops from nonneural tissue; consists of endocrine cells that synthesize and secrete several tropic and nontropic hormones.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anterior pituitary</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antidiuretic hormone (ADH)</span>"	A peptide hormone, also known as vasopressin, that promotes water retention by the kidneys. Produced in the hypothalamus and released from the posterior pituitary, [this] also has activities in the brain.
A peptide hormone, also known as vasopressin, that promotes water retention by the kidneys. Produced in the hypothalamus and released from the posterior pituitary, [this] also has activities in the brain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antidiuretic hormone (ADH)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autocrine</span>"	Referring to a secreted molecule that acts on the cell that secreted it.
Referring to a secreted molecule that acts on the cell that secreted it.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autocrine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biological clock</span>"	An internal timekeeper that controls an organism’s biological rhythms. [This] marks time with or without environmental cues but often requires signals from the environment to remain tuned to an appropriate period. See also circadian rhythm.
An internal timekeeper that controls an organism’s biological rhythms. [This] marks time with or without environmental cues but often requires signals from the environment to remain tuned to an appropriate period. See also circadian rhythm.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biological clock</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">calcitonin</span>"	A hormone secreted by the thyroid gland that lowers blood calcium levels by promoting calcium deposition in bone and calcium excretion from the kidneys; nonessential in adult humans.
A hormone secreted by the thyroid gland that lowers blood calcium levels by promoting calcium deposition in bone and calcium excretion from the kidneys; nonessential in adult humans.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">calcitonin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">catecholamine</span>"	Any of a class of neurotransmitters and hormones, including the hormones epinephrine and norepinephrine, that are synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine.
Any of a class of neurotransmitters and hormones, including the hormones epinephrine and norepinephrine, that are synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">catecholamine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">circadian rhythm</span>"	A physiological cycle of about 24 hours that is present in all eukaryotic organisms and that persists even in the absence of external cues.
A physiological cycle of about 24 hours that is present in all eukaryotic organisms and that persists even in the absence of external cues.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">circadian rhythm</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">corticosteroid</span>"	Any steroid hormone produced and secreted by the adrenal cortex.
Any steroid hormone produced and secreted by the adrenal cortex.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">corticosteroid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytokine</span>"	Any of a group of proteins secreted by a number of cell types, including macrophages and helper T cells, that regulate the function of lymphocytes and other cells of the immune system.
Any of a group of proteins secreted by a number of cell types, including macrophages and helper T cells, that regulate the function of lymphocytes and other cells of the immune system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytokine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecdysone</span>"	A steroid hormone, secreted by the prothoracic glands, that triggers molting in arthropods.
A steroid hormone, secreted by the prothoracic glands, that triggers molting in arthropods.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecdysone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endocrine gland</span>"	A ductless gland that secretes hormones directly into the interstitial fluid, from which they diffuse into the bloodstream.
A ductless gland that secretes hormones directly into the interstitial fluid, from which they diffuse into the bloodstream.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endocrine gland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endocrine system</span>"	The internal system of communication involving hormones, the ductless glands that secrete hormones, and the molecular receptors on or in target cells that respond to hormones; functions in concert with the nervous system to effect internal regulation and maintain homeostasis.
The internal system of communication involving hormones, the ductless glands that secrete hormones, and the molecular receptors on or in target cells that respond to hormones; functions in concert with the nervous system to effect internal regulation and maintain homeostasis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endocrine system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">estradiol</span>"	A steroid hormone that stimulates the development and maintenance of the female reproductive system and secondary sex characteristics; the major estrogen in mammals.
A steroid hormone that stimulates the development and maintenance of the female reproductive system and secondary sex characteristics; the major estrogen in mammals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">estradiol</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">estrogen</span>"	Any steroid hormone, such as estradiol, that stimulates the development and maintenance of the female reproductive system and secondary sex characteristics.
Any steroid hormone, such as estradiol, that stimulates the development and maintenance of the female reproductive system and secondary sex characteristics.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">estrogen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)</span>"	A tropic hormone that is produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary and that stimulates the production of eggs by the ovaries and sperm by the testes.
A tropic hormone that is produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary and that stimulates the production of eggs by the ovaries and sperm by the testes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G protein-coupled receptor</span>"	A signal receptor protein in the plasma membrane that responds to the binding of a signaling molecule by activating a G protein. Also called a G protein-linked receptor.
A signal receptor protein in the plasma membrane that responds to the binding of a signaling molecule by activating a G protein. Also called a G protein-linked receptor.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">G protein-coupled receptor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glucagon</span>"	A hormone secreted by pancreatic alpha cells that raises blood glucose levels. It promotes glycogen breakdown and release of glucose by the liver.
A hormone secreted by pancreatic alpha cells that raises blood glucose levels. It promotes glycogen breakdown and release of glucose by the liver.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glucagon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glucocorticoid</span>"	A steroid hormone that is secreted by the adrenal cortex and that influences glucose metabolism and immune function.
A steroid hormone that is secreted by the adrenal cortex and that influences glucose metabolism and immune function.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glucocorticoid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">growth hormone (GH)</span>"	A hormone that is produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary and that has both direct (nontropic) and tropic effects on a wide variety of tissues.
A hormone that is produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary and that has both direct (nontropic) and tropic effects on a wide variety of tissues.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">growth hormone (GH)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hormone</span>"	In multicellular organisms, one of many types of secreted chemicals that are formed in specialized cells, travel in body fluids, and act on specific target cells in other parts of the body to change their functioning.
In multicellular organisms, one of many types of secreted chemicals that are formed in specialized cells, travel in body fluids, and act on specific target cells in other parts of the body to change their functioning.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hormone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hypothalamus</span>"	The ventral part of the vertebrate forebrain; functions in maintaining homeostasis, especially in coordinating the endocrine and nervous systems; secretes hormones of the posterior pituitary and releasing factors that regulate the anterior pituitary.
The ventral part of the vertebrate forebrain; functions in maintaining homeostasis, especially in coordinating the endocrine and nervous systems; secretes hormones of the posterior pituitary and releasing factors that regulate the anterior pituitary.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hypothalamus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">islets of Langerhans</span>"	Clusters of endocrine cells within the pancreas that produce and secrete the hormones glucagon (from alpha cells) and insulin (from beta cells).
Clusters of endocrine cells within the pancreas that produce and secrete the hormones glucagon (from alpha cells) and insulin (from beta cells).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">islets of Langerhans</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">juvenile hormone</span>"	A hormone in arthropods, secreted by the corpora allata (a pair of glands), that promotes the retention of larval characteristics.
A hormone in arthropods, secreted by the corpora allata (a pair of glands), that promotes the retention of larval characteristics.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">juvenile hormone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH)</span>"	A hormone produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary that regulates the activity of pigment-containing cells in the skin of some vertebrates.
A hormone produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary that regulates the activity of pigment-containing cells in the skin of some vertebrates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">melatonin</span>"	A hormone secreted by the pineal gland that regulates body functions related to seasonal day length.
A hormone secreted by the pineal gland that regulates body functions related to seasonal day length.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">melatonin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mineralocorticoid</span>"	A steroid hormone secreted by the adrenal cortex that regulates salt and water homeostasis.
A steroid hormone secreted by the adrenal cortex that regulates salt and water homeostasis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mineralocorticoid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nervous system</span>"	The fast-acting internal system of communication involving sensory receptors, networks of nerve cells, and connections to muscles and glands that respond to nerve signals; functions in concert with the endocrine system to effect internal regulation and maintain homeostasis.
The fast-acting internal system of communication involving sensory receptors, networks of nerve cells, and connections to muscles and glands that respond to nerve signals; functions in concert with the endocrine system to effect internal regulation and maintain homeostasis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nervous system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neurohormone</span>"	A molecule that is secreted by a neuron, travels in body fluids, and acts on specific target cells to change their functioning.
A molecule that is secreted by a neuron, travels in body fluids, and acts on specific target cells to change their functioning.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neurohormone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oxytocin</span>"	A hormone produced by the hypothalamus and released from the posterior pituitary. It induces contractions of the uterine muscles during labor and causes the mammary glands to eject milk during nursing.
A hormone produced by the hypothalamus and released from the posterior pituitary. It induces contractions of the uterine muscles during labor and causes the mammary glands to eject milk during nursing.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oxytocin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pancreas</span>"	A gland with the following dual functions: The nonendocrine portion functions in digestion, secreting enzymes and an alkaline solution into the small intestine via a duct; the ductless endocrine portion functions in homeostasis, secreting the hormones insulin and glucagon into the blood.
A gland with the following dual functions: The nonendocrine portion functions in digestion, secreting enzymes and an alkaline solution into the small intestine via a duct; the ductless endocrine portion functions in homeostasis, secreting the hormones insulin and glucagon into the blood.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pancreas</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paracrine</span>"	Referring to a secreted molecule that acts on a neighboring cell.
Referring to a secreted molecule that acts on a neighboring cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paracrine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parathyroid gland</span>"	Any of four small endocrine glands, embedded in the surface of the thyroid gland, that secrete parathyroid hormone.
Any of four small endocrine glands, embedded in the surface of the thyroid gland, that secrete parathyroid hormone.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parathyroid gland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parathyroid hormone (PTH)</span>"	A hormone secreted by the parathyroid glands that raises blood calcium level by promoting calcium release from bone and calcium retention by the kidneys.
A hormone secreted by the parathyroid glands that raises blood calcium level by promoting calcium release from bone and calcium retention by the kidneys.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parathyroid hormone (PTH)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pheromone</span>"	In animals and fungi, a small molecule released into the environment that functions in communication between members of the same species. In animals, it acts much like a hormone in influencing physiology and behavior.
In animals and fungi, a small molecule released into the environment that functions in communication between members of the same species. In animals, it acts much like a hormone in influencing physiology and behavior.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pheromone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pineal gland</span>"	A small gland on the dorsal surface of the vertebrate forebrain that secretes the hormone melatonin.
A small gland on the dorsal surface of the vertebrate forebrain that secretes the hormone melatonin.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pineal gland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pituitary gland</span>"	An endocrine gland at the base of the hypothalamus; consists of a posterior lobe (neurohypophysis), which stores and releases two hormones produced by the hypothalamus, and an anterior lobe (adenohypophysis), which produces and secretes many hormones that regulate diverse body functions.
An endocrine gland at the base of the hypothalamus; consists of a posterior lobe (neurohypophysis), which stores and releases two hormones produced by the hypothalamus, and an anterior lobe (adenohypophysis), which produces and secretes many hormones that regulate diverse body functions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pituitary gland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">posterior pituitary</span>"	Also called the neurohypophysis; an extension of the hypothalamus composed of nervous tissue that secretes oxytocin and antidiuretic hormone made in the hypothalamus; a temporary storage site for these hormones.
Also called the neurohypophysis; an extension of the hypothalamus composed of nervous tissue that secretes oxytocin and antidiuretic hormone made in the hypothalamus; a temporary storage site for these hormones.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">posterior pituitary</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">progesterone</span>"	A steroid hormone that prepares the uterus for pregnancy; the major progestin in mammals.
A steroid hormone that prepares the uterus for pregnancy; the major progestin in mammals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">progesterone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prolactin (PRL)</span>"	A hormone produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary with a great diversity of effects in different vertebrate species. In mammals, it stimulates growth of and milk production by the mammary glands.
A hormone produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary with a great diversity of effects in different vertebrate species. In mammals, it stimulates growth of and milk production by the mammary glands.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prolactin (PRL)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prostaglandin (PG)</span>"	One of a group of modified fatty acids secreted by virtually all tissues and performing a wide variety of functions as local regulators.
One of a group of modified fatty acids secreted by virtually all tissues and performing a wide variety of functions as local regulators.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prostaglandin (PG)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prostate gland</span>"	A gland in human males that secretes an acid-neutralizing component of semen.
A gland in human males that secretes an acid-neutralizing component of semen.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">prostate gland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">semen</span>"	The fluid that is ejaculated by the male during orgasm; contains sperm and secretions from several glands of the male reproductive tract.
The fluid that is ejaculated by the male during orgasm; contains sperm and secretions from several glands of the male reproductive tract.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">semen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thyroid gland</span>"	An endocrine gland, located on the ventral surface of the trachea, that secretes two iodine-containing hormones, triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4), as well as calcitonin.
An endocrine gland, located on the ventral surface of the trachea, that secretes two iodine-containing hormones, triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4), as well as calcitonin.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thyroid gland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thyroxine (T4)</span>"	One of two iodine-containing hormones that are secreted by the thyroid gland and that help regulate metabolism, development, and maturation in vertebrates.
One of two iodine-containing hormones that are secreted by the thyroid gland and that help regulate metabolism, development, and maturation in vertebrates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thyroxine (T4)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">triiodothyronine (T3)</span>"	One of two iodine-containing hormones that are secreted by the thyroid gland and that help regulate metabolism, development, and maturation in vertebrates.
One of two iodine-containing hormones that are secreted by the thyroid gland and that help regulate metabolism, development, and maturation in vertebrates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">triiodothyronine (T3)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tropic hormone</span>"	A hormone that has another endocrine gland as a target.
A hormone that has another endocrine gland as a target.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tropic hormone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Alzheimer's disease</span>"	An age-related dementia (mental deterioration) characterized by confusion, memory loss, and other symptoms.
An age-related dementia (mental deterioration) characterized by confusion, memory loss, and other symptoms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Alzheimer's disease</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amygdala</span>"	A structure in the temporal lobe of the vertebrate brain that has a major role in the processing of emotions.
A structure in the temporal lobe of the vertebrate brain that has a major role in the processing of emotions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amygdala</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">astrocyte</span>"	A glial cell with diverse functions, including providing structural support for neurons, regulating the interstitial environment, facilitating synaptic transmission, and assisting in regulating the blood supply to the brain.
A glial cell with diverse functions, including providing structural support for neurons, regulating the interstitial environment, facilitating synaptic transmission, and assisting in regulating the blood supply to the brain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">astrocyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autonomic nervous system</span>"	An efferent branch of the vertebrate peripheral nervous system that regulates the internal environment; consists of the sympathetic, parasympathetic, and enteric divisions.
An efferent branch of the vertebrate peripheral nervous system that regulates the internal environment; consists of the sympathetic, parasympathetic, and enteric divisions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autonomic nervous system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bipolar disorder</span>"	Depressive mental illness characterized by swings of mood from high to low; also called manic-depressive disorder.
Depressive mental illness characterized by swings of mood from high to low; also called manic-depressive disorder.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bipolar disorder</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">blood-brain barrier</span>"	A specialized capillary arrangement in the brain that restricts the passage of most substances into the brain, thereby preventing dramatic fluctuations in the brain’s environment.
A specialized capillary arrangement in the brain that restricts the passage of most substances into the brain, thereby preventing dramatic fluctuations in the brain’s environment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">blood-brain barrier</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">brainstem</span>"	Collection of structures in the vertebrate brain, including the midbrain, the pons, and the medulla oblongata; functions in homeostasis, coordination of movement, and conduction of information to higher brain centers.
Collection of structures in the vertebrate brain, including the midbrain, the pons, and the medulla oblongata; functions in homeostasis, coordination of movement, and conduction of information to higher brain centers.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">brainstem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">central canal</span>"	The narrow cavity in the center of the spinal cord that is continuous with the fluid-filled ventricles of the brain.
The narrow cavity in the center of the spinal cord that is continuous with the fluid-filled ventricles of the brain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">central canal</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cephalization</span>"	An evolutionary trend toward the concentration of sensory equipment at the anterior end of the body.
An evolutionary trend toward the concentration of sensory equipment at the anterior end of the body.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cephalization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebellum</span>"	Part of the vertebrate hindbrain located dorsally; functions in unconscious coordination of movement and balance.
Part of the vertebrate hindbrain located dorsally; functions in unconscious coordination of movement and balance.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebellum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebral cortex</span>"	The surface of the cerebrum; the largest and most complex part of the mammalian brain, containing nerve cell bodies of the cerebrum; the part of the vertebrate brain most changed through evolution.
The surface of the cerebrum; the largest and most complex part of the mammalian brain, containing nerve cell bodies of the cerebrum; the part of the vertebrate brain most changed through evolution.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebral cortex</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebral hemisphere</span>"	The right or left side of the cerebrum.
The right or left side of the cerebrum.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebral hemisphere</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebrospinal fluid</span>"	Blood-derived fluid that surrounds, protects against infection, nourishes, and cushions the brain and spinal cord.
Blood-derived fluid that surrounds, protects against infection, nourishes, and cushions the brain and spinal cord.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebrospinal fluid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebrum</span>"	The dorsal portion of the vertebrate forebrain, composed of right and left hemispheres; the integrating center for memory, learning, emotions, and other highly complex functions of the central nervous system.
The dorsal portion of the vertebrate forebrain, composed of right and left hemispheres; the integrating center for memory, learning, emotions, and other highly complex functions of the central nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cerebrum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">corpus callosum</span>"	The thick band of nerve fibers that connects the right and left cerebral hemispheres in mammals, enabling the hemispheres to process information together.
The thick band of nerve fibers that connects the right and left cerebral hemispheres in mammals, enabling the hemispheres to process information together.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">corpus callosum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cranial nerve</span>"	A nerve that originates in the brain and terminates in an organ of the head or upper body.
A nerve that originates in the brain and terminates in an organ of the head or upper body.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cranial nerve</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">enteric division</span>"	Networks of neurons in the digestive tract, pancreas, and gallbladder; normally regulated by the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions of the autonomic nervous system.
Networks of neurons in the digestive tract, pancreas, and gallbladder; normally regulated by the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions of the autonomic nervous system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">enteric division</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">forebrain</span>"	One of three ancestral and embryonic regions of the vertebrate brain; develops into the thalamus, hypothalamus, and cerebrum.
One of three ancestral and embryonic regions of the vertebrate brain; develops into the thalamus, hypothalamus, and cerebrum.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">forebrain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gray matter</span>"	Regions of dendrites and clustered neuron cell bodies within the CNS.
Regions of dendrites and clustered neuron cell bodies within the CNS.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gray matter</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hindbrain</span>"	One of three ancestral and embryonic regions of the vertebrate brain; develops into the medulla oblongata, pons, and cerebellum.
One of three ancestral and embryonic regions of the vertebrate brain; develops into the medulla oblongata, pons, and cerebellum.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hindbrain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lateralization</span>"	Segregation of functions in the cortex of the left and right hemispheres of the brain.
Segregation of functions in the cortex of the left and right hemispheres of the brain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lateralization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">long-term memory</span>"	The ability to hold, associate, and recall information over one’s lifetime.
The ability to hold, associate, and recall information over one’s lifetime.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">long-term memory</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">long-term potentiation (LTP)</span>"	An enhanced responsiveness to an action potential (nerve signal) by a receiving neuron.
An enhanced responsiveness to an action potential (nerve signal) by a receiving neuron.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">long-term potentiation (LTP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">major depressive disorder</span>"	A mood disorder characterized by feelings of sadness, lack of self-worth, emptiness, or loss of interest in nearly all things.
A mood disorder characterized by feelings of sadness, lack of self-worth, emptiness, or loss of interest in nearly all things.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">major depressive disorder</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">medulla oblongata</span>"	The lowest part of the vertebrate brain, commonly called the medulla; a swelling of the hindbrain anterior to the spinal cord that controls autonomic, homeostatic functions, including breathing, heart and blood vessel activity, swallowing, digestion, and vomiting.
The lowest part of the vertebrate brain, commonly called the medulla; a swelling of the hindbrain anterior to the spinal cord that controls autonomic, homeostatic functions, including breathing, heart and blood vessel activity, swallowing, digestion, and vomiting.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">medulla oblongata</span>"
