"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">midbrain</span>"	One of three ancestral and embryonic regions of the vertebrate brain; develops into sensory integrating and relay centers that send sensory information to the cerebrum.
One of three ancestral and embryonic regions of the vertebrate brain; develops into sensory integrating and relay centers that send sensory information to the cerebrum.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">midbrain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">motor system</span>"	An efferent branch of the vertebrate peripheral nervous system composed of motor neurons that carry signals to skeletal muscles in response to external stimuli.
An efferent branch of the vertebrate peripheral nervous system composed of motor neurons that carry signals to skeletal muscles in response to external stimuli.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">motor system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nerve</span>"	A ropelike bundle of neuron fibers (axons) tightly wrapped in connective tissue.
A ropelike bundle of neuron fibers (axons) tightly wrapped in connective tissue.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nerve</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nerve net</span>"	A weblike system of neurons, characteristic of radially symmetrical animals, such as hydra.
A weblike system of neurons, characteristic of radially symmetrical animals, such as hydra.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nerve net</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neural plasticity</span>"	The capacity of a nervous system to change with experience.
The capacity of a nervous system to change with experience.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neural plasticity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parasympathetic division</span>"	One of three divisions of the autonomic nervous system; generally enhances body activities that gain and conserve energy, such as digestion and reduced heart rate.
One of three divisions of the autonomic nervous system; generally enhances body activities that gain and conserve energy, such as digestion and reduced heart rate.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parasympathetic division</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pons</span>"	Portion of the brain that participates in certain automatic, homeostatic functions, such as regulating the breathing centers in the medulla.
Portion of the brain that participates in certain automatic, homeostatic functions, such as regulating the breathing centers in the medulla.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pons</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radial glia</span>"	In an embryo, supporting cells that form tracks along which newly formed neurons migrate from the neural tube; can also act as stem cells that give rise to other glia and neurons.
In an embryo, supporting cells that form tracks along which newly formed neurons migrate from the neural tube; can also act as stem cells that give rise to other glia and neurons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radial glia</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reflex</span>"	An automatic reaction to a stimulus, mediated by the spinal cord or lower brain.
An automatic reaction to a stimulus, mediated by the spinal cord or lower brain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reflex</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reticular formation</span>"	A diffuse network of neurons in the core of the brainstem that filters information traveling to the cerebral cortex.
A diffuse network of neurons in the core of the brainstem that filters information traveling to the cerebral cortex.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reticular formation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">schizophrenia</span>"	Severe mental disturbance characterized by psychotic episodes in which patients lose the ability to distinguish reality from hallucination.
Severe mental disturbance characterized by psychotic episodes in which patients lose the ability to distinguish reality from hallucination.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">schizophrenia</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">short-term memory</span>"	The ability to hold information, anticipations, or goals for a time and then release them if they become irrelevant.
The ability to hold information, anticipations, or goals for a time and then release them if they become irrelevant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">short-term memory</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spinal nerve</span>"	In the vertebrate peripheral nervous system, a nerve that carries signals to or from the spinal cord.
In the vertebrate peripheral nervous system, a nerve that carries signals to or from the spinal cord.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spinal nerve</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN)</span>"	A group of neurons in the hypothalamus of mammals that functions as a biological clock.
A group of neurons in the hypothalamus of mammals that functions as a biological clock.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sympathetic division</span>"	One of three divisions of the autonomic nervous system of vertebrates; generally increases energy expenditure and prepares the body for action.
One of three divisions of the autonomic nervous system of vertebrates; generally increases energy expenditure and prepares the body for action.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sympathetic division</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thalamus</span>"	One of two integrating centers of the vertebrate forebrain. Neurons with cell bodies in the [this] relay neural input to specific areas in the cerebral cortex and regulate what information goes to the cerebral cortex.
One of two integrating centers of the vertebrate forebrain. Neurons with cell bodies in the [this] relay neural input to specific areas in the cerebral cortex and regulate what information goes to the cerebral cortex.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thalamus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">twin study</span>"	A behavioral study in which researchers compare the behavior of identical twins raised apart with that of identical twins raised in the same household.
A behavioral study in which researchers compare the behavior of identical twins raised apart with that of identical twins raised in the same household.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">twin study</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ventricle</span>"	(1) A heart chamber that pumps blood out of the heart. (2) A space in the vertebrate brain, filled with cerebrospinal fluid.
(1) A heart chamber that pumps blood out of the heart. (2) A space in the vertebrate brain, filled with cerebrospinal fluid.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ventricle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">white matter</span>"	Tracts of axons within the CNS.
Tracts of axons within the CNS.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">white matter</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acquired immunity</span>"	A vertebrate-specific defense that is mediated by B lymphocytes (B cells) and T lymphocytes (T cells). It exhibits specificity, memory, and self-nonself recognition. Also called adaptive immunity.
A vertebrate-specific defense that is mediated by B lymphocytes (B cells) and T lymphocytes (T cells). It exhibits specificity, memory, and self-nonself recognition. Also called adaptive immunity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">acquired immunity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">active immunity</span>"	Long-lasting immunity conferred by the action of B cells and T cells and the resulting B and T memory cells specific for a pathogen. [This] can develop as a result of natural infection or immunization.
Long-lasting immunity conferred by the action of B cells and T cells and the resulting B and T memory cells specific for a pathogen. [This] can develop as a result of natural infection or immunization.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">active immunity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antibody</span>"	A protein secreted by plasma cells (differentiated B cells) that binds to a particular antigen; also called immunoglobulin. All [this] molecules have the same Y-shaped structure and in their monomer form consist of two identical heavy chains and two identical light chains.
A protein secreted by plasma cells (differentiated B cells) that binds to a particular antigen; also called immunoglobulin. All [this] molecules have the same Y-shaped structure and in their monomer form consist of two identical heavy chains and two identical light chains.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antibody</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antigen</span>"	A macromolecule that elicits an immune response by binding to receptors of B cells or T cells
A macromolecule that elicits an immune response by binding to receptors of B cells or T cells	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antigen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antigen presentation</span>"	The process by which an MHC molecule binds to a fragment of an intracellular protein antigen and carries it to the cell surface, where it is displayed and can be recognized by a T cell.
The process by which an MHC molecule binds to a fragment of an intracellular protein antigen and carries it to the cell surface, where it is displayed and can be recognized by a T cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antigen presentation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antigen receptor</span>"	The general term for a surface protein, located on B cells and T cells, that binds to antigens, initiating acquired immune responses. The [these] on B cells are called B cell receptors, and the [these] on T cells are called T cell receptors.
The general term for a surface protein, located on B cells and T cells, that binds to antigens, initiating acquired immune responses. The [these] on B cells are called B cell receptors, and the [these] on T cells are called T cell receptors.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antigen receptor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antigen-presenting cell</span>"	A cell that upon ingesting pathogens or internalizing pathogen proteins generates peptide fragments that are bound by class II MHC molecules and subsequently displayed on the cell surface to T cells. Macrophages, dendritic cells, and B cells are the primary [these].
A cell that upon ingesting pathogens or internalizing pathogen proteins generates peptide fragments that are bound by class II MHC molecules and subsequently displayed on the cell surface to T cells. Macrophages, dendritic cells, and B cells are the primary [these].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antigen-presenting cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autoimmune disease</span>"	An immunological disorder in which the immune system turns against self.
An immunological disorder in which the immune system turns against self.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">autoimmune disease</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">B cell receptor</span>"	The antigen receptor on B cells: a Y-shaped, membrane-bound molecule consisting of two identical heavy chains and two identical light chains linked by disulfide bridges and containing two antigen-binding sites.
The antigen receptor on B cells: a Y-shaped, membrane-bound molecule consisting of two identical heavy chains and two identical light chains linked by disulfide bridges and containing two antigen-binding sites.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">B cell receptor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">B cells</span>"	The lymphocytes that complete their development in the bone marrow and become effector cells for the humoral immune response.
The lymphocytes that complete their development in the bone marrow and become effector cells for the humoral immune response.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">B cells</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">CD4</span>"	A surface protein, present on most helper T cells, that binds to class II MHC molecules, enhancing the interaction between the T cell and an antigen-presenting cell.
A surface protein, present on most helper T cells, that binds to class II MHC molecules, enhancing the interaction between the T cell and an antigen-presenting cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">CD4</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">CD8</span>"	A surface protein, present on most cytotoxic T cells, that binds to class I MHC molecules, enhancing the interaction between the T cell and a target cell.
A surface protein, present on most cytotoxic T cells, that binds to class I MHC molecules, enhancing the interaction between the T cell and a target cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">CD8</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell-mediated immune response</span>"	The branch of acquired immunity that involves the activation of cytotoxic T cells, which defend against infected cells.
The branch of acquired immunity that involves the activation of cytotoxic T cells, which defend against infected cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cell-mediated immune response</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">class I MHC molecule</span>"	A type of MHC molecule found on the surface of nearly all nucleated cells and that functions in identification of infected cells by cytotoxic T ells.
A type of MHC molecule found on the surface of nearly all nucleated cells and that functions in identification of infected cells by cytotoxic T ells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">class I MHC molecule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">class II MHC molecule</span>"	A type of MHC molecule restricted to a few specialized immune cell types (dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells) that serve as antigen-presenting cells.
A type of MHC molecule restricted to a few specialized immune cell types (dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells) that serve as antigen-presenting cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">class II MHC molecule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">clonal selection</span>"	The process by which an antigen selectively binds to and activates only those lymphocytes bearing receptors specific for the antigen. The selected lymphocytes proliferate and differentiate into a clone of effector cells and a clone of memory cells specific for the stimulating antigen.
The process by which an antigen selectively binds to and activates only those lymphocytes bearing receptors specific for the antigen. The selected lymphocytes proliferate and differentiate into a clone of effector cells and a clone of memory cells specific for the stimulating antigen.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">clonal selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">complement system</span>"	A group of about 30 blood proteins that may amplify the inflammatory response, enhance phagocytosis, or directly lyse extracellular pathogens.
A group of about 30 blood proteins that may amplify the inflammatory response, enhance phagocytosis, or directly lyse extracellular pathogens.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">complement system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytokine<br></span>"	Any of a group of proteins secreted by a number of cell types, including macrophages and helper T cells, that regulate the function of lymphocytes and other cells of the immune system.
Any of a group of proteins secreted by a number of cell types, including macrophages and helper T cells, that regulate the function of lymphocytes and other cells of the immune system.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytokine<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytotoxic T cell</span>"	A type of lymphocyte that, when activated, kills infected cells as well as certain cancer cells and transplanted cells.
A type of lymphocyte that, when activated, kills infected cells as well as certain cancer cells and transplanted cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cytotoxic T cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dendritic cell</span>"	An antigen-presenting cell, located mainly in lymphatic tissues and skin, that is particularly efficient in presenting antigens to helper T cells, thereby initiating a primary immune response.
An antigen-presenting cell, located mainly in lymphatic tissues and skin, that is particularly efficient in presenting antigens to helper T cells, thereby initiating a primary immune response.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dendritic cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">effector cell</span>"	(1) A muscle cell or gland cell that performs the body’s response to stimuli as directed by signals from the brain or other processing center of the nervous system. (2) A lymphocyte that has undergone clonal selection and is capable of mediating an acquired immune response.
(1) A muscle cell or gland cell that performs the body’s response to stimuli as directed by signals from the brain or other processing center of the nervous system. (2) A lymphocyte that has undergone clonal selection and is capable of mediating an acquired immune response.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">effector cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eosinophil</span>"	A type of white blood cell with low phagocytic activity that is thought to play a role in defense against parasitic worms by releasing enzymes toxic to these invaders.
A type of white blood cell with low phagocytic activity that is thought to play a role in defense against parasitic worms by releasing enzymes toxic to these invaders.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eosinophil</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epitope</span>"	A small, accessible region of an antigen to which an antigen receptor or antibody binds; also called an antigenic determinant.
A small, accessible region of an antigen to which an antigen receptor or antibody binds; also called an antigenic determinant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epitope</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heavy chain</span>"	One of the two types of polypeptide chains that make up an antibody molecule and B cell receptor; consists of a variable region, which contributes to the antigen-binding site, and a constant region.
One of the two types of polypeptide chains that make up an antibody molecule and B cell receptor; consists of a variable region, which contributes to the antigen-binding site, and a constant region.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heavy chain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">helper T cell</span>"	A type of T cell that, when activated, secretes cytokines that promote the response of B cells (humoral response) and cytotoxic T cells (cell-mediated response) to antigens.
A type of T cell that, when activated, secretes cytokines that promote the response of B cells (humoral response) and cytotoxic T cells (cell-mediated response) to antigens.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">helper T cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">histamine</span>"	A substance released by mast cells that causes blood vessels to dilate and become more permeable in inflammatory and allergic responses.
A substance released by mast cells that causes blood vessels to dilate and become more permeable in inflammatory and allergic responses.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">histamine</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)</span>"	A hormone secreted by the chorion that maintains the corpus luteum of the ovary during the first three months of pregnancy.
A hormone secreted by the chorion that maintains the corpus luteum of the ovary during the first three months of pregnancy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">humoral immune response</span>"	The branch of acquired immunity that involves the activation of B cells and that leads to the production of antibodies, which defend against bacteria and viruses in body fluids.
The branch of acquired immunity that involves the activation of B cells and that leads to the production of antibodies, which defend against bacteria and viruses in body fluids.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">humoral immune response</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immune system</span>"	An animal body’s system of defenses against agents that cause disease.
An animal body’s system of defenses against agents that cause disease.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immune system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immunization</span>"	The process of generating a state of immunity by artificial means. In active [this], also called vaccination, an inactive or weakened form of a pathogen is administered, inducing B and T cell responses and immunological memory. In passive [this], antibodies specific for a particular microbe are administered, conferring immediate but temporary protection.
The process of generating a state of immunity by artificial means. In active [this], also called vaccination, an inactive or weakened form of a pathogen is administered, inducing B and T cell responses and immunological memory. In passive [this], antibodies specific for a particular microbe are administered, conferring immediate but temporary protection.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immunization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immunodeficiency</span>"	A disorder in which the ability of an immune system to protect against pathogens is defective or absent.
A disorder in which the ability of an immune system to protect against pathogens is defective or absent.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immunodeficiency</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immunoglobulin (Ig)</span>"	Any of the class of proteins that function as antibodies. [These] are divided into five major classes that differ in their distribution in the body and antigen disposal activities.
Any of the class of proteins that function as antibodies. [These] are divided into five major classes that differ in their distribution in the body and antigen disposal activities.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immunoglobulin (Ig)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inflammatory response</span>"	An innate immune defense triggered by physical injury or infection of tissue involving the release of substances that promote swelling, enhance the infiltration of white blood cells, and aid in tissue repair and destruction of invading pathogens.
An innate immune defense triggered by physical injury or infection of tissue involving the release of substances that promote swelling, enhance the infiltration of white blood cells, and aid in tissue repair and destruction of invading pathogens.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inflammatory response</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">innate immunity</span>"	A form of defense common to all animals that is active immediately upon exposure to pathogens and that is the same whether or not the pathogen has been encountered previously.
A form of defense common to all animals that is active immediately upon exposure to pathogens and that is the same whether or not the pathogen has been encountered previously.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">innate immunity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interferon</span>"	A protein that has antiviral or immune regulatory functions. [This]-α and [this]-β, secreted by virus-infected cells, help nearby cells resist viral infection; [this]-γ, secreted by T cells, helps activate macrophages.
A protein that has antiviral or immune regulatory functions. [This]-α and [this]-β, secreted by virus-infected cells, help nearby cells resist viral infection; [this]-γ, secreted by T cells, helps activate macrophages.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interferon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">light chain</span>"	One of the two types of polypeptide chains that make up an antibody molecule and B cell receptor; consists of a variable region, which contributes to the antigen-binding site, and a constant region.
One of the two types of polypeptide chains that make up an antibody molecule and B cell receptor; consists of a variable region, which contributes to the antigen-binding site, and a constant region.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">light chain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lymphocyte</span>"	A type of white blood cell that mediates acquired immunity. The two main classes are B cells and T cells.
A type of white blood cell that mediates acquired immunity. The two main classes are B cells and T cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lymphocyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">macrophage</span>"	A phagocytic cell present in many tissues that functions in innate immunity by destroying microbes and in acquired immunity as an antigen-presenting cell.
A phagocytic cell present in many tissues that functions in innate immunity by destroying microbes and in acquired immunity as an antigen-presenting cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">macrophage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">major histocompatibility complex (MHC)</span>"	A family of genes that encode a large set of cell-surface proteins that function in antigen presentation. Foreign [this] molecules on transplanted tissue can trigger T cell responses that may lead to rejection of the transplant.
A family of genes that encode a large set of cell-surface proteins that function in antigen presentation. Foreign [this] molecules on transplanted tissue can trigger T cell responses that may lead to rejection of the transplant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">major histocompatibility complex (MHC)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mast cell</span>"	A vertebrate body cell that produces histamine and other molecules that trigger inflammation in response to infection and in allergic reactions.
A vertebrate body cell that produces histamine and other molecules that trigger inflammation in response to infection and in allergic reactions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mast cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">memory cell</span>"	One of a clone of long-lived lymphocytes, formed during the primary immune response, that remains in a lymphoid organ until activated by exposure to the same antigen that triggered its formation. Activated [these] mount the secondary immune response.
One of a clone of long-lived lymphocytes, formed during the primary immune response, that remains in a lymphoid organ until activated by exposure to the same antigen that triggered its formation. Activated [these] mount the secondary immune response.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">memory cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monoclonal antibody</span>"	Any of a preparation of antibodies that have been produced by a single clone of cultured cells and thus are all specific for the same epitope.
Any of a preparation of antibodies that have been produced by a single clone of cultured cells and thus are all specific for the same epitope.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monoclonal antibody</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">natural killer (NK) cell</span>"	A type of white blood cell that can kill tumor cells and virus-infected cells as part of innate immunity.
A type of white blood cell that can kill tumor cells and virus-infected cells as part of innate immunity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">natural killer (NK) cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neutrophil</span>"	The most abundant type of white blood cell. [These] are phagocytic and tend to self-destruct as they destroy foreign invaders, limiting their life span to a few days.
The most abundant type of white blood cell. [These] are phagocytic and tend to self-destruct as they destroy foreign invaders, limiting their life span to a few days.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neutrophil</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">passive immunity</span>"	Short-term immunity conferred by the transfer of antibodies, as occurs in the transfer of maternal antibodies to a fetus or nursing infant.
Short-term immunity conferred by the transfer of antibodies, as occurs in the transfer of maternal antibodies to a fetus or nursing infant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">passive immunity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pathogen</span>"	An organism or virus that causes disease.
An organism or virus that causes disease.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pathogen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasma cell</span>"	The antibody-secreting effector cell of humoral immunity; arises from antigen-stimulated B cells.
The antibody-secreting effector cell of humoral immunity; arises from antigen-stimulated B cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasma cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary immune response</span>"	The initial acquired immune response to an antigen, which appears after a lag of about 10 to 17 days.
The initial acquired immune response to an antigen, which appears after a lag of about 10 to 17 days.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary immune response</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary immune response</span>"	The acquired immune response elicited on second or subsequent exposures to a particular antigen. The [this] is more rapid, of greater magnitude, and of longer duration than the primary immune response.
The acquired immune response elicited on second or subsequent exposures to a particular antigen. The [this] is more rapid, of greater magnitude, and of longer duration than the primary immune response.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary immune response</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">T cells</span>"	The class of lymphocytes that mature in the thymus and that includes both effector cells for the cell-mediated immune response and helper cells required for both branches of adaptive immunity.
The class of lymphocytes that mature in the thymus and that includes both effector cells for the cell-mediated immune response and helper cells required for both branches of adaptive immunity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">T cells</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">T cell receptor</span>"	The antigen receptor on T cells; a membrane-bound molecule consisting of one α chain and one β chain linked by a disulfide bridge and containing one antigen-binding site.
The antigen receptor on T cells; a membrane-bound molecule consisting of one α chain and one β chain linked by a disulfide bridge and containing one antigen-binding site.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">T cell receptor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thymus</span>"	A small organ in the thoracic cavity of vertebrates where maturation of T cells is completed.
A small organ in the thoracic cavity of vertebrates where maturation of T cells is completed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thymus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Toll-like receptor (TLR)</span>"	A membrane receptor on a phagocytic white blood cell that recognizes fragments of molecules common to a set of pathogens.
A membrane receptor on a phagocytic white blood cell that recognizes fragments of molecules common to a set of pathogens.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Toll-like receptor (TLR)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">afferent arteriole</span>"	In the kidney, the blood vessel supplying a nephron.
In the kidney, the blood vessel supplying a nephron.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">afferent arteriole</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aldosterone</span>"	A steroid hormone that acts on tubules of the kidney to regulate the transport of sodium ions (Na+) and potassium ions (K+).
A steroid hormone that acts on tubules of the kidney to regulate the transport of sodium ions (Na+) and potassium ions (K+).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aldosterone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">angiotensin II</span>"	A peptide hormone that stimulates constriction of precapillary arterioles and increases reabsorption of NaCl and water by the proximal tubules of the kidney, increasing blood pressure and volume.
A peptide hormone that stimulates constriction of precapillary arterioles and increases reabsorption of NaCl and water by the proximal tubules of the kidney, increasing blood pressure and volume.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">angiotensin II</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anhydrobiosis</span>"	A dormant state involving loss of almost all body water.
A dormant state involving loss of almost all body water.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">anhydrobiosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)</span>"	A peptide hormone secreted by cells of the atria of the heart in response to high blood pressure. [This]’s effects on the kidney alter ion and water movement and thereby reduce blood pressure.
A peptide hormone secreted by cells of the atria of the heart in response to high blood pressure. [This]’s effects on the kidney alter ion and water movement and thereby reduce blood pressure.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Bowman’s capsule</span>"	A cup-shaped receptacle in the vertebrate kidney that is the initial, expanded segment of the nephron where filtrate enters from the blood.
A cup-shaped receptacle in the vertebrate kidney that is the initial, expanded segment of the nephron where filtrate enters from the blood.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Bowman’s capsule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">collecting duct</span>"	The location in the kidney where processed filtrate, called urine, is collected from the renal tubules.
The location in the kidney where processed filtrate, called urine, is collected from the renal tubules.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">collecting duct</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cortical nephron</span>"	In mammals and birds, a nephron with a loop of Henle located almost entirely in the renal cortex.
In mammals and birds, a nephron with a loop of Henle located almost entirely in the renal cortex.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cortical nephron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">countercurrent multiplier system</span>"	A countercurrent system in which energy is expended in active transport to facilitate exchange of materials and generate concentration gradients.
A countercurrent system in which energy is expended in active transport to facilitate exchange of materials and generate concentration gradients.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">countercurrent multiplier system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">distal tubule</span>"	In the vertebrate kidney, the portion of a nephron that helps refine filtrate and empties it into a collecting duct.
In the vertebrate kidney, the portion of a nephron that helps refine filtrate and empties it into a collecting duct.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">distal tubule</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">euryhaline</span>"	Referring to organisms that tolerate substantial changes in external osmolarity.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">glomerulus</span>"	A ball of capillaries surrounded by Bowman’s capsule in the nephron and serving as the site of filtration in the vertebrate kidney.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA)</span>"	A specialized tissue in nephrons that releases the enzyme renin in response to a drop in blood pressure or volume.
A specialized tissue in nephrons that releases the enzyme renin in response to a drop in blood pressure or volume.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">juxtamedullary nephron</span>"	In mammals and birds, a nephron with a loop of Henle that extends far into the renal medulla.
In mammals and birds, a nephron with a loop of Henle that extends far into the renal medulla.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">juxtamedullary nephron</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">loop of Henle</span>"	The hairpin turn, with a descending and ascending limb, between the proximal and distal tubules of the vertebrate kidney; functions in water and salt reabsorption.
The hairpin turn, with a descending and ascending limb, between the proximal and distal tubules of the vertebrate kidney; functions in water and salt reabsorption.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">loop of Henle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Malpighian tubule</span>"	A unique excretory organ of insects that empties into the digestive tract, removes nitrogenous wastes from the hemolymph, and functions in osmoregulation.
A unique excretory organ of insects that empties into the digestive tract, removes nitrogenous wastes from the hemolymph, and functions in osmoregulation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Malpighian tubule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metanephridium</span>"	An excretory organ found in many invertebrates that typically consists of tubules connecting ciliated internal openings to external openings.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">countercurrent exchange</span>"	The exchange of a substance or heat between two fluids flowing in opposite directions. For example, blood in a fish gill flows in the opposite direction of water passing over the gill, maximizing diffusion of oxygen into and carbon dioxide out of the blood.
The exchange of a substance or heat between two fluids flowing in opposite directions. For example, blood in a fish gill flows in the opposite direction of water passing over the gill, maximizing diffusion of oxygen into and carbon dioxide out of the blood. "<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ectothermic</span>"	Referring to organisms for which external sources provide most of the heat for temperature regulation.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endothermic</span>"	Referring to organisms with bodies that are warmed by heat generated by metabolism. This heat is usually used to maintain a relatively stable body temperature higher than that of the external environment.
Referring to organisms with bodies that are warmed by heat generated by metabolism. This heat is usually used to maintain a relatively stable body temperature higher than that of the external environment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endothermic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epidermis</span>"	(1) The dermal tissue system of nonwoody plants, usually consisting of a single layer of tightly packed cells. (2) The outermost layer of cells in an animal.
(1) The dermal tissue system of nonwoody plants, usually consisting of a single layer of tightly packed cells. (2) The outermost layer of cells in an animal.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epidermis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epithelial tissue</span>"	Sheets of tightly packed cells that line organs and body cavities as well as external surfaces.
Sheets of tightly packed cells that line organs and body cavities as well as external surfaces.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">epithelial tissue</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fibroblast</span>"	A type of cell in loose connective tissue that secretes the protein ingredients of the extracellular fibers.
A type of cell in loose connective tissue that secretes the protein ingredients of the extracellular fibers.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fibroblast</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hibernation</span>"	A physiological state in which metabolism decreases, the heart and respiratory system slow down, and body temperature is maintained at a lower level than normal.
A physiological state in which metabolism decreases, the heart and respiratory system slow down, and body temperature is maintained at a lower level than normal.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hibernation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homeostasis</span>"	The steady-state physiological condition of the body.
The steady-state physiological condition of the body.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homeostasis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">integumentary system</span>"	The outer covering of a mammal’s body, including skin, hair, and nails.
The outer covering of a mammal’s body, including skin, hair, and nails.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">integumentary system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ligament</span>"	A fibrous connective tissue that joins bones together at joints.
A fibrous connective tissue that joins bones together at joints.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ligament</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metabolic rate</span>"	The total amount of energy an animal uses in a unit of time.
The total amount of energy an animal uses in a unit of time.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metabolic rate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">muscle tissue</span>"	Tissue consisting of long muscle cells that can contract, either on its own or when stimulated by nerve impulses.
Tissue consisting of long muscle cells that can contract, either on its own or when stimulated by nerve impulses.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">muscle tissue</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">normal range</span>"	An upper and lower limit of a variable.
An upper and lower limit of a variable.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">normal range</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organ</span>"	A specialized center of body function composed of several different types of tissues.
A specialized center of body function composed of several different types of tissues.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organ</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organ system</span>"	A group of organs that work together in performing vital body functions.
A group of organs that work together in performing vital body functions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organ system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">physiology</span>"	The processes and functions of an organism and their study.
The processes and functions of an organism and their study.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">physiology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">regulator</span>"	An animal for which mechanisms of homeostasis moderate internal changes in the face of external fluctuations.
An animal for which mechanisms of homeostasis moderate internal changes in the face of external fluctuations.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">regulator</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">response</span>"	(1) In cellular communication, the change in a specific cellular activity brought about by a transduced signal from outside the cell. (2) In homeostasis, a physiological activity that helps return a variable to a set point.
(1) In cellular communication, the change in a specific cellular activity brought about by a transduced signal from outside the cell. (2) In homeostasis, a physiological activity that helps return a variable to a set point.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">response</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sensor</span>"	In homeostasis, a receptor that detects a stimulus.
In homeostasis, a receptor that detects a stimulus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sensor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">set point</span>"	In animal bodies, a value maintained for a particular variable, such as body temperature or solute concentration, to achieve homeostasis.
In animal bodies, a value maintained for a particular variable, such as body temperature or solute concentration, to achieve homeostasis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">set point</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">standard metabolic rate (SMR)</span>"	The metabolic rate of a resting, fasting, and nonstressed ectotherm at a particular temperature.
The metabolic rate of a resting, fasting, and nonstressed ectotherm at a particular temperature.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">standard metabolic rate (SMR)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stimulus</span>"	In homeostasis, a fluctuation in a variable that triggers a return to a set point.
In homeostasis, a fluctuation in a variable that triggers a return to a set point.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stimulus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tendon</span>"	A fibrous connective tissue that attaches muscle to bone.
A fibrous connective tissue that attaches muscle to bone.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tendon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thermoregulation</span>"	The maintenance of internal body temperature within a tolerable range.
The maintenance of internal body temperature within a tolerable range.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thermoregulation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tissue</span>"	An integrated group of cells with a common function, structure, or both.
An integrated group of cells with a common function, structure, or both.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tissue</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">torpor</span>"	A physiological state in which activity is low and metabolism decreases.
A physiological state in which activity is low and metabolism decreases.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">torpor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vasoconstriction</span>"	A decrease in the diameter of blood vessels caused by contraction of smooth muscles in the vessel walls.
A decrease in the diameter of blood vessels caused by contraction of smooth muscles in the vessel walls.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vasoconstriction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vasodilation</span>"	An increase in the diameter of blood vessels caused by relaxation of smooth muscles in the vessel walls.
An increase in the diameter of blood vessels caused by relaxation of smooth muscles in the vessel walls.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vasodilation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">agonistic behavior</span>"	In animals, an often ritualized contest that determines which competitor gains access to a resource, such as food or mates.
In animals, an often ritualized contest that determines which competitor gains access to a resource, such as food or mates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">agonistic behavior</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">altruism</span>"	Selflessness; behavior that reduces an individual’s fitness while increasing the fitness of another individual.
Selflessness; behavior that reduces an individual’s fitness while increasing the fitness of another individual.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">altruism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">associative learning</span>"	The acquired ability to associate one environmental feature (such as a color) with another (such as danger).
The acquired ability to associate one environmental feature (such as a color) with another (such as danger).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">associative learning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">behavior</span>"	(in animals) Individually, an action carried out by muscles or glands under control of the nervous system in response to a stimulus; collectively, the sum of an animal’s responses to external and internal stimuli.
(in animals) Individually, an action carried out by muscles or glands under control of the nervous system in response to a stimulus; collectively, the sum of an animal’s responses to external and internal stimuli.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">behavior</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">behavioral ecology</span>"	The study of the evolution of and ecological basis for animal behavior.
The study of the evolution of and ecological basis for animal behavior.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">behavioral ecology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">classical conditioning</span>"	A type of associative learning in which an arbitrary stimulus becomes associated with a particular outcome.
A type of associative learning in which an arbitrary stimulus becomes associated with a particular outcome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">classical conditioning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">coefficient of relatedness</span>"	The fraction of genes that, on average, are shared by two individuals.
The fraction of genes that, on average, are shared by two individuals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">coefficient of relatedness</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cognition</span>"	The process of knowing that may include awareness, reasoning, recollection, and judgment.
The process of knowing that may include awareness, reasoning, recollection, and judgment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cognition</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cognitive map</span>"	A neural representation of the abstract spatial relationships between objects in an animal’s surroundings.
A neural representation of the abstract spatial relationships between objects in an animal’s surroundings.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cognitive map</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">communication</span>"	In animal behavior, a process involving transmission of, reception of, and response to signals. The term is also used in connection with other organisms, as well as individual cells of multicellular organisms.
In animal behavior, a process involving transmission of, reception of, and response to signals. The term is also used in connection with other organisms, as well as individual cells of multicellular organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">communication</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cross-fostering study</span>"	A behavioral study in which the young of one species are placed in the care of adults from another species.
A behavioral study in which the young of one species are placed in the care of adults from another species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cross-fostering study</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">culture</span>"	A system of information transfer through social learning or teaching that influences the behavior of individuals in a population.
A system of information transfer through social learning or teaching that influences the behavior of individuals in a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">culture</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecology</span>"	The study of how organisms interact with each other and their environment.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ethology</span>"	The scientific study of how animals behave, particularly in their natural environments.
The scientific study of how animals behave, particularly in their natural environments.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ethology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fixed action pattern</span>"	In animal behavior, a sequence of unlearned acts that is essentially unchangeable and, once initiated, usually carried to completion.
In animal behavior, a sequence of unlearned acts that is essentially unchangeable and, once initiated, usually carried to completion.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fixed action pattern</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">foraging</span>"	The seeking and obtaining of food.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">game theory</span>"	An approach to evaluating alternative strategies in situations where the outcome of a particular strategy depends on the strategies used by other individuals.
An approach to evaluating alternative strategies in situations where the outcome of a particular strategy depends on the strategies used by other individuals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">game theory</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">habituation</span>"	A simple type of learning that involves a loss of responsiveness to stimuli that convey little or no new information.
A simple type of learning that involves a loss of responsiveness to stimuli that convey little or no new information.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">habituation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Hamilton’s rule</span>"	The principle that for natural selection to favor an altruistic act, the benefit to the recipient, devalued by the coefficient of relatedness, must exceed the cost to the altruist.
The principle that for natural selection to favor an altruistic act, the benefit to the recipient, devalued by the coefficient of relatedness, must exceed the cost to the altruist.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Hamilton’s rule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">imprinting</span>"	In animal behavior, the formation at a specific stage in life of a long-lasting behavioral response to a specific individual or object. (See also genomic [this].)
In animal behavior, the formation at a specific stage in life of a long-lasting behavioral response to a specific individual or object. (See also genomic [this].)	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">imprinting</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inclusive fitness</span>"	The total effect an individual has on proliferating its genes by producing its own offspring and by providing aid that enables other close relatives to increase the production of their offspring.
The total effect an individual has on proliferating its genes by producing its own offspring and by providing aid that enables other close relatives to increase the production of their offspring.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inclusive fitness</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">innate behavior</span>"	Animal behavior that is developmentally fixed and under strong genetic control. [This] is exhibited in virtually the same form by all individuals in a population despite internal and external environmental differences during development and throughout their lifetimes.
Animal behavior that is developmentally fixed and under strong genetic control. [This] is exhibited in virtually the same form by all individuals in a population despite internal and external environmental differences during development and throughout their lifetimes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">innate behavior</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kin selection</span>"	Natural selection that favors altruistic behavior by enhancing the reproductive success of relatives.
Natural selection that favors altruistic behavior by enhancing the reproductive success of relatives.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kin selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kinesis</span>"	A change in activity or turning rate in response to a stimulus.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">landmark</span>"	A location indicator—a point of reference for orientation during navigation.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">learning</span>"	The modification of behavior based on specific experiences.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mate choice copying</span>"	Behavior in which individuals in a population copy the mate choice of others, apparently as a result of social learning.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">model organism</span>"	A particular species chosen for research into broad biological principles because it is representative of a larger group and usually easy to grow in a lab.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monogamous</span>"	Referring to a type of relationship in which one male mates with just one female.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">operant conditioning</span>"	A type of associative learning in which an animal learns to associate one of its own behaviors with a reward or punishment and then tends to repeat or avoid that behavior; also called trial-and-error learning.
A type of associative learning in which an animal learns to associate one of its own behaviors with a reward or punishment and then tends to repeat or avoid that behavior; also called trial-and-error learning.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">operant conditioning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyandry</span>"	A polygamous mating system involving one female and many males.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polygyny</span>"	A polygamous mating system involving one male and many females.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">problem solving</span>"	The cognitive activity of devising a method to proceed from one state to another in the face of real or apparent obstacles.
The cognitive activity of devising a method to proceed from one state to another in the face of real or apparent obstacles.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">problem solving</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">promiscuous</span>"	Referring to a type of relationship in which mating occurs with no strong pair-bonds or lasting relationships.
Referring to a type of relationship in which mating occurs with no strong pair-bonds or lasting relationships.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">promiscuous</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proximate causation</span>"	The mechanistic explanation of “how” a behavior (or other aspect of an organism’s biology) occurs or is modified; that is, how a stimulus elicits a behavior, what physiological mechanisms mediate the response, and how experience influences the response.
The mechanistic explanation of “how” a behavior (or other aspect of an organism’s biology) occurs or is modified; that is, how a stimulus elicits a behavior, what physiological mechanisms mediate the response, and how experience influences the response.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">proximate causation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reciprocal altruism</span>"	Altruistic behavior between unrelated individuals, whereby the altruistic individual benefits in the future when the beneficiary reciprocates.
Altruistic behavior between unrelated individuals, whereby the altruistic individual benefits in the future when the beneficiary reciprocates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reciprocal altruism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sensitive period</span>"	A limited phase in an individual animal’s development when learning of particular behaviors can take place; also called a critical period.
A limited phase in an individual animal’s development when learning of particular behaviors can take place; also called a critical period.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sensitive period</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sign stimulus</span>"	An external sensory cue that triggers a fixed action pattern by an animal.
An external sensory cue that triggers a fixed action pattern by an animal.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sign stimulus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">signal</span>"	In animal behavior, transmission of a stimulus from one animal to another. The term is also used in the context of communication in other kinds of organisms and in cell-to-cell communication in all multicellular organisms.
In animal behavior, transmission of a stimulus from one animal to another. The term is also used in the context of communication in other kinds of organisms and in cell-to-cell communication in all multicellular organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">signal</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">social learning</span>"	Modification of behavior through the observation of other individuals.
Modification of behavior through the observation of other individuals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">social learning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sociobiology</span>"	The study of social behavior based on evolutionary theory.
The study of social behavior based on evolutionary theory.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sociobiology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spatial learning</span>"	The establishment of a memory that reflects the environment’s spatial structure.
The establishment of a memory that reflects the environment’s spatial structure.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">spatial learning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">taxis</span>"	An oriented movement toward or away from a stimulus.
An oriented movement toward or away from a stimulus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">taxis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ultimate causation</span>"	The evolutionary explanation of “why” a behavior (or other aspect of an organism’s biology) occurs, that is, the benefit to survival and reproduction or the evolutionary significance of the behavioral act.
The evolutionary explanation of “why” a behavior (or other aspect of an organism’s biology) occurs, that is, the benefit to survival and reproduction or the evolutionary significance of the behavioral act.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ultimate causation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polygamous</span>"	Referring to a type of relationship in which an individual of one sex mates with several of the other.
Referring to a type of relationship in which an individual of one sex mates with several of the other.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polygamous</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">abyssal zone</span>"	The part of the ocean’s benthic zone between 2,000 and 6,000 m deep.
The part of the ocean’s benthic zone between 2,000 and 6,000 m deep.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">abyssal zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aphotic zone</span>"	The part of an ocean or lake beneath the photic zone, where light does not penetrate sufficiently for photosynthesis to occur.
The part of an ocean or lake beneath the photic zone, where light does not penetrate sufficiently for photosynthesis to occur.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aphotic zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">benthic zone</span>"	The bottom surface of an aquatic environment.
The bottom surface of an aquatic environment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">benthic zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">benthos</span>"	The communities of organisms living in the benthic zone of an aquatic biome.
The communities of organisms living in the benthic zone of an aquatic biome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">benthos</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biome</span>"	Any of the world’s major ecosystems, often classified according to the predominant vegetation and characterized by adaptations of organisms to that particular environment.
Any of the world’s major ecosystems, often classified according to the predominant vegetation and characterized by adaptations of organisms to that particular environment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biosphere</span>"	The entire portion of Earth inhabited by life; the sum of all the planet’s ecosystems.
The entire portion of Earth inhabited by life; the sum of all the planet’s ecosystems.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biosphere</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">canopy</span>"	The uppermost layer of vegetation in a terrestrial biome.
The uppermost layer of vegetation in a terrestrial biome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">canopy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chaparral</span>"	A scrubland biome of dense, spiny evergreen shrubs found at midlatitudes along coasts where cold ocean currents circulate offshore; characterized by mild, rainy winters and long, hot, dry summers.
A scrubland biome of dense, spiny evergreen shrubs found at midlatitudes along coasts where cold ocean currents circulate offshore; characterized by mild, rainy winters and long, hot, dry summers.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chaparral</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">climate</span>"	The long-term prevailing weather conditions at a locality.
The long-term prevailing weather conditions at a locality.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">climate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">climograph</span>"	A plot of the temperature and precipitation in a particular region.
A plot of the temperature and precipitation in a particular region.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">climograph</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">community</span>"	All the organisms that inhabit a particular area; an assemblage of populations of different species living close enough together for potential interaction.
All the organisms that inhabit a particular area; an assemblage of populations of different species living close enough together for potential interaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">community</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">community ecology</span>"	The study of how interactions between species affect community structure and organization.
The study of how interactions between species affect community structure and organization.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">community ecology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">coral reef</span>"	Typically a warm-water, tropical ecosystem dominated by the hard skeletal structures secreted primarily by the resident cnidarians. Some reefs also exist in cold, deep waters.
Typically a warm-water, tropical ecosystem dominated by the hard skeletal structures secreted primarily by the resident cnidarians. Some reefs also exist in cold, deep waters.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">coral reef</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">deep-sea hydrothermal vent</span>"	A dark, hot, oxygen-deficient environment associated with volcanic activity on or near the seafloor. The producers in a vent community are chemoautotrophic prokaryotes.
A dark, hot, oxygen-deficient environment associated with volcanic activity on or near the seafloor. The producers in a vent community are chemoautotrophic prokaryotes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">deep-sea hydrothermal vent</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">desert</span>"	A terrestrial biome characterized by very low precipitation.
A terrestrial biome characterized by very low precipitation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">desert</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">detritus</span>"	Dead organic matter.
Dead organic matter.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">detritus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dispersal</span>"	The movement of individuals (or gametes) away from their parent location. This movement sometimes expands the geographic range of a population or species.
The movement of individuals (or gametes) away from their parent location. This movement sometimes expands the geographic range of a population or species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dispersal</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecosystem</span>"	All the organisms in a given area as well as the abiotic factors with which they interact; one or more communities and the physical environment around them.
All the organisms in a given area as well as the abiotic factors with which they interact; one or more communities and the physical environment around them.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecosystem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecosystem ecology</span>"	The study of energy flow and the cycling of chemicals among the various biotic and abiotic components in an ecosystem.
The study of energy flow and the cycling of chemicals among the various biotic and abiotic components in an ecosystem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecosystem ecology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecotone</span>"	The transition from one type of habitat or ecosystem to another, such as the transition from a forest to a grassland.
The transition from one type of habitat or ecosystem to another, such as the transition from a forest to a grassland.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecotone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">estuary</span>"	The area where a freshwater stream or river merges with the ocean.
The area where a freshwater stream or river merges with the ocean.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">estuary</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eutrophic lake</span>"	A lake that has a high rate of biological productivity supported by a high rate of nutrient cycling.
A lake that has a high rate of biological productivity supported by a high rate of nutrient cycling.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eutrophic lake</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">global ecology</span>"	The study of the functioning and distribution of organisms across the biosphere and how the regional exchange of energy and materials affects them.
The study of the functioning and distribution of organisms across the biosphere and how the regional exchange of energy and materials affects them.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">global ecology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intertidal zone</span>"	The shallow zone of the ocean adjacent to land and between the high- and low-tide lines.
The shallow zone of the ocean adjacent to land and between the high- and low-tide lines.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intertidal zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">landscape ecology</span>"	The study of how the spatial arrangement of habitat types affects the distribution and abundance of organisms and ecosystem processes.
The study of how the spatial arrangement of habitat types affects the distribution and abundance of organisms and ecosystem processes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">landscape ecology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">limnetic zone</span>"	In a lake, the well-lit, open surface waters farther from shore.
In a lake, the well-lit, open surface waters farther from shore.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">limnetic zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">littoral zone</span>"	In a lake, the shallow, well-lit waters close to shore.
In a lake, the shallow, well-lit waters close to shore.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">littoral zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">macroclimate</span>"	Large-scale patterns in climate; the climate of an entire region.
Large-scale patterns in climate; the climate of an entire region.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">macroclimate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">marine benthic zone</span>"	The ocean floor.
The ocean floor.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">marine benthic zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microclimate</span>"	Very fine scale patterns of climate, such as the specific climatic conditions underneath a log.
Very fine scale patterns of climate, such as the specific climatic conditions underneath a log.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microclimate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neritic zone</span>"	The shallow region of the ocean overlying the continental shelf.
The shallow region of the ocean overlying the continental shelf.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neritic zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">northern coniferous forest</span>"	A terrestrial biome characterized by long, cold winters and dominated by cone-bearing trees.
A terrestrial biome characterized by long, cold winters and dominated by cone-bearing trees.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">northern coniferous forest</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oceanic pelagic zone</span>"	Most of the ocean’s waters far from shore, constantly mixed by ocean currents.
Most of the ocean’s waters far from shore, constantly mixed by ocean currents.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oceanic pelagic zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oligotrophic lake</span>"	A nutrient-poor, clear lake with few phytoplankton.
A nutrient-poor, clear lake with few phytoplankton.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oligotrophic lake</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organismal ecology</span>"	The branch of ecology concerned with the morphological, physiological, and behavioral ways in which individual organisms meet the challenges posed by their biotic and abiotic environments.
The branch of ecology concerned with the morphological, physiological, and behavioral ways in which individual organisms meet the challenges posed by their biotic and abiotic environments.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organismal ecology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">permafrost</span>"	A permanently frozen soil layer.
A permanently frozen soil layer.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">permafrost</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photic zone</span>"	The narrow top layer of an ocean or lake, where light penetrates sufficiently for photosynthesis to occur.
The narrow top layer of an ocean or lake, where light penetrates sufficiently for photosynthesis to occur.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photic zone</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">savanna</span>"	A tropical grassland biome with scattered individual trees and large herbivores and maintained by occasional fires and drought.
A tropical grassland biome with scattered individual trees and large herbivores and maintained by occasional fires and drought.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">savanna</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">temperate broadleaf forest</span>"	A biome located throughout midlatitude regions where there is sufficient moisture to support the growth of large, broadleaf deciduous trees.
A biome located throughout midlatitude regions where there is sufficient moisture to support the growth of large, broadleaf deciduous trees.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">temperate broadleaf forest</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">temperate grassland</span>"	A terrestrial biome dominated by grasses and forbs.
A terrestrial biome dominated by grasses and forbs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">temperate grassland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thermocline</span>"	A narrow stratum of rapid temperature change in the ocean and in many temperate-zone lakes.
A narrow stratum of rapid temperature change in the ocean and in many temperate-zone lakes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thermocline</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tropical rain forest</span>"	A terrestrial biome characterized by high levels of precipitation and high temperatures year-round.
A terrestrial biome characterized by high levels of precipitation and high temperatures year-round.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tropical rain forest</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tropics</span>"	Latitudes between 23.5° north and south.
Latitudes between 23.5° north and south.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tropics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tundra</span>"	A terrestrial biome at the extreme limits of plant growth. At the northernmost limits, it is called arctic [this], and at high altitudes, where plant forms are limited to low shrubby or matlike vegetation, it is called alpine [this].
A terrestrial biome at the extreme limits of plant growth. At the northernmost limits, it is called arctic [this], and at high altitudes, where plant forms are limited to low shrubby or matlike vegetation, it is called alpine [this].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tundra</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">turnover</span>"	The mixing of waters as a result of changing water-temperature profiles in a lake.
The mixing of waters as a result of changing water-temperature profiles in a lake.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">turnover</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">wetland</span>"	A habitat that is inundated by water at least some of the time and that supports plants adapted to water-saturated soil.
A habitat that is inundated by water at least some of the time and that supports plants adapted to water-saturated soil.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">wetland</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">age structure</span>"	The relative number of individuals of each age in a population.
The relative number of individuals of each age in a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">age structure</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">big-bang reproduction</span>"	Reproduction in which an organism produces all of its offspring in a single event; also known as semelparity.
Reproduction in which an organism produces all of its offspring in a single event; also known as semelparity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">big-bang reproduction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carrying capacity</span>"	The maximum population size that can be supported by the available resources, symbolized as K.
The maximum population size that can be supported by the available resources, symbolized as K.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carrying capacity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cohort</span>"	A group of individuals of the same age in a population.
A group of individuals of the same age in a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cohort</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">density</span>"	The number of individuals per unit area or volume.
The number of individuals per unit area or volume.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">density</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">density dependent</span>"	Referring to any characteristic that varies according to an increase in population density.
Referring to any characteristic that varies according to an increase in population density.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">density dependent</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">density independent</span>"	Referring to any characteristic that is not affected by population density.
Referring to any characteristic that is not affected by population density.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">density independent</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dispersion</span>"	The pattern of spacing among individuals within the boundaries of the geographic population.
The pattern of spacing among individuals within the boundaries of the geographic population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dispersion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecological footprint</span>"	The aggregate land and water area required by a person, city, or nation to produce all of the resources it consumes and to absorb all of the waste it generates.
The aggregate land and water area required by a person, city, or nation to produce all of the resources it consumes and to absorb all of the waste it generates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecological footprint</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">emigration</span>"	The movement of individuals out of a population.
The movement of individuals out of a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">emigration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exponential population growth</span>"	Growth of a population in an ideal, unlimited environment, represented by a J-shaped curve when population size is plotted over time.
Growth of a population in an ideal, unlimited environment, represented by a J-shaped curve when population size is plotted over time.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exponential population growth</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immigration</span>"	The influx of new individuals into a population from other areas.
The influx of new individuals into a population from other areas.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">immigration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">iteroparity</span>"	Reproduction in which adults produce offspring over many years; also known as repeated reproduction.
Reproduction in which adults produce offspring over many years; also known as repeated reproduction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">iteroparity</span>"
