"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">K-selection</span>"	Selection for life history traits that are sensitive to population density; also called density-dependent selection.
Selection for life history traits that are sensitive to population density; also called density-dependent selection.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">K-selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">life history</span>"	The traits that affect an organism’s schedule of reproduction and survival.
The traits that affect an organism’s schedule of reproduction and survival.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">life history</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">life table</span>"	A table of data summarizing mortality in a population.
A table of data summarizing mortality in a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">life table</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">logistic population growth</span>"	Population growth that levels off as population size approaches carrying capacity.
Population growth that levels off as population size approaches carrying capacity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">logistic population growth</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mark-recapture method</span>"	A sampling technique used to estimate the size of animal populations.
A sampling technique used to estimate the size of animal populations.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mark-recapture method</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metapopulation</span>"	A group of spatially separated populations of one species that interact through immigration and emigration.
A group of spatially separated populations of one species that interact through immigration and emigration.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">metapopulation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">population dynamics</span>"	The study of how complex interactions between biotic and abiotic factors influence variations in population size.
The study of how complex interactions between biotic and abiotic factors influence variations in population size.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">population dynamics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">population ecology</span>"	The study of populations in relation to their environment, including environmental influences on population density and distribution, age structure, and variations in population size.
The study of populations in relation to their environment, including environmental influences on population density and distribution, age structure, and variations in population size.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">population ecology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">repeated reproduction</span>"	Reproduction in which adults produce offspring over many years; also known as iteroparity.
Reproduction in which adults produce offspring over many years; also known as iteroparity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">repeated reproduction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reproductive table</span>"	An age-specific summary of the reproductive rates in a population.
An age-specific summary of the reproductive rates in a population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">reproductive table</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">r-selection</span>"	Selection for life history traits that maximize reproductive success in uncrowded environments; also called density-independent selection.
Selection for life history traits that maximize reproductive success in uncrowded environments; also called density-independent selection.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">r-selection</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">semelparity</span>"	Reproduction in which an organism produces all of its offspring in a single event; also known as big-bang reproduction.
Reproduction in which an organism produces all of its offspring in a single event; also known as big-bang reproduction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">semelparity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">survivorship curve</span>"	A plot of the number of members of a cohort that are still alive at each age; one way to represent age-specific mortality.
A plot of the number of members of a cohort that are still alive at each age; one way to represent age-specific mortality.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">survivorship curve</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">territoriality</span>"	A behavior in which an animal defends a bounded physical space against encroachment by other individuals, usually of its own species.
A behavior in which an animal defends a bounded physical space against encroachment by other individuals, usually of its own species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">territoriality</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">zero population growth (ZPG)</span>"	A period of stability in population size, when the per capita birth rate and death rate are equal.
A period of stability in population size, when the per capita birth rate and death rate are equal.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">zero population growth (ZPG)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aposematic coloration</span>"	The bright coloration of animals with effective physical or chemical defenses that acts as a warning to predators.
The bright coloration of animals with effective physical or chemical defenses that acts as a warning to predators.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">aposematic coloration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Batesian mimicry</span>"	A type of mimicry in which a harmless species looks like a species that is poisonous or otherwise harmful to predators.
A type of mimicry in which a harmless species looks like a species that is poisonous or otherwise harmful to predators.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Batesian mimicry</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biomanipulation</span>"	An approach that applies the top-down model of community organization to alter ecosystem characteristics. For example, ecologists can prevent algal blooms and eutrophication by altering the density of higher-level consumers in lakes instead of by using chemical treatments.
An approach that applies the top-down model of community organization to alter ecosystem characteristics. For example, ecologists can prevent algal blooms and eutrophication by altering the density of higher-level consumers in lakes instead of by using chemical treatments.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biomanipulation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biomass</span>"	The total mass of organic matter comprising a group of organisms in a particular habitat.
The total mass of organic matter comprising a group of organisms in a particular habitat.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biomass</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bottom-up model</span>"	A model of community organization in which mineral nutrients influence community organization by controlling plant or phytoplankton numbers, which in turn control herbivore numbers, which in turn control predator numbers.
A model of community organization in which mineral nutrients influence community organization by controlling plant or phytoplankton numbers, which in turn control herbivore numbers, which in turn control predator numbers.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bottom-up model</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">character displacement</span>"	The tendency for characteristics to be more divergent in sympatric populations of two species than in allopatric populations of the same two species.
The tendency for characteristics to be more divergent in sympatric populations of two species than in allopatric populations of the same two species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">character displacement</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">commensalism</span>"	A symbiotic relationship in which one organism benefits but the other is neither helped nor harmed.
A symbiotic relationship in which one organism benefits but the other is neither helped nor harmed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">commensalism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">competitive exclusion</span>"	The concept that when populations of two similar species compete for the same limited resources, one population will use the resources more efficiently and have a reproductive advantage that will eventually lead to the elimination of the other population.
The concept that when populations of two similar species compete for the same limited resources, one population will use the resources more efficiently and have a reproductive advantage that will eventually lead to the elimination of the other population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">competitive exclusion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cryptic coloration</span>"	Camouflage that makes a potential prey difficult to spot against its background.
Camouflage that makes a potential prey difficult to spot against its background.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cryptic coloration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">disturbance</span>"	A natural or human-caused event that changes a biological community and usually removes organisms from it. [These], such as fires and storms, play a pivotal role in structuring many communities.
A natural or human-caused event that changes a biological community and usually removes organisms from it. [These], such as fires and storms, play a pivotal role in structuring many communities.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">disturbance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dominant species</span>"	A species with substantially higher abundance or biomass than other species in a community. [These] exert a powerful control over the occurrence and distribution of other species.
A species with substantially higher abundance or biomass than other species in a community. [These] exert a powerful control over the occurrence and distribution of other species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dominant species</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dynamic stability hypothesis</span>"	The idea that long food chains are less stable than short chains.
The idea that long food chains are less stable than short chains.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dynamic stability hypothesis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecological niche</span>"	The sum of a species’ use of the biotic and abiotic resources in its environment.
The sum of a species’ use of the biotic and abiotic resources in its environment.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecological niche</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecological succession</span>"	Transition in the species composition of a community following a disturbance; the establishment of a community in an area virtually barren of life.
Transition in the species composition of a community following a disturbance; the establishment of a community in an area virtually barren of life.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecological succession</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ectoparasite</span>"	A parasite that feeds on the external surface of a host.
A parasite that feeds on the external surface of a host.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ectoparasite</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endoparasite</span>"	A parasite that lives within a host.
A parasite that lives within a host.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endoparasite</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">energetic hypothesis</span>"	The concept that the length of a food chain is limited by the inefficiency of energy transfer along the chain.
The concept that the length of a food chain is limited by the inefficiency of energy transfer along the chain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">energetic hypothesis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evapotranspiration</span>"	The total evaporation of water from an ecosystem, including evaporation from soil and the outside of plants, as well as the transpiration of water from within plants through stomata.
The total evaporation of water from an ecosystem, including evaporation from soil and the outside of plants, as well as the transpiration of water from within plants through stomata.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">evapotranspiration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">facilitator</span>"	A species that has a positive effect on the survival and reproduction of other species in a community and that influences community structure.
A species that has a positive effect on the survival and reproduction of other species in a community and that influences community structure.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">facilitator</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">food chain</span>"	The pathway along which food energy is transferred from trophic level to trophic level, beginning with producers.
The pathway along which food energy is transferred from trophic level to trophic level, beginning with producers.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">food chain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">food web</span>"	The interconnected feeding relationships in an ecosystem.
The interconnected feeding relationships in an ecosystem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">food web</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">herbivory</span>"	An interaction in which an organism eats parts of a plant or alga.
An interaction in which an organism eats parts of a plant or alga.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">herbivory</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">host</span>"	The larger participant in a symbiotic relationship, serving as home and food source for the smaller symbiont.
The larger participant in a symbiotic relationship, serving as home and food source for the smaller symbiont.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">host</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intermediate disturbance hypothesis</span>"	The concept that moderate levels of disturbance can foster greater species diversity than low or high levels of disturbance.
The concept that moderate levels of disturbance can foster greater species diversity than low or high levels of disturbance.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">intermediate disturbance hypothesis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interspecific competition</span>"	Competition for resources between individuals of two or more species when resources are in short supply.
Competition for resources between individuals of two or more species when resources are in short supply.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interspecific competition</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interspecific interaction</span>"	A relationship between individuals of two or more species in a community.
A relationship between individuals of two or more species in a community.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">interspecific interaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">invasive species</span>"	A species, often introduced by humans, that takes hold outside its native range.
A species, often introduced by humans, that takes hold outside its native range.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">invasive species</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">keystone species</span>"	A species that is not necessarily abundant in a community yet exerts strong control on community structure by the nature of its ecological role or niche.
A species that is not necessarily abundant in a community yet exerts strong control on community structure by the nature of its ecological role or niche.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">keystone species</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Müllerian mimicry</span>"	A mutual mimicry by two unpalatable species.
A mutual mimicry by two unpalatable species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Müllerian mimicry</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nonequilibrium model</span>"	A model that maintains that communities change constantly after being buffeted by disturbances.
A model that maintains that communities change constantly after being buffeted by disturbances.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nonequilibrium model</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parasite</span>"	An organism that feeds on the cell contents, tissues, or body fluids of another species (the host) while in or on the host organism. [These] harm but usually do not kill their host.
An organism that feeds on the cell contents, tissues, or body fluids of another species (the host) while in or on the host organism. [These] harm but usually do not kill their host.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parasite</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parasitism</span>"	A symbiotic relationship in which one organism, the parasite, benefits at the expense of another, the host, by living either within or on the host.
A symbiotic relationship in which one organism, the parasite, benefits at the expense of another, the host, by living either within or on the host.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parasitism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">predation</span>"	An interaction between species in which one species, the predator, eats the other, the prey.
An interaction between species in which one species, the predator, eats the other, the prey.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">predation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary succession</span>"	A type of ecological succession that occurs in an area where there were originally no organisms present and where soil has not yet formed.
A type of ecological succession that occurs in an area where there were originally no organisms present and where soil has not yet formed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary succession</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">relative abundance</span>"	The proportional abundance of different species in a community.
The proportional abundance of different species in a community.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">relative abundance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">resource partitioning</span>"	The division of environmental resources by coexisting species such that the niche of each species differs by one or more significant factors from the niches of all coexisting species.
The division of environmental resources by coexisting species such that the niche of each species differs by one or more significant factors from the niches of all coexisting species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">resource partitioning</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary succession</span>"	A type of succession that occurs where an existing community has been cleared by some disturbance that leaves the soil or substrate intact.
A type of succession that occurs where an existing community has been cleared by some disturbance that leaves the soil or substrate intact.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary succession</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Shannon diversity</span>"	An index of community diversity symbolized by H and represented by the equation H = - [(pA ln pA) + (pB ln pB) + (pC ln pC) + . . .], where A, B, C . . . are the species in the community, p is the relative abundance of each species, and ln is the natural logarithm.
An index of community diversity symbolized by H and represented by the equation H = - [(pA ln pA) + (pB ln pB) + (pC ln pC) + . . .], where A, B, C . . . are the species in the community, p is the relative abundance of each species, and ln is the natural logarithm.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Shannon diversity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">species diversity</span>"	The number and relative abundance of species in a biological community.
The number and relative abundance of species in a biological community.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">species diversity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">species richness</span>"	The number of species in a biological community.
The number of species in a biological community.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">species richness</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">species-area curve</span>"	The biodiversity pattern, first noted by Alexander von Humboldt, that shows that the larger the geographic area of a community is, the more species it has.
The biodiversity pattern, first noted by Alexander von Humboldt, that shows that the larger the geographic area of a community is, the more species it has.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">species-area curve</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">symbiosis</span>"	An ecological relationship between organisms of two different species that live together in direct and intimate contact.
An ecological relationship between organisms of two different species that live together in direct and intimate contact.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">symbiosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">top-down model</span>"	A model of community organization in which predation influences community organization by controlling herbivore numbers, which in turn control plant or phytoplankton numbers, which in turn control nutrient levels; also called the trophic cascade model.
A model of community organization in which predation influences community organization by controlling herbivore numbers, which in turn control plant or phytoplankton numbers, which in turn control nutrient levels; also called the trophic cascade model.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">top-down model</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trophic structure</span>"	The different feeding relationships in an ecosystem, which determine the route of energy flow and the pattern of chemical cycling.
The different feeding relationships in an ecosystem, which determine the route of energy flow and the pattern of chemical cycling.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trophic structure</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vector</span>"	An organism that transmits pathogens from one host to another.
An organism that transmits pathogens from one host to another.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vector</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">zoonotic pathogen</span>"	A disease-causing agent that is transmitted to humans from other animals.
A disease-causing agent that is transmitted to humans from other animals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">zoonotic pathogen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">actual evapotranspiration</span>"	The amount of water transpired by plants and evaporated from a landscape over a given period of time, usually measured in millimeters and estimated for a year.
The amount of water transpired by plants and evaporated from a landscape over a given period of time, usually measured in millimeters and estimated for a year.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">actual evapotranspiration</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biogeochemical cycle</span>"	Any of the various chemical cycles, which involve both biotic and abiotic components of ecosystems.
Any of the various chemical cycles, which involve both biotic and abiotic components of ecosystems.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biogeochemical cycle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biological magnification</span>"	A process in which retained substances become more concentrated at each higher trophic level in a food chain.
A process in which retained substances become more concentrated at each higher trophic level in a food chain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biological magnification</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">critical load</span>"	The amount of added nutrient, usually nitrogen or phosphorus, that can be absorbed by plants without damaging ecosystem integrity.
The amount of added nutrient, usually nitrogen or phosphorus, that can be absorbed by plants without damaging ecosystem integrity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">critical load</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">decomposer</span>"	An organism that absorbs nutrients from nonliving organic material such as corpses, fallen plant material, and the wastes of living organisms and converts them to inorganic forms; a detritivore.
An organism that absorbs nutrients from nonliving organic material such as corpses, fallen plant material, and the wastes of living organisms and converts them to inorganic forms; a detritivore.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">decomposer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">detritivore</span>"	A consumer that derives its energy and nutrients from nonliving organic material such as corpses, fallen plant material, and the wastes of living organisms; a decomposer.
A consumer that derives its energy and nutrients from nonliving organic material such as corpses, fallen plant material, and the wastes of living organisms; a decomposer.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">detritivore</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eutrophication</span>"	A process by which nutrients, particularly phosphorus and nitrogen, become highly concentrated in a body of water, leading to increased growth of organisms such as algae or cyanobacteria.
A process by which nutrients, particularly phosphorus and nitrogen, become highly concentrated in a body of water, leading to increased growth of organisms such as algae or cyanobacteria.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eutrophication</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">green world hypothesis</span>"	The conjecture that terrestrial herbivores consume relatively little plant biomass because they are held in check by a variety of factors, including predators, parasites, and disease.
The conjecture that terrestrial herbivores consume relatively little plant biomass because they are held in check by a variety of factors, including predators, parasites, and disease.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">green world hypothesis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">greenhouse effect</span>"	The warming of Earth due to the atmospheric accumulation of carbon dioxide and certain other gases, which absorb reflected infrared radiation and reradiate some of it back toward Earth.
The warming of Earth due to the atmospheric accumulation of carbon dioxide and certain other gases, which absorb reflected infrared radiation and reradiate some of it back toward Earth.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">greenhouse effect</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gross primary production (GPP)</span>"	The total primary production of an ecosystem.
The total primary production of an ecosystem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gross primary production (GPP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">law of conservation of mass</span>"	A physical law stating that matter can change form but cannot be created or destroyed. In a closed system, the mass of the system is constant.
A physical law stating that matter can change form but cannot be created or destroyed. In a closed system, the mass of the system is constant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">law of conservation of mass</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">limiting nutrient</span>"	An element that must be added for production to increase in a particular area.
An element that must be added for production to increase in a particular area.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">limiting nutrient</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">net primary production (NPP)</span>"	The gross primary production of an ecosystem minus the energy used by the producers for respiration.
The gross primary production of an ecosystem minus the energy used by the producers for respiration.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">net primary production (NPP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary consumer</span>"	An herbivore; an organism that eats plants or other autotrophs.
An herbivore; an organism that eats plants or other autotrophs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary consumer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary producer</span>"	An autotroph, usually a photosynthetic organism. Collectively, autotrophs make up the trophic level of an ecosystem that ultimately supports all other levels.
An autotroph, usually a photosynthetic organism. Collectively, autotrophs make up the trophic level of an ecosystem that ultimately supports all other levels.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary producer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary production</span>"	The amount of light energy converted to chemical energy (organic compounds) by autotrophs in an ecosystem during a given time period.
The amount of light energy converted to chemical energy (organic compounds) by autotrophs in an ecosystem during a given time period.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary production</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">production efficiency</span>"	The percentage of energy stored in food that is not used for respiration or eliminated as waste.
The percentage of energy stored in food that is not used for respiration or eliminated as waste.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">production efficiency</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary consumer</span>"	A carnivore that eats herbivores.
A carnivore that eats herbivores.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary consumer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary production</span>"	The amount of chemical energy in consumers’ food that is converted to their own new biomass during a given time period.
The amount of chemical energy in consumers’ food that is converted to their own new biomass during a given time period.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary production</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tertiary consumer</span>"	A carnivore that eats other carnivores.
A carnivore that eats other carnivores.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tertiary consumer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trophic efficiency</span>"	The percentage of production transferred from one trophic level to the next.
The percentage of production transferred from one trophic level to the next.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">trophic efficiency</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">turnover time</span>"	The time required to replace the standing crop of a population or group of populations (for example, of phytoplankton), calculated as the ratio of standing crop to production.
The time required to replace the standing crop of a population or group of populations (for example, of phytoplankton), calculated as the ratio of standing crop to production.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">turnover time</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ABC model</span>"	A model of flower formation identifying three classes of organ identity genes that direct formation of the four types of floral organs.
A model of flower formation identifying three classes of organ identity genes that direct formation of the four types of floral organs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ABC model</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">annual</span>"	A flowering plant that completes its entire life cycle in a single year or growing season.
A flowering plant that completes its entire life cycle in a single year or growing season.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">annual</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apical bud</span>"	A bud at the tip of a plant stem; also called a terminal bud.
A bud at the tip of a plant stem; also called a terminal bud.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apical bud</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apical dominance</span>"	Concentration of growth at the tip of a plant shoot, where a terminal bud partially inhibits axillary bud growth.
Concentration of growth at the tip of a plant shoot, where a terminal bud partially inhibits axillary bud growth.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apical dominance</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apical meristem</span>"	Embryonic plant tissue in the tips of roots and the buds of shoots. The dividing cells of [this] enable the plant to grow in length.
Embryonic plant tissue in the tips of roots and the buds of shoots. The dividing cells of [this] enable the plant to grow in length.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apical meristem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">axillary bud</span>"	A structure that has the potential to form a lateral shoot, or branch. The bud appears in the angle formed between a leaf and a stem.
A structure that has the potential to form a lateral shoot, or branch. The bud appears in the angle formed between a leaf and a stem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">axillary bud</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bark</span>"	All tissues external to the vascular cambium, consisting mainly of the secondary phloem and layers of periderm.
All tissues external to the vascular cambium, consisting mainly of the secondary phloem and layers of periderm.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bark</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biennial</span>"	A flowering plant that requires two years to complete its life cycle.
A flowering plant that requires two years to complete its life cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biennial</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">blade</span>"	(1) A leaflike structure of a seaweed that provides most of the surface area for photosynthesis. (2) The flattened portion of a typical leaf.
(1) A leaflike structure of a seaweed that provides most of the surface area for photosynthesis. (2) The flattened portion of a typical leaf.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">blade</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">collenchyma cell</span>"	A flexible plant cell type that occurs in strands or cylinders that support young parts of the plant without restraining growth.
A flexible plant cell type that occurs in strands or cylinders that support young parts of the plant without restraining growth.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">collenchyma cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">companion cell</span>"	A type of plant cell that is connected to a sieve-tube element by many plasmodesmata and whose nucleus and ribosomes may serve one or more adjacent sieve-tube elements.
A type of plant cell that is connected to a sieve-tube element by many plasmodesmata and whose nucleus and ribosomes may serve one or more adjacent sieve-tube elements.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">companion cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cork cambium</span>"	A cylinder of meristematic tissue in woody plants that replaces the epidermis with thicker, tougher cork cells.
A cylinder of meristematic tissue in woody plants that replaces the epidermis with thicker, tougher cork cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cork cambium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cortex</span>"	(1) The outer region of cytoplasm in a eukaryotic cell, lying just under the plasma membrane, that has a more gel-like consistency than the inner regions, due to the presence of multiple microfilaments. (2) In plants, ground tissue that is between the vascular tissue and dermal tissue in a root or eudicot stem.
(1) The outer region of cytoplasm in a eukaryotic cell, lying just under the plasma membrane, that has a more gel-like consistency than the inner regions, due to the presence of multiple microfilaments. (2) In plants, ground tissue that is between the vascular tissue and dermal tissue in a root or eudicot stem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cortex</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cuticle</span>"	(1) A waxy covering on the surface of stems and leaves that acts as an adaptation that prevents desiccation in terrestrial plants. (2) The exoskeleton of an arthropod, consisting of layers of protein and chitin that are variously modified for different functions. (3) A tough coat that covers the body of a nematode.
(1) A waxy covering on the surface of stems and leaves that acts as an adaptation that prevents desiccation in terrestrial plants. (2) The exoskeleton of an arthropod, consisting of layers of protein and chitin that are variously modified for different functions. (3) A tough coat that covers the body of a nematode.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cuticle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dermal tissue system</span>"	The outer protective covering of plants.
The outer protective covering of plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dermal tissue system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">determinate growth</span>"	A type of growth characteristic of most animals and some plant organs, in which growth stops after a certain size is reached.
A type of growth characteristic of most animals and some plant organs, in which growth stops after a certain size is reached.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">determinate growth</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endodermis</span>"	The innermost layer of the cortex in plant roots; a cylinder one cell thick that forms the boundary between the cortex and the vascular cylinder.
The innermost layer of the cortex in plant roots; a cylinder one cell thick that forms the boundary between the cortex and the vascular cylinder.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endodermis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fiber</span>"	A lignified cell type that reinforces the xylem of angiosperms and functions in mechanical support; a slender, tapered sclerenchyma cell that usually occurs in bundles.
A lignified cell type that reinforces the xylem of angiosperms and functions in mechanical support; a slender, tapered sclerenchyma cell that usually occurs in bundles.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fiber</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ground tissue system</span>"	Plant tissues that are neither vascular nor dermal, fulfilling a variety of functions, such as storage, photosynthesis, and support.
Plant tissues that are neither vascular nor dermal, fulfilling a variety of functions, such as storage, photosynthesis, and support.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ground tissue system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">guard cells</span>"	The two cells that flank the stomatal pore and regulate the opening and closing of the pore.
The two cells that flank the stomatal pore and regulate the opening and closing of the pore.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">guard cells</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">indeterminate growth</span>"	A type of growth characteristic of plants, in which the organism continues to grow as long as it lives.
A type of growth characteristic of plants, in which the organism continues to grow as long as it lives.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">indeterminate growth</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">internode</span>"	A segment of a plant stem between the points where leaves are attached.
A segment of a plant stem between the points where leaves are attached.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">internode</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lateral meristem</span>"	A meristem that thickens the roots and shoots of woody plants. The vascular cambium and cork cambium are [these].
A meristem that thickens the roots and shoots of woody plants. The vascular cambium and cork cambium are [these].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lateral meristem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lateral root</span>"	A root that arises from the pericycle of an established root.
A root that arises from the pericycle of an established root.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lateral root</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">leaf primordium</span>"	A finger-like projection along the flank of a shoot apical meristem, from which a leaf arises.
A finger-like projection along the flank of a shoot apical meristem, from which a leaf arises.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">leaf primordium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lenticel</span>"	A small raised area in the bark of stems and roots that enables gas exchange between living cells and the outside air.
A small raised area in the bark of stems and roots that enables gas exchange between living cells and the outside air.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lenticel</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meristem</span>"	Plant tissue that remains embryonic as long as the plant lives, allowing for indeterminate growth.
Plant tissue that remains embryonic as long as the plant lives, allowing for indeterminate growth.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meristem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meristem identity gene</span>"	A plant gene that promotes the switch from vegetative growth to flowering.
A plant gene that promotes the switch from vegetative growth to flowering.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">meristem identity gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">morphology</span>"	An organism’s external form.
An organism’s external form.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">morphology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">node</span>"	A point along the stem of a plant at which leaves are attached.
A point along the stem of a plant at which leaves are attached.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">node</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organ identity gene</span>"	A plant homeotic gene that uses positional information to determine which emerging leaves develop into which types of floral organs.
A plant homeotic gene that uses positional information to determine which emerging leaves develop into which types of floral organs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">organ identity gene</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parenchyma cell</span>"	A relatively unspecialized plant cell type that carries out most of the metabolism, synthesizes and stores organic products, and develops into a more differentiated cell type.
A relatively unspecialized plant cell type that carries out most of the metabolism, synthesizes and stores organic products, and develops into a more differentiated cell type.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parenchyma cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">perennial</span>"	A flowering plant that lives for many years.
A flowering plant that lives for many years.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">perennial</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pericycle</span>"	The outermost layer in the vascular cylinder from which lateral roots arise.
The outermost layer in the vascular cylinder from which lateral roots arise.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pericycle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">periderm</span>"	The protective coat that replaces the epidermis in woody plants during secondary growth, formed of the cork and cork cambium.
The protective coat that replaces the epidermis in woody plants during secondary growth, formed of the cork and cork cambium.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">periderm</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">petiole</span>"	The stalk of a leaf, which joins the leaf to a node of the stem.
The stalk of a leaf, which joins the leaf to a node of the stem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">petiole</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phase change</span>"	A shift from one developmental phase to another.
A shift from one developmental phase to another.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phase change</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phloem</span>"	Vascular plant tissue consisting of living cells arranged into elongated tubes that transport sugar and other organic nutrients throughout the plant.
Vascular plant tissue consisting of living cells arranged into elongated tubes that transport sugar and other organic nutrients throughout the plant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phloem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pith</span>"	Ground tissue that is internal to the vascular tissue in a stem; in many monocot roots, parenchyma cells that form the central core of the vascular cylinder.
Ground tissue that is internal to the vascular tissue in a stem; in many monocot roots, parenchyma cells that form the central core of the vascular cylinder.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pith</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polarity</span>"	A lack of symmetry; structural differences in opposite ends of an organism or structure, such as the root end and shoot end of a plant.
A lack of symmetry; structural differences in opposite ends of an organism or structure, such as the root end and shoot end of a plant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polarity</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">preprophase band</span>"	Microtubules in the cortex (outer cytoplasm) of a cell that are concentrated into a ring.
Microtubules in the cortex (outer cytoplasm) of a cell that are concentrated into a ring.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">preprophase band</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary growth</span>"	Growth produced by apical meristems, lengthening stems and roots.
Growth produced by apical meristems, lengthening stems and roots.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary growth</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary plant body</span>"	The tissues produced by apical meristems, which lengthen stems and roots.
The tissues produced by apical meristems, which lengthen stems and roots.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">primary plant body</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">root</span>"	An organ in vascular plants that anchors the plant and enables it to absorb water and minerals from the soil.
An organ in vascular plants that anchors the plant and enables it to absorb water and minerals from the soil.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">root</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">root cap</span>"	A cone of cells at the tip of a plant root that protects the apical meristem.
A cone of cells at the tip of a plant root that protects the apical meristem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">root cap</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">root hair</span>"	A tiny extension of a root epidermal cell, growing just behind the root tip and increasing surface area for absorption of water and minerals.
A tiny extension of a root epidermal cell, growing just behind the root tip and increasing surface area for absorption of water and minerals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">root hair</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">root system</span>"	All of a plant’s roots, which anchor it in the soil, absorb and transport minerals and water, and store food.
All of a plant’s roots, which anchor it in the soil, absorb and transport minerals and water, and store food.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">root system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sclereid</span>"	A short, irregular sclerenchyma cell in nutshells and seed coats. [These] are scattered throughout the parenchyma of some plants.
A short, irregular sclerenchyma cell in nutshells and seed coats. [These] are scattered throughout the parenchyma of some plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sclereid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sclerenchyma cell</span>"	A rigid, supportive plant cell type usually lacking a protoplast and possessing thick secondary walls strengthened by lignin at maturity.
A rigid, supportive plant cell type usually lacking a protoplast and possessing thick secondary walls strengthened by lignin at maturity.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sclerenchyma cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary growth</span>"	Growth produced by lateral meristems, thickening the roots and shoots of woody plants.
Growth produced by lateral meristems, thickening the roots and shoots of woody plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary growth</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary plant body</span>"	The tissues produced by the vascular cambium and cork cambium, which thicken the stems and roots of woody plants.
The tissues produced by the vascular cambium and cork cambium, which thicken the stems and roots of woody plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary plant body</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">shoot system</span>"	The aerial portion of a plant body, consisting of stems, leaves, and (in angiosperms) flowers.
The aerial portion of a plant body, consisting of stems, leaves, and (in angiosperms) flowers.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">shoot system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sieve-tube element</span>"	A living cell that conducts sugars and other organic nutrients in the phloem of angiosperms; also called a sieve-tube member. Connected end to end, they form sieve tubes.
A living cell that conducts sugars and other organic nutrients in the phloem of angiosperms; also called a sieve-tube member. Connected end to end, they form sieve tubes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sieve-tube element</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stele</span>"	The vascular tissue of a stem or root.
The vascular tissue of a stem or root.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stele</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stem</span>"	A vascular plant organ consisting of an alternating system of nodes and internodes that support the leaves and reproductive structures.
A vascular plant organ consisting of an alternating system of nodes and internodes that support the leaves and reproductive structures.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">taproot</span>"	A main vertical root that develops from an embryonic root and gives rise to lateral (branch) roots.
A main vertical root that develops from an embryonic root and gives rise to lateral (branch) roots.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">taproot</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tissue system</span>"	One or more tissues organized into a functional unit connecting the organs of a plant.
One or more tissues organized into a functional unit connecting the organs of a plant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tissue system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tracheid</span>"	A long, tapered water-conducting cell found in the xylem of nearly all vascular plants. Functioning [these] are no longer living.
A long, tapered water-conducting cell found in the xylem of nearly all vascular plants. Functioning [these] are no longer living.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">tracheid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vascular cambium</span>"	A cylinder of meristematic tissue in woody plants that adds layers of secondary vascular tissue called secondary xylem (wood) and secondary phloem.
A cylinder of meristematic tissue in woody plants that adds layers of secondary vascular tissue called secondary xylem (wood) and secondary phloem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vascular cambium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vascular tissue system</span>"	A transport system formed by xylem and phloem throughout a vascular plant. Xylem transports water and minerals; phloem transports sugars, the products of photosynthesis.
A transport system formed by xylem and phloem throughout a vascular plant. Xylem transports water and minerals; phloem transports sugars, the products of photosynthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vascular tissue system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vein</span>"	(1) In animals, a vessel that carries blood toward the heart. (2) In plants, a vascular bundle in a leaf.
(1) In animals, a vessel that carries blood toward the heart. (2) In plants, a vascular bundle in a leaf.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vein</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vessel element</span>"	A short, wide water-conducting cell found in the xylem of most angiosperms and a few nonflowering vascular plants. Dead at maturity, [these] are aligned end to end to form micropipes called vessels.
A short, wide water-conducting cell found in the xylem of most angiosperms and a few nonflowering vascular plants. Dead at maturity, [these] are aligned end to end to form micropipes called vessels.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vessel element</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vessel</span>"	A continuous water-conducting micropipe found in most angiosperms and a few nonflowering vascular plants.
A continuous water-conducting micropipe found in most angiosperms and a few nonflowering vascular plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vessel</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">xylem</span>"	Vascular plant tissue consisting mainly of tubular dead cells that conduct most of the water and minerals upward from the roots to the rest of the plant.
Vascular plant tissue consisting mainly of tubular dead cells that conduct most of the water and minerals upward from the roots to the rest of the plant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">xylem</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ammonite</span>"	A member of a group of shelled cephalopods that were important marine predators for hundreds of millions of years until their extinction at the end of the Cretaceous period (65.5 mya).
A member of a group of shelled cephalopods that were important marine predators for hundreds of millions of years until their extinction at the end of the Cretaceous period (65.5 mya).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ammonite</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Cambrian explosion</span>"	A relatively brief time in geologic history when large, hard-bodied forms of animals with most of the major body plans known today appeared in the fossil record. This burst of evolutionary change occurred about 535–525 million years ago.
A relatively brief time in geologic history when large, hard-bodied forms of animals with most of the major body plans known today appeared in the fossil record. This burst of evolutionary change occurred about 535–525 million years ago.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Cambrian explosion</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endosymbiosis</span>"	A process in which a unicellular organism (the “host”) engulfs another cell, which lives within the host cell and ultimately becomes an organelle in the host cell; also refers to the hypothesis that mitochondria and plastids were formerly small prokaryotes that began living within larger cells.
A process in which a unicellular organism (the “host”) engulfs another cell, which lives within the host cell and ultimately becomes an organelle in the host cell; also refers to the hypothesis that mitochondria and plastids were formerly small prokaryotes that began living within larger cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endosymbiosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">geologic record</span>"	The division of Earth’s history into time periods, grouped into three eons—Archaean, Proterozoic, and Phanerozoic—and further subdivided into eras, periods, and epochs.
The division of Earth’s history into time periods, grouped into three eons—Archaean, Proterozoic, and Phanerozoic—and further subdivided into eras, periods, and epochs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">geologic record</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">half-life</span>"	The amount of time it takes for 50% of a sample of a radioactive isotope to decay.
The amount of time it takes for 50% of a sample of a radioactive isotope to decay.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">half-life</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterochrony</span>"	Evolutionary change in the timing or rate of an organism’s development.
Evolutionary change in the timing or rate of an organism’s development.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterochrony</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mass extinction</span>"	Period of time when global environmental changes lead to the elimination of a large number of species throughout Earth.
Period of time when global environmental changes lead to the elimination of a large number of species throughout Earth.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mass extinction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paedomorphosis</span>"	The retention in an adult organism of the juvenile features of its evolutionary ancestors.
The retention in an adult organism of the juvenile features of its evolutionary ancestors.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paedomorphosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protobiont</span>"	A collection of abiotically produced molecules surrounded by a membrane or membrane-like structure.
A collection of abiotically produced molecules surrounded by a membrane or membrane-like structure.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protobiont</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radiometric dating</span>"	A method for determining the absolute ages of rocks and fossils, based on the half-life of radioactive isotopes.
A method for determining the absolute ages of rocks and fossils, based on the half-life of radioactive isotopes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radiometric dating</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">serial endosymbiosis</span>"	A hypothesis for the origin of eukaryotes consisting of a sequence of endosymbiotic events in which mitochondria, chloroplasts, and perhaps other cellular structures were derived from small prokaryotes that had been engulfed by larger cells.
A hypothesis for the origin of eukaryotes consisting of a sequence of endosymbiotic events in which mitochondria, chloroplasts, and perhaps other cellular structures were derived from small prokaryotes that had been engulfed by larger cells.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">serial endosymbiosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stromatolite</span>"	Layered rock that results from the activities of prokaryotes that bind thin films of sediment together.
Layered rock that results from the activities of prokaryotes that bind thin films of sediment together.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stromatolite</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">analogy</span>"	Similarity between two species that is due to convergent evolution rather than to descent from a common ancestor with the same trait.
Similarity between two species that is due to convergent evolution rather than to descent from a common ancestor with the same trait.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">analogy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Animalia</span>"	The kingdom that consists of multicellular eukaryotes that ingest their food.
The kingdom that consists of multicellular eukaryotes that ingest their food.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Animalia</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">binomial</span>"	The two-part latinized name of a species, consisting of the genus and specific epithet.
The two-part latinized name of a species, consisting of the genus and specific epithet.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">binomial</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">branch point</span>"	The representation on a phylogenetic tree of the divergence of two or more taxa from a common ancestor. Most [these] are shown as dichotomies, in which a branch representing the ancestral lineage splits into two branches, one for each of the two descendant taxa.
The representation on a phylogenetic tree of the divergence of two or more taxa from a common ancestor. Most [these] are shown as dichotomies, in which a branch representing the ancestral lineage splits into two branches, one for each of the two descendant taxa.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">branch point</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carnivore</span>"	An animal that mainly eats other animals.
An animal that mainly eats other animals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carnivore</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">clade</span>"	A group of species that includes an ancestral species and all its descendants.
A group of species that includes an ancestral species and all its descendants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">clade</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cladistics</span>"	An approach to systematics in which organisms are placed into groups called clades based primarily on common descent.
An approach to systematics in which organisms are placed into groups called clades based primarily on common descent.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cladistics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">class</span>"	In classification, the taxonomic category above the level of order.
In classification, the taxonomic category above the level of order.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">class</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">family</span>"	In classification, the taxonomic category above genus.
In classification, the taxonomic category above genus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">family</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genus</span>"	A taxonomic category above the species level, designated by the first word of a species’ two-part scientific name.
A taxonomic category above the species level, designated by the first word of a species’ two-part scientific name.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">genus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homoplasy</span>"	Similar (analogous) structure or molecular sequence that has evolved independently in two species.
Similar (analogous) structure or molecular sequence that has evolved independently in two species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homoplasy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">horizontal gene transfer</span>"	The transfer of genes from one genome to another through mechanisms such as transposable elements, plasmid exchange, viral activity, and perhaps fusions of different organisms.
The transfer of genes from one genome to another through mechanisms such as transposable elements, plasmid exchange, viral activity, and perhaps fusions of different organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">horizontal gene transfer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ingroup</span>"	A species or group of species whose evolutionary relationships we seek to determine.
A species or group of species whose evolutionary relationships we seek to determine.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ingroup</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kingdom</span>"	A taxonomic category, the second broadest after domain.
A taxonomic category, the second broadest after domain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kingdom</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">maximum likelihood</span>"	As applied to systematics, a principle that states that when considering multiple phylogenetic hypotheses, one should take into account the hypothesis that reflects the most likely sequence of evolutionary events, given certain rules about how DNA changes over time.
As applied to systematics, a principle that states that when considering multiple phylogenetic hypotheses, one should take into account the hypothesis that reflects the most likely sequence of evolutionary events, given certain rules about how DNA changes over time.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">maximum likelihood</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">maximum parsimony</span>"	A principle that states that when considering multiple explanations for an observation, one should first investigate the simplest explanation that is consistent with the facts.
A principle that states that when considering multiple explanations for an observation, one should first investigate the simplest explanation that is consistent with the facts.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">maximum parsimony</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecular clock</span>"	A method for estimating the time required for a given amount of evolutionary change, based on the observation that some regions of genomes appear to evolve at constant rates.
A method for estimating the time required for a given amount of evolutionary change, based on the observation that some regions of genomes appear to evolve at constant rates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecular clock</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecular systematics</span>"	A scientific discipline that uses nucleic acids or other molecules in different species to infer evolutionary relationships.
A scientific discipline that uses nucleic acids or other molecules in different species to infer evolutionary relationships.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">molecular systematics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monophyletic</span>"	Pertaining to a group of taxa that consists of a common ancestor and all its descendants. A [this] taxon is equivalent to a clade.
Pertaining to a group of taxa that consists of a common ancestor and all its descendants. A [this] taxon is equivalent to a clade.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monophyletic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neutral theory</span>"	The hypothesis that much evolutionary change in genes and proteins has no effect on fitness and therefore is not influenced by Darwinian natural selection.
The hypothesis that much evolutionary change in genes and proteins has no effect on fitness and therefore is not influenced by Darwinian natural selection.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">neutral theory</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">orthologous genes</span>"	Homologous genes that are found in different species because of speciation.
Homologous genes that are found in different species because of speciation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">orthologous genes</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">outgroup</span>"	A species or group of species from an evolutionary lineage that is known to have diverged before the lineage that contains the group of species being studied. [This] is selected so that its members are closely related to the group of species being studied, but not as closely related as any study-group members are to each other.
A species or group of species from an evolutionary lineage that is known to have diverged before the lineage that contains the group of species being studied. [This] is selected so that its members are closely related to the group of species being studied, but not as closely related as any study-group members are to each other.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">outgroup</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paralogous genes</span>"	Homologous genes that are found in the same genome as a result of gene duplication.
Homologous genes that are found in the same genome as a result of gene duplication.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paralogous genes</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paraphyletic</span>"	Pertaining to a group of taxa that consists of a common ancestor and some, but not all, of its descendants.
Pertaining to a group of taxa that consists of a common ancestor and some, but not all, of its descendants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">paraphyletic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">PhyloCode</span>"	System of classification of organisms based on evolutionary relationships: Only groups that include a common ancestor and all of its descendents are named.
System of classification of organisms based on evolutionary relationships: Only groups that include a common ancestor and all of its descendents are named.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">PhyloCode</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylogenetic bracketing</span>"	An approach in which features shared by two groups of organisms are predicted (by parsimony) to be present in their common ancestor and all of its descendants.
An approach in which features shared by two groups of organisms are predicted (by parsimony) to be present in their common ancestor and all of its descendants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylogenetic bracketing</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylogeny</span>"	The evolutionary history of a species or group of related species.
The evolutionary history of a species or group of related species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylogeny</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylum</span>"	In classification, the taxonomic category above class.
In classification, the taxonomic category above class.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phylum</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Plantae</span>"	The kingdom that consists of multicellular eukaryotes that carry out photosynthesis.
The kingdom that consists of multicellular eukaryotes that carry out photosynthesis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Plantae</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyphyletic</span>"	Pertaining to a group of taxa derived from two or more different ancestors.
Pertaining to a group of taxa derived from two or more different ancestors.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polyphyletic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polytomy</span>"	In a phylogenetic tree, a branch point from which more than two descendant taxa emerge. A [this] indicates that the evolutionary relationships among the descendant taxa are not yet clear.
In a phylogenetic tree, a branch point from which more than two descendant taxa emerge. A [this] indicates that the evolutionary relationships among the descendant taxa are not yet clear.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">polytomy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">rooted</span>"	Describing a phylogenetic tree that contains a branch point (typically, the one farthest to the left) representing the last common ancestor of all taxa in the tree.
Describing a phylogenetic tree that contains a branch point (typically, the one farthest to the left) representing the last common ancestor of all taxa in the tree.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">rooted</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">shared ancestral character</span>"	A character, shared by members of a particular clade, that originated in an ancestor that is not a member of that clade.
A character, shared by members of a particular clade, that originated in an ancestor that is not a member of that clade.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">shared ancestral character</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">shared derived character</span>"	An evolutionary novelty that is unique to a particular clade.
An evolutionary novelty that is unique to a particular clade.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">shared derived character</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sister taxa</span>"	Groups of organisms that share an immediate common ancestor and hence are each other’s closest relatives.
Groups of organisms that share an immediate common ancestor and hence are each other’s closest relatives.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sister taxa</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">systematics</span>"	A scientific discipline focused on classifying organisms and determining their evolutionary relationships.
A scientific discipline focused on classifying organisms and determining their evolutionary relationships.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">systematics</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">taxon</span>"	A named taxonomic unit at any given level of classification.
A named taxonomic unit at any given level of classification.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">taxon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">taxonomy</span>"	A scientific discipline concerned with naming and classifying the diverse forms of life.
A scientific discipline concerned with naming and classifying the diverse forms of life.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">taxonomy</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bioremediation</span>"	The use of organisms to detoxify and restore polluted and degraded ecosystems.
The use of organisms to detoxify and restore polluted and degraded ecosystems.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bioremediation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemoautotroph</span>"	An organism that needs only carbon dioxide as a carbon source but obtains energy by oxidizing inorganic substances.
An organism that needs only carbon dioxide as a carbon source but obtains energy by oxidizing inorganic substances.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemoautotroph</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemoheterotroph</span>"	An organism that must consume organic molecules for both energy and carbon.
An organism that must consume organic molecules for both energy and carbon.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">chemoheterotroph</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">conjugation</span>"	In prokaryotes, the direct transfer of DNA between two cells (of the same or different species) that are temporarily joined. In ciliates, a sexual process in which two cells exchange haploid micronuclei.
In prokaryotes, the direct transfer of DNA between two cells (of the same or different species) that are temporarily joined. In ciliates, a sexual process in which two cells exchange haploid micronuclei.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">conjugation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endospore</span>"	A thick-coated, resistant cell produced by a bacterial cell exposed to harsh conditions.
A thick-coated, resistant cell produced by a bacterial cell exposed to harsh conditions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endospore</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endotoxin</span>"	A toxic component of the outer membrane of certain gram-negative bacteria that is released only when the bacteria die.
A toxic component of the outer membrane of certain gram-negative bacteria that is released only when the bacteria die.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endotoxin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exotoxin</span>"	A toxic protein that is secreted by a prokaryote or other pathogen and that produces specific symptoms, even if the pathogen is no longer present.
A toxic protein that is secreted by a prokaryote or other pathogen and that produces specific symptoms, even if the pathogen is no longer present.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">exotoxin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extreme halophile</span>"	An organism that lives in a highly saline environment, such as the Great Salt Lake or the Dead Sea.
An organism that lives in a highly saline environment, such as the Great Salt Lake or the Dead Sea.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extreme halophile</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extreme thermophile</span>"	An organism that thrives in hot environments (often 60–80°C or hotter).
An organism that thrives in hot environments (often 60–80°C or hotter).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extreme thermophile</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extremophile</span>"	An organism that lives in an environment whose conditions are so extreme that few other species can survive there. [These] include extreme halophiles and extreme thermophiles.
An organism that lives in an environment whose conditions are so extreme that few other species can survive there. [These] include extreme halophiles and extreme thermophiles.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extremophile</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">F factor</span>"	In bacteria, the DNA segment that confers the ability to form pili for conjugation and associated functions required for the transfer of DNA from donor to recipient. [This] may exist as a plasmid or be integrated into the bacterial chromosome.
In bacteria, the DNA segment that confers the ability to form pili for conjugation and associated functions required for the transfer of DNA from donor to recipient. [This] may exist as a plasmid or be integrated into the bacterial chromosome.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">F factor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">F plasmid</span>"	The plasmid form of the F factor.
The plasmid form of the F factor.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">F plasmid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fimbria</span>"	A short, hairlike appendage of a prokaryotic cell that helps it adhere to the substrate or to other cells; also known as an attachment pilus.
A short, hairlike appendage of a prokaryotic cell that helps it adhere to the substrate or to other cells; also known as an attachment pilus.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fimbria</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Gram stain</span>"	A staining method that distinguishes between two different kinds of bacterial cell walls.
A staining method that distinguishes between two different kinds of bacterial cell walls.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Gram stain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gram-negative</span>"	Describing the group of bacteria that have a cell wall that is structurally more complex and contains less peptidoglycan than the cell wall of gram-positive bacteria. [This] bacteria are often more toxic than gram-positive bacteria.
Describing the group of bacteria that have a cell wall that is structurally more complex and contains less peptidoglycan than the cell wall of gram-positive bacteria. [This] bacteria are often more toxic than gram-positive bacteria.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gram-negative</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gram-positive</span>"	Describing the group of bacteria that have a cell wall that is structurally less complex and contains more peptidoglycan than the cell wall of gram-negative bacteria. [This] bacteria are usually less toxic than gram-negative bacteria.
Describing the group of bacteria that have a cell wall that is structurally less complex and contains more peptidoglycan than the cell wall of gram-negative bacteria. [This] bacteria are usually less toxic than gram-negative bacteria.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gram-positive</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterocyte</span>"	A specialized cell that engages in nitrogen fixation in some filamentous cyanobacteria; formerly called heterocyst.
A specialized cell that engages in nitrogen fixation in some filamentous cyanobacteria; formerly called heterocyst.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterocyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">methanogen</span>"	An organism that obtains energy by using carbon dioxide to oxidize hydrogen, producing methane as a waste product; all known [these] are in domain Archaea.
An organism that obtains energy by using carbon dioxide to oxidize hydrogen, producing methane as a waste product; all known [these] are in domain Archaea.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">methanogen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mutualism</span>"	A symbiotic relationship in which both participants benefit.
A symbiotic relationship in which both participants benefit.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mutualism</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nitrogen fixation</span>"	The conversion of atmospheric nitrogen (N2) to ammonia (NH3). Biological [this] is carried out by certain prokaryotes, some of which have mutualistic relationships with plants.
The conversion of atmospheric nitrogen (N2) to ammonia (NH3). Biological [this] is carried out by certain prokaryotes, some of which have mutualistic relationships with plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">nitrogen fixation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">obligate aerobe</span>"	An organism that requires oxygen for cellular respiration and cannot live without it.
An organism that requires oxygen for cellular respiration and cannot live without it.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">obligate aerobe</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peptidoglycan</span>"	A type of polymer in bacterial cell walls consisting of modified sugars cross-linked by short polypeptides.
