A type of polymer in bacterial cell walls consisting of modified sugars cross-linked by short polypeptides.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peptidoglycan</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photoheterotroph</span>"	An organism that uses light to generate ATP but must obtain carbon in organic form.
An organism that uses light to generate ATP but must obtain carbon in organic form.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">photoheterotroph</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">R plasmid</span>"	A bacterial plasmid carrying genes that confer resistance to certain antibiotics.
A bacterial plasmid carrying genes that confer resistance to certain antibiotics.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">R plasmid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">symbiont</span>"	The smaller participant in a symbiotic relationship, living in or on the host.
The smaller participant in a symbiotic relationship, living in or on the host.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">symbiont</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alveolate</span>"	A protist with membrane-bounded sacs (alveoli) located just under the plasma membrane.
A protist with membrane-bounded sacs (alveoli) located just under the plasma membrane.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alveolate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amoebozoan</span>"	A protist in a clade that includes many species with lobe- or tube-shaped pseudopodia.
A protist in a clade that includes many species with lobe- or tube-shaped pseudopodia.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amoebozoan</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apicomplexan</span>"	A protist in a clade that includes many species that parasitize animals. Some [these] cause human disease.
A protist in a clade that includes many species that parasitize animals. Some [these] cause human disease.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">apicomplexan</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Archaeplastida</span>"	One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes. This monophyletic group, which includes red algae, green algae, and land plants, descended from an ancient protist ancestor that engulfed a cyanobacterium. See also Excavata, Chromalveolata, Rhizaria, and Unikonta.
One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes. This monophyletic group, which includes red algae, green algae, and land plants, descended from an ancient protist ancestor that engulfed a cyanobacterium. See also Excavata, Chromalveolata, Rhizaria, and Unikonta.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Archaeplastida</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">brown alga</span>"	A multicellular, photosynthetic protist with a characteristic brown or olive color that results from carotenoids in its plastids. Most [these] are marine, and some have a plantlike body (thallus).
A multicellular, photosynthetic protist with a characteristic brown or olive color that results from carotenoids in its plastids. Most [these] are marine, and some have a plantlike body (thallus).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">brown alga</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cellular slime mold</span>"	A type of protist that has unicellular amoeboid cells and aggregated reproductive bodies in its life cycle.
A type of protist that has unicellular amoeboid cells and aggregated reproductive bodies in its life cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cellular slime mold</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Chromalveolata</span>"	One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes. [These] may have originated by secondary endosymbiosis and include two large protist clades, the alveolates and the stramenopiles. See also Excavata, Rhizaria, Archaeplastida, and Unikonta.
One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes. [These] may have originated by secondary endosymbiosis and include two large protist clades, the alveolates and the stramenopiles. See also Excavata, Rhizaria, Archaeplastida, and Unikonta.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Chromalveolata</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ciliate</span>"	A type of protist that moves by means of cilia.
A type of protist that moves by means of cilia.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ciliate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diatom</span>"	A unicellular photosynthetic alga with a unique glassy cell wall containing silica.
A unicellular photosynthetic alga with a unique glassy cell wall containing silica.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diatom</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dinoflagellate</span>"	Member of a group of mostly unicellular photosynthetic algae with two flagella situated in perpendicular grooves in cellulose plates covering the cell.
Member of a group of mostly unicellular photosynthetic algae with two flagella situated in perpendicular grooves in cellulose plates covering the cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dinoflagellate</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diplomonad</span>"	A protist that has modified mitochondria, two equal-sized nuclei, and multiple flagella.
A protist that has modified mitochondria, two equal-sized nuclei, and multiple flagella.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diplomonad</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">euglenid</span>"	A protist, such as Euglena or its relatives, characterized by an anterior pocket from which one or two flagella emerge.
A protist, such as Euglena or its relatives, characterized by an anterior pocket from which one or two flagella emerge.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">euglenid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">euglenozoan</span>"	Member of a diverse clade of flagellated protists that includes predatory heterotrophs, photosynthetic autotrophs, and pathogenic parasites.
Member of a diverse clade of flagellated protists that includes predatory heterotrophs, photosynthetic autotrophs, and pathogenic parasites.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">euglenozoan</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Excavata</span>"	One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes. [This] members have unique cytoskeletal features, and some species have an “excavated” feeding groove on one side of the cell body. See also Chromalveolata, Rhizaria, Archaeplastida, and Unikonta.
One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes. [This] members have unique cytoskeletal features, and some species have an “excavated” feeding groove on one side of the cell body. See also Chromalveolata, Rhizaria, Archaeplastida, and Unikonta.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Excavata</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">foram (foraminiferan)</span>"	An aquatic protist that secretes a hardened shell containing calcium carbonate and extends pseudopodia through pores in the shell.
An aquatic protist that secretes a hardened shell containing calcium carbonate and extends pseudopodia through pores in the shell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">foram (foraminiferan)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">golden alga</span>"	A biflagellated, photosynthetic protist named for its color, which results from its yellow and brown carotenoids.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heteromorphic</span>"	Referring to a condition in the life cycle of plants and certain algae in which the sporophyte and gametophyte generations differ in morphology.
Referring to a condition in the life cycle of plants and certain algae in which the sporophyte and gametophyte generations differ in morphology.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heteromorphic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">holdfast</span>"	A rootlike structure that anchors a seaweed.
A rootlike structure that anchors a seaweed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">holdfast</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">isomorphic</span>"	Referring to alternating generations in plants and certain algae in which the sporophytes and gametophytes look alike, although they differ in chromosome number.
Referring to alternating generations in plants and certain algae in which the sporophytes and gametophytes look alike, although they differ in chromosome number.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">isomorphic</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kinetoplastid</span>"	A protist, such as a trypanosome, that has a single large mitochondrion that houses an organized mass of DNA.
A protist, such as a trypanosome, that has a single large mitochondrion that houses an organized mass of DNA.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">kinetoplastid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mixotroph</span>"	An organism that is capable of both photosynthesis and heterotrophy.
An organism that is capable of both photosynthesis and heterotrophy.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mixotroph</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oomycete</span>"	A protist with flagellated cells, such as a water mold, white rust, or downy mildew, that acquires nutrition mainly as a decomposer or plant parasite.
A protist with flagellated cells, such as a water mold, white rust, or downy mildew, that acquires nutrition mainly as a decomposer or plant parasite.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">oomycete</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">opisthokont</span>"	Member of the diverse clade Opisthokonta, organisms that descended from an ancestor with a posterior flagellum, including fungi, animals, and certain protists.
Member of the diverse clade Opisthokonta, organisms that descended from an ancestor with a posterior flagellum, including fungi, animals, and certain protists.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">opisthokont</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parabasalid</span>"	A protist, such as a trichomonad, with modified mitochondria.
A protist, such as a trichomonad, with modified mitochondria.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">parabasalid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmodial slime mold</span>"	A type of protist that has amoeboid cells, flagellated cells, and a plasmodial feeding stage in its life cycle.
A type of protist that has amoeboid cells, flagellated cells, and a plasmodial feeding stage in its life cycle.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmodial slime mold</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmodium</span>"	A single mass of cytoplasm containing many diploid nuclei that forms during the life cycle of some slime molds.
A single mass of cytoplasm containing many diploid nuclei that forms during the life cycle of some slime molds.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">plasmodium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protist</span>"	An informal term applied to any eukaryote that is not a plant, animal, or fungus. Most [these] are unicellular, though some are colonial or multicellular.
An informal term applied to any eukaryote that is not a plant, animal, or fungus. Most [these] are unicellular, though some are colonial or multicellular.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protist</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radiolarian</span>"	A protist, usually marine, with a shell generally made of silica and pseudopodia that radiate from the central body.
A protist, usually marine, with a shell generally made of silica and pseudopodia that radiate from the central body.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radiolarian</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">red alga</span>"	A photosynthetic protist, named for its color, which results from a red pigment that masks the green of chlorophyll. Most [these] are multicellular and marine.
A photosynthetic protist, named for its color, which results from a red pigment that masks the green of chlorophyll. Most [these] are multicellular and marine.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">red alga</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">redox reaction</span>"	A chemical reaction involving the complete or partial transfer of one or more electrons from one reactant to another; short for oxidation-reduction reaction.
A chemical reaction involving the complete or partial transfer of one or more electrons from one reactant to another; short for oxidation-reduction reaction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">redox reaction</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Rhizaria</span>"	One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes; a morphologically diverse protist clade that is defined by DNA similarities. See also Excavata, Chromalveolata, Archaeplastida, and Unikonta.
One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes; a morphologically diverse protist clade that is defined by DNA similarities. See also Excavata, Chromalveolata, Archaeplastida, and Unikonta.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Rhizaria</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary endosymbiosis</span>"	A process in eukaryotic evolution in which a heterotrophic eukaryotic cell engulfed a photosynthetic eukaryotic cell, which survived in a symbiotic relationship inside the heterotrophic cell.
A process in eukaryotic evolution in which a heterotrophic eukaryotic cell engulfed a photosynthetic eukaryotic cell, which survived in a symbiotic relationship inside the heterotrophic cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">secondary endosymbiosis</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stipe</span>"	A stemlike structure of a seaweed.
A stemlike structure of a seaweed.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stipe</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stramenopile</span>"	A protist in which a “hairy” flagellum (one covered with fine, hairlike projections) is paired with a shorter, smooth flagellum.
A protist in which a “hairy” flagellum (one covered with fine, hairlike projections) is paired with a shorter, smooth flagellum.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stramenopile</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thallus</span>"	A seaweed body that is plantlike, consisting of a holdfast, stipe, and blades, yet lacks true roots, stems, and leaves.
A seaweed body that is plantlike, consisting of a holdfast, stipe, and blades, yet lacks true roots, stems, and leaves.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thallus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Unikonta</span>"	One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes. This clade, which is supported by studies of myosin proteins and DNA, consists of amoebozoans and opisthokonts. See also Excavata, Chromalveolata, Rhizaria, and Archaeplastida.
One of five supergroups of eukaryotes proposed in a current hypothesis of the evolutionary history of eukaryotes. This clade, which is supported by studies of myosin proteins and DNA, consists of amoebozoans and opisthokonts. See also Excavata, Chromalveolata, Rhizaria, and Archaeplastida.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Unikonta</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">angiosperm</span>"	A flowering plant, which forms seeds inside a protective chamber called an ovary.
A flowering plant, which forms seeds inside a protective chamber called an ovary.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">angiosperm</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antheridium</span>"	In plants, the male gametangium, a moist chamber in which gametes develop.
In plants, the male gametangium, a moist chamber in which gametes develop.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">antheridium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">archegonium</span>"	In plants, the female gametangium, a moist chamber in which gametes develop.
In plants, the female gametangium, a moist chamber in which gametes develop.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">archegonium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bryophyte</span>"	An informal name for a moss, liverwort, or hornwort; a nonvascular plant that lives on land but lacks some of the terrestrial adaptations of vascular plants.
An informal name for a moss, liverwort, or hornwort; a nonvascular plant that lives on land but lacks some of the terrestrial adaptations of vascular plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bryophyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">embryophyte</span>"	Alternate name for land plants that refers to their shared derived trait of multicellular, dependent embryos.
Alternate name for land plants that refers to their shared derived trait of multicellular, dependent embryos.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">embryophyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">foot</span>"	(1) The portion of a bryophyte sporophyte that gathers sugars, amino acids, water, and minerals from the parent gametophyte via transfer cells. (2) One of the three main parts of a mollusc; a muscular structure usually used for movement. See also mantle, visceral mass.
(1) The portion of a bryophyte sporophyte that gathers sugars, amino acids, water, and minerals from the parent gametophyte via transfer cells. (2) One of the three main parts of a mollusc; a muscular structure usually used for movement. See also mantle, visceral mass.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">foot</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gametangium</span>"	Multicellular plant structure in which gametes are formed. Female [these] are called archegonia, and male [these] are called antheridia.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">grade</span>"	A group of organisms that share the same level of organizational complexity or share a key adaptation.
A group of organisms that share the same level of organizational complexity or share a key adaptation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">grade</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">gymnosperm</span>"	A vascular plant that bears naked seeds—seeds not enclosed in specialized chambers.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterosporous</span>"	Referring to a plant species that has two kinds of spores: microspores, which develop into male gametophytes, and megaspores, which develop into female gametophytes.
Referring to a plant species that has two kinds of spores: microspores, which develop into male gametophytes, and megaspores, which develop into female gametophytes.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heterosporous</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homosporous</span>"	Referring to a plant species that has a single kind of spore, which typically develops into a bisexual gametophyte.
Referring to a plant species that has a single kind of spore, which typically develops into a bisexual gametophyte.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">homosporous</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hornwort</span>"	A small, herbaceous nonvascular plant that is a member of the phylum Anthocerophyta.
A small, herbaceous nonvascular plant that is a member of the phylum Anthocerophyta.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hornwort</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lignin</span>"	A hard material embedded in the cellulose matrix of vascular plant cell walls that provides structural support in terrestrial species.
A hard material embedded in the cellulose matrix of vascular plant cell walls that provides structural support in terrestrial species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lignin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">liverwort</span>"	A small, herbaceous nonvascular plant that is a member of the phylum Hepatophyta.
A small, herbaceous nonvascular plant that is a member of the phylum Hepatophyta.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">liverwort</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lycophyte</span>"	An informal name for a member of the phylum Lycophyta, which includes club mosses, spike mosses, and quillworts.
An informal name for a member of the phylum Lycophyta, which includes club mosses, spike mosses, and quillworts.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">lycophyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">megaphyll</span>"	A leaf with a highly branched vascular system, characteristic of the vast majority of vascular plants.
A leaf with a highly branched vascular system, characteristic of the vast majority of vascular plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">megaphyll</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">megaspore</span>"	A spore from a heterosporous plant species that develops into a female gametophyte.
A spore from a heterosporous plant species that develops into a female gametophyte.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">megaspore</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microphyll</span>"	In lycophytes, a small leaf with a single unbranched vein.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microspore</span>"	A spore from a heterosporous plant species that develops into a male gametophyte.
A spore from a heterosporous plant species that develops into a male gametophyte.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">microspore</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">moss</span>"	A small, herbaceous nonvascular plant that is a member of the phylum Bryophyta.
A small, herbaceous nonvascular plant that is a member of the phylum Bryophyta.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">moss</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">mycorrhiza</span>"	A mutualistic association of plant roots and fungus.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peat</span>"	Extensive deposits of partially decayed organic material formed primarily from the wetland moss Sphagnum.
Extensive deposits of partially decayed organic material formed primarily from the wetland moss Sphagnum.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peat</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peristome</span>"	A ring of interlocking, tooth-like structures on the upper part of a moss capsule (sporangium), often specialized for gradual spore discharge.
A ring of interlocking, tooth-like structures on the upper part of a moss capsule (sporangium), often specialized for gradual spore discharge.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">peristome</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phragmoplast</span>"	An alignment of cytoskeletal elements and Golgi-derived vesicles that forms across the midline of a dividing plant cell.
An alignment of cytoskeletal elements and Golgi-derived vesicles that forms across the midline of a dividing plant cell.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">phragmoplast</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">placental transfer cell</span>"	A plant cell that enhances the transfer of nutrients from parent to embryo.
A plant cell that enhances the transfer of nutrients from parent to embryo.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">placental transfer cell</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protonema</span>"	A mass of green, branched, one-cell-thick filaments produced by germinating moss spores.
A mass of green, branched, one-cell-thick filaments produced by germinating moss spores.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">protonema</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pterophyte</span>"	An informal name for a member of the phylum Pterophyta, which includes ferns, horsetails, and whisk ferns and their relatives.
An informal name for a member of the phylum Pterophyta, which includes ferns, horsetails, and whisk ferns and their relatives.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pterophyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">rhizoid</span>"	A long, tubular single cell or filament of cells that anchors bryophytes to the ground. Unlike roots, [these] are not composed of tissues, lack specialized conducting cells, and do not play a primary role in water and mineral absorption.
A long, tubular single cell or filament of cells that anchors bryophytes to the ground. Unlike roots, [these] are not composed of tissues, lack specialized conducting cells, and do not play a primary role in water and mineral absorption.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">rhizoid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">seed</span>"	An adaptation of some terrestrial plants consisting of an embryo packaged along with a store of food within a protective coat.
An adaptation of some terrestrial plants consisting of an embryo packaged along with a store of food within a protective coat.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">seed</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">seedless vascular plant</span>"	An informal name for a plant that has vascular tissue but lacks seeds. [These] form a paraphyletic group that includes the phyla Lycophyta (club mosses and their relatives) and Pterophyta (ferns and their relatives).
An informal name for a plant that has vascular tissue but lacks seeds. [These] form a paraphyletic group that includes the phyla Lycophyta (club mosses and their relatives) and Pterophyta (ferns and their relatives).	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">seedless vascular plant</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sorus</span>"	A cluster of sporangia on a fern sporophyll. [These] may be arranged in various patterns, such as parallel lines or dots, which are useful in fern identification.
A cluster of sporangia on a fern sporophyll. [These] may be arranged in various patterns, such as parallel lines or dots, which are useful in fern identification.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sorus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporangium</span>"	A multicellular organ in fungi and plants in which meiosis occurs and haploid cells develop.
A multicellular organ in fungi and plants in which meiosis occurs and haploid cells develop.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporangium</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporocyte</span>"	A diploid cell, also known as a spore mother cell, that undergoes meiosis and generates haploid spores.
A diploid cell, also known as a spore mother cell, that undergoes meiosis and generates haploid spores.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporocyte</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporophyll</span>"	A modified leaf that bears sporangia and hence is specialized for reproduction.
A modified leaf that bears sporangia and hence is specialized for reproduction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporophyll</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporopollenin</span>"	A durable polymer that covers exposed zygotes of charophyte algae and forms the walls of plant spores, preventing them from drying out.
A durable polymer that covers exposed zygotes of charophyte algae and forms the walls of plant spores, preventing them from drying out.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sporopollenin</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">strobilus</span>"	The technical term for a cluster of sporophylls known commonly as a cone, found in most gymnosperms and some seedless vascular plants.
The technical term for a cluster of sporophylls known commonly as a cone, found in most gymnosperms and some seedless vascular plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">strobilus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vascular plant</span>"	A plant with vascular tissue. [These] include all living plant species except mosses, liverworts, and hornworts.
A plant with vascular tissue. [These] include all living plant species except mosses, liverworts, and hornworts.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">vascular plant</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">alimentary canal</span>"	A digestive tract consisting of a tube running between a mouth and an anus; also called a complete digestive tract.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">amylase</span>"	An enzyme in saliva that hydrolyzes starch (a glucose polymer from plants) and glycogen (a glucose polymer from animals) into smaller polysaccharides and the disaccharide maltose.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bile</span>"	A mixture of substances that is produced in the liver but stored in the gallbladder and that enables formation of fat droplets in water as an aid in the digestion and absorption of fats.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heart</span>"	A muscular pump that uses metabolic energy to elevate the hydrostatic pressure of the circulatory fluid (blood or hemolymph). The fluid then flows down a pressure gradient through the body and eventually returns to the [this].
A muscular pump that uses metabolic energy to elevate the hydrostatic pressure of the circulatory fluid (blood or hemolymph). The fluid then flows down a pressure gradient through the body and eventually returns to the [this].	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heart</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hydrostatic skeleton</span>"	A skeletal system composed of fluid held under pressure in a closed body compartment; the main skeleton of most cnidarians, flatworms, nematodes, and annelids.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">inner ear</span>"	One of three main regions of the vertebrate ear; includes the cochlea (which in turn contains the organ of Corti) and the semicircular canals.

The intensity of the [this] determines the frequency of action potentials traveling to the nervous system.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sliding-filament model</span>"	The theory explaining how muscle contracts, based on change within a sarcomere, the basic unit of muscle organization. According to this model, thin (actin) filaments slide across thick (myosin) filaments, shortening the sarcomere. The shortening of all sarcomeres in a myofibril shortens the entire myofibril.
The theory explaining how muscle contracts, based on change within a sarcomere, the basic unit of muscle organization. According to this model, thin (actin) filaments slide across thick (myosin) filaments, shortening the sarcomere. The shortening of all sarcomeres in a myofibril shortens the entire myofibril.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sliding-filament model</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">slow-twitch fiber</span>"	A muscle fiber that can sustain long contractions.
A muscle fiber that can sustain long contractions.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">slow-twitch fiber</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">smooth muscle</span>"	A type of muscle lacking the striations of skeletal and cardiac muscle because of the uniform distribution of myosin filaments in the cell; responsible for involuntary body activities.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">statolith</span>"	(1) In plants, a specialized plastid that contains dense starch grains and may play a role in detecting gravity. (2) In invertebrates, a grain or other dense granule that settles in response to gravity and is found in sensory organs that function in equilibrium.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">thin filament</span>"	A filament consisting of two strands of actin and two strands of regulatory protein coiled around one another; a component of myofibrils in muscle fibers.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atrioventricular (AV) node</span>"	A region of specialized heart muscle tissue between the left and right atria where electrical impulses are delayed for about 0.1 second before spreading to both ventricles and causing them to contract.
A region of specialized heart muscle tissue between the left and right atria where electrical impulses are delayed for about 0.1 second before spreading to both ventricles and causing them to contract.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atrioventricular (AV) node</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atrioventricular (AV) valve</span>"	A heart valve located between each atrium and ventricle that prevents a backflow of blood when the ventricle contracts.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">atrium</span>"	A chamber of the vertebrate heart that receives blood from the veins and transfers blood to a ventricle.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Bohr shift</span>"	A lowering of the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, caused by a drop in pH. It facilitates the release of oxygen from hemoglobin in the vicinity of active tissues.
A lowering of the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, caused by a drop in pH. It facilitates the release of oxygen from hemoglobin in the vicinity of active tissues.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">Bohr shift</span>"

Ventilation of the lungs through alternating inhalation and exhalation.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">breathing</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">breathing control center</span>"	A brain center that directs the activity of organs involved in breathing.
A brain center that directs the activity of organs involved in breathing.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">breathing control center</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bronchiole</span>"	A fine branch of the bronchi that transports air to alveoli.
A fine branch of the bronchi that transports air to alveoli.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bronchiole</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bronchus</span>"	One of a pair of breathing tubes that branch from the trachea into the lungs.
One of a pair of breathing tubes that branch from the trachea into the lungs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">bronchus</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">capillary</span>"	A microscopic blood vessel that penetrates the tissues and consists of a single layer of endothelial cells that allows exchange between the blood and interstitial fluid.
A microscopic blood vessel that penetrates the tissues and consists of a single layer of endothelial cells that allows exchange between the blood and interstitial fluid.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">capillary</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">capillary bed</span>"	A network of capillaries in a tissue or organ.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cardiac cycle</span>"	The alternating contractions and relaxations of the heart.
The alternating contractions and relaxations of the heart.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cardiac cycle</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cardiac output</span>"	The volume of blood pumped per minute by each ventricle of the heart.
The volume of blood pumped per minute by each ventricle of the heart.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cardiac output</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cardiovascular system</span>"	A closed circulatory system with a heart and branching network of arteries, capillaries, and veins. The system is characteristic of vertebrates.
A closed circulatory system with a heart and branching network of arteries, capillaries, and veins. The system is characteristic of vertebrates.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cardiovascular system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">closed circulatory system</span>"	A circulatory system in which blood is confined to vessels and is kept separate from the interstitial fluid.
A circulatory system in which blood is confined to vessels and is kept separate from the interstitial fluid.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">closed circulatory system</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diaphragm</span>"	(1) A sheet of muscle that forms the bottom wall of the thoracic cavity in mammals. Contraction of the [this] pulls air into the lungs. (2) A dome-shaped rubber cup fitted into the upper portion of the vagina before sexual intercourse. It serves as a physical barrier to the passage of sperm into the uterus.
(1) A sheet of muscle that forms the bottom wall of the thoracic cavity in mammals. Contraction of the [this] pulls air into the lungs. (2) A dome-shaped rubber cup fitted into the upper portion of the vagina before sexual intercourse. It serves as a physical barrier to the passage of sperm into the uterus. "<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">diastole</span>"	The stage of the cardiac cycle in which a heart chamber is relaxed and fills with blood.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">double circulation</span>"	A circulatory system consisting of separate pulmonary and systemic circuits, in which blood passes through the heart after completing each circuit.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endothelin</span>"	A peptide produced by a blood vessel’s endothelium that causes the vessel to constrict.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">erythropoietin (EPO)</span>"	A hormone that stimulates the production of erythrocytes. It is secreted by the kidney when body tissues do not receive enough oxygen.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">heart murmur</span>"	A hissing sound that most often results from blood squirting backward through a leaky valve in the heart.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">high-density lipoprotein (HDL)</span>"	A particle in the blood made up of cholesterol and other lipids surrounded by a single layer of phospholipids in which proteins are embedded. [This] carries less cholesterol than a related lipoprotein, LDL, and high [this] levels in the blood may be correlated with a decreased risk of blood vessel blockage.
A particle in the blood made up of cholesterol and other lipids surrounded by a single layer of phospholipids in which proteins are embedded. [This] carries less cholesterol than a related lipoprotein, LDL, and high [this] levels in the blood may be correlated with a decreased risk of blood vessel blockage. "<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fragmentation</span>"	A means of asexual reproduction whereby a single parent breaks into parts that regenerate into whole new individuals.
A means of asexual reproduction whereby a single parent breaks into parts that regenerate into whole new individuals.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fragmentation</span>"

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">hermaphroditism</span>"	A condition in which an individual has both female and male gonads and functions as both a male and female in sexual reproduction by producing both sperm and eggs.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ovary</span>"	(1) In flowers, the portion of a carpel in which the egg-containing ovules develop. (2) In animals, the structure that produces female gametes and reproductive hormones.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biodiversity hot spot</span>"	A relatively small area with an exceptional concentration of endemic species and often a large number of endangered and threatened species.

"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biological augmentation</span>"	An approach to restoration ecology that uses organisms to add essential materials to a degraded ecosystem.
An approach to restoration ecology that uses organisms to add essential materials to a degraded ecosystem.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">biological augmentation</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">conservation biology</span>"	The integrated study of ecology, evolutionary biology, physiology, molecular biology, and genetics to sustain biological diversity at all levels.
The integrated study of ecology, evolutionary biology, physiology, molecular biology, and genetics to sustain biological diversity at all levels.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">conservation biology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecosystem service</span>"	A function performed by an ecosystem that directly or indirectly benefits humans.
A function performed by an ecosystem that directly or indirectly benefits humans.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ecosystem service</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">effective population size</span>"	An estimate of the size of a population based on the numbers of females and males that successfully breed; generally smaller than the total population.
An estimate of the size of a population based on the numbers of females and males that successfully breed; generally smaller than the total population.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">effective population size</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endangered species</span>"	A species that is in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.
A species that is in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endangered species</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extinction vortex</span>"	A downward population spiral in which inbreeding and genetic drift combine to cause a small population to shrink and, unless the spiral is reversed, to become extinct.
A downward population spiral in which inbreeding and genetic drift combine to cause a small population to shrink and, unless the spiral is reversed, to become extinct.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">extinction vortex</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">introduced species</span>"	A species moved by humans, either intentionally or accidentally, from its native location to a new geographic region; also called non-native or exotic species.
A species moved by humans, either intentionally or accidentally, from its native location to a new geographic region; also called non-native or exotic species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">introduced species</span>"

An area containing several different ecosystems linked by exchanges of energy, materials, and organisms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">landscape</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">minimum viable population (MVP)</span>"	The smallest population size at which a species is able to sustain its numbers and survive.
The smallest population size at which a species is able to sustain its numbers and survive.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">minimum viable population (MVP)</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">movement corridor</span>"	A series of small clumps or a narrow strip of quality habitat (usable by organisms) that connects otherwise isolated patches of quality habitat.
A series of small clumps or a narrow strip of quality habitat (usable by organisms) that connects otherwise isolated patches of quality habitat.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">movement corridor</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restoration ecology</span>"	Applying ecological principles in an effort to return ecosystems that have been disturbed by human activity to a condition as similar as possible to their natural state.
Applying ecological principles in an effort to return ecosystems that have been disturbed by human activity to a condition as similar as possible to their natural state.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">restoration ecology</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sustainable development</span>"	Development that meets the needs of people today without limiting the ability of future generations to meet their needs.
Development that meets the needs of people today without limiting the ability of future generations to meet their needs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sustainable development</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">threatened species</span>"	A species that is considered likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future.
A species that is considered likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">threatened species</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">zoned reserve</span>"	An extensive region that includes areas relatively undisturbed by humans surrounded by areas that have been changed by human activity and are used for economic gain.
An extensive region that includes areas relatively undisturbed by humans surrounded by areas that have been changed by human activity and are used for economic gain.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">zoned reserve</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">basal angiosperm</span>"	Member of a clade of three early-diverging lineages of flowering plants. Examples are Amborella, water lilies, and star anise and its relatives.
Member of a clade of three early-diverging lineages of flowering plants. Examples are Amborella, water lilies, and star anise and its relatives.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">basal angiosperm</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carpel</span>"	The ovule-producing reproductive organ of a flower, consisting of the stigma, style, and ovary.
The ovule-producing reproductive organ of a flower, consisting of the stigma, style, and ovary.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">carpel</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">conifer</span>"	Member of the largest gymnosperm phylum. Most conifers are cone-bearing trees, such as pines and firs.
Member of the largest gymnosperm phylum. Most conifers are cone-bearing trees, such as pines and firs.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">conifer</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cotyledon</span>"	A seed leaf of an angiosperm embryo. Some species have one cotyledon, others two.
A seed leaf of an angiosperm embryo. Some species have one cotyledon, others two.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cotyledon</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cross-pollination</span>"	in angiosperms, the transfer of pollen from an anther of a flower on one plant to the stigma of a flower on another plant of the same species.
in angiosperms, the transfer of pollen from an anther of a flower on one plant to the stigma of a flower on another plant of the same species.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">cross-pollination</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dicot</span>"	A term traditionally used to refer to flowering plants that have two embryonic seed leaves, or cotyledons. Recent molecular evidence indicates that dicots do not form a clade; species once classified as dicots are now grouped into eudicots, magnoliids, and several lineages of basal angiosperms.
A term traditionally used to refer to flowering plants that have two embryonic seed leaves, or cotyledons. Recent molecular evidence indicates that dicots do not form a clade; species once classified as dicots are now grouped into eudicots, magnoliids, and several lineages of basal angiosperms.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">dicot</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">double fertilization</span>"	A mechanism of fertilization in angiosperms in which two sperm cells unite with two cells in the female gametophyte (embryo sac) to form the zygote and endosperm.
A mechanism of fertilization in angiosperms in which two sperm cells unite with two cells in the female gametophyte (embryo sac) to form the zygote and endosperm.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">double fertilization</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endosperm</span>"	In angiosperms, a nutrient-rich tissue formed by the union of a sperm with two polar nuclei during double fertilization. The endosperm provides nourishment to the developing embryo in angiosperm seeds.
In angiosperms, a nutrient-rich tissue formed by the union of a sperm with two polar nuclei during double fertilization. The endosperm provides nourishment to the developing embryo in angiosperm seeds.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">endosperm</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eudicot</span>"	Member of a clade consisting of the vast majority of flowering plants that have two embryonic seed leaves, or cotyledons.
Member of a clade consisting of the vast majority of flowering plants that have two embryonic seed leaves, or cotyledons.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">eudicot</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">filament</span>"	In an angiosperm, the stalk portion of the stamen, the pollen-producing reproductive organ of a flower.
In an angiosperm, the stalk portion of the stamen, the pollen-producing reproductive organ of a flower.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">filament</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">flower</span>"	In an angiosperm, a short stem with up to four sets of modified leaves, bearing structures that function in sexual reproduction.
In an angiosperm, a short stem with up to four sets of modified leaves, bearing structures that function in sexual reproduction.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">flower</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fruit</span>"	A mature ovary of a flower. The fruit protects dormant seeds and often aids in their dispersal.
A mature ovary of a flower. The fruit protects dormant seeds and often aids in their dispersal.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">fruit</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">indeterminate cleavage</span>"	A type of embryonic development in deuterostomes in which each cell produced by early cleavage divisions retains the capacity to develop into a complete embryo.
A type of embryonic development in deuterostomes in which each cell produced by early cleavage divisions retains the capacity to develop into a complete embryo.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">indeterminate cleavage</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">integument</span>"	Layer of sporophyte tissue that contributes to the structure of an ovule of a seed plant.
Layer of sporophyte tissue that contributes to the structure of an ovule of a seed plant.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">integument</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">magnoliid</span>"	Member of the angiosperm clade most closely related to eudicots. Extant examples are magnolias, laurels, and black pepper plants.
Member of the angiosperm clade most closely related to eudicots. Extant examples are magnolias, laurels, and black pepper plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">magnoliid</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monocot</span>"	Member of a clade consisting of flowering plants that have one embryonic seed leaf, or cotyledon.
Member of a clade consisting of flowering plants that have one embryonic seed leaf, or cotyledon.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">monocot</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ovule</span>"	A structure that develops within the ovary of a seed plant and contains the female gametophyte.
A structure that develops within the ovary of a seed plant and contains the female gametophyte.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">ovule</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">petal</span>"	A modified leaf of a flowering plant. Petals are the often colorful parts of a flower that advertise it to insects and other pollinators.
A modified leaf of a flowering plant. Petals are the often colorful parts of a flower that advertise it to insects and other pollinators.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">petal</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pollen grain</span>"	In seed plants, a structure consisting of the male gametophyte enclosed within a pollen wall.
In seed plants, a structure consisting of the male gametophyte enclosed within a pollen wall.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pollen grain</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pollination</span>"	The transfer of pollen to the part of a seed plant containing the ovules, a process required for fertilization.
The transfer of pollen to the part of a seed plant containing the ovules, a process required for fertilization.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">pollination</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">progymnosperm</span>"	An extinct seedless vascular plant that may be ancestral to seed plants.
An extinct seedless vascular plant that may be ancestral to seed plants.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">progymnosperm</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radial symmetry</span>"	Symmetry in which the body is shaped like a pie or barrel (lacking a left side and a right side) and can be divided into mirror-imaged halves by any plane through its central axis.
Symmetry in which the body is shaped like a pie or barrel (lacking a left side and a right side) and can be divided into mirror-imaged halves by any plane through its central axis.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">radial symmetry</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sepal</span>"	A modified leaf in angiosperms that helps enclose and protect a flower bud before it opens.
A modified leaf in angiosperms that helps enclose and protect a flower bud before it opens.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">sepal</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stamen</span>"	The pollen-producing reproductive organ of a flower, consisting of an anther and a filament.
The pollen-producing reproductive organ of a flower, consisting of an anther and a filament.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stamen</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stigma</span>"	The sticky part of a flower’s carpel, which traps pollen grains.
The sticky part of a flower’s carpel, which traps pollen grains.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">stigma</span>"
"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">style</span>"	The stalk of a flower’s carpel, with the ovary at the base and the stigma at the top.
The stalk of a flower’s carpel, with the ovary at the base and the stigma at the top.	"<span style=""font-size: 35px; 0ff"">style</span>"

life span	the period from birth to natural death of an organism represent its life span. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
organism with no death	unicellular organism <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>
