tortoise	100 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what the reproduction ensures	continuity of species <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
hw many types of reproduction is there	2<div>asexual and sexual</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
speciality of asexual reproduction	clone,similar,unicellular ,single parent <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
type of asexual reproduction	fission,budding,vegetative propagation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for fission	protists and monerans <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
two type of fissio	binary and multiple <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for binary fission	ameoba and paramecium <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for multiple fission	amoeba and plasmodium <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
budding&nbsp;	small bud,mature,detach,new <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for budding	hydra,sponge,yeast <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
other asexual reproductive structure	zoospore,conidia,gemmules <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
zoospores	algae ,protist microscopic motile structure <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
conidia	pencillium <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
gemmules	sponge <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for vegeatative propagules	runner,rhizome,sucker,tuber,offset,bulb <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for vegetative propagation	-from buds of potato,banana,ginger<div>-bud form the notches of bryophyllum</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
juveline &nbsp;phase	the period of growth to reach in maturity for sexual reproduction. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how we can understant the end of vegetative phase	flowering <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
ANNual and binneal plant show ---than perrinial	clear cut vegetative phase reproand senescense <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
unusual floweing	bamboo<div>srobilanthus kunthiana</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
bamboo	flower once in 100-150 yrs lifetime <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
strobilanthus kunthiana flowers	once in 12 years <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the stages to reach reproduction	juveline-physio and morpho chang-repro <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
non primates	cows,sheep,rat,deer,dog,tiger <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primates	monkey,apes,human <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
oestrous and mentrous cycle	the change that undergo in the activities of ovary,accesory duct and glands and hormones <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what happens in the scenesce	concomitant changes occur <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what is responsible for life phase change	hormones <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
events in sexual reproduction	prefertilisation.fertilisation and post fertilisation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
prefertilisation consist of&nbsp;	gametogenesis and gamate transfer <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
homogametes	in some algae all gametes are similar and cant chatagorise into genders <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
heterogamates	the male and female gamtes can be distinguished <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
male and female gamates are called&nbsp;	antherozoids and egg <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for dioecious plants	papaya and date palm <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for monoecious	cucurbits and cocunut <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
homothallic	bisexual <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
heterothallic	unisexual <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
hermaphrodites	bisexual animal <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for bisexual animal	earthworm,leech,sponge,tapeworm <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for unisexual animals	cockroach and higher animals <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for haploid meiocytes	monera,fungi,algae,bryophytes <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for diploid moecyte	pteridophytes,gymnosperm,angiosperm,animals <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
syngamy	the process of fusion of gamates to form zygote. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for parthanogenic animal	rotifers,honeybee,lizard,birds <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
aprthanogenesis	female gamates develops to new organism without fertilisation. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
types of fertilisation	-internal and external <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for external fertilisation	-algae,bony fishes,amphibians <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for internal fertilisation	fungi,animal-reptiles,birds,mammal,plants-bryophyte,pteri,gymn,ang <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what occurs in the process of embryogenesis	division and differentiation of cell <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Cerebrum	With cerebellum, controls all voluntary action; contains cerebral cortex, hippocampus, basal ganglia, and olfactory bulb
Cerebellum	Integrates input from spinal cord and cerebrum to regulate motor activity, as well as some cognitive functions
Medial Cerebral Fissure	Groove between two hemispheres of cerebrum
Olfactory Bulb	Receives and interprets olfactory signals; located on underside of brain
Optic Nerve	Transmits visual information from retina to brain
Optic Chiasma	X-shaped structure where optic nerves cross over each other in order to allow for binocular vision
Infundibular Stalk	Joins hypothalamus and posterior pituitary
Trigeminal Nerve	Transmits sensory information from face and motor instructions to mandible
Pons	Conducts signals from cerebrum to cerebellum and medulla and carries sensory signals to thalamus
Facial Nerve	Controls facial muscles and transmits taste information to brain
Medulla Oblongata	Responsible for autonomic functions
Pineal Body	Endocrine gland that produces melatonin
Pituitary Gland	Endocrine gland that regulates physiological processes&nbsp;
Thalamus	Relays sensory and motor signals to cerebrum, regulates consciousness; between cerebrum and midbrain
Hypothalamus	Links nervous system to endocrine system; above brainstem, below thalamus
Frontal Lobe	Houses motor cortex, prefrontal cortex, and Broca's area
Parietal Lobe	Houses somatosensory cortex and sensory association cortex
Occipital Lobe	Houses visual association cortex and visual cortex
Temporal Lobe	Houses auditory cortex and Wernicke's Area
Motor Cortex	Control of skeletal muscles
Prefrontal Cortex	Decision making, planning
Broca's Area	Forming speech
Auditory Cortex	Hearing
Wernicke's Area	Comprehending language
Visual Cortex	Processing visual stimuli and pattern recognition
Visual Association Cortex	Combining images and object recognition
Sensory Association Cortex	Integration of sensory information
Somatosensory Cortex	Sense of touch
what is ecosystem	an ecosystem is a functional unit of nature ,where living organisms interact among themselves and also with the surrounding physical environment. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Terrestial ecosystem	Forest ,grassland,desert <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Aquatic ecosystem	pond,lake,wetland,river,estuary <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Man made ecosystem	crop fields and aquariums <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
entire biosphere can be regarded as	global ecosystem <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what function as unit in ecosystem	biotic and abiotic <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
stratification	vertical distribution of different species occupyin different &nbsp;levels&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for stratification	trees -top vertical &nbsp;strata&nbsp;<div>shrubs - second</div><div>herbs -bottom layer</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
4 basic components of functioning of an ecosystem	1.productivity&nbsp;<div>2.decomposition</div><div>3.energy flow</div><div>4.nutrient cycle</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Pond	A pond is a shallow ,simple ,self sustained water body that exhibit all basic component of an ecosystem. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Abiotic components in ponds	water and rich soil deposit at the bottom. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Climatic condition that affect the &nbsp;pond ecosystem	solar input ,the cycle of temp,day length <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Autotrophic components of pond	phytoplanktons,algae,floating,submerged and marginal plants <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Consumers of ponds	zooplanktons,free swimming &nbsp;and bottom dwelling forms <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Decomposers of pond	fungi,bacteria ,flagellates <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
pond perform all the ecosytem -	-inorganic to organic in light by autotrophs<div>-heterotrophs consume autotrophs</div><div>-decomposition and mineralisation of dead</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primary production	the amount of biomass or organic matter produced per unit area over a time period by plants during photosynthesis <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
unit of primary production	[sound:rec1453416828.mp3] <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
productivity	the rate of biomass production <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
unit of productivity	[sound:rec1453416870.mp3] <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
two type of productivity	NPP,GPP <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
GPP	gross primary productivity<div>it is the rate of production of organic matter during photosynthesis .A considerable &nbsp;GPP is used by plants</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
NPP	net primary productivity<div>GPP-R(respiration loss)</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
secondary productivity	it is the rate of formation of new organic matter by consumers <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primary productivity depend on&nbsp;	-the plant species inhabiting a particular area.<div>-environmental factor</div><div>-availibilty of nutrients</div><div>-photosynthetic capacity of plants</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
annula net primary productivity	170 billion tons dry weight-70 on surface and 55 bt on ocien <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
decomposition	it is the breakdown of complex organic matter &nbsp;by decomposers into inorganic substances like carbon dioxide and nutrients-oxygen requiring process <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Detritus	dead plant remainingsuch as leaves ,bark,flowers and dead remains of animal,including fecal matter is the raw material for decomposition <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
steps of decomposition	a.fragmentation<div>b.leaching</div><div>c.catabolism</div><div>d.humification</div><div>e.mineralization</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
fragmentation	it is the breakdown of detrirus into smaller particles by detritovores-earthworm <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
leaching&nbsp;	by this process ,water soluble inorganic nutrients go down into the soil horizon and get precipitatedas unavailable salt <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
catabolism	degradation of detritus into simpler inorganic &nbsp;substance by bacterial and fungal enzyme <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
humification	accumulation of humus in soil ,decompose very slowly serves as reserve of nutreients <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
mineralization	it is the releasse of inorganic nutrients dueto the degradation of humus some microbes <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Factors affecting decomposition	-chemical composition of detritus<div>-climatic factors like temp and soil moisture</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Chemical composition of detritus	decomposition rate slow if detritus is rich in lignin and chitin &nbsp;and fst if richin nitrogen and water soluble substances like sugar <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how Climatic facter like temp and soil moisture affect decomposition	warm and mosit environment favour decomposition whereas &nbsp;low temp and anaerobiosis inhibit &nbsp;decomposition resulting in buildinup of organic matter <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the energy source like Sun	deep sea hydro thermal ecosytem <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
PAR	50% of sun is photosynthetically active radiation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
plant capture	2-10 % of PAR <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Ecosystem obey 2nd law of thermodyanamics	they need constand supply of energy to synthesise the molecules they require ,to counteract the universal tendency toward disorderliness <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
producers	all organism depend on producers for their food&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primary producers in aquatic&nbsp;	phytoplankton,algae,higher plant <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what is beginning of detritus food chain	death of the organism <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
a simple grazing foodchain please	grass -goat-man <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
GFC	grazing food chain <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
DFC	begins with dead matters.it is made up of decomposer (saprotrophs) which are heterotrophic organismeg fungi and bacteria <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how decomposers meet energy need	by degrading dead organic matteror detritus&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how decomposr degrade food material	they produce enzyme which breakdown dead and waste material &nbsp;into simple inorganic material ,which are subsequently absorbed &nbsp;by them <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
in aquatic ecosystem which is the major conduit for energy	GFC <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
in a terrestial the major conduit for energy is&nbsp;	DFC <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
trophic level	a specific place of organisms in the natural in the food chain is known as their trophic level. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for 1st trophic level	phytoplanktons,grass ,trees <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
2nd trophic level	zooplanktons ,grasshoper,cow <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
3rd trophic level	birds ,fishes,wolf <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
4th trophic level	man,lion <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
food web	the interconnectionof food chain is called food web <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
standing crop	Each trophic level has a certain mass of living material at aparticular time called standing crop <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how standing crop is measured	as the mass of living organisms or the number &nbsp;in a unit area-biomass of a species is measured in dry weight because it is more accurate <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
why no of trophic level in GFC is restricted&nbsp;	as the transfer of energy follows 10% law&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
10 % law	only 10 % of the energy is transfered to each trophic levels from the lower levels <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Ecological pyramids	the represenaition of a food chain in the form of a &nbsp;pyramid is called ecological pyramid <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
3 types of the ecological pyramids	a.pyramid of number<div>b.pyramid of biomass</div><div>c.pyramid of energy</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
energy at lower levels is&nbsp;	higher than of that of higher level-hrbivorous are more in number than that of carnivorous <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
examples for inverted pyramids	-insects feeding on a big tree<div>-pyramid of biomass in sea is generally inverted because the biomass of fishes far exceeds that of phytoplankton</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how energy is lost	IN the form of heat <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
limitaion of ecological pyramids	-it does take into account thesame species belonging 2 or more trophic level.<div>-it does not accomodate the food web</div><div>-saprophyte are not included in ecological pyramids even though they play a major role</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
ecological succession	it is &nbsp;a gradual ,slow and predictable change in the species composition of an area leading to a climax community <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
climax community	community that is in equilibrium with the environment <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
succession leads	to incerease in number or decline of other species <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
sere	the entire sequence of community that successively &nbsp;change in a given area <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
seral stages or community	the individual transitional community are termed <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
in successive seral stage what occur	change i n the diversity of species ,increase in &nbsp;number and organism and increase in the total biomass <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
succession and evolution are parallel&nbsp;	in earlier times <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
succession is of two types	-primary and secondary <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primary succession	the succession takes place in are where no li ving &nbsp;organism ever existed <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for primary succession	newly cooled lava,bare rocks,newly created pond <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primary succession speed	very slow <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
secondary succession	the succession take place in an area after the existed organism are lost <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg forsecondary succession	abondoned farmland,brned or cut forest,land that have been flooded <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
species that invade depend on the condition	of th e soil,availibility of water <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
in succession ,changes in the vegetation	affect food and shelter &nbsp;of various organism <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
which can convert a particular seral stage of succession to an earlier stage	deforestation and fire by human induced disturbance <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
two types of succession of plant	-Hydrarch<div>-Xerarch</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Hydrarch succession	It takes place in wetter areas.the succession series progress from hydric to the mesic condition. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Xerarch succession	it takes place in dry areas.the series progress from &nbsp;xeric to mesic condition <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
all succesion leads to&nbsp;	medium water condition-mesic <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the species invading a bare area is called	pioneer species <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primary succession on rocks-xerophytic habitat	1.Lichen-secrete acids to dissolve rock<div>2.small bryophyte</div><div>3.bigger plants</div><div>4forest-climax</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
climax community remain stable as long as	the environment remain unchanged <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primary succesion in water	1.Phytoplankton<div>2.free -floating angiosperms</div><div>3.rooted hydrophytes</div><div>4.sedges,grasses &nbsp;</div><div>5.trees</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
standing state	the amount of nutrient like carbon,nitrogen,phosphorous ,calcium etc present in the soiil at given time ,is refered <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how the standing state varies	different kind of ecosystem and on seasonal basis <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
nutrient cycle(biogeochemical cycles)	the movement of nutrient elements through various components of an acosystem <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
nutrient cycle are 2 types	a.gaseous cycle<div>b.sedimentary cycle</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
gaseous cycle	for this ,the reservoir exist in the atmosphere(nitrogen ,carbon cycle etc) <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
sedimentary cycle	the reservoir is located in earths crust(sulphur and phosphorous cycle) <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
rate of release of nutrient are based on	soil, moisture,pH,temperature etc) <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the reservoir meets with the deficit of nutrients due to&nbsp;	imbalance in the ratte of influx and efflux <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
reservoir of C	atm-1%<div>orga(dry weight)-49%</div><div>ocean-regualte atmospheric CO2-71%&nbsp;</div><div>fossil fuel</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
through where C cycle occur	atmo,ocean,living and dead organism <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how much C is fixed through photosyntheses	4*10<sup>13</sup>&nbsp;kg <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
some amount of C is lost how&nbsp;	lost to sediment and removed from circulation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
role of human activities in carbon cycle	deforestation ,burning of fossil fueletc.has increased the rate of release of CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;into the atmosphere <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
reaervoir of P	constituent of the biological membrane,nucleic acid,cellular &nbsp;enrgy transfer system <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
natural reservoir of P	rock(in the form of phosphates) <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the P cycle flowchart&nbsp;	refer text book <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
difference b/w C andP cycle	refer text <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
ecosystem services	the products of ecosystem processes&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what healthy ecosystem provide	purify air an d water<div>habitat</div><div>mitigate drought and floods</div><div>cycle nutrients</div><div>storage site for C</div><div>aesthetic and spiritual value</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
who price tagged the nature life support servicess	Robert Constanza <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how much is price of the ecosystem service	33 trillion dollar 18 twice that of global Gross National Product <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
contribution of soil to 33 trillion	is 50% <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
recreation and nutrient cycle to 33 trillion	less than 10% <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
climatic regulation and habitat for wildlife RC	6% <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Old biotechnology	deals with techniques of using live organisms or their enzymes for products and processes useful to human <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
EFB	european federaion of biotechnoly <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
biotechnology-EFB	defines biotechnology as the integrationof natural science ,cells ,parts thereof ,and molecular analogues for products and services <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
biotechnology deals with	-microbe mediated<div>-invitro</div><div>-synthesis and using of a gene</div><div>-preparation of DNA vaccine</div><div>-correcting a defective gene</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Principle of biotechnology	a.genetic engineering<div>b.maintanace of sterile ambience</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
genetic engineering	the technique in ehich the genetic material is chemically altered and indroduced into host organism to change the phenotype <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
why sterile ambience	the traditionamethod leads to inclusion and multiplcation of undesired gene along with the desired gene.genetic engineering helps to isolate and indroduce only desirable gene. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how the first recombinanat DNA emerged	from the possibility of linking a gene of antibiotic resistance with the native plasmid of &nbsp;Salmonella triphimurium&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
who isolated the antibiotic resistance gene	Stanley Cohen and Herbert Boyer in 1972 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
3 basic step in genetically modifying an organism	1.Identification of DNA with the desirable genes.<div>2.Indroduction of the identified DNA into the host</div><div>3.Maintanance of indroduced DNA in the host and transfer of the DNA into progeny</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Tools of recombinant dna technology	1.Restriction enzyme<div>2.Cloning vector</div><div>3.Competent Host</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how the restriction enzyme is found	1963-two enzyme responsible for the restricting the growth of bacteriophage in E.coli were isolated .one added methyl gp other cut DNA <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
first restriction endonuclease	Hind II <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
recognition sequence	a sequence of six pair where the restriction enzymes cut <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how many restriction enzyme is found	900 from over 230 strain of bacteria <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Naming of restriction enzyme	EcoRI &nbsp;roman number =the order in which the enzyme were isolated from the strain of bacteria <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
two type of nuclease	exonucleases and endonucleases <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
exonuclease	they remove nucleotides from the ends of the DNA <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Endonucleases&nbsp;	they cut at specific position within the DNA <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how restriciton endonuclease cut DNA	they can recognize specific sequence and cut each of two strands at specific position <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
palindromic sequence	dna sequence of base pair that reads the same in both direction if orientation is kept the same <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
sticky end	the restriciton enzyme cut the DNA little awy from the palindromic sites b/w the same bases,this result in &nbsp;overhanging structure at the end <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the pros of the sticky ends	they form H bond with complementary cut .this stickiness facilitates the action of DNA ligases <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
gel electrophorosis	DNA fragments formed by restriction enzyme can be seperated by a technique <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
process of electrophorosis	they are made to move toward the anode as it is -ve chargedunder an electric field through a medium or matrix such as agarose <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the smaller sized fragments move	faster <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how it is identified	visualised after staining with ethidium bromide followed by exposture to UV rays-bright orange colour DNA bands can be seen <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Elution	the seperated DNA bands are cu out from agarose gel and extracted from gel piece <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Cloning vectors	They are the DNA molecule that can carry a foreign &nbsp;DNA segment and replicate inside the host cell <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for the cloning vector	plasmid and bacteriophage <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
feature of cloning vector	a.ori<div>b.selectable marker</div><div>c.Cloning site</div><div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
ori	this is a sequence from where replication starts .a piece of dna linked to ori can replicate within the host cells. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
selectable marker	it helps to select the transformanants and non transformanants <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
transformation	is a procedure in which a piece of DNA is indroduced in a host bacterium <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
selectable marer of &nbsp;E choli	ampicilin ,chloramphenicol,tetracyclin or kanamycin&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
ligation of alien gene is carried out in	one of the two antibiotic resistance gene <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
alternate selectalbe marer	chromogenic substrate&nbsp;<div>lined to enzyme ,alpha galactosidase ,if recombinant then it become inacivated and no colour is there</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Agrobacterium tumifaciens	a pathogen of many dicot plants can deliver T DNA which is tumour inducing.it is modified to cloning vector to deliver genes of interest into plants. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Retrovirus&nbsp;	can transform normal cells into cancerous cell <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Making host competetnt	dna is hydrophilic -no passage through cell membrane<div><br /></div><div>so bacterial cel are treated with a specific con of a divalent cation-DNA enters through pores</div><div>-incubated with DNA on ice .then place briefly on 42 and put them back on ice</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
other method to indroduce alien DNA into host cell	Micro injection<div>Biolistic</div><div>Disarmed pathogen vector</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Microinjection	In this ,recombinant DNA is directly injected into the nucleas of an animal cell. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Biolistic	In this ,cells are ombareded with high velocity micro particle of gold or tungsten coated with DNA <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Processes of recombianat DNA technology	1.Isolation of the genetic material<div>2.Cutting of DNA at specific Location</div><div>3.Amplification of Gene of interest using PCR</div><div>4.Insertion of Recombianant DNA into the host cell</div><div>5.Obtaining the foreign gene product</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Isolation of genetic material	cell are treated with &nbsp;enzymes<div>lysozyme -bacteria</div><div>cellulase-plant cells</div><div>chitinase-fungi</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how is RNA removed	ribonucleases <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how is the DNA precipitated	when they are treated with chilled ethanol <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Cutting of DNA at specific Location	-incubate purified DNA with restriction enzyme at optimal temperature<div>-Agarose gel electrophorosis is emplyed for progression</div><div>-interest gene and the vector are mixed and ligase is added</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
PCR	is the synthesis of mulitiple copies of the gene of interest &nbsp;in vitro using 2 sets of primer and the enzyme DNA polymerase <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
primers	are small chemically synthesized oligonucleotides that are complementary to the region of DNA<div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
DNA polymerease	extend the primers using nucleotide and the genomic DNA and amplified to 1Billion <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
for amplification a thermostable DNA polymerease is used &nbsp;	Thermus aquaticus <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what is ultimate aim of the recombinant DNA technology	to produce desirable products <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
recombinant protein	if a protein encoding gene is expressed in a heterologous host&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
bioreactor	to produce large quantities of products ,the bioreactor are used where large volumes &nbsp;of culture can be processed <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
bioreactor-	are the vessels in which &nbsp;raw material are biologically converted into specific products ,enzyme etc using microbial plants ,animal or human cells <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
stirred tank reactor	it is usually cylindrical or with a curved base to facilitate the mixing of the reactor content .the stirer facilitate even mixing and oxygen availibility &nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
bioreactor has	-an agitator system<div>-an oxygen delivery system</div><div>-a foam control system</div><div>-a temp control system</div><div>-pH control system</div><div>-Sampling port</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Down stream processing	it is a series of processes such as seperation and purification of products after the biosynthetic stage clinical trials also carried out <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
applications of biotechnology	a.biopharmaceuticals<div>b.therapeutics</div><div>c.diagnostics</div><div>d.GMC for agriculture</div><div>e.processed food</div><div>f.biomediation</div><div>g.waste treatment</div><div>h.energy production</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
3 critical reserch areas	a.providing the best catalyst in the form of improved organism usually a microbe or pure enzyme<div>b.creating optimal condition&nbsp;</div><div>c.Downstream processing technologies to purify the protein compound</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
3 options for increasing food production	a.agro -chemical bassed food production<div>b.organic agriculture</div><div>c.genetically engineeredcrop -based agriculture</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
GMO	are the plants ,bacteria ,fungi and animals whise genes are altered by manipulation. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
advantage of GMO	-moretolerant to abiotic stress<div>-reduce use of chemical pest</div><div>-reduce post &nbsp;harvest loss</div><div>-increase efficiency of mineral usage by plants</div><div>-it enhancing nutritional value &nbsp;of food</div><div>-GM is used to create tailor made plants to supply alternative resources to industries ,in the form of starch ,fuels and pharmaceuticals</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
pest resistant plants	bio pesticides<div>eg-bt cotton,rice,tomato,potato,soyabean</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Bt&nbsp;	Bacillus thuringensis <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Bt kill	coleopterans-beetles<div>lepidopterans-tobacco budworm</div><div>dipterans-flies ,mosquitoes</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
why Protein doesnt kill Bt	because it exist as inactive protoxin <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how then protein kill	when an insect ingest the inactive toxin ,it is activated due to alkaly pHof the gut which solubulise the crystal <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how protein kill	toxin bind to the surface of midgut epithelial cells and create pores -it causes swelling ,lysis <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>

how can nematode Meloidegayne incognito infecttion removed	RNA interference&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
RNAi	is amethod of cellular defense in all eukaryotic &nbsp;organisms.it prevents translation of a specific mRNA due to a complementary dsRNA molecule <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the source of this comlpemntary RNA	is from an infection by RNA viruses or mobile genetic element that replicate via an RNA intermediate <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
transpons	mobile &nbsp;gentic elements <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how -nematode resisted	-nematode specific gene is indroduced which produce sense and antisense RNA in the host which complementary and form dsRNA that initaited RNAi and silence the specific mRNA of nematode <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>

Gene Therapy	it is the method of correcting a gene defect diagnosed ina child or embryo&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how is gene therapy carried outo&nbsp;	gene is inserted into a person cell and tissue to treat a heriditary disease. it compensate for the non functional gene. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
first gene therapy	1990 to a 4 year old girls with ADA(adenosine deaminasse deficiency <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
why ADA occurs h	deletion of the gene fot AD crucial for the immune system to function <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>

vegetative cells	is bigger , has abundent food reserve and a large irregularly shaped nucleas. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>

Hormone	A signal molecule produced by a gland to regulate physiological function through the bloodstream
A signal molecule produced by a gland to regulate physiological function through the bloodstream	Hormone
Endocrine Gland	Secrete hormones directly into blood, e.g. pituitary gland
Secrete hormones directly into blood, e.g. pituitary gland	Endocrine Gland
Exocrine Gland	Secrete products through a duct onto tissue, e.g. mucous glands
Secrete products through a duct onto tissue, e.g. mucous glands	Exocrine Gland
Non-Steroidal Hormone Communication	Binds to a receptor site on surface of cell, which triggers transduction pathway to cause physiological change either immediately or through second messenger
Steroid Hormone Communication	Travels into nucleus and binds to receptor protein that causes mRNA synthesis to produce protein
Stimulates cell growth, reproduction, and regeneration	Growth hormone (GH)
Stimulates production of thyroxine to increase metabolism&nbsp;	Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
Stimulates production of cortisol to incease blood sugar and metabolism	Adrenocortocotropic hormone (ACTH)
Stimulates lactation and cervical dilation	Oxytocin (OXT)
Aids in water retention and constriction of arteries	Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
Stimulates metabolism, protein synthesis, and cell growth/differentiation	Thyroxin (T<sub>4</sub>)
Lowers calcium levels in the blood	Calcitonin (CT)
Raises calcium levels in the blood&nbsp;	Parathyroid hormone (PTH)
"Mobilize brain and body for action (""fight-or-flight"" response)"	Epinephrine (EPI) and norepinephrine (NE)
Regulates glucose intake, glycogenesis, and glycolysis	Insulin (INS)
Regulates glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis; increases blood sugar levels	Glucagon (GCG)
Regulates blood pressure	Aldosterone (A)
Synchronizes circadian rhythms	Melatonin (MT)
Stimulates growth of secondary sexual characteristics in males	Testosterostone (T)
Sclera	Protective outer layer of eye
Cornea	Transparent part of sclera that allows passage of light through pupil
Lens	Changes shape to focus light on retina
Ciliary Body	Allows lens to change shape
Choroid	Supplies blood to the eye&nbsp;
Iris	Controls amount of light passing through pupil
Retina	Receives image and transmits it through optic nerve
Optic Nerve	Transmits visual images from retina to optic lobe
Rods	More sensitive photoreceptors without color vision, allowing night vision and peripheral vision
Cones	Less sensitive but more responsive photoreceptors, allowing perception of color and fine detail
Pinna	Outer part of the ear that funnels vibrations into the ear canal
Ear Canal&nbsp;	Conducts outside vibrations to tympanic membrane
Tympanic Membrane	Resonates with vibrations in the air, moving malleus
Incus	Transmits and amplifies vibrations from malleus to stapes
Stapes	Receives vibrations from incus and pushes against oval window
Receives vibrations from incus and pushes against oval window	Stapes
Oval Window	Receives vibrations from stapes and transmits to wave in lymphatic fluid of cochlea
Receives vibrations from stapes and transmits to wave in lymphatic fluid of cochlea	Oval Window
Cochlea	Wave caused by movement of oval window disturbs hair cells in organ of Corti, which transmit signals through auditory nerve
Wave caused by movement of oval window disturbs hair cells in organ of Corti, which transmit signals through auditory nerve	Cochlea
Round Window	Allows wave in lymphatic fluid of cochlea to dissipate
Allows wave in lymphatic fluid of cochlea to dissipate	Round Window
Otolith Organs	Detect orientation and gravity through motion of viscous fluid and granules of calcium carbonate, which disturb hair cells
Detect orientation and gravity through motion of viscous fluid and granules of calcium carbonate, which disturb hair cells	Otolith Organs
Semicircular Canals	Detect motion and acceleration through movement of endolymph fluid, which disturbs hair cells
Detect motion and acceleration through movement of endolymph fluid, which disturbs hair cells	Semicircular Canals
Eustachian Tube	Allows pressure to equalize on either side of tympanic membrane
Allows pressure to equalize on either side of tympanic membrane	Eustachian Tube

animal husbandary deals with	-the care and breeding of live stock<div>-poultary farming and fisheries</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>

milk yield depend on	quality of breed in the farm <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
for the yield potential	- well looked after&nbsp;<div>-the feeding of cattle&nbsp;</div><div>-stringent cleaning and hygiene</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
hw to ensure the hygiene	-regular inspection<div>-regular visit by vetenary doctor</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
poultry	is the domesticated birds used for food or eggs <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for poultry	chicken,ducks,turkey ,geese <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
components of poultry farm management	-selection of disease free and suitable<div>-proper and safe farm condition</div><div>-feed and water</div><div>-hygiene and health care</div><div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
breed	a breed is a gp of animals related by similar general appearence ,features,size <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
breeding	is the modification of genotype of an organism to make that organism more useful to humans <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
aim of animal breeding	increase the yield of animal and improving the desirable qualities of produce <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
two type &nbsp;of breeding&nbsp;	a.inbreeding<div>b.ourbreeding</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
inbreeding	mating of more closely related individuals within the same breed for 4-6 generation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
process of inbreeding	-superiormale and female is mated<div>-from progeny same method is repeated</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
advantage of inbreedinf	-increse homozygosity to evolve pure line<div>-expose harmful recessive gene eliminated</div><div>-accumulation of superior genes and elemination of less desirable gene</div><div>-increase productivity</div><div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
inbreeding depression	continued inbreeding ,especially close inbreeding ,may reduce fertility and productivity <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how to change inbreeding deppression	mated with unrelated superior animal of same breed <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
out breeding	it is the breeding of unrelated animals <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
type of out breeding	out crossing,cross breeding ,interspecific hybridisation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
out crossing	this is mating of animals within the same breed ,but having no common ancestor on either side of their pedigree up to 4-6 generation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
offspring of our crossing&nbsp;	out cross <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
pros of outcrossing	overcome inbreeding depression<div>it is for low productivity,growth rate in beef cattle</div><div><br /></div><div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
cross breeding	in this method,superior male of one is mated with the superior female of another breed <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
fn of cross breeding	may be used for commercial<div>subjected to inbreedingand selection of stable superior breed</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for the cross breeding	Hisardale sheep developed in punjab by crossing Bikaneri and Marino rams <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Inter specific hybridisation	it is the mating of male and female of two different species <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for interspecific hybridisation	mule <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
MOET	Multiple Ovulation Embryo Transfer Technology <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
moet	it is a programme for herd improvement .cow is administered with fsh like activity ,to induce follicular maturation and super ovulation<div>at 8-32 stage then it is transfered into surrogate mothers</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
apiculture	it is the maintanace of hives of honey bee for the production of honey&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
pros of honey	high nutritive value and medicinal value<div>bee wax for cosmetics and polishes</div><div>can be done in any area having sufficient bee pastures of wild shrubs ,fruit orchads and cultivated crop</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
important points for successful bee-keeping	knowledge of the nature and habir<div>selection of suitable location</div><div>catching and hiving of swarms&nbsp;</div><div>management of beehives during diff season</div><div>handling and collectionof honey and beewax</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
bees are pollinator of&nbsp;	sunflower ,brassica ,apple and pear <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
fisheries	is an industry of catching ,processing or selling of fish,shellfish or other aquatic animals(prawn ,crab,lobster,oyster) <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
freshwater fishes	Catla,Rohu ,common carp <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
marine fish	hilsa,sardines,mackeral,pomfrets <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
aqua culture and pisciculture are&nbsp;	the techniques to increase the production of aquatic animal and plants <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
blue revolution	the development and flourishing of the fishing industries <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
plant breeding	it is the purposeful manipulation of plant species in order to create desirable plant types that are better suited for cultivation ,give better yields and are disease resistent <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Green revolution	the development and flourishing of the agriculture.it was dependent on the plant breeding <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Classical plant breeding	involves hybridisation &nbsp;of pure lines and artificial selection to produce desirable traits. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
desirable genes that breeders try to incorporate	-crop yield,quality ,tolerance to environmental stresses.tolerance to insect pests <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Steps of breeding	collection of genetic variability<div>evaluation and selection of parents</div><div>cross hybridisation among selected parents</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
germplasm collection	the entire collectionof plants /seeds having all the alleles for all genes in a given crop <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
collection of genetic variability	collection and preservation of all the different wild varieties,species and relatives of the cultivated species is a pre requisite for effective exploitation of natural gene <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
evaluation and selection of parents	the germplasm is evaluated so as to identify plants with desirable combination of character <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Cross hybridisation among the selected parents	the desirable character have to be combined from two different plants.this is possible by cross hybridizing the two parents to produce hybrids that genetically combine the desired characters in one plant <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
limitation of cross hybridisation	-time consuming<div>-may not combine the desirable character</div><div>-only one in hundreds to a thousands crosses shows the desirable combination</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
selection and testing of superior recombinant	it is crucial to the success of the breeding objective and require careful scientific evaluation of the progeny<div>they are self pollinated till they attain a state of uniformity</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
testing ,release and commercialization	evaluated for their yield and other agronomic traits of quality ,disease resistance <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the test	they are grown on research field under ideal fertilizers and other management strategy<div>then in farmers field for atleast 3 growing seasons at several locations&nbsp;</div><div>-material is evaluated in comparison to the best available local crop cultivator(a check or reference cultivar)</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
increase in wheat production	from 1960-2000 11m to 75m<div>rice35m-89.5m</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
who indroduced semi dwarf &nbsp;whear	nobel naurate Norman E.Borlayg(international centre for wheat and maize improvement ,Mexico) <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the high yield ,disease resistent wheat in india	Sonalika and Kalyan Sona <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Semi dwarf rice derived from	IR-8(International rice research institute)<div>and Taichung Native-1 from Taiwan</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the semi dwarf rice variety in india	Jaya and Ratna <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Sugar cane	Saccharam barberi (bad) crossed with Saccharam officinarum(tropical cane in south india do not grow in north india <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Millets:hybrid maize ,jowar and bajra	resistant to water stress <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
plant breeding for disease resistance	it enhances food production and helps to reduce the use of fungicides and bacteriocides <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
fungal disease	rust(brown rust of wheat,red rot of sugarcane and late blight of potato) <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Bacterial disease	black rot of crucifers <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
viral disease	tobacco mosaic ,turnip mosaic <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
method of breeding for disease resistance	1.Conventional methods.<div>2.Mutation breeding.</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
conventional methods	-screening germ plasma for resistnr source<div>-hybridisation of selected parent</div><div>-selection and evaluation of the hybrid</div><div>-testing and release of new varieties</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
disease resistance variety of the wheat	himgiri <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>leaf and stripe rust ,hill bunt</div> 
brassica	pusa swarnim(karan rai) <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>white rust</div> 
cauliflower	pusa subhra,pusa snowball K-1 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>bacterial blight</div> 
Chilli	pusa sadabahar <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>chilly mosaic virus , tobacco mosaic virus ,and leaf curl</div> 
mutational breeding	can create new desirable character not found in the parental type <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Mutational breeding	is the breeding by mutation through use of chemicals or radiation (like gamma radiation) and selecting and using the plants that have desirable character as a source in breeding <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for mutational breeding	mung bean,resistance to yellow mosaic virus and powdery mildew were induced by mutation.<div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for from wild to high yield	resistance to yellow mosaic virus in bhindi was transfered from a wild species &nbsp;and resulted in a new variety called Parbhani kranti <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Transfer of resistance genes is achieved	by sexual hybridisation b/w &nbsp;the target and the source plant <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
insect resistance in host plants may be due to&nbsp;	morphological ,biochemical,physiological <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
hairy leaves	resistance to jassids in cotton and cereal leaf beatles in wheat <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
solid stem in wheat	lead to non preference by the stem sawfly <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
smooth leaved and nector less cotton varieties	do not attract bollworm <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
high aspartic acid,low nitrogen and sugar	leads to resistance to maize stem borers <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
brassica(rapeseed mustards)	pusa gaurav <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>aphids</div> 
flat bean	pusa sem2,pusa sem3 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>jassids,aphids,fruit borer</div> 
okra bhindhi	pusa sawami<div>pusa A4</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>shoot and fruit borer</div> 
hidden hunger	3 billion people suffer from mal nutrient,protein and vitamin deficiency <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
biofortification	breeding crop with high level of nutrients helps to improve public health <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
objectives of breeding for improved nutriional quality	improve<div>-protein&nbsp;</div><div>-oil</div><div>-vitamin</div><div>-micronutrient and mineral</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for improved nutritional quality plants	maize with twice the amount of amino acid,lysine and tryptophan&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>wheat variety atlas having high protein content<div>iron fortified rice 5 times existing iron</div></div> 
vegetable crops in vitamin and minerals	released by indian agriculture research institute ,new delhi <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for vegetable crops richin vitamin	vitamin A enriched carrots,spinach,pumpkin;vitamin C enriched bitter gourd,bathua ,mustard,tomato;iron and calcium enriched spinach and bathu and protein enriched beans(broad ,lablab,french ,garden peas <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
SCP	it is an alternate source of proteins for animal and human nutrition <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'>eg microbed like spirulina</div> 
Spirulina	is rich in protein ,minerals ,fats ,carbohydrate and vitamins.it is grown on materials like waste water from potato processing plants ,straw ,molasses,animal manure and sewage.reduce environemental pollution. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
250g of micro organism&nbsp;	Methylophilus methylotrophus produce 25 tonnes. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Tissue culture	a technique of growing plant cells/tissue/organs in sterile cultural medium under controlled aseptic condition. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
totipotency	the ability to generate a whole plant from any cell/explant&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
explant	is any part of a plant that is grown in a testtube under sterile nutrient media <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the nutrient medium in explants	carbon source (sucrose),inorganic salts,vitamin ,amino acids and growth regulators like auxins,cytokinins <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
micropropogation	the method of producing thousands of plants in very short &nbsp;time through tissue culture <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
soma clones	these plants will be genetically identical to original plant,from which they are grown <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for tissue culture	tomato ,banana,apple <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
meristem	free from the virus <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for meristem tissue culture	banana,sugarcane,potato <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
somatic hybridization	protoplasts from two different varieties of plants (with desirable gene) are fused to get hybrid protoplast.somatic plant. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Pollution	Is any indesirable change in physical ,chemical or biological characteristics of air ,water,land and soil. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
When govt take action and how	Environment protection act in 1986 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Causes of pollution	particulate and gaseous air pollutants from smokestack of thermal powerplant ,smelter etc <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what is harmful for human being	the particulate size less than that of 2.5 pico meter <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
consequences of pollution	-injury to all organism<div>-reduce growth and yield</div><div>-affect the respiratory system.</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
control of air pollution	particulate matter must be seperated<div>lead free petrol</div><div>phasing out of old vehicle</div><div>pollution level norm</div><div>low sulphur petrol and diesal&nbsp;</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Electrostatic precipitators&nbsp;	it is the device used to remove particulate matter.<div>it can remove over 99% particulate matter present in the exhaust from a thermal power plant.</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
working oof the electrostatic precipitors	-the electrode wire charges the particles<div>-then allowed to fall</div><div>-SO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;removed by scrubber-passed through a spray of water or lime.</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
when air act is amended	1987 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Sources of sound pollution	music instrument<div>loudspeaker</div><div>crackers</div><div>industries</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
effect of noise	-psychological and physiology<div>-above 150dB may damage ear drum</div><div>-chronic exposture to relatively lower noise may damage hearing abilities of hyman.</div><div>-Sleeplessness,increased heartbeat and breathing ,stress</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
control of noise pollution	-sound absorbent material<div>-horn free zorn delimitation</div><div>-permissible sound levels of crackers and loadspeacker</div><div>-timing of using &nbsp;of loudspeacker</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
law and policies of india to control vehiculr pollution	a.Auto fuel policy&nbsp;<div>b.Euro II norms</div><div>c.The Bharat stage II&nbsp;</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
auto fuel&nbsp;	has laid out a road map to cut down vehicular pollution in india cities <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Euro II norm	it stipulate that sulphur be controlled &nbsp;at 350ppm in diesal and 150ppm iin petrol<div><br /></div><div>aromatic hydrocarbons are to be contained at 42 of the concerned &nbsp;fuel</div><div>reduce sulphur 50ppm in petrol and diesel and bring down the level to 35%&nbsp;</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the Bharat stageII	all must met the euro III in 11 cities &nbsp;1 april 2005 and euro IV in 1 april 2010<div>euro III emission norm compliant by 2010</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the law of govt on water body	water prevention and control of pollution &nbsp;act in1974 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what make sewage unfit	0.1% of impurities <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
BOD	the amount of biodegradable organic matter in sewage &nbsp;water is estimated by BOD <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
algal bloom	planktonic algae grow excessively due to nutrients <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
water hyacinth	Eichhornia crassioes-terror of bengal <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the cons of water hyacinth	they reprduce very well<div>they cause ecosystem imbalance</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Biomagnification	is the accumulation of the toxicant at succesive trophic levels . <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
causes of biomagnification	mercuty ,DDT industrial waste <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
biomagnification in aquatic food chain	water 0.003 }zooplan 0.04}small fishes0.5}large fish 2}birds}5ppm <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how DDT disturbs birds	the disturb calcium metabolism in birds.causes thining of eggshell and premature breaking <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Eutrophication	it is the natural aging of a lake &nbsp;by nutrient enrichment <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what induce eutrophication	effluent &nbsp;from the industries .homes<div>-Cultural or accelerated eutrophication</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
prime contaminant of the eutrophication	nitrates and phosphates&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
causes of eutrophication	overstimulate algae,unsighty scum, robbing oxygen,from other lake may cause death <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
waste water treatment example	arcata,northern coast of california .Humbolt state university <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
waste water treatment	sedimentation and &nbsp;six connected marshland <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
sedimentation&nbsp;	dangerous pollutant &nbsp;heavy metal &nbsp;still remains .innovative project <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the marsh land in the treatment	six connected &nbsp;60 hectres-&nbsp;<div>the algae fungi and plant assimilate it&nbsp;</div><div>high biodiversity</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
FOAM	Friends Of The Arcata Marsh <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Ecological sanitation	dry compost,practical ,hygienic ,efficient and cost effective <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
solid waste	refer everything that goes out in a trash. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Municipal solid wastes&nbsp;	are wastes from homes ,offices ,stores ,schools,hospitals &nbsp;that are collected and disposed by municipality <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
sanitary landfills	were adopted as the substitute &nbsp;for open burning dumps.in it ,wastes are dumped in a depression or trench after compaction.and covered with dirt. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
tree types of wastess	biodegradable<div>non bio</div><div>recyclable</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
rag pickers	Kabadiwallahs <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
ewastes	Irreparable computers and other electronic goods are known as e wastes<div>buried or incinerated</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Polyblend who	Ahmed Khan <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Polyblend	it is a fine powder of recycled modified &nbsp;plastics .mixed with the bitumin and is used to lay road<div>water repellant property and increase road life</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
chemical fertilisers cause	Eutrophication <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Integrated organic farming	it is a cyclical ,zero waste procedure ,where wastes products from one process are cycled in as nutriebt for other <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
who indroduced IOF	Ramesh Chandra Dagar <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
effect of radioactive wastes	accidental leakage<div>safe disposal</div><div>mutation</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
leakage of radioactive material	incident in the three mile island and chernobyl&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
safety radioactive	sufficient pre treatment.shielded container,buried within the rocks .500m <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
green house effect	is a natural phenomenon responsible for heating of earths surface &nbsp;and atmosphere.it maintain 15 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
imapct of global warming	deletetious change in environment resulting in odd climate change &nbsp;El nino effect <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
thickness of ozone measured in	&nbsp;Dobson units <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
which Uv absorbed by earth and what cause mutatio	less than UV-B<div>UV-B causes mutation</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
UV -B causes	aging of skin,damage skin cells,skin cancers.inflammation of cornea snow blindness..cataract&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Montreal Protocol	an international treaty in canada,1987 was signed to control the emission of ozone depleting substance <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Soil erosion and desertification	human activities such as over cultivation ,deforestation ,grazing and poor irrigation practices ,leads to soil erosion &nbsp;arid patches of land and desertification and urbanisation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
National forest policy of india recommended 33% forest cover for the plant and 67 for the hils .but only &nbsp;19.4 forest cover is present &nbsp;was about &nbsp;30%	<div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>

cons of deforestio	loss of biodiversity,soil erostion hydrologic cycle disturbs <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>
