Ecology&nbsp;	is the study of interaction among organisms and between the organisms and its physical &nbsp;environment. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
ecology is concerned with 4 level of biological organizations	organisms ,population,communities,biomes <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
oecology at physiological level	explain how different organisms adapt to their encvironment in terms of survival annd reproductiion <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what causes variation in temp and seasons	rotation of earth and tilt of its axis&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
major biomes	desert ,rain forest ,tundra formed due to variation and precipitation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what forms habitat	regional and local variation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
some extreme places	rajasthan desert,rain soaked meghalaya,deep ocean trenches ,torrential streams,polar regions ,high mountain tops <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for abiotic factors	temp,water, light,soil <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
temp	most ecological relevant environmental factors<div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
temperature effects what	kinetics of enzyme ,basal metabolism,and &nbsp;physiological factors <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eury thermal	&nbsp;they can tolerate and thrive in a wide range of temp <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
stenothermal&nbsp;	they can tolerate only a narrow range of temperature <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Water	next to temp<div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
for what plant depend on water	productivity and distributioin <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
for aquatic waters role	chemical composition and pH <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the salt of inland	&lt;5&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
salt in sea	30-35 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
in hypersaline lagoons	&gt;100 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Eury haline	tolerate wide range of salinities <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Stenohaline	tolerate narrow range of salinity <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
uses of Light	sunlight for photoperiodism<div>ultimate source of energy</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
animal use diurnal and seasonal variation iin&nbsp;	light intensity and photoperiod for timing their foraging ,reproductive &nbsp;and migratory &nbsp;activities <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
nature of soil depend	depend on climate ,weathering process ,sedimentation,method for soil development <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what determine percolation and water holding capacity	soil composition,grain size and aggregation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what determine the vegetation	pH ,mineral composition and topography&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what determine the type of benthic animals	sediment characteristics <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
different type of organism on the &nbsp;basis the mean homeostasis regulation	regulate .conform.migrate ,suspend <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Regulate	it is the maintanance of homeostasis by physiological and behavioural &nbsp;means that ensure constant body temperture &nbsp;,constant osmotic concentration -osmoregulation <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for regulates	birds and mammals very few vertebrates and invetrebrates <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
conform	99% cannot maintain constant temp <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
why small animals are low in the polar region	they have a larger surface area relative to their volume.so they lose body heat fast <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Migrate	many animal like birds move away temporarily from stressful habitat to a more hospitable region and return when stress is over <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for migrate	Kiolado national park during winter host migrate from siberians and other cold countries <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Hibernation	bears during winter <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Aestivation	of some snails and fishes during summer <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Diapause -a stage of suspended development	zooplanktons in lakes and ponds <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Adaptation	is the morphological ,physiological and behavioural &nbsp;attributes that enables an organisms to survive and reproduce in its habitat <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
adaptation of kangaroo rats	-internal fat oxidation gives water as byproduct<div>-Ability to concentrate urine so that minimal volume &nbsp;of water is used to remove excertory products</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Adaptation of desert plants	thick cuticle on leaf surface .<div>their stomata are arranged in deep pits</div><div>-CAM that enables close the stomata</div><div>-Opuntia has no leaves</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Adaptation of mammal in polar region	colder climate have shorter ears and limbs to reduce heat loss<div>-Seals have thick layer of fats below their skin -blubber</div><div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
At high altitude &gt;3500 symptoms are	altitude sickness<div>nausea ,heart palpitation and fatigue</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Behavioural adaptation	-Desert lizard bask in sun<div>-some species are capable of burrowing into the soil to hide and escape</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Population	is a gp of individual of same species that live &nbsp;in a given geographical area ,share orcompete for similar resource and potentialy reproduce <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for population	Cormorants in wet land<div>Rats in abondened dwelling</div><div>Teak wood in forest tract</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Why is populationecology in important	links to ecology of population genetics and evolution <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Population attributes	-Birth rates<div>-Death rates</div><div>-Sex ratio</div><div>-Age pyramids</div><div>-Population size or population</div><div><br /></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Birth rates	refer to per capita births <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
death rates	refer to per capita deaths <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
sex ratio	a population has a sex ratio <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Age pyramids&nbsp;	if a age distribution is plotted for the population ,the resulting structure is called an age group <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
age gp may be	expanding ,stable,declining <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
population sizw or density	&nbsp;it is the number of individuals of a species per unit area or volume&nbsp; <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
population size of chlamydomonas	millions <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
when there is huge banyan and parthenium how population size is measure	&nbsp;%cover or biomass <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how large population is measured	relative population density &nbsp;is used per trap <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
how tiger is measured&nbsp;	pug marks and fecal pellets <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Population growth depend on	food availability ,predation pressure ,weather <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
4 basic processes that fluctuate the population density	a.Natality<div>b.Mortality</div><div>c.Immigration</div><div>d.Emigration</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
natality&nbsp;	number of births in a population during a given period <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
mortality	it is the number of deaths in a population during a given period <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Immigration	it is the number of individuals of the same species that have come into &nbsp;the habitat <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the figure of fluctuation in population	<div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Growth models&nbsp;	a.exponential growth<div>b.logistic growth</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
exponential growth	geometric fasion<div>unlimited resources</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eqn of exponential growth	dN/dt = (b – d) × N<div>dN/dt = rN</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
r in&nbsp;dN/dt = rN	intrinsic rate of natural increase is a important parameter for accessing impacts of any biotic or abiotic factors <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
r for norway rats	0.015 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
r for flour beetle	0.12 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
r for human population in india	0.0205 <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
integral form of exponential growth	<div><br /></div><div>Nt&nbsp;= N<sub>o</sub>ert</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
logistic growth	fittest survive and reproduce <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
carrying capacity	in nature ,a given habitat has enough resources to support a maximum possible number .beyond which no further growth is possible <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Verhulst-Pearl Logistic growth	intialy a lag phase ,followed by phases of acceleration and deceleration and finally asymptote,when the population reaches the carrying capacity <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eqn of logistic growth	[sound:rec1455285875.mp3] <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
population growth curve&nbsp;	<div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
once breeder	pacific salmon fish ,bamboo <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
small sized &nbsp;offspring	Oysters and pelagic fishes<div>small number large offspring bring ,mammals</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Population interaction	-Mutualism<div>-Competition</div><div>-Parasitism</div><div>-Predation</div><div>-Commensalism</div><div>-Amensalism</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Predation	all carnivore herbivore and 25%phytophagous <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
importance of the predators&nbsp;	the prickly pear cactus.the cactus feeding &nbsp;predator was indroduced moth in auatralia<div>when cactus is removed from american pacific coast&nbsp;</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the defenses of insect and frogs	camouflaged (cryptically cloured) to avoid being detected by the predators <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the monarch butterfly&nbsp;	is highly &nbsp;distasteful to its predators due to a special &nbsp;chemical in its body .by feeding on poisonous weed <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
defense of plants	thorns Acacia,cactus <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Calotropis&nbsp;	a weed growing in abondoned field produce highly &nbsp;poisonous cardiac glycoside <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
useful defenses	Nicotine,caffeine ,quinine,strychinene ,opium etc <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Competition	is a potent force in organic evolution<div>process in which fitness of one species is significantly lower in presence of another species.</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
what occur in interference competition	even resource is abundant the presence of species feeding efficiency is reduced due to the interfering and inhibitary &nbsp;presence <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
unrelated competition	flamingoes and fishes compete for zooplanktons in south american shallow lake <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
the Abingdon and goat	in Galapogas <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Competitive release	A species restricted to a small geographical area due to superior ,expands &nbsp;its distributional range when the competitive species is experimentaly removed <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for competitive release	connell's field experiment rockyy sea coasrs of scotland the larger and compertitively superior barnacle Balanus dominates interridal area ,and excludes the smaller barnacle Chathamalus from the zone <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Gause's competitive exclusion principle	it states that two closely related species compering for the same resources cannot co exist indefinitely and the competitvely inferior one will be eliminated eventualy. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Resource partitioning	if 2 species compete for the same resources they could avoid competition by choosing &nbsp;different times for feeding or different foraging pattern <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for resource partitioning	Macarthur &nbsp;warbler of same species can survive in same trees difference in foraging activities. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Adaptation of parasites	loss of sense organs ,presence of adhesive organs,sucker to cling on to the host , loss of digestive system,high reproductive capacity. <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for parasites	human liver fluke depends on 2 intermediate hosts snail and fish<div>&nbsp;to complete its life cycle<div>malarial need mosquitoes.</div></div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
ecto parasites	lice on humas and ticks on dogs,<div>cuscuta on hedge plants,lost its chlorophyl&nbsp;</div><div>femal mosquito need blood for reproduction but not parasite</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
Commensalism eg	orchid growin as epiphyte on a mango branch<div>-Barnacles growing on the back of a whale</div><div>-Cattle egret and grazing cattles</div><div>-Sea anemone and clown fish</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
eg for mutualism	lichen&nbsp;<div>mycorrhizaeo fungi and roots</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div> 
mutualism b/w plants and animal	fig trees and wasps<div>-orchids shoe diversity of floral pattern bees and bumble bees</div><div>-Sexual deceit &nbsp;of Ophrys one petal of its flower resembles female bee in size and colour -pseudocopulation.</div> <div style='font-family: Arial; font-size: 20px;'></div>

Lytic Cycle	Replicative cycle that results in death of the host
Replicative cycle that results in death of the host	Lytic Cycle
Virulent Phage	Replicates only by the lytic cycle
Replicates only by the lytic cycle	Virulent Phage
Restriction Enzymes	Bacterial enzymes that identify and destroy foreign DNA, limiting attack ability of phage
Bacterial enzymes that identify and destroy foreign DNA, limiting attack ability of phage	Restriction Enzymes
Lysogenic Cycle	Allows replication of phage without destroying host
Allows replication of phage without destroying host	Lysogenic Cycle
Temperate Phages	Phages capable of replicating through both the lytic and lysogenic cycles
Phages capable of replicating through both the lytic and lysogenic cycles	Temperate Phages
Prophage	Viral DNA integrated into a bacterial chromosome
Viral DNA integrated into a bacterial chromosome	Prophage

Cocci	<div>Spherical prokaryotes</div>
<div>Spherical prokaryotes</div>	Cocci
Bacilli	Rod-shaped prokaryotes
Rod-shaped prokaryotes	Bacilli
Spirilla	Helical prokaryotes
Helical prokaryotes	Spirilla
Strepto-&nbsp;	Chains of cells
Chains of cells	Strepto-&nbsp;
Staphylo-	Bunches of cells
Bunches of cells	Staphylo-
Gram-positive bacteria	Simpler walls with more peptidoglycan
Simpler walls with more peptidoglycan	Gram-positive bacteria
Gram-negative bacteria	<div>More complex cell walls with less peptidoglycan, often with toxic lipopolysaccharides on walls and/or greater protection from cellular defenses</div>
<div>More complex cell walls with less peptidoglycan, often with toxic lipopolysaccharides on walls and/or greater protection from cellular defenses</div>	Gram-negative bacteria
Peptidoglycan	Polymers of modified sugars cross-linked by short polypeptides&nbsp;
Polymers of modified sugars cross-linked by short polypeptides&nbsp;	Peptidoglycan
Capsule	Additional protective layer secreted by bacteria
Additional protective layer secreted by bacteria	Capsule
Pili	Surface appendages used for adhesion to substratum or cohesion during conjugation
Surface appendages used for adhesion to substratum or cohesion during conjugation	Pili
Fimbriae	Hairlike appendages used for adhesion
Hairlike appendages used for adhesion	Fimbriae
Taxis	Directed movement towards or away from stimulus, incl. phototaxis (moths) and chemotaxis (mosquitoes)
Directed movement towards or away from stimulus, incl. phototaxis (moths) and chemotaxis (mosquitoes)	Taxis
Plasmids	Small, independently replicating rings of bacterial DNA
Small, independently replicating rings of bacterial DNA	Plasmids
Binary Fission	Asexual reproduction of prokaryotes, involving growth and division into two&nbsp;
Asexual reproduction of prokaryotes, involving growth and division into two&nbsp;	Binary Fission
Endospore	A copy of a bacterial chromosome surrounded in a tough multilayered structure that allows survival in extreme conditions
A copy of a bacterial chromosome surrounded in a tough multilayered structure that allows survival in extreme conditions	Endospore
Horizontal Gene Transfer	The movement of genes from one organism to another of a different species, through transformation, transduction, or conjugation.
The movement of genes from one organism to another of a different species, through transformation, transduction, or conjugation.	Horizontal Gene Transfer
Transformation	Alteration of a prokaryote genome through the uptake of foreign DNA from surroundings
Alteration of a prokaryote genome through the uptake of foreign DNA from surroundings	Transformation
Transduction	Transfer by phages of one host cell's genes to another
Transfer by phages of one host cell's genes to another	Transduction
Conjugation	Transfer of DNA between two temporarily attached prokaryotic cells (always one-way in bacteria)
Transfer of DNA between two temporarily attached prokaryotic cells (always one-way in bacteria)	Conjugation

Phage proteins prevent synthesis of cellular proteins and fragment DNA</div><div>3.&nbsp;Fragment of DNA with A<sup>+ </sup>allele packaged into capsid during assembly of new phages</div><div>4.&nbsp;Carrier phage infects A<sup>- </sup>B<sup>-</sup>&nbsp;cell; recombination occurs between sets of DNA</div><div>5.&nbsp;Recombinant cell differs from both donor and recipient, with A<sup>+ </sup>B<sup>-</sup></div>	Transduction in Bacteria:<div><br /></div><div>1.&nbsp;<span class=cloze>Phage infects bacterial cells with A<sup>+ </sup>and B<sup>+ </sup>alleles</span></div><div>2. Obligate aerobes	Must use O<sub>2 </sub>for cellular respiration
Must use O<sub>2 </sub>for cellular respiration	Obligate aerobes
Obligate anaerobes&nbsp;	Poisoned by O<sub>2</sub>
Poisoned by O<sub>2</sub>	Obligate anaerobes&nbsp;
Anaerobic Respiration	Substances other than O<sub>2 </sub>accept electrons at end of ETC
Substances other than O<sub>2 </sub>accept electrons at end of ETC	Anaerobic Respiration
Facultative anaerobes	Use O<sub>2 </sub>if present, but can also carry out fermentation or anaerobic respiration

Nitrogen Fixation	Conversion of atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia for incorporation into organic compounds
Conversion of atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia for incorporation into organic compounds	Nitrogen Fixation

Monosaccharide	Carbohydrate composed of a single sugar molecule (e.g. glucose, fructose)
Disaccharide	Carbohydrate composed of two sugar molecules joined by glycosidic linkage (water molecule lost), e.g. sucrose
Condensation/Dehydration Reaction	Liberation of hydrogen from one molecule and hydroxide from another, forming H2O.
Hydrolysis	Splitting of a molecule through the addition of water
Polysaccharide	Series of connected monosaccharides, e.g. starch, glycogen, cellulose, chitin

Splitting a molecule through the addition of water	Hydrolysis

Defensins	Polypeptides produced by white blood cells to break bacterial cell walls
Polypeptides produced by white blood cells to break bacterial cell walls	Defensins
Collectins	Cause pathogens to clump together, allowing white blood cells to detect them more easily
Cause pathogens to clump together, allowing white blood cells to detect them more easily	Collectins
Compliment System	When stimulated by the presence of invaders, enzyme cascade activates proteins to form membrane attack complexes
When stimulated by the presence of invaders, enzyme cascade activates proteins to form membrane attack complexes	Compliment System
Histamines	Cause capillaries to leak plasma and white blood cells
Cause capillaries to leak plasma and white blood cells	Histamines
Neutrophils	Digests microorganisms in the blood, esp. parasites; 50-70% of white blood cell population, can creep out of capillary slits
Digests microorganisms in the blood, esp. parasites; 50-70% of white blood cell population, can creep out of capillary slits	Neutrophils
Macrophages	Use cytoplasmic extensions to lasso and ingest pathogens
Use cytoplasmic extensions to lasso and ingest pathogens	Macrophages
Natural Killer Cells	Attack and kill infected cells with cytoplasmic swords
Attack and kill infected cells with cytoplasmic swords	Natural Killer Cells
Lymph nodes	Where white blood cells ambush pathogens; includes tonsils, spleen
Where white blood cells ambush pathogens; includes tonsils, spleen	Lymph nodes
B cells	Produced in bone marrow and enter general circulation
Produced in bone marrow and enter general circulation	B cells
T cells	Produced in bone marrow, then migrate to thymus where they mature and learn to recognize pathogens
Produced in bone marrow, then migrate to thymus where they mature and learn to recognize pathogens	T cells
Antigen	Antibody generator; any foreign molecule recognized by immune cells
Antibody generator; any foreign molecule recognized by immune cells	Antigen
Antigen (examples)	Bee venom, allergens, bacterial cell walls, viral particles
Bee venom, allergens, bacterial cell walls, viral particles	Antigen (examples)
Antibody	Y-shaped proteins that bond to specific antigens to block movement or clump together; produced by plasma cells
Y-shaped proteins that bond to specific antigens to block movement or clump together; produced by plasma cells	Antibody
Major Histocompatibility Complex	Allows recognition of cells by immune system; in macrophage, displays fragment of antigen for recognition by T cells
Allows recognition of cells by immune system; in macrophage, displays fragment of antigen for recognition by T cells	Major Histocompatibility Complex
Cellular Immune Response	Macrophage eats pathogen, then displays antigen on surface to activate T cells
Macrophage eats pathogen, then displays antigen on surface to activate T cells	Cellular Immune Response
Helper T cells	Sense shape of antigen on macrophage; replicate and produce Interleukin I and II to activate and stimulate mitosis of other T cells
Sense shape of antigen on macrophage; replicate and produce Interleukin I and II to activate and stimulate mitosis of other T cells	Helper T cells
Cytotoxic T cells	Kill infected body cells by puncturing membrane
Kill infected body cells by puncturing membrane	Cytotoxic T cells
Memory T cells	Remember antigen and if exposed to it again rapidly divide into cytotoxic T cells
Remember antigen and if exposed to it again rapidly divide into cytotoxic T cells	Memory T cells
Humoral Immune Response	IL-II stimulates division of B cells, which mature into plasma cells to produce antibodies and memory cells
IL-II stimulates division of B cells, which mature into plasma cells to produce antibodies and memory cells	Humoral Immune Response
Mast Cells	Acquire antibodies produced by plasma cells and become sensitized to allergen in allergic response
Acquire antibodies produced by plasma cells and become sensitized to allergen in allergic response	Mast Cells
Mast Cells	Acquire antibodies produced by plasma cells and become sensitized to allergen in allergic response
Acquire antibodies produced by plasma cells and become sensitized to allergen in allergic response	Mast Cells
Hydrophobic Effect	During protein synthesis, hydrophobic R groups move towards center of protein
During protein synthesis, hydrophobic R groups move towards center of protein	Hydrophobic Effect
Disulfide Bonds	Occurs when sulfur atoms in cysteine amino acids bond to each other during protein synthesis, helping polypeptide maintain folds
Occurs when sulfur atoms in cysteine amino acids bond to each other during protein synthesis, helping polypeptide maintain folds	Disulfide Bonds
Metabolism	Chemical reactions that occur in biological systems
Chemical reactions that occur in biological systems	Metabolism
Catabolism	The breaking down of substances
The breaking down of substances	Catabolism
Anabolism	The formation of new products
The formation of new products	Anabolism
Enzymes	Globular proteins that acts as catalysts for metabolic reactions
Globular proteins that acts as catalysts for metabolic reactions	Enzymes
Substrate	Specific substace on which an enzyme acts
Specific substace on which an enzyme acts	Substrate
Denaturation	Loss of shape as hydrogen bonds and peptide bonds begin to break down
Loss of shape as hydrogen bonds and peptide bonds begin to break down	Denaturation
Induced Fit Model	Interaction of reactants and enzyme's active site causes enzyme to change shape to allow reaction
Interaction of reactants and enzyme's active site causes enzyme to change shape to allow reaction	Induced Fit Model
Cofactors	Nonprotein molecules that assist enzymes
Nonprotein molecules that assist enzymes	Cofactors
Coenzymes	Organic cofactors that usually donate or accept component of reaction
Organic cofactors that usually donate or accept component of reaction	Coenzymes
Phosphorylation	Reassembly of ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate
Reassembly of ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate	Phosphorylation
Allosteric Effector	Molecule that bonds to enzyme to regulate chemical reactions
Molecule that bonds to enzyme to regulate chemical reactions	Allosteric Effector
Allosteric Activator	Binds to enzyme and induces enzyme's active form
Binds to enzyme and induces enzyme's active form	Allosteric Activator
Allosteric Inhibitor	Binds to enzyme and induces inactive form
Binds to enzyme and induces inactive form	Allosteric Inhibitor
Feedback Inhibition	End product of series of reactions serves as allosteric inhibitor
End product of series of reactions serves as allosteric inhibitor	Feedback Inhibition
Competitive Inhibition	Substance that mimics substrate bonds to enzyme and prevents reaction
Substance that mimics substrate bonds to enzyme and prevents reaction	Competitive Inhibition
Noncompetitive Inhibition	Substance inhibits action of enzyme by bonding to it in location other than active site
Substance inhibits action of enzyme by bonding to it in location other than active site	Noncompetitive Inhibition
Cooperativity in Enzymes	Enzyme becomes more receptive to additional substrates after first substrate has bonded, e.g. hemoglobin
Enzyme becomes more receptive to additional substrates after first substrate has bonded, e.g. hemoglobin	Cooperativity in Enzymes
Plasma Membrane	Separates internal metabolic events from external environment and controls movement of materials into and out of the cell
Separates internal metabolic events from external environment and controls movement of materials into and out of the cell	Plasma Membrane
Fluid Mosaic Model	Scattered proteins within a flexible matrix of phospholipid molecules
Scattered proteins within a flexible matrix of phospholipid molecules	Fluid Mosaic Model
Permeability of plasma membrane	Only small, uncharged polar molecules&nbsp;and hydrophobic molecules can pass across membrane
Channel Proteins	Open passageways through plasma membrane for certain hydrophilic substances
Aquaporins	Channel proteins for water molecules, formed by six alpha helices bundled together with positive and negative residues (-, +, -)
Ion Channels	Allow passage of ions across plasma membrane
Gated Channels	Ion channels in nerve and muscle cells that open and close in response to chemical or electrical stimuli to allow passage of specific ions
Carrier Proteins	Bind to specific molecules (e.g. glucose) that are transferred across plasma membrane after shape change
Bind to specific molecules (e.g. glucose) that are transferred across plasma membrane after shape change	Carrier Proteins
Transport Proteins	Active transport using ATP, e.g. sodium-potassium pump
Active transport using ATP, e.g. sodium-potassium pump	Transport Proteins
Recognition Proteins	Glycoproteins in the plasma membrane that identify the cell to immune system
Glycoproteins in the plasma membrane that identify the cell to immune system	Recognition Proteins
Receptor Proteins	Provide binding sites for hormones and other trigger molecules to induce specific cellular reaction
Provide binding sites for hormones and other trigger molecules to induce specific cellular reaction	Receptor Proteins
Adhesion Proteins	Attach cells to each other or provide anchors for internal filaments and tubules
Attach cells to each other or provide anchors for internal filaments and tubules	Adhesion Proteins
Cholesterol&nbsp;	Molecule in the phospholipid bilayer that provides stability to plasma membranes of animal cells
Molecule in the phospholipid bilayer that provides stability to plasma membranes of animal cells	Cholesterol&nbsp;
Nucleus	Where genetic information is stored in the cell
Where genetic information is stored in the cell	Nucleus
Nuclear Envelope	Dual phospholipid bilayer, extends into the endoplasmic reticulum
Dual phospholipid bilayer, extends into the endoplasmic reticulum	Nuclear Envelope
Chromatin	Uncondensed DNA during interphase
Uncondensed DNA during interphase	Chromatin
Chromosome	DNA packaged for replication; two DNA molecules plus nucleosomes bundled by histomes
DNA packaged for replication; two DNA molecules plus nucleosomes bundled by histomes	Chromosome
Nuclear Pores	Serve as passageways through nuclear envelope for proteins and RNA molecules
Serve as passageways through nuclear envelope for proteins and RNA molecules	Nuclear Pores
Ribosome&nbsp;	Comprised of 60S LRS and 40S SRS that assemble into 80S ribosome during translation
Comprised of 60S LRS and 40S SRS that assemble into 80S ribosome during translation	Ribosome&nbsp;
S-Value	Measures how readily a product forms sediment in a centrifuge
Measures how readily a product forms sediment in a centrifuge	S-Value
Rough E.R.	Studded with sites where ribosomes can attach during translation; attaches polysaccharides to polypeptides as they are assembled to form glycoproteins
Studded with sites where ribosomes can attach during translation; attaches polysaccharides to polypeptides as they are assembled to form glycoproteins	Rough E.R.
Smooth E.R.	Synthesizes lipids and steroids; in liver cells, involved in breakdown of toxins
Synthesizes lipids and steroids; in liver cells, involved in breakdown of toxins	Smooth E.R.
Golgi Apparatus	Collects and modifies proteins and lipids made in other parts of the cell and package into vesicles for release at the cell membrane
Collects and modifies proteins and lipids made in other parts of the cell and package into vesicles for release at the cell membrane	Golgi Apparatus
Cisternae	Flattened sacs comprising Golgi apparatus
Flattened sacs comprising Golgi apparatus	Cisternae
Lysosomes	Vesicles from Golgi apparatus that contain hydrolytic enzymes to break down food, debris, and foreign particles
Vesicles from Golgi apparatus that contain hydrolytic enzymes to break down food, debris, and foreign particles	Lysosomes
Peroxisomes	Involved in catabolism of organic materials (e.g. fatty acids), which leads to production of hydrogen peroxide as byproduct; catalase contained in organelle used to destroy peroxide when job done&nbsp;
Involved in catabolism of organic materials (e.g. fatty acids), which leads to production of hydrogen peroxide as byproduct; catalase contained in organelle used to destroy peroxide when job done&nbsp;	Peroxisomes
Mitochondria	Carry out aerobic respiration
Carry out aerobic respiration	Mitochondria
Chloroplasts	Carry out photosynthesis
Carry out photosynthesis	Chloroplasts
Microtubules	Hollow tubulin structures that provide support and motility for cellular activities; found in spindle apparatus, flagella, and cilia
Hollow tubulin structures that provide support and motility for cellular activities; found in spindle apparatus, flagella, and cilia	Microtubules
Intermediate Filaments	Supercoiled fibrous protein; provide support for maintaining the shape of the cell
Supercoiled fibrous protein; provide support for maintaining the shape of the cell	Intermediate Filaments
Microfilaments	Actin filaments found in muscle cells and other cells that move through shape changes; involved in cytoplasmic streaming in plants
Actin filaments found in muscle cells and other cells that move through shape changes; involved in cytoplasmic streaming in plants	Microfilaments
Cytoplasmic Streaming	Movement of cytoplasmic materials around the cell
Movement of cytoplasmic materials around the cell	Cytoplasmic Streaming
Flagella and cilia	9+2 microtubule pattern; make wave-like movements&nbsp;
9+2 microtubule pattern; make wave-like movements&nbsp;	Flagella and cilia
Centrioles and basal bodies	9 triplet microtubule pattern; serve as MTOCs
9 triplet microtubule pattern; serve as MTOCs	Centrioles and basal bodies
Centrioles	Pair enclosed in centrosome&nbsp;give rise to microtubules of spindle apparatus
Pair enclosed in centrosome&nbsp;give rise to microtubules of spindle apparatus	Centrioles
Basal bodies	Organize development of flagella and cilia and anchor to cell surface
Organize development of flagella and cilia and anchor to cell surface	Basal bodies
Transport Vesicles	Move materials between organelles or between organelles and plasma membrane
Move materials between organelles or between organelles and plasma membrane	Transport Vesicles
Food Vacuoles	Temporary receptacles of nutrients; often merge with lysosomes
Temporary receptacles of nutrients; often merge with lysosomes	Food Vacuoles
Contractile Vacuoles	Collect and pump excess water out of the cell
Collect and pump excess water out of the cell	Contractile Vacuoles
Central Vacuoles	Exert turgor; store starch, nutrients, pigments, waste, toxins; carry out digestion; provide cell growth; provide favorable cytoplasm surface area
Exert turgor; store starch, nutrients, pigments, waste, toxins; carry out digestion; provide cell growth; provide favorable cytoplasm surface area	Central Vacuoles
Cell Walls	Cellulose structures that provide support for plasma membrane
Cellulose structures that provide support for plasma membrane	Cell Walls
Extracellular Matrix	Area between adjacent cells; contains fibrous structural proteins, adhesion proteins, and glycoproteins
Area between adjacent cells; contains fibrous structural proteins, adhesion proteins, and glycoproteins	Extracellular Matrix
Anchoring Junctions	Protein attachments between adjacent animal cells
Protein attachments between adjacent animal cells	Anchoring Junctions
Desmosome	Anchoring junction that provides mechanical stability to tissues; intermediate filaments extend into the cell interior
Anchoring junction that provides mechanical stability to tissues; intermediate filaments extend into the cell interior	Desmosome
Tight Junction	Tightly stitched seam between animal cells that prevents the passage of materials between the cells
Tightly stitched seam between animal cells that prevents the passage of materials between the cells	Tight Junction
Communicating Junctions	Passageways between cells that allow transfer of chemical or electrical signals
Passageways between cells that allow transfer of chemical or electrical signals	Communicating Junctions
Gap Junctions	Narrow tunnels between animal cells that allow the passage of ions and small molecules
Narrow tunnels between animal cells that allow the passage of ions and small molecules	Gap Junctions
Plasmodesmata	Narrow channels between plant cells; narrow tube of E.R. surrounded by cytoplasm and plasma membrane passes through channel
Narrow channels between plant cells; narrow tube of E.R. surrounded by cytoplasm and plasma membrane passes through channel	Plasmodesmata
Name three differences between prokaryotes and eukaryotes.	1. Presence or absence of nucleus &amp; membrane-bound organelles<div>2. Presence or absence of histone complexes in DNA<br /><div>3. Size of ribosomes (70S vs 80S)</div></div><div>4. Microtubule-less flagella in prokaryotes</div>
Hypertonic	Higher concentration of solutes
Hypotonic	Lower concentration of solutes
Lower concentration of solutes	Hypotonic
Isotonic	Equal concentration of solutes
Equal concentration of solutes	Isotonic
Bulk Flow	Collective movement of substances in same direction in response to force
Collective movement of substances in same direction in response to force	Bulk Flow
Passive Transport	Movement of substances from higher to lower concentration, without expenditure of ATP&nbsp;
Movement of substances from higher to lower concentration, without expenditure of ATP&nbsp;	Passive Transport
Turgor	Hydrostatic pressure exerted by movement of water into cells
Hydrostatic pressure exerted by movement of water into cells	Turgor
Osmosis	Diffusion of water across semi-permeable membrane
Diffusion of water across semi-permeable membrane	Osmosis
Plasmolysis	Movement of water out of cell that results in collapse of cell
Movement of water out of cell that results in collapse of cell	Plasmolysis
Cell Lysis	When swelling of cell due to osmosis causes it to burst
When swelling of cell due to osmosis causes it to burst	Cell Lysis
Facilitated Diffusion	Diffusion of solutes or water through channel proteins or carrier proteins in plasma membrane
Diffusion of solutes or water through channel proteins or carrier proteins in plasma membrane	Facilitated Diffusion
Countercurrent Exchange	Diffusion of substances between two regions through which bulk flow in opposite directions&nbsp;
Diffusion of substances between two regions through which bulk flow in opposite directions&nbsp;	Countercurrent Exchange
Active Transport	Movement of solutes against a gradient, requiring expenditure of ATP (e.g. Na/K pump)
Movement of solutes against a gradient, requiring expenditure of ATP (e.g. Na/K pump)	Active Transport
Exocytosis	Vesicles releasing substance to exterior of cell
Vesicles releasing substance to exterior of cell	Exocytosis
Endocytosis	Capture of substance outside cell in vesicle
Capture of substance outside cell in vesicle	Endocytosis
Phagocytosis	Endocytosis of undissolved substances
Endocytosis of undissolved substances	Phagocytosis
Pinocytosis	Endocytosis of dissolved substances
Endocytosis of dissolved substances	Pinocytosis
Receptor-mediated endocytosis	Specific ligands in fluid surrounding cell bind to receptors and cause it to fold inward and form vesicle
Specific ligands in fluid surrounding cell bind to receptors and cause it to fold inward and form vesicle	Receptor-mediated endocytosis
First Law of Thermodynamics	Total amount of energy in universe remains constant
Total amount of energy in universe remains constant	First Law of Thermodynamics
Second Law of Thermodynamics	Some energy always lost in energy conversions, usually as heat
Some energy always lost in energy conversions, usually as heat	Second Law of Thermodynamics
Closed System	Considers energy transfers only among specific items
Considers energy transfers only among specific items	Closed System
Open System	Includes transfers of energy with surroundings
Includes transfers of energy with surroundings	Open System
Gibbs free energy	Energy in a system available for conversions
Energy in a system available for conversions	Gibbs free energy
ΔG	Change in free energy as a result of energy conversion
Change in free energy as a result of energy conversion	ΔG
Exergonic Reaction	Negative&nbsp;ΔG - &nbsp;net release of free energy, e.g. breakdown of glucose
Negative&nbsp;ΔG - &nbsp;net release of free energy, e.g. breakdown of glucose	Exergonic Reaction
ΔG of the breakdown of glucose to CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and H<sub>2</sub>O	-686 kcal/mol
ΔG for creation of glucose from CO<sub>2 </sub>and H<sub>2</sub>O	686 kcal/mol
Endergonic Reactions	Positive&nbsp;ΔG - requires adding free energy to the reaction
Positive&nbsp;ΔG - requires adding free energy to the reaction	Endergonic Reactions
Activation Energy	Energy required to contort or destabilize reactants to allow reaction; may be lowered by presence of a catalyst
Energy required to contort or destabilize reactants to allow reaction; may be lowered by presence of a catalyst	Activation Energy
Substrate-level phosphorylation	Occurs when phosphate group and associated energy are transferred to ADP to form ATP
Occurs when phosphate group and associated energy are transferred to ADP to form ATP	Substrate-level phosphorylation
Oxidative phosphorylation	Occurs when a phosphate group is transferred to ADP without the energy to form a bond
Occurs when a phosphate group is transferred to ADP without the energy to form a bond	Oxidative phosphorylation

Recombinant DNA	Combination of nucleotide sequences from two different sources <i>in vitro</i>

Gene Cloning	Foreign DNA inserted into plasmid, subsequently into bacteria; reproduction results in cloning of plasmid incl. foreign DNA&nbsp;
Cloning Vector	DNA molecule that can carry foreign DNA ino host and replicate there; usually a plasmid
DNA molecule that can carry foreign DNA ino host and replicate there; usually a plasmid	Cloning Vector
Genomic Library&nbsp;	Storage of bacteria containing all genes in a given genome; DNA may later be denatured and radioactively tagged
Storage of bacteria containing all genes in a given genome; DNA may later be denatured and radioactively tagged	Genomic Library&nbsp;
Expression Vector	Promoter molecule more attractive to polymerase molecules, used to ensure bacteria express inserted gene&nbsp;
Promoter molecule more attractive to polymerase molecules, used to ensure bacteria express inserted gene&nbsp;	Expression Vector
Electroporation	Applying a brief electric pulse to create temporary holes in plasma membranes in order to introduce recombinant DNA to eukaryotic cells
Applying a brief electric pulse to create temporary holes in plasma membranes in order to introduce recombinant DNA to eukaryotic cells	Electroporation
Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)	"<img src=""PCR.jpg"" />"
"<img src=""PCR.jpg"" />"	Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)
Gel Electrophoresis	Use of electrical current and gel as molecular sieve to separate fragments of DNA; since DNA has an overall negative charge due to to phosphate groups, migrate toward positive electrode of electrical current applied
Use of electrical current and gel as molecular sieve to separate fragments of DNA; since DNA has an overall negative charge due to to phosphate groups, migrate toward positive electrode of electrical current applied	Gel Electrophoresis
Polymorphism	Variation in DNA sequence
Variation in DNA sequence	Polymorphism
RFLP	Restriction fragment length polymorphism - alters restriction sites
Restriction fragment length polymorphism - alters restriction sites	RFLP
Dideoxy Chain Termination	Modified nucleotides tagged with fluorescent labels to identify final nucleotide of DNA attach to synthesized strands of different lengths
Modified nucleotides tagged with fluorescent labels to identify final nucleotide of DNA attach to synthesized strands of different lengths	Dideoxy Chain Termination
Describe the characteristics of fungi.	Largely multicellular, heterotrophic, most sapphrophytic, cell walls made of chitin, feed by absorption, alteration of generations (typically haploid-dominated), hyphae, mycelium, budding
Hyphae	Branching strands of fungal cells end-to-end
Branching strands of fungal cells end-to-end	Hyphae
Mycelia	Root-like strands of bundled fungal hyphae
Root-like strands of bundled fungal hyphae	Mycelia
Zygomycota	Molds and mildews; mycorrhizae = symbiotic association with plant roots to facilitate absorption of water and nutrients
Molds and mildews; mycorrhizae = symbiotic association with plant roots to facilitate absorption of water and nutrients	Zygomycota
Ascomycota	Sac fungi, lichens (mutualistic with algae, given single species name), some parasitic
Sac fungi, lichens (mutualistic with algae, given single species name), some parasitic	Ascomycota
Basidiomycota	Club fungi, shelf fungi, toadstools, mushrooms, puffballs; sexual reproduction dominates
Club fungi, shelf fungi, toadstools, mushrooms, puffballs; sexual reproduction dominates	Basidiomycota
Ectomycorrhizae	Maximize surface area for nutrient exchange through fungal hyphae between cortical cells of root.&nbsp;
Maximize surface area for nutrient exchange through fungal hyphae between cortical cells of root.&nbsp;	Ectomycorrhizae
Arbuscular mycorrhizae	Fungal hyphae extend into cortical cells of root, forming arbuscles and fungal vesicles
Fungal hyphae extend into cortical cells of root, forming arbuscles and fungal vesicles	Arbuscular mycorrhizae
Plasmogamy	Cytoplasmic fusion in fungi
Cytoplasmic fusion in fungi	Plasmogamy
Karyogamy	Fusion of nuclei in fungi
Fusion of nuclei in fungi	Karyogamy
cDNA	Obtained through the use of reverse transcriptase to copy DNA molecules from a sample of mRNA molecules, not including introns. &nbsp;
Obtained through the use of reverse transcriptase to copy DNA molecules from a sample of mRNA molecules, not including introns. &nbsp;	cDNA
<i>In situ </i>hybridization	Uses fluorescent dyes attached to probes to identify the location of specific mRNAs in place in the intact organism
Uses fluorescent dyes attached to probes to identify the location of specific mRNAs in place in the intact organism	<i>In situ </i>hybridization
DNA Microarray Assays	Compare patterns of gene expression in different tissues, at different times, or under different conditions; fluorescence indicates expression when cDNA applied to microarray with complementary DNA
Compare patterns of gene expression in different tissues, at different times, or under different conditions; fluorescence indicates expression when cDNA applied to microarray with complementary DNA	DNA Microarray Assays
<i>In vitro </i>mutagenesis	Mutations introduced into cloned gene and returned to cell for phenotype analysis
Mutations introduced into cloned gene and returned to cell for phenotype analysis	<i>In vitro </i>mutagenesis
SNP	Single nucleotide polymorphism; may indicate location of disease-causing gene&nbsp;
Single nucleotide polymorphism; may indicate location of disease-causing gene&nbsp;	SNP
Totipotence	Capability of a cell to generate a complete new organism&nbsp;
Capability of a cell to generate a complete new organism&nbsp;	Totipotence
Nuclear Transplantation	Nucleus of an unfertilized egg cell or zygote replaced with nucleus of differentiated cell&nbsp;
Nucleus of an unfertilized egg cell or zygote replaced with nucleus of differentiated cell&nbsp;	Nuclear Transplantation
Stem Cells	Unspecialized cell that can reproduce itself indefinitely and differentiate into specialized cells; embryonic stem cells can differentiate into all cell types
Unspecialized cell that can reproduce itself indefinitely and differentiate into specialized cells; embryonic stem cells can differentiate into all cell types	Stem Cells
iPS Cells	Induced pluripotent cells, transformed from skin cells through the use of viruses to introduce stem cell master regulatory genes
Induced pluripotent cells, transformed from skin cells through the use of viruses to introduce stem cell master regulatory genes	iPS Cells
Transgenic	Animals made by introducing genes from one species into genome of another
Animals made by introducing genes from one species into genome of another	Transgenic
STRs	Short tandem repeats, variations in number of repeats of specific sequence; unique to individuals, can be used in forensics
Short tandem repeats, variations in number of repeats of specific sequence; unique to individuals, can be used in forensics	STRs
Ti Plasmid	Most common cloning vector for plant cells
Most common cloning vector for plant cells	Ti Plasmid
Cristae	Infoldings of the mitochondria's inner membrane to maximize surface area for proton pumps and ATP synthase complexes
Infoldings of the mitochondria's inner membrane to maximize surface area for proton pumps and ATP synthase complexes	Cristae
Stroma	Fluid material filling inside of chloroplast's inner membrane; where the Calvin cycle occurs
Fluid material filling inside of chloroplast's inner membrane; where the Calvin cycle occurs	Stroma
Thylakoids	Disks of chloroplasts containing protein complexes, cytochromes, and other electron carriers; protons accumulate in lumen&nbsp;
Disks of chloroplasts containing protein complexes, cytochromes, and other electron carriers; protons accumulate in lumen&nbsp;	Thylakoids
Grana	Stacks of thylakoids in chloroplasts
Stacks of thylakoids in chloroplasts	Grana
Neurotransmitter	Short-lived chemical signal that crosses gap junction to bond to specific receptor proteins
Short-lived chemical signal that crosses gap junction to bond to specific receptor proteins	Neurotransmitter
Paracrine Signaling	Local communication—cells secrete substances absorbed by nearby cells&nbsp;
Local communication—cells secrete substances absorbed by nearby cells&nbsp;	Paracrine Signaling
Ligand	Signaling molecules; first messengers that bind to receptor proteins in order to induce change
Signaling molecules; first messengers that bind to receptor proteins in order to induce change	Ligand
Hydrophilic ligands	Bind to membrane receptors at cell surface
Bind to membrane receptors at cell surface	Hydrophilic ligands
Hydrophobic ligands	Able to cross plasma membrane; bond to intracellular receptors
Able to cross plasma membrane; bond to intracellular receptors	Hydrophobic ligands
Second Messengers	Molecules that relay signal from initial receptor protein to other molecules; small, nonprotein molecules such as Ca<sup>2+ </sup>and cAMP
Molecules that relay signal from initial receptor protein to other molecules; small, nonprotein molecules such as Ca<sup>2+ </sup>and cAMP	Second Messengers
Signal Transduction Pathway	Series of molecular interactions that transform extracellular signal into specific cellular response
Series of molecular interactions that transform extracellular signal into specific cellular response	Signal Transduction Pathway
Relay/Response/Substrate/Effector Proteins	Carry signal response from receptor protein to other proteins to initiate cellular response
Carry signal response from receptor protein to other proteins to initiate cellular response	Relay/Response/Substrate/Effector Proteins
Signaling Cascade	Series of enymatic reactions amplifying response
Series of enymatic reactions amplifying response	Signaling Cascade
Kinase/Phosphorylation Cascade	Signaling cascade where each kinase phosphorylates and activates in turn to ultimately phosphorylate and activate a specific protein
Signaling cascade where each kinase phosphorylates and activates in turn to ultimately phosphorylate and activate a specific protein	Kinase/Phosphorylation Cascade
Scaffold Proteins	Improve efficiency of signaling cascade by holding all participating enzymes in close proximity
Improve efficiency of signaling cascade by holding all participating enzymes in close proximity	Scaffold Proteins
Protein Phosphatase&nbsp;	Enzyme that dephosphorylates substrate, to e.g. terminate signaling response in kinase cascade
Enzyme that dephosphorylates substrate, to e.g. terminate signaling response in kinase cascade	Protein Phosphatase&nbsp;
Advantages of signal transduction pathways (name 3):	Amplification/speed, control (all components must fuction correctly), multiplicity (single signaling molecule can activate multiple pathways, allowing coordination)
Amplification/speed, control (all components must fuction correctly), multiplicity (single signaling molecule can activate multiple pathways, allowing coordination)	Advantages of signal transduction pathways (name 3):
Describe a gated ion receptor.	Two types, ligand-gated (acetylcholine) and voltage-gated ion channels; former causes Na+ gate to open for nerve impulse/muscle contraction, latter cause Na+ and K+ gates to open for nerve transmission.&nbsp;
Acetylcholine	Transmits nerve impulses between neurons by opening ion channel for Na+ to change action potential&nbsp;
Transmits nerve impulses between neurons by opening ion channel for Na+ to change action potential&nbsp;	Acetylcholine
Describe an intracellular receptor	Cytoplasmic or nuclear receptors; steroid hormones (testosterone/estrogen) as ligands; result in e.g. development of sex characteristics
Purpose of urinary system (4):	Remove nitrogenous wastes from blood, control water balance in body, secrete erythropoietin and renin
In the nephron, <span class=cloze>[...]</span> causes water and other substances to leave the glomerulus and enter the space inside Bowman's capsule. This process is called glomerular filtration.	In the nephron, <span class=cloze>hydrostatic pressure</span> causes water and other substances to leave the glomerulus and enter the space inside Bowman's capsule. This process is called glomerular filtration.<br>

This process is called glomerular filtration.<br>

This process is called glomerular filtration.<br> 
In the nephron, hydrostatic pressure causes water and other substances to leave the glomerulus and enter the space inside Bowman's capsule. This process is called <span class=cloze>[...]</span>.	In the nephron, hydrostatic pressure causes water and other substances to leave the glomerulus and enter the space inside Bowman's capsule. This process is called <span class=cloze>glomerular filtration</span>.<br> 
In the nephron, as <span class=cloze>[...]</span> passes through the proximal convoluted tubule, substances such as glucose are brought back into the capillaries through reabsorption. As it passes through the distal convoluted tubule, tubular secretion causes substances such as nitrogenous wastes to be transported into the tubule for excretion.&nbsp;	In the nephron, as <span class=cloze>glomerular filtrate</span> passes through the proximal convoluted tubule, substances such as glucose are brought back into the capillaries through reabsorption. As it passes through the distal convoluted tubule, tubular secretion causes substances such as nitrogenous wastes to be transported into the tubule for excretion.&nbsp;<br>
