As it passes through the distal convoluted tubule, <span class=cloze>[...]</span> causes substances such as nitrogenous wastes to be transported into the tubule for excretion.&nbsp;	In the nephron, as glomerular filtrate passes through the proximal convoluted tubule, substances such as glucose are brought back into the capillaries through reabsorption. As it passes through the distal convoluted tubule, <span class=cloze>tubular secretion</span> causes substances such as nitrogenous wastes to be transported into the tubule for excretion.&nbsp;<br> 
Describe how the kidney retains water.	In the proximal convoluted tubule, Na+/K+ pumps move ions into the capillaries, causing diffusion of water into the blood; in the Loop of Henle, pumps in the water impermeable side of the loop move ions into the tissue, causing diffusion of water from the water permeable side into collecting ducts.&nbsp;
Explain the renin-angiotensin system.&nbsp;	Decreasing blood pressure and/or sodium ion concentration stimulate secretion of renin and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), which convert angiotensinogen to angiotensin II, which stimulates the production of aldosterone to preserve water.&nbsp;
Cholera	Waterborne bacteria secrete a toxin that prevents the deactivation of GCPRs, resulting in continual generation of cAMP, transportation of Cl-, and osmosis of water into lumen of intestine, causing diarrhea and potentially fatal dehydration.&nbsp;
Cancer	Damaged protein 53 (product of p53 transcription factor) prevents DNA surveillance and apoptosis of damaged cells, leading to uncontrolled replication and proliferation of malignant cells; begins with transformation/mutation, then proliferation into tumor, becomes invasive/malignant and starts interfering with normal function, may metastatize and spread through bloodstream
Nonvascular plants	No xylem or phloem, e.g. mosses
No xylem or phloem, e.g. mosses	Nonvascular plants
Vascular plants	Possess xylem and phloem for conducting water and photosynthesis products
Possess xylem and phloem for conducting water and photosynthesis products	Vascular plants
Lower vascular plants	Reproduce using spores, e.g. ferns
Reproduce using spores, e.g. ferns	Lower vascular plants
Higher vascular plants	Reproduce using seeds
Reproduce using seeds	Higher vascular plants
Gymnosperms	"Don't produce flowers, ""naked seeds,"" e.g. pines"
"Don't produce flowers, ""naked seeds,"" e.g. pines"	Gymnosperms
Angiosperms	Produce flowers
Produce flowers	Angiosperms
Monocots	One seed-leaf, e.g. grasses
One seed-leaf, e.g. grasses	Monocots
Eudicots	Two seed-leaves, e.g. oaks
Two seed-leaves, e.g. oaks	Eudicots
Root hairs	Extensions of a plant's epidermal cells into its substrate to increase the absorbing surface area
Extensions of a plant's epidermal cells into its substrate to increase the absorbing surface area	Root hairs
Mycorrhizae	Mutualistic associations of fungi that absorb water and nutrients with plants that provide the fungus with sugars
Mutualistic associations of fungi that absorb water and nutrients with plants that provide the fungus with sugars	Mycorrhizae
Palisade mesophyll	Tightly packed vertical cells at leaf surface, where most photosynthesis takes place.&nbsp;
Tightly packed vertical cells at leaf surface, where most photosynthesis takes place.&nbsp;	Palisade mesophyll
Spongy mesophyll	Loosely arranged photosynthetic cells with spaces to allow gas exchange
Loosely arranged photosynthetic cells with spaces to allow gas exchange	Spongy mesophyll
Stomata	Openings in epidermis of leaves to allow CO2 to enter and O2 to exit.&nbsp;
Openings in epidermis of leaves to allow CO2 to enter and O2 to exit.&nbsp;	Stomata
Transpiration	Loss of water through evaporation
Loss of water through evaporation	Transpiration
Cuticle	Waxy covering of leaf to reduce transpiration
Waxy covering of leaf to reduce transpiration	Cuticle
Guard cell&nbsp;	Control opening and closing of stomata to prevent excessive transpiration in dry environments; when light sensed, H+ pumped out of guard cells and ions (K+/Cl-) migrate in, followed by water.&nbsp;
Control opening and closing of stomata to prevent excessive transpiration in dry environments; when light sensed, H+ pumped out of guard cells and ions (K+/Cl-) migrate in, followed by water.&nbsp;	Guard cell&nbsp;
Sunken stomata	Stomata that occur in depressions below the surrounding leaf surface to reduce transpiration caused by movement of wind&nbsp;
Stomata that occur in depressions below the surrounding leaf surface to reduce transpiration caused by movement of wind&nbsp;	Sunken stomata
Trichomes	Plant hairs that can interfere with air movement, increase solar reflection, reduce browsing, and discourage egg laying; if glandular, may secrete toxic substances
Plant hairs that can interfere with air movement, increase solar reflection, reduce browsing, and discourage egg laying; if glandular, may secrete toxic substances	Trichomes
Flowers	Reproductive organs that produce gametes (eggs and pollen) and allow pollen to be transported to other flowers
Reproductive organs that produce gametes (eggs and pollen) and allow pollen to be transported to other flowers	Flowers
Xylem	Transports water and minerals and provides mechanical support to vascular plants; columns of largely dead cells with openings at either end
Transports water and minerals and provides mechanical support to vascular plants; columns of largely dead cells with openings at either end	Xylem
Phloem	Transports products of photosynthesis, e.g. sugars; living cells with pores acting as fluid-conducting columns
Transports products of photosynthesis, e.g. sugars; living cells with pores acting as fluid-conducting columns	Phloem
Apical meristem	Where plant puts on length-wise growth
Where plant puts on length-wise growth	Apical meristem
Describe the principal tenets of cohesion-tension theory	• Transpiration removes water from leaves<div>• Adhesion of water to xylem walls prevents it from descending under gravity</div><div>• Cohesion of water produces single polymer-like water column&nbsp;</div><div>• Tension causes the movement of water to replace evaporated molecules</div>
Ethylene	Gas produced by ripening fruit and filling intercellular air spaces, which promotes enzymatic breakdown
Describe phototropism in plants.	Auxin produced in apical meristem, moves down shoot and generates growth by activating proton pumps which decreases pH to activate an enzyme that breaks down connections between cellulose fibers which increases absorption of water and therefore turgor; when apical meristem unevenly lit, auxin collects on shady side and causes more growth on that side, causing plant to bend towards light source.&nbsp;
Describe gravitropism in plants.&nbsp;	Amyloplasts sink to the bottom of cells and may be involved; auxin is also likely involved (causing horizontal stems to grow up, etc.).&nbsp;
Describe dormancy in plants.	• Abcission: Photosynthesis shut down and leaves dropped during winter, with resources withdrawn first (e.g. chlorophyll); apical meristems protected with bud scales<div>• Seed dormancy: Absence of water in seeds arrests metabolic activity, prevents germination; seed coat protects embryo and nutritive material from organisms (incl. microbes)</div>
Describe seed germination and the breaking of dormancy in plants.&nbsp;	Water necessary to activate enzymes that stimulate cellular respiration, oxygen required for aerobic respiration, gibberellins provide enzymes necessary to germination; temperature, fire, photoperiods, and scarification sometimes act as stimuli.
Gibberellins	Plant hormones that bind to DNA and release transcription factors to activate genes producing enzymes necessary for germination.&nbsp;
Plant hormones that bind to DNA and release transcription factors to activate genes producing enzymes necessary for germination.&nbsp;	Gibberellins
Describe the maintenance of the circadian rhythm in plants.	P<sub>r </sub>and P<sub>fr </sub>are photoreversible; P<sub>r </sub>synthesized by plant cells converted to P<sub>fr </sub>when exposed to red light; P<sub>fr</sub>, or active form of P<sub>r</sub>, converted back to P<sub>r</sub>&nbsp;when exposed to far-red light. P<sub>fr </sub>accumulates during the day, and P<sub>r </sub>accumulates at night; night length responsible for resetting circadian-rhythm clock through ratio of P<sub>r </sub>to P<sub>fr</sub>
List the three types of flowering plants.	• Long-day plants: Flower in spring and early summer; flower when daylight exceeds defined length<div>• Short-day plants: Flower in late summer and early fall; flower when daylight is less than defined length</div><div>• Day-neutral plants: Flower in response to environmental cue such as temperature or water</div>
Describe structural defenses of plants.&nbsp;	Sharp thorns/spines, irritating trichomes, glandular trichomes, tree bark, seed coats
Describe chemical defenses of plants.&nbsp;	Secondary metabolites to discourage browsing, including nicotine (tobacco), capsicum (hot peppers), mustard oils (broccoli), all toxic to insects. Many metabolites toxic only after digestion.&nbsp;
Describe symbiotic defenses of plants.&nbsp;	Parasitoid wasps recruited to attack browsing insects that release attracting chemicals; volatile substances produced warn neighboring plants; certain acacias employ ants to attack browsers and trim shading plants.&nbsp;
Describe wound responses in plants.&nbsp;	• Systemin hormone produced in response to saliva of insect, distributed through plant via phloem, and elicits production of proteinase inhibitors that inactivate digestive enzymes in insect gut<div>• In hypersensitive response, pathogen invasion spurs apoptosis for containment when R protein of plant binds to protein of pathogen.&nbsp;</div>
Cytokinesis in plants vs. animals	Plants - Vesicles from Golgi body migrate to metaphase plate and fuse to form cell plate&nbsp;<div>Animals - Microfilaments form ring inside plasma membrane and tighten, cleavage furrow dividing cell in two</div>
List the phases of the cell cycle.&nbsp;	<div>G0 - Exit from cell cycle</div>G1 - Growth<div>S - Duplication of DNA and growth</div><div>G2 - Preparation for cell division and growth</div><div>M - Prophase, metaphase, anaphase, telophase, cytokinesis</div>
<p>Please edit this note and add some cloze deletions. (<a href=http://ankisrs.net/docs/manual.html#cloze>help</a>)	<br> 
Wavelengths of light plants can use for photosynthesis	680 and 700 nm; PS II uses 680, PS I uses 700&nbsp;
Why did plants have to adapt to terrestrial life?	Photosynthesis requires red light; not enough dissolved gases
Evidence for evolution of plants from green algae	Chlorophyll B, storage of energy in starch, cellulose, chloroplast structure and DNA, mitotic divisions
Plant adaptations to terrestrial life	Multicellularity (large size advantageous in unstable terrestrial environment), stomata and guard cells (allow gas exchange with deep tissue and prevention of dehydration), cuticle (reduce transpiration), roots (absorption from soil), lignin (protein that binds together cellulose fibers and hardens cell wall to resist gravitational force)
Apoplast	Transporting water to xylem through linkages in cell walls&nbsp;
Transporting water to xylem through linkages in cell walls&nbsp;	Apoplast
Symplastic	Transporting water to xylem through plasmodesmata
Transporting water to xylem through plasmodesmata	Symplastic
Describe the two functional limitations on cell size that influence division.	• Surface-to-volume ratio: When exchange of substances with inner cell becomes difficult<div>• Genome-to-volume ratio: When genome can't produce enough material to regulate cellular activity</div>
Describe the three major checkpoints of the cell cycle.	• G<sub>1 </sub>checkpoint: At end of G<sub>1 </sub>phase, quality of DNA evaluated and repair attempted or apoptosis triggered; if nutrients/growth factors absent, remains in G<sub>1 </sub>until conditions appropriate<div>• G<sub>2 </sub>checkpoint: At end of G<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;phase, replication accuracy evaluated and instructions given to begin mitosis/repair DNA/initiate apoptosis</div><div>• M checkpoint: During metaphase, ensures microtubules properly attached to kinetochores at metaphase plate before division continues</div>
Cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks)	Kinases that phosphorylate proteins to advance cell past checkpoint; activated by specific cyclins that are destroyed after checkpoint passed (vary throughout cycle); e.g. mitosis-promoting factor or MPF is complex that allows cell to pass through G<sub>2 </sub>checkpoint to&nbsp;enter mitosis.&nbsp;
Kinases that phosphorylate proteins to advance cell past checkpoint; activated by specific cyclins that are destroyed after checkpoint passed (vary throughout cycle); e.g. mitosis-promoting factor or MPF is complex that allows cell to pass through G<sub>2 </sub>checkpoint to&nbsp;enter mitosis.&nbsp;	Cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks)
Describe the external factors that influence the cell cycle.&nbsp;	• Growth factors: Bind to plasma membrane of specific cells and stimulate division, e.g. platelet-derived growth factor stimlates division of fibroblasts for scabbing<div>• Density-dependent inhibition: Cells may stop dividing when surrounding cell density reaches certain maximum</div><div>• Anchorage dependence: Cells only divide when attached to external surface, e.g. neighboring cells</div>
Law of Segregation	Chromatids migrate to opposite poles during meiosis II, so each gamete contains only one copy of a chromosome
Chromatids migrate to opposite poles during meiosis II, so each gamete contains only one copy of a chromosome	Law of Segregation
Law of Independent Assortment	Migration of homologues in one pair does not influence migration in other homologous pairs during meiosis, so each trait determined independently (not true with loci physically close together)
Migration of homologues in one pair does not influence migration in other homologous pairs during meiosis, so each trait determined independently (not true with loci physically close together)	Law of Independent Assortment
Monohybrid Cross	Only one trait is being investigated
Only one trait is being investigated	Monohybrid Cross
Dihybrid Cross	Two traits investigated in a cross.&nbsp;
Two traits investigated in a cross.&nbsp;	Dihybrid Cross
Complete dominance vs. incomplete dominance vs. codominance	One trait, blend of both traits, or both traits simultaneously expressed, respectively
Polygenic Inheritance	Interaction of many genes to shape single phenotype
Interaction of many genes to shape single phenotype	Polygenic Inheritance
Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)	Produced by pituitary; stimulates growth and development of follicle in ovary
Produced by pituitary; stimulates growth and development of follicle in ovary	Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
Estrogen	Produced by walls of follicle in ovary to allow brain to determine size of follicle&nbsp;
Produced by walls of follicle in ovary to allow brain to determine size of follicle&nbsp;	Estrogen
Luteinizing Hormone (LH)	Produced by brain to stimulate ovulation and expulsion of developed follicle and subsequent development of corpus luteum
Produced by brain to stimulate ovulation and expulsion of developed follicle and subsequent development of corpus luteum	Luteinizing Hormone (LH)
Progesterone	Produced by corpus luteum to stop the production of FSH in the pituitary and cause thickening of the endometrium in the uterus for the embryo to parasitize
Produced by corpus luteum to stop the production of FSH in the pituitary and cause thickening of the endometrium in the uterus for the embryo to parasitize	Progesterone
Autosome	Non-sex chromosomes.&nbsp;
Non-sex chromosomes.&nbsp;	Autosome
Barr body	X-inactivation occurs when one X chromosome doesn't uncoil into chromatin but remains condensed; daughter cells have same chromosome inactivated - this is why women are stripey
X-inactivation occurs when one X chromosome doesn't uncoil into chromatin but remains condensed; daughter cells have same chromosome inactivated - this is why women are stripey	Barr body
Nondisjunction	Failure of one or more chromosome pairs or chromatids of single chromosome to properly move to opposite poles
Failure of one or more chromosome pairs or chromatids of single chromosome to properly move to opposite poles	Nondisjunction
Mosaicism	Fraction of body cells have missing or extra chromosomes due to nondisjunction during meiosis
Fraction of body cells have missing or extra chromosomes due to nondisjunction during meiosis	Mosaicism
Polyploidy	Occurs when all chromosomes undergo meiotic nondisjunction and produe gametes with twice usual number of chromosomes; tetraploid individuals cannot interbreed with their origin species because triploidy is fatal&nbsp;
Occurs when all chromosomes undergo meiotic nondisjunction and produe gametes with twice usual number of chromosomes; tetraploid individuals cannot interbreed with their origin species because triploidy is fatal&nbsp;	Polyploidy
Point mutations&nbsp;	Single nucleotide in DNA incorrect; substitution, deletion, or insertion
Single nucleotide in DNA incorrect; substitution, deletion, or insertion	Point mutations&nbsp;
Sickle-cell disease	Nucleotide substitution produces defective hemoglobin (oxygen-carrying protein), which causes deformity of red blood cells in low-oxygen conditions, prevents movement through capillaries, and causes anemia; however, heterozygote advantage means individuals heterozygous for sickle-cell gene resistant to malaria
Nucleotide substitution produces defective hemoglobin (oxygen-carrying protein), which causes deformity of red blood cells in low-oxygen conditions, prevents movement through capillaries, and causes anemia; however, heterozygote advantage means individuals heterozygous for sickle-cell gene resistant to malaria	Sickle-cell disease
Tay-Sachs disease	Nucleotide insertion causes lysosome to lack enzyme necessary to break down certain fats, causing buildup in nerve cells and early death
Nucleotide insertion causes lysosome to lack enzyme necessary to break down certain fats, causing buildup in nerve cells and early death	Tay-Sachs disease
Aneuploidy	Genome with extra or missing chromosomes, usually caused by nondisjunction
Genome with extra or missing chromosomes, usually caused by nondisjunction	Aneuploidy
Down syndrome	Gamete with extra chromosome 21 fuses with normal gamete, resulting in trisomy 21 and mental and physical issues
Gamete with extra chromosome 21 fuses with normal gamete, resulting in trisomy 21 and mental and physical issues	Down syndrome
Turner syndrome	Nondisjunction of sex chromosomes results in gamete with no sex chromosomes fusing with X gamete to form XO zygote (sterile female; physical abnormalities)
Nondisjunction of sex chromosomes results in gamete with no sex chromosomes fusing with X gamete to form XO zygote (sterile female; physical abnormalities)	Turner syndrome
Klinefelter syndrome	Nondisjunction results in XX or XY gamete that fuses with X gamete to produce XXY gamete (male, may be sterile and express female secondary sex characteristics)
Nondisjunction results in XX or XY gamete that fuses with X gamete to produce XXY gamete (male, may be sterile and express female secondary sex characteristics)	Klinefelter syndrome
Chromosomal duplications (&amp; example)	Chromosome segment repeated on same chromosome, e.g. Huntington's disease codes for defective enzyme that causes death of nerve cells in brain
Chromosome segment repeated on same chromosome, e.g. Huntington's disease codes for defective enzyme that causes death of nerve cells in brain	Chromosomal duplications (&amp; example)
Chromosomal inversions	Chromosome segments rearranged; usually no abnormalities
Chromosome segments rearranged; usually no abnormalities	Chromosomal inversions
Chromosomal translocations	Segment of chromosome moved to other chromosome; e.g. Down syndrome can also occur with 14/21 (to 14 from 21) translocation.&nbsp;
Segment of chromosome moved to other chromosome; e.g. Down syndrome can also occur with 14/21 (to 14 from 21) translocation.&nbsp;	Chromosomal translocations
Maternal inheritance	Mitochrondral or chloroplast DNA inherited from mother through organelles in gamete
Mitochrondral or chloroplast DNA inherited from mother through organelles in gamete	Maternal inheritance
Give three examples of environmental influences on phenotypic expression.&nbsp;	Nutrition (e.g. insufficient calcium), temperature (incubation determines sex), day length/UV exposure (darker coloration)
Frederick Griffith	Discovered transformation between bacteria by mixing dead disease-causing bacteria and live innocuous bacteria.&nbsp;
Discovered transformation between bacteria by mixing dead disease-causing bacteria and live innocuous bacteria.&nbsp;	Frederick Griffith
Avery, MacLeod, and McCarty	Through experiments on tranformation in bacteria, determined DNA to inform heredity
Through experiments on tranformation in bacteria, determined DNA to inform heredity	Avery, MacLeod, and McCarty
Hershey and Chase	Established that DNA was genetic material of phages by inserting radioactive material in phage proteins, then phage DNA, discovering that DNA entered bacteria
Established that DNA was genetic material of phages by inserting radioactive material in phage proteins, then phage DNA, discovering that DNA entered bacteria	Hershey and Chase
Watson, Crick, Wilkins, and Franklin	Determined the structure of DNA through Franklin's X-ray crystallography and Watson and Crick's model-building.&nbsp;
Determined the structure of DNA through Franklin's X-ray crystallography and Watson and Crick's model-building.&nbsp;	Watson, Crick, Wilkins, and Franklin
Semiconservative Replication	Both products of DNA replication contain one strand of original molecule and one new strand
Both products of DNA replication contain one strand of original molecule and one new strand	Semiconservative Replication
Helicase	Unwinds DNA helix to form Y-shaped replication fork
Unwinds DNA helix to form Y-shaped replication fork	Helicase
Single-strand binding proteins	Attach to each strand of uncoiled DNA at replication fork to keep strands separated
Attach to each strand of uncoiled DNA at replication fork to keep strands separated	Single-strand binding proteins
Topoisomerases	Break and rejoin double helix during DNA replication to unravel twists and prevent knots
Break and rejoin double helix during DNA replication to unravel twists and prevent knots	Topoisomerases
DNA Polymerase	In assembly of nucleotides during DNA replication, moves in 3'-5' direction along each DNA template strand&nbsp;
In assembly of nucleotides during DNA replication, moves in 3'-5' direction along each DNA template strand&nbsp;	DNA Polymerase
Lagging strand	5'-3' strand of DNA means DNA polymerase can only move away from replication fork, forming Okazaki fragments as it returns to fork again and again&nbsp;
5'-3' strand of DNA means DNA polymerase can only move away from replication fork, forming Okazaki fragments as it returns to fork again and again&nbsp;	Lagging strand
Primase	Begins replication with short segment of RNA nucleotides, with which leading strand and every Okazaki fragment must begin&nbsp;
Begins replication with short segment of RNA nucleotides, with which leading strand and every Okazaki fragment must begin&nbsp;	Primase
Telomerase	Extends lagging strand of DNA to prevent loss of important DNA at end of strand when DNA polymerase cannot attach to replace lost primers; becomes less active with age
Extends lagging strand of DNA to prevent loss of important DNA at end of strand when DNA polymerase cannot attach to replace lost primers; becomes less active with age	Telomerase
Mechanisms to repair errors in DNA replication	• Proofreading: DNA polymerase checks to ensure correct pairing<div>• Mismatch Repair: Proteins repair errors that escaped polymerase</div><div>• Excision Repair: Identify and remove entire section of damaged DNA</div>
Frameshift mutation	Deletion or insertion that causes diplacement of all subsequent nucleotides&nbsp;
Deletion or insertion that causes diplacement of all subsequent nucleotides&nbsp;	Frameshift mutation
Silent mutation	Point mutation results in new codon that codes for same amino acid; in last of three nuceotides, may be aided by wobble pairing
Point mutation results in new codon that codes for same amino acid; in last of three nuceotides, may be aided by wobble pairing	Silent mutation
Missense mutation	Point mutation resulting in codon that codes for new amino acid, which may prevent proper folding
Point mutation resulting in codon that codes for new amino acid, which may prevent proper folding	Missense mutation
Nonsense mutation	Point mutation causes new codon to code for stop codon, preventing completion of translation
Point mutation causes new codon to code for stop codon, preventing completion of translation	Nonsense mutation
Transposons	Naturally occuring mutations that insert themselves throughout genome after copying or deleting selves from other area
Naturally occuring mutations that insert themselves throughout genome after copying or deleting selves from other area	Transposons
Endoderm	Develops into digestive tract and accessory organs, respiratory system
Develops into digestive tract and accessory organs, respiratory system	Endoderm
Mesoderm	Develops into circulatory, reproductive, urinary, skeleto-muscular systems
Develops into circulatory, reproductive, urinary, skeleto-muscular systems	Mesoderm
Ectoderm	Develops into skin, nervous system
Develops into skin, nervous system	Ectoderm
Morphogenesis	Orderly changes in embryo's size and proportions due to migration and proliferation of cells, directed by pseudopodia and cytoskeleton
Orderly changes in embryo's size and proportions due to migration and proliferation of cells, directed by pseudopodia and cytoskeleton	Morphogenesis
Phases of Meiosis	<div>1. Prophase I - Chromosomes appear, nuclear envelope disappears, spindle apparatus develops, homologous chromosomes pair with each other and cross over</div><div>2. Metaphase I - Chromosomes align doubly on metaphase plate; microtubules attach to both members of homologous chromosome pairs</div><div>3. Anaphase I - Homologues uncouple and travel to poles</div><div>4. Telophase I - Nuclear membrane reappears, forming two nuclei with half usual number of chromosomes, but each chromosome has two chromatids</div><div>Cytokinesis or Interphase II</div><div>5. Prophase II - Nuclear envelope disappears, spindle apparatus develops</div><div>6. Metaphase II - Chromosomes align singly on metaphase plate</div><div>7. Anaphase II - Chromosomes separate into chromatids and migrate along microtubules to poles</div><div>8. Telophase II - Nuclear envelope reappears, cytokinesis divides daughter cell into four haploid cells with a single chromatid</div>
G Protein Transduction Pathway	<div>1. GPCR receives signal from ligand</div><div>2. GPCR activates G protein by displacing GDP with GTP&nbsp;</div><div>3. G protein binds to effector proteins</div><div>4. Effector protein initiates response (enzymatic activity, production of cAMP, production of IP3 and DAG, production of Ca2+)</div><div>5. GPCR signaling is deactivated when GTP is hydrolyzed&nbsp;</div>
Conjugation and Transfer of F Plasmid	<div>1. F+ cell forms mating bridge with F- cell; one strand of plasmid DNA breaks</div><div>2. F+ cell synthesizes new plasmid strand; broken strand enters F- cell to begin synthesis</div><div>3. Synthesis continues as broken strand moves farther into F- cell</div><div>4. Plasmid in recipient cell circularizes; both cells are now F+</div>
Alternation of Generations in Plants	<div>1. Fertilization/Syngamy</div><div>2. Zygote</div><div>3. Embryo</div><div>4. Sporophyte</div><div>5. Meiosis</div><div>6. Spores</div><div>7. Gametophyte</div><div>8. Mitosis</div><div>9. Gametes</div>
Basidiomycete Life Cycle	<div>1. Haploid mycelia of different mating types undergo plasmogamy</div><div>2. Dikaryotic mycelium grows, crowds out parents</div><div>3. Environmental cues induce mycelium to form basidiocarps</div><div>4. Karyogamy in basidium (terminal dikaryotic cells in gills) produce diploid nuclei</div><div>5. After meiosis, each diploid nucleus yields four haploid cells to form basidiospores</div><div>6. Mature basidiospores dispersed by wind</div><div>7. Basidiospores germinate and grow into haploid mycelia</div>
Life Cycle of Malaria Parasite&nbsp;	<div>1. Sporozoites inoculated into human host by mosquito; invade liver cells</div><div>2. Sporozoites divide into many merozoites or dormant hypnozoites</div><div>3. Merozoites enter bloodstream and mature into schizonts that rupture to release more merozoites</div><div>4. Some merozoites instead develop into male and female gametocytes for sexual reproduction</div><div>5. Mosquito ingests gametocytes, which develop into gametes in the midgut</div><div>6. Gametes fuse to form diploid zygotes, which develop into ookinetes that burrow through the mosquito midgut wall and form oocysts on the other side.</div><div>7. Oocysts produce sporozoites that travel to the mosquito's salivary glands</div>
Development of Flowers	<div>1. Concentration of CONSTANS (CO) protein measures day length</div><div>2. Phytochromes regulate CO concentrations</div><div>3. CO stimulates transcription of of FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene</div><div>4. FT mRNA produces FT protein that travels through phloem to shoot apex to initiate flower development.</div><div><br /></div><div>FT is believed to be the theorized florigen.&nbsp;</div>
Mold Life Cycle	<div>1. Two mating types come in contact</div><div>2. Hyphal extensions called gametangia containing multiple haploid nuclei formed</div><div>Plasmogamy</div><div>3. Zygosporanium containing haploid nuclei from both parents formed</div><div>4. Zygosporanium develops thick-walled coating to resist harsh conditions</div><div>Karyogamy (when conditions favorable)</div><div>Meiosis</div><div>5. Sporangium disperses genetically diverse haploid spores&nbsp;</div><div>(Sporangium can also disperse identical haploid spores if produced asexually)</div><div>6. Spores germinate, grow into new mycelia</div>
Levels of Protein Structure	<div>Primary Structure - Order of amino acids</div><div>Secondary Structure - Shape that occurs as a result of hydrogen bonding (alpha helix/pleated sheet)</div><div>Tertiary Structure - Additional shaping, incl. bonding between R groups, hydrophobic effect, disulphide bonds</div><div>Quaternary Structure - &nbsp;Assemblage of multiple peptide chains into a protein</div>
RTK Transduction Sequence	<div>1. RTK receives signal at outer surface of membrane</div><div>2. Two RTKs associate, forming dimer</div><div>3. RTK is activated by autophosphorylation</div><div>4. Relay protein(s) are activated by phosphorylation</div><div>5. Relay protein(s) activate transduction pathway(s)</div><div>6. RTK pathway is deactivated by dephosphorylation or isolation</div>
Creation of Recombinant DNA	<div>1. Restriction enzyme cuts sugar-phosphate backbones</div><div>2. DNA fragment added from molecule cut by same enzyme; base pairing occurs</div><div>3. DNA ligase seals strands&nbsp;</div>
Eudicot Life Cycle	<div>1. Mature flower on sporophyte plant possesses ovary and anthers</div><div>2. Anthers produce microspores in pollen grains, while ovules in ovaries produce megaspores that undergo mitosis to become eggs</div><div>3. After being dispersed, pollen grains land on stigma and sperm crawl down pollen tube to egg</div><div>4. Pollen tube connects to egg nucleus and discharged sperm nuclei fertilize egg</div><div>5. Fertilized egg contains zygote and developing endosperm</div><div>6. Egg develops into sperm with an embryo, endosperm food supply, and seed coat</div><div>7. Seed germinates into sporophyte plant.</div>
Redox Reactions	Reduction/oxidation reactions; reduction = gain of electrons/loss of oxygen, oxidation = loss of electrons/gain of oxygen
Glycogen	Animal starch; branched
Animal starch; branched	Glycogen
Amylose	Plant starch; looped
Plant starch; looped	Amylose
Omega-3 vs Omega-6 Fatty Acids	Dietary fats; carboxyl end of fatty acid = alpha end, other end omega; distance of double-bonded carbon atom from omega end determines whether omega-3 or omega-6.&nbsp;
Digestion of Saturated vs. Unsaturated Fats	Enzymes break molecule at double bonds, so unsaturated fats get broken down into smaller pieces while saturated fats get folded into cholesterol and then into other steroids if needed
Amino Acid Structure	"<img src=""Amino-Acid-Structure.jpg"" />"
Acid	Donates H+
Donates H+	Acid
Base	Accepts H+
Accepts H+	Base
Types of Isomers	• Structural Isomers - same formula, built differently (e.g. glucose)<div>• Geometric Isomers - same structure, differ in e.g. double bonding<br></div><div>• Enantiomers - mirror each other<br></div>
"<img src=""Amino-Acid-Structure.jpg"" />"	Amino Acid Structure
Nucleotide base pairing	A and G are purines; T, C, and U are pyrimidines. Purines and pyrimidines bond.&nbsp;

Endomembrane System	Includes nuclear envelope, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi body, vesicles, vacuoles, lysosomes, and other membrane-bound cellular parts, but not endosymbionts
Includes nuclear envelope, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi body, vesicles, vacuoles, lysosomes, and other membrane-bound cellular parts, but not endosymbionts	Endomembrane System
Nucleolus	Dense chromatin at center of nucleus, site of ribosomal RNA synthesis, size varies with protein needs of cells, but number is constant within species
Dense chromatin at center of nucleus, site of ribosomal RNA synthesis, size varies with protein needs of cells, but number is constant within species	Nucleolus
Nuclear pore complex	Protein structure allowing passage of proteins and mRNA through nuclear membrane bilayer
Protein structure allowing passage of proteins and mRNA through nuclear membrane bilayer	Nuclear pore complex
Dialysis	The movement of a solute through a selectively permeable membrane
The movement of a solute through a selectively permeable membrane	Dialysis
Water Potential Equation	Ψ (water potential) =&nbsp;Ψ<sub>p</sub>&nbsp;(pressure potential) +&nbsp;Ψ<sub>s</sub>&nbsp;(solute potential)
Middle Lamella	Pectin layer cementing cell walls of adjacent plants together

Electron carriers in ETC	NADH allows pumping of 10 H+, FADH<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;6; ATP synthase phosphorylates one ATP per 4 H+.&nbsp;
End of ETC	4H<sup>+ </sup>+ 4e<sup>- </sup>+ O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;--&gt; 2H<sub>2</sub>O
Chemiosmosis	Powering the synthesis of ATP through a proton gradient across the inner mitochondral membrane, which causes ATP Synthase to rotate and open and close active sites that synthesize ATP from ADP&nbsp;
Powering the synthesis of ATP through a proton gradient across the inner mitochondral membrane, which causes ATP Synthase to rotate and open and close active sites that synthesize ATP from ADP&nbsp;	Chemiosmosis
How does the cell use excess glucose?	Excess glucose is stored in starch or in fat. When fat is used, it is broken down into a glycerol 'backbone' and three fatty acids. The glycerol is turned into Pgal through gluconeogenesis and fed into glycolysis, while the fatty acids are turned into Acetyl CoA and used to power the Krebs cycle.&nbsp;
Excess glucose is stored in starch or in fat. When fat is used, it is broken down into a glycerol 'backbone' and three fatty acids. The glycerol is turned into Pgal through gluconeogenesis and fed into glycolysis, while the fatty acids are turned into Acetyl CoA and used to power the Krebs cycle.&nbsp;	How does the cell use excess glucose?
ATP	Adenosine triphosphate, inherently unstable due to shape (adenine, ribose, three phosphates); work done due to shape change caused by addition of P<sub>i</sub>&nbsp;or energy released when bond broken
Adenosine triphosphate, inherently unstable due to shape (adenine, ribose, three phosphates); work done due to shape change caused by addition of P<sub>i</sub>&nbsp;or energy released when bond broken	ATP
How does a non-steroidal hormone communicate with a cell?	The hormone binds to a receptor site on the surface of the cell, which triggers a transduction pathway that causes the physiological change either immediately or through a second messenger.&nbsp;
How does a steroidal hormone communicate with a cell?	The hormone travels into the nucleus and binds to a receptor protein that causes mRNA synthesis, which ultimately results in the production of a protein to carry out a specific cellular activity.&nbsp;
Nervous System	Central nervous system - Controls cognition; storage and synthesis of information<div>Peripheral nervous system - Controls body/motor action</div><div>—Somatic nervous system - Controls intentional motor action</div><div>——Afferent neurons - Transmit sensory information to brain</div><div>——Efferent neurons - Receive motor commands from brain</div><div>—Autonomic nervous system - Controls non-conscious reactions</div><div>——Sympathetic nervous system - Controls skeletal muscle</div><div>——Parasympathetic nervous system - Controls organs, glands, blood vessels</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</div>
Reflex arc	Causes automatic responses; three parts - sensory neuron, motor neuron, and interneuron in spinal cord connecting the two; since brain not involved, requires no thought
Causes automatic responses; three parts - sensory neuron, motor neuron, and interneuron in spinal cord connecting the two; since brain not involved, requires no thought	Reflex arc
Retrovirus	<div>Viral RNA enters cell with reverse transcriptase, which catalyzes synthesis of DNA strand complementary to RNA and then second DNA strand complementary to first, allowing genes to be incorporated into cell DNA as provirus and transcribed as RNA molecules that are both translated into proteins and used as genomes for the next generation.</div>
Name/Energy Source/Carbon Source/Types of Organisms	<div>Photoautotroph / Light / Carbon dioxide, bicarbonate / Plants, algae, cyanobacteria</div><div>Chemoautotroph / Inorganic chemicals / Carbon dioxide, bicarbonate / Certain prokaryotes</div><div>Photoheterotroph / Light / Organic compounds / Aquatic, halophile prokaryotes</div><div>Chemoheterotroph / Organic compounds / Organic compounds / Fungi, animals, plants, many prokaryotes and protists</div>
Polymerases of prokaryotes	Pol III builds leading strand and Okazaki fragments, does most proofreading; Pol I replaces RNA primers
Heterochromatin	Remains condensed during interphase
Euchromatin	Can be read and transcribed during interphase
Can be read and transcribed during interphase	Euchromatin
Remains condensed during interphase	Heterochromatin
Packaging of chromosomes	DNA strand forms nucleosomes wrapped around histone complexes, then coiled, looped, and condensed into chromosome
Spermatogenesis	Produces four equitable gametes
Produces four equitable gametes	Spermatogenesis
Oogenesis	Prouces one mature egg and three polar bodies; egg needs to be capable of sustaining embryo metabolism and development
Prouces one mature egg and three polar bodies; egg needs to be capable of sustaining embryo metabolism and development	Oogenesis
Kinetochores	Protein discs at centrosome of chromosome where microtubules attach; secretes inhibitory protein to stop anaphase until microtubules attached; motor protein causes chromosome to move along microtubule and break it down into tubulin subunits afterwards.&nbsp;
Protein discs at centrosome of chromosome where microtubules attach; secretes inhibitory protein to stop anaphase until microtubules attached; motor protein causes chromosome to move along microtubule and break it down into tubulin subunits afterwards.&nbsp;	Kinetochores
Homozygous vs heterozygous vs hemizygous	Same allele, different alleles, only one allele (sex-linked gene in males)
Complete genetic linkage	Crossing-over rarely occur between loci, so only parental-type gametes produced
Crossing-over rarely occur between loci, so only parental-type gametes produced	Complete genetic linkage
Incomplete genetic linkage	Loci physically close, but not so that crossing over doesn't occur
Loci physically close, but not so that crossing over doesn't occur	Incomplete genetic linkage
Trans Arrangement	In heterozygous parent, linked loci have one recessive and one dominant allele
In heterozygous parent, linked loci have one recessive and one dominant allele	Trans Arrangement
Cis Arrangement	In heterozygous parent, linked loci are both recessive or dominant
In heterozygous parent, linked loci are both recessive or dominant	Cis Arrangement
X<sup>2</sup>	(O-E)<sup>2</sup>/E, compared to degrees of freedom table (one less than number of traits), accept either H<sub>0</sub>&nbsp;(same population) or H<sub>a</sub>&nbsp;(different populations)
Linkage Map Distance	(# recombinants/total offspring)*100 CMU; 50 = independence
Origin of replication	Where DNA replication begins, proceeding in two leading strands and two lagging strands along 3'5' direction
Where DNA replication begins, proceeding in two leading strands and two lagging strands along 3'5' direction	Origin of replication
Operon	Cluster of genes controlled by promoter and resulting in either monocistronic or polycistronic mRNA
Cluster of genes controlled by promoter and resulting in either monocistronic or polycistronic mRNA	Operon
Monocistronic mRNA	Eukaryotic mRNA; translates to only one polypeptide
Eukaryotic mRNA; translates to only one polypeptide	Monocistronic mRNA
Polycistronic mRNA	Prokaryotic mRNA; multiple open reading frames with promoter and operator
Prokaryotic mRNA; multiple open reading frames with promoter and operator	Polycistronic mRNA
Transcription	1. Transcription factor proteins bond to promoter region of DNA<div>2. RNA Polymerase II enzyme locates transcription factors, then begins unwinding helix and assembling RNA nucleotides</div><div>3. Polymerases transcribe DNA from 3' to 5' end until polyadenylation signal attracts cutting proteins</div><div>4. mRNA is processed; given GTP cap on 5' end to attract ribosome, 'poly-A' tail to locate nucleopores</div><div>5. mRNA is spliced; introns cut out and recyled, exons and UTRs/caps and tails left (SnRNA ribozyme --&gt; snRNP --&gt; spliceosome)</div><div>6. mRNA is exported through a nuclear pore into the cytoplasm/rough E.R.&nbsp;</div>
Translation	1. SRS binds to 5' end of mRNA<div>2. tRNA charged with methionine through ATP --&gt; AMP reaction on aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase; binds to start codon</div><div>3. Through degradation of GTP, ribosome assembled in cytoplasm or on rough E.R. with exit site, peptidyl-tRNA binding side, aminoacyl-tRNA binding site</div><div>4. With tRNA in P site, second tRNA enters A site</div><div>5. Amino string of tRNA in P site transfers to tRNA in A site (powered by GTP)</div><div>6. Ribosome shifts, moving both tRNA molecules towards 5' end of mRNA; molecule in E site exits ribosome (powered by GTP)</div><div>7. When stop codon is reached, release factor binds to mRNA in place of tRNA molecule</div><div>8. Release factor attracts water molecule to break bonds between polypeptide and tRNA molecule</div><div>9. GTP and proteins cause disintegration of ribosome</div>
4 Methods of Gene Control	1. Condensation - heterochromatin remains wrapped around histone complexes<div>2. Methylation - methyl groups added to cytosine bases to block transcription</div><div>3. Steroid hormones - steroid necessary for hormone-receptor complexes to induce transcription</div><div>4. RNA inhibitors - molecules bind to DNA to block polymerase or to polymerase directly</div>
Lac Operon	• Transcription blocked when lac repressor binds to operator region, preventing polymerase access; lactose sugar binds to repressor, inactivating it and allowing polymerase access to DNA<div>• When glucose level low, cAMP binds to promoter molecule that binds to operator region, attracting RNA polymerase and increasing rate of transcription</div>
• Transcription blocked when lac repressor binds to operator region, preventing polymerase access; lactose sugar binds to repressor, inactivating it and allowing polymerase access to DNA<div>• When glucose level low, cAMP binds to promoter molecule that binds to operator region, attracting RNA polymerase and increasing rate of transcription</div>	Lac Operon
Biological species concept	A group of organisms that actually or potentially interbreed with each other to produce viable offspring and do not under normal conditions interbreed with members of other groups
Phylogenetic species concept	Adds time element to biological species concept; species defined as single banch on phylogenetic tree
Prezygotic Isolating Mechanisms	"<span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Ecological - different preferences<div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Temporal - breeding periods don't overlap</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Ethological - behavorial/sensory, often scent</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Structural - reproductive structures shaped differently</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Gametic - sperm can only penetrate own species' eggs</div>"
"<span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Ecological - different preferences<div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Temporal - breeding periods don't overlap</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Ethological - behavorial/sensory, often scent</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Structural - reproductive structures shaped differently</div><div><span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span>• Gametic - sperm can only penetrate own species' eggs</div>"	Prezygotic Isolating Mechanisms
Postzygotic Isolating Mechanisms (if two species can produce zygote, must be very similar)	• Reduced hybrid viability - usually dead<div>• Reduced hybrid fertility - sterile due to non-homologous chromosomes</div><div>• Hybrid breakdown - cannot interbreed with each other or parents</div>
• Reduced hybrid viability - usually dead<div>• Reduced hybrid fertility - sterile due to non-homologous chromosomes</div><div>• Hybrid breakdown - cannot interbreed with each other or parents</div>	Postzygotic Isolating Mechanisms (if two species can produce zygote, must be very similar)
Allopatric speciation	"Geographic isolation results in species evolving in two different environments, splitting into two ""sister species"""
"Geographic isolation results in species evolving in two different environments, splitting into two ""sister species"""	Allopatric speciation
Sympatric speciation	Speciation occurs in group occupying same habitat, may be due to sexual selection or ecological preferences&nbsp;
Speciation occurs in group occupying same habitat, may be due to sexual selection or ecological preferences&nbsp;	Sympatric speciation
Allopolyploidy	Viable offspring inherits multiple chromosomes from different species; occurs in plants (e.g. wheat)
Viable offspring inherits multiple chromosomes from different species; occurs in plants (e.g. wheat)	Allopolyploidy
Punctuated equilibrium	Theory derived from Stephen Jay Gould's analysis of marine fossils showing that there are long periods of time where evolutionary pressure is absent, creating significant changes in brief periods of time
Theory derived from Stephen Jay Gould's analysis of marine fossils showing that there are long periods of time where evolutionary pressure is absent, creating significant changes in brief periods of time	Punctuated equilibrium
Microevolution vs macroevolution	Changes in genes or species vs development of new taxonomic name
Changes in genes or species vs development of new taxonomic name	Microevolution vs macroevolution
Covergent Evolution	Two or more unrelated species becoming more similar due to occupying a similar niche
Two or more unrelated species becoming more similar due to occupying a similar niche	Covergent Evolution
Coevolution	Evolution of two species in response to each other, esp. resulting in symbiosis
Evolution of two species in response to each other, esp. resulting in symbiosis	Coevolution
Adaptive Radiation	Rapid multiplication of species as population enters new habitat, or as new adaptation opens up ecological niche
Rapid multiplication of species as population enters new habitat, or as new adaptation opens up ecological niche	Adaptive Radiation
Georges Cuvier	"Advocate for fossils as remains of organisms, ""catastrophism"" = fossils caused by extinction events (dramatic, immediate changes)"
"Advocate for fossils as remains of organisms, ""catastrophism"" = fossils caused by extinction events (dramatic, immediate changes)"	Georges Cuvier
Thomas Malthus	Overpopulation, necessity of povery, more offspring than supportable = only successful survive, linear resource vs quadratic population growth&nbsp;
Overpopulation, necessity of povery, more offspring than supportable = only successful survive, linear resource vs quadratic population growth&nbsp;	Thomas Malthus
Jean-Baptiste Lamarck	Published theory of acquired characteristics same year Darwin was born (can inherit environmentally incluenced phenotypic characteristics)
Published theory of acquired characteristics same year Darwin was born (can inherit environmentally incluenced phenotypic characteristics)	Jean-Baptiste Lamarck
James Hutton	Geologic change happens gradually, demonstrated age of earth, proposed first theory of biological adaptation and natural selection
Geologic change happens gradually, demonstrated age of earth, proposed first theory of biological adaptation and natural selection	James Hutton
Charles Lyell	"Rate of geologic and biological change remains constant over time (""uniformitarianism""), therefore the earth must be milions of years old"
"Rate of geologic and biological change remains constant over time (""uniformitarianism""), therefore the earth must be milions of years old"	Charles Lyell
Outgroup	Related species lacking features used for cladistic analysis, often ancestor
Related species lacking features used for cladistic analysis, often ancestor	Outgroup
Parsimony	Computerized cladistics; phylogenetic tree with fewest branches most likely to be correct
Computerized cladistics; phylogenetic tree with fewest branches most likely to be correct	Parsimony
Molecular clock theory	Under normal conditions, rate of mutation consistent, therefore DNA differences can allow us to approximate time of reproductive isolation (should use as many sequences as possible, evaluate on case-by-case basis, correct for selectionary pressure)
Under normal conditions, rate of mutation consistent, therefore DNA differences can allow us to approximate time of reproductive isolation (should use as many sequences as possible, evaluate on case-by-case basis, correct for selectionary pressure)	Molecular clock theory
Monophyletic vs polyphyletic vs paraphyletic	Must include common ancestor and all descendents (polyphyly doesn't include ancestor, paraphyly doesn't include all descendents)
Autopomorphy	Unique derived feature
Unique derived feature	Autopomorphy
Synapomorphy	Shared derived feature; what cladistic analysis focuses on
Shared derived feature; what cladistic analysis focuses on	Synapomorphy
Symplesiomorphy	Shared primitive feature
Shared primitive feature	Symplesiomorphy
Miller-Urey experiments	Confirmed abiotic synthesis of nucleic acids possible
Confirmed abiotic synthesis of nucleic acids possible	Miller-Urey experiments
Ribozyme	RNA that can both store genetic information and act as a catalyst, which may have been absorbed into a vesicular protocell and resulted in the beginning of natural selection and the origin of true organisms
RNA that can both store genetic information and act as a catalyst, which may have been absorbed into a vesicular protocell and resulted in the beginning of natural selection and the origin of true organisms	Ribozyme
Cretaceous-Paleogene Extinction	Mass extinction event resulting in extinction of all non-avian dinosaurs and subsequent radiation of mammals
Mass extinction event resulting in extinction of all non-avian dinosaurs and subsequent radiation of mammals	Cretaceous-Paleogene Extinction
Cambrian Explosion	Emergence of predators and diversification of phyla (most modern animal phyla appeared then, over relatively short evolutionary time period)
Emergence of predators and diversification of phyla (most modern animal phyla appeared then, over relatively short evolutionary time period)	Cambrian Explosion
Progression of Biological Classification of Organisms	"• Linnaeus - Kingdoms Animalia, Plantae<div>• Whittaker - Kingdoms Animalia, Plantae, Monera, Protista, Fungi</div><div>• Woese - Domains Bacteria, Archaea, Eukarya (Animalia, Plantae, Protista, Fungi)</div><div>• Rivera &amp; Lake - ""Ring of Life""</div>"
Ring of Life	Due to prevalence of horizontal gene transfer during early evolution, shouldn't separate domains until genetic independence reached
Types of natural selection (&amp; examples)	• Stabilizing Selection - selects for common trait, e.g. # of offspring<div>• Directional Selection - selects for one extreme, e.g. pesticide resistance</div><div>• Disruptive Selection - selects for both extremes, e.g. weeds</div><div>• Sexual Selection - selects for desirability to females, e.g. plumage</div>
Genetic recombination in sexual selection	• Crossing over<div>• Independent assortment of homologues</div><div>• Random joining of gametes</div>
Heterosis	Offspring resulting from crosses between two different inbred strains of plants have advantage, as no deleterious homozygous recessive conditions
Offspring resulting from crosses between two different inbred strains of plants have advantage, as no deleterious homozygous recessive conditions	Heterosis
Frequency-dependent selection	Less common phenotype selected for until it becomes majority, then selected against; e.g. scale-eating cichlids
Less common phenotype selected for until it becomes majority, then selected against; e.g. scale-eating cichlids	Frequency-dependent selection
Evidence for Evolution	Paleontological (fossil record), biogeographical (convergence), embryological (ontogenic similarities), anatomical (homologies), biochemical (gene and protein sequencing)
Paleontological (fossil record), biogeographical (convergence), embryological (ontogenic similarities), anatomical (homologies), biochemical (gene and protein sequencing)	Evidence for Evolution
Founder Effect	Allele frequencies in small group of migrants may not be representative of origin population, e.g. polydactyly in Amish
Allele frequencies in small group of migrants may not be representative of origin population, e.g. polydactyly in Amish	Founder Effect
Bottleneck Effect	When population dramatically decreases, allele frequencies in remainders may not be representative of former population, e.g. all European bison descended from 12
When population dramatically decreases, allele frequencies in remainders may not be representative of former population, e.g. all European bison descended from 12	Bottleneck Effect
Usefulness of Hardy-Weinberg calculations	Reveal how allele frequences are changing, which equilibrium conditions are being violated, and what mechanisms are driving evolution
Alternative Splicing	Different ways of processing mRNA (excising exons as well as introns) to result in different proteins from the same gene.&nbsp;
Different ways of processing mRNA (excising exons as well as introns) to result in different proteins from the same gene.&nbsp;	Alternative Splicing
Intron purposes	Increase frequency of crossing over and decrease likelihood of damage to coding sections&nbsp;
Increase frequency of crossing over and decrease likelihood of damage to coding sections&nbsp;	Intron purposes
Polyribosomes	Clusters of multiple ribosomes translating the same mRNA
Clusters of multiple ribosomes translating the same mRNA	Polyribosomes
How proteins get from ribosomes to the E.R.&nbsp;	1. SRP binds to signal peptide at end of protein<div>2. SRP binds to SRP receptor protein at translocation complex</div><div>3. Signal peptide removed after protein channeled into E.R. lumen</div><div>4. Ribosome carries out action, e.g. addition of polysaccharides to form glycoproteins</div>
Quorum Sensing	Bacteria of same species move together to form colonies due to concentration gradient of signaling molecules (positive chemotaxis), creating biofilms and allowing bacteria to adhere more strongly to substrate
Bacteria of same species move together to form colonies due to concentration gradient of signaling molecules (positive chemotaxis), creating biofilms and allowing bacteria to adhere more strongly to substrate	Quorum Sensing
Origin of Life	1. Earth and atmosphere ~4.6 bya<div>2. Primordial seas</div><div>3. Organic molecules, incl. amino acids</div><div>4. Polymers and self-replicating molecules (ribozymes)</div><div>5. Protobionts—chemical reactions enclosed in semipermeable border</div><div>6. Primitive heterotrophic prokaryotes ~3.9 bya</div><div>7. Primitive autotrophic prokaryotes through mutation</div><div>8. Oxygen and ozone layer due to autotrophs</div><div>9. Eukaryotes (endosymbionts)</div>
Protobionts (and example)	Precursors of cells with chemical reactions enclosed within membrane-like border; liposomes and coacervates experimentally produced
Precursors of cells with chemical reactions enclosed within membrane-like border; liposomes and coacervates experimentally produced	Protobionts (and example)
Evidence for endosymbiont theory	• Endosymbiont DNA resembles that of bacteria<div>• Endosymbiont ribosomes resemble those of bacteria</div><div>• Endosymbionts reproduce independently, similar to binarry fission</div><div>• Endosymbionts have two membranes, which could indicate a vesicle</div>
Biofilm	Dense population of bacteria linked by adhesive proteins, with channels for respiration
Dense population of bacteria linked by adhesive proteins, with channels for respiration	Biofilm
Tonsils	Trap airborne germs
Trap airborne germs	Tonsils

Simple Squamous Epithelium	Specialized for exchange of material by diffusion, lines blood vessels and alveoli

Pseudostratified Columnar Epithelium	Ciliated to move mucus on surface, found in parts of respiratory tract
Ciliated to move mucus on surface, found in parts of respiratory tract	Pseudostratified Columnar Epithelium
Stratified Squamous Epithelium	Regenerates rapidly with outer cells sloughed off, e.g. skin, mouth, anal/vaginal lining
Regenerates rapidly with outer cells sloughed off, e.g. skin, mouth, anal/vaginal lining	Stratified Squamous Epithelium
Keratin	Fills cells in stratified squamous epithelium of epidermis as they move too far from blood vessels, allowing them to function as a durable and waterproof outermost layer
Fills cells in stratified squamous epithelium of epidermis as they move too far from blood vessels, allowing them to function as a durable and waterproof outermost layer	Keratin
Loose/areolar connective tissue	Most common type of connective tissue; binds epithelium to tissues, holds organs in place - found in skin and throughout body
Most common type of connective tissue; binds epithelium to tissues, holds organs in place - found in skin and throughout body	Loose/areolar connective tissue
Fibrous connective tissue	Dense with collagenous fibers, found in tendons and ligaments
Dense with collagenous fibers, found in tendons and ligaments	Fibrous connective tissue
Bone (calcified) tissue	Osteoblasts deposit collagen; filled by calcium, magnesium, phosphate; osteons = concentric rings around canal with blood vessels and nerves&nbsp;

Adipose tissue&nbsp;	Stores fuel as fat in adipose cells that swell and shrink, pads and insulates body

Blood	Erythrocytes, leukocytes, and platelets suspended in plasma (water, salts, dissolved proteins)

Lymphocytes	Produce B and T stem cells to augment immune reaction
Produce B and T stem cells to augment immune reaction	Lymphocytes
Monocytes	Remove dead and damaged tissues

Basophils	Prevent blood from clotting too rapidly

Eosonophils&nbsp;	Consume foreign substances detected in the blood

Erythrocytes	Red blood cells specialized for the role of delivering gases, lacking nuclei or other organelles and produced only when the body detects an oxygen deficiency

Ligament	Connective tissue in joints

Skeletal Muscle	Responsible for voluntary movement; sarcomeres bundled into muscle fibers

Skeletal Muscle	Responsible for voluntary movement; sarcomeres bundled into muscle fibers

Smooth Muscle	Spindle-shaped cells responsible for involuntary activity; thin and thick filaments not all lined up; digestive tract, urinary bladder, arteries, etc.&nbsp;
Spindle-shaped cells responsible for involuntary activity; thin and thick filaments not all lined up; digestive tract, urinary bladder, arteries, etc.&nbsp;	Smooth Muscle
Cardiac Muscle	Contractile wall of heart; striated, intercalated disks relay cell-cell signals
Contractile wall of heart; striated, intercalated disks relay cell-cell signals	Cardiac Muscle
Contraction of sarcomere	The 'heads' of the thick myosin filament are attracted to points along the thin actin filament, but typically blocked by the tropomysin membrane. When a calcium ion shifts the tropomysin, the myosin can bond to the actin, and when ATP energizes the myosin, it can release and grip another point. Thus, the myosin brings the two sets of actin filaments closer together, making the distance between the Z lines smaller and thus contracting the sarcomere.&nbsp;
The 'heads' of the thick myosin filament are attracted to points along the thin actin filament, but typically blocked by the tropomysin membrane. When a calcium ion shifts the tropomysin, the myosin can bond to the actin, and when ATP energizes the myosin, it can release and grip another point. Thus, the myosin brings the two sets of actin filaments closer together, making the distance between the Z lines smaller and thus contracting the sarcomere.&nbsp;	Contraction of sarcomere
Epithelium vs endothelium	Epithelium covers, endothelium lines
Homeostasis	Maintenance of a balance of conditions (e.g. pH or temperature) within the body that is optimal for the functions of that body given its environment
Maintenance of a balance of conditions (e.g. pH or temperature) within the body that is optimal for the functions of that body given its environment	Homeostasis
Negative feedback loop	When environmental factors change condition to be above or below set point, stimulus detected by bodily sensor and triggers physiological response to dampen effect of condition (e.g. sweating/shivering)
When environmental factors change condition to be above or below set point, stimulus detected by bodily sensor and triggers physiological response to dampen effect of condition (e.g. sweating/shivering)	Negative feedback loop
Integumentary system	Skin, hair, nails, and exocrine glands
Skin, hair, nails, and exocrine glands	Integumentary system
-Blasts vs -cytes	-Blasts assemble matrices, -cytes maintain their health
Osteon	Haversian Canal at center contains blood vessels, from which concentric layers called lamellae extend; networks of canaliculi facilitate exchange of nutrients and waste between osteocytes living in spaces called lacunae
Haversian Canal at center contains blood vessels, from which concentric layers called lamellae extend; networks of canaliculi facilitate exchange of nutrients and waste between osteocytes living in spaces called lacunae	Osteon
Homeotic genes	Control development by organizing tissues in different regions of the body; produce “homeodomain” proteins within the different body regions that bond to gene promoter sequences and turn on certain genes important to the development in that region
Control development by organizing tissues in different regions of the body; produce “homeodomain” proteins within the different body regions that bond to gene promoter sequences and turn on certain genes important to the development in that region	Homeotic genes
Hox genes	Homeotic genes organizing body plan along head-tail axis, resulting in differentiation of body segments and limbs

Dosage compensation	Inactivation of one X-chromosome in females to ensure quantity of proteins remains constant between males and females
Inactivation of one X-chromosome in females to ensure quantity of proteins remains constant between males and females	Dosage compensation

How tissues contribute to organ structure and function	• Epithelial tissues separate and cover organs from each other<div>• Connective tissues give the body form and structure</div><div>• Muscle tissues allow organs to move and fulfill roles</div>
Kidney	Urine produced in nephrons of renal pyramids (glomerulus and convoluted tubules in renal cortex, Loop of Henle and collecting duct in renal medulla), flows through gravitational force into minor calyces, into pelvis, and down ureter

"<img src=""Nephron.jpg"" />"	Glomerulus (afferent arteriole -&gt; efferent arteriole), Bowman's capsule, proximal convoluted tubule, Loop of Henle (with peritubular capillaries), renal venule, collecting duct
"<img src=""Neuron_1449629417708.jpg"" />"	1. Dendrite<div>2. Nucleus</div><div>3. Cell body</div><div>4. Schwann cell (w/ Nodes of Ranvier)</div><div>5. Axon</div><div>6. Axonal bulb</div>
Schwann cells	Insulate neurons, supply neurons with oxygen and nutrients
Insulate neurons, supply neurons with oxygen and nutrients	Schwann cells
Impulse transmission in a neuron	1. Resting neuron is polarized by using Na/K pumps to keep inside negative (K+) and outside positive (Na+) to achieve resting potential of -70 millivolts<div>2. In response to a stimulus, gated ion channels open and allow membrane to become depolarized; if stimulus above threshold level of axon hillock (-55 mv), more Na+ channels open and action potential of +40 reached, causing opening of Na+ channels all the way down the length of the membrane</div><div>3. Repolarization occurs as gated channels allow K+ to exit cell and Na+ channels close; however, Na+ and K+ are on the wrong sides of the membrane</div><div>4. By the time the K+ channels close, the membrane has become hyperpolarized at -90 mv</div><div>5. During refractory period, Na/K pumps reestablish resting potential; neuron now capable of responding to new stimuli</div>
How a neuronal message jumps a synaptic cleft	1. Brain decides to send message<div>2. Electrical impulse sent from brain down neuron</div><div>3. At end of nerve fiber, neurotransmitter released from nerve end</div><div>4. Neurotransmitter travels across cleft between pre- and postsynaptic neurons</div><div>5. Neurotransmitter fits receptor on other side like key in lock</div><div>6. Shape change of receptor sets off electrical impulse</div><div>7. Re-uptake allows transmitter to be broken down by enzymes and recycled</div>
Neuromuscular junction	Synapse between motor neuron and muscle fiber&nbsp;
Synapse between motor neuron and muscle fiber&nbsp;	Neuromuscular junction
Cholinesterase	Enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of neurotransmitters
Enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of neurotransmitters	Cholinesterase
Node of Ranvier	Where ion channels open and depolarization travels down length of neuron, jumping from one node to the next&nbsp;
Where ion channels open and depolarization travels down length of neuron, jumping from one node to the next&nbsp;	Node of Ranvier
Forebrain	Associated with the cerebrum, hypothalamus and pituitary gland, and limbic system
Associated with the cerebrum, hypothalamus and pituitary gland, and limbic system	Forebrain
Cerebrum	Derived into two cerebral hemispheres connected by bundle of nerve fibers called the corpus callosum; divided into frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital lobe

Hypothalamus	Links the nervous system to the endocrine gland via the pituitary gland, which secretes hormones to regulate physiological functions

Limbic System	Though not technically derived from forebrain, develops in and around cerebrum; network of neurons associated with emotions
Though not technically derived from forebrain, develops in and around cerebrum; network of neurons associated with emotions	Limbic System
Prions	Misfolded proteins that can induce other proteins to change their shape to fit with the prion, which can result in slow degeneration, usually in the brain (e.g. Creutzfeld-Jakob disease, kuru)
Misfolded proteins that can induce other proteins to change their shape to fit with the prion, which can result in slow degeneration, usually in the brain (e.g. Creutzfeld-Jakob disease, kuru)	Prions
Prokaryotic vs eukaryotic genomes	Former stored in looped DNA to prevent erosion, has only one origin of replication and one replication bubble per DNA molecule; latter stored as multiple chromosomes or strands of chromatin in membrane-bound nucleus
Former stored in looped DNA to prevent erosion, has only one origin of replication and one replication bubble per DNA molecule; latter stored as multiple chromosomes or strands of chromatin in membrane-bound nucleus	Prokaryotic vs eukaryotic genomes
Differences between archaea and eubacteria	• Archaea use multiple DNA polymerases during replication; bacteria only one<div>• Archaean DNA forms nucleosomes; bacterial DNA is always uncondensed<br></div><div>• Bacteria are inhibited by antibiotics that archaea show no reaction to<br></div><div>• Archaea can live in extreme environments where neither bacteria nor eukaryotes can survive<br></div>
Saltatory conduction	Action potential jumps from node to node, increasing speed of impulse
Action potential jumps from node to node, increasing speed of impulse	Saltatory conduction
Negative feedback in INS/GCG	Insulin stimulates absorption of glucose by liver and transformation into glycogen/fat, glucagon stimulates breakdown of glycogen and release of glucose by liver; thus appropriate levels of glucose in bloodstream are reached
Insulin stimulates absorption of glucose by liver and transformation into glycogen/fat, glucagon stimulates breakdown of glycogen and release of glucose by liver; thus appropriate levels of glucose in bloodstream are reached	Negative feedback in INS/GCG
Thermoregulation	Ectotherms obtain heat from the environment, endotherms generate their own; temperatures regulates through evaporation, shivering, metabolism of fat, surface area, countercurrent exchange
Ectotherms obtain heat from the environment, endotherms generate their own; temperatures regulates through evaporation, shivering, metabolism of fat, surface area, countercurrent exchange	Thermoregulation
Respiratory Strategies	Direct, gills (covered by operculum, countercurrent exchange maximizes diffusion), tracheae (w/ spiracles), lungs (incl. book lungs)
Gas exchange in humans	Nose, pharynx, larynx -&gt; trachea (epiglottis protects) -&gt; two bronchi, dividing into bronchioles -&gt; alveoli surrounded by capillaries -&gt; diffusion between alveolar chambers and blood -&gt; red blood cells -&gt; diffusion into cells -&gt; formation of bicarbonate in red blood cells -&gt; export of bicarbonate
Control of respiration in humans	Volume of lungs modulated by pressure differential created by contraction of diaphragm and intercostal muscles; when body active, bicarbonate production results in pH drop; chemoreceptors send nerve impulse to muscles to increase respiratory rate.&nbsp;
Open circulatory system	Pump blood into hemocoel, which bathes tissues with hemolymph that returns to heart through ostia
Pump blood into hemocoel, which bathes tissues with hemolymph that returns to heart through ostia	Open circulatory system
Closed circulatory system	Blood carrying nutrients, oxygen, and waste confined to vessels; arteries move away from heart, branch into arterioles and then into capillaries; gas diffuses into interstitial fluids and cells; deoxygenated blood returns to heart through venules merging to form veins, then pumped into capillary beds of respiratory organ and back to heart
Blood carrying nutrients, oxygen, and waste confined to vessels; arteries move away from heart, branch into arterioles and then into capillaries; gas diffuses into interstitial fluids and cells; deoxygenated blood returns to heart through venules merging to form veins, then pumped into capillary beds of respiratory organ and back to heart	Closed circulatory system
"<img src=""Heart I.png"">"	1. Right atrium<div>2. Right ventricle</div><div>3. Left atrium</div><div>4. Left ventricle</div><div>5. Pulmonary arteries</div><div>6. Aortic arch</div><div>7. Superior vena cava</div><div>8. Inferior vena cava</div><div>9. Pulmonary veins</div>
Cardiac Cycle (lub-dup)	1. Sinoatrial (SA) node, or pacemaker, initiates cycle by contacting both atria and sending impulse that simulate atrioventriucular (AV) node<div>2. AV node sends imulse through bundle of His to Purkinje fibers, which results in contraction of ventricles</div><div>3. Contraction (systolic phase) results in blood being forced through aorta, closing AV valves; relaxation (diastolic phase) results in backflow closing semilunar valves&nbsp;</div>
1. Sinoatrial (SA) node, or pacemaker, initiates cycle by contacting both atria and sending impulse that simulate atrioventriucular (AV) node<div>2. AV node sends imulse through bundle of His to Purkinje fibers, which results in contraction of ventricles</div><div>3. Contraction (systolic phase) results in blood being forced through aorta, closing AV valves; relaxation (diastolic phase) results in backflow closing semilunar valves&nbsp;</div>	Cardiac Cycle (lub-dup)
Lymphatic system	Lymph moves through lymphatic vessels by contraction of adjacent muscles to return insterstitial fluids and wastes to circulatory system; lymph nodes act as cleaning filters and as ambush site for pathogens

Parthenogenesis	Unfertilized egg, either haplod or diploid, starts dividing and becomes embryo; in species with X-Y sex determination, or most lizards, offspring automatically female, w/o X chromosome inactivation

Skene's glands (f), prostrate gland (m)	Produce lubricative fluid, involved in ejaculation (f), produces seminal fluid to de-acidify vaginal canal as well as feed and transport spermatozoa (m)

Labia majora (f), scrotum (m)	Protext external genitalia from abrasion and debris (f), folds that grow together in embryological development to enclose testes (m)
Protext external genitalia from abrasion and debris (f), folds that grow together in embryological development to enclose testes (m)	Labia majora (f), scrotum (m)
Labia minora (f), penile shaft (m)	Seal vaginal canal, form clitoral hood, provides lubrication (f), encloses urethra (m)
Seal vaginal canal, form clitoral hood, provides lubrication (f), encloses urethra (m)	Labia minora (f), penile shaft (m)

Menstrual Cycle	1. Follicular Phase - development of egg and secretion of estrogen<div>2. Ovulation - midcycle release of egg</div><div>3. Luteal Phase - secretion of estrogen and progesterone from corpus luteum</div>
