Protostomes vs deuterostomes	Schizocoelates with mouth developing from blastopore vs enterocoelates with anus developing from blastopore
Schizocoelates with mouth developing from blastopore vs enterocoelates with anus developing from blastopore	Protostomes vs deuterostomes
Schizocoelus	Coelum forms from split solid masses of mesoderm
Coelum forms from split solid masses of mesoderm	Schizocoelus
Enterocoelus	Coelum forms from folds of archenteron
Coelum forms from folds of archenteron	Enterocoelus
Platelets	Together with coagulation pathway leading to fibrin formation, form blood clots.&nbsp;
Together with coagulation pathway leading to fibrin formation, form blood clots.&nbsp;	Platelets
Mechanisms responsible for influencing cell development and differentiation	• If cleavage determinate, cannot develop into complete embryo and developmental program limited to defined cells<div>• Cytoplasmic determinants may affect gene expression, e.g. morphogen gradient across cells determines axes of embryo</div><div>• Embryonic induction occurs through cell-cell communication, e.g. dorsal lip of blasopore induces notochord formation</div><div>• Apoptosis occurs when external signal triggers signal trnsduction pathway to activate genes that code for proteases and fragment cell</div>
Fixed action patterns	Innate behaviors following unvarying pattern, e.g. graylag goose's collection of eggs
Innate behaviors following unvarying pattern, e.g. graylag goose's collection of eggs	Fixed action patterns
Imprinting	Innate program for acquiring specific behavior if and only if appropriate stimulus is experienced during critical period, e.g. salmon returning to birthplace (imprint on odor)
Innate program for acquiring specific behavior if and only if appropriate stimulus is experienced during critical period, e.g. salmon returning to birthplace (imprint on odor)	Imprinting
Associative learning	Animal recognizes connection between events, e.g. classical conditioning (Pavlov's dogs)
Animal recognizes connection between events, e.g. classical conditioning (Pavlov's dogs)	Associative learning
Operant conditioning	Animal connects own behavior with environmental response (positive/negative conditioning), e.g. Skinner boxes
Animal connects own behavior with environmental response (positive/negative conditioning), e.g. Skinner boxes	Operant conditioning
Spatial learning	Association of landmarks with reward from returning to location, e.g. wasps locating nests by pinecones
Association of landmarks with reward from returning to location, e.g. wasps locating nests by pinecones	Spatial learning
Habituation	Learned behavior that allows animl to disregard meaningless stimuli, e.g. sea anemones' attempts to capture food&nbsp;
Learned behavior that allows animl to disregard meaningless stimuli, e.g. sea anemones' attempts to capture food&nbsp;	Habituation
Observational learning	Animals copy behavior of another animal without prior positive reinforcement, e.g. Japanese monkeys washing potatoes
Animals copy behavior of another animal without prior positive reinforcement, e.g. Japanese monkeys washing potatoes	Observational learning
Insight	Animal exposed to new situation and without prior relevant experience performs behavior that generates positive outcome, e.g. chimpanzees stacking boxes
Animal exposed to new situation and without prior relevant experience performs behavior that generates positive outcome, e.g. chimpanzees stacking boxes	Insight
Survival responses	Occur when animals encounter dangerous situations, e.g. flight-or-flight response (EPI/NOR), avoidance response, alarm response (e.g. Belding's ground squirrels)
Occur when animals encounter dangerous situations, e.g. flight-or-flight response (EPI/NOR), avoidance response, alarm response (e.g. Belding's ground squirrels)	Survival responses
Parental care	Innate behavior in response to producing offspring, e.g. birds' incubation of eggs and feeding of hatchlings, seahorses' deposition of eggs into male's pouch, mammals' production of milk and protection
Innate behavior in response to producing offspring, e.g. birds' incubation of eggs and feeding of hatchlings, seahorses' deposition of eggs into male's pouch, mammals' production of milk and protection	Parental care
Foraging behaviors	Visual and chemical stimuli induce, incl. flower color/scent (coevolution), fruit color/scent (avoiding toxins), body scents (detect presence of predators)
Visual and chemical stimuli induce, incl. flower color/scent (coevolution), fruit color/scent (avoiding toxins), body scents (detect presence of predators)	Foraging behaviors
Kinesis	Undirected change in speed of animal's movement in response to stimulus, e.g. lifting of log
Undirected change in speed of animal's movement in response to stimulus, e.g. lifting of log	Kinesis
Circadian rhythm/Biological clock	Pattern of physiological or behaviorial activity aligned with 24-hour day, e.g. day/night rhythms of diurnal and nocturnal animals (maintained by MT in humans)
Pattern of physiological or behaviorial activity aligned with 24-hour day, e.g. day/night rhythms of diurnal and nocturnal animals (maintained by MT in humans)	Circadian rhythm/Biological clock
Estivation	Dormancy during hot/dry periods by burrowing into mud or retreating to underground tunnels, e.g. African lungfishes
Dormancy during hot/dry periods by burrowing into mud or retreating to underground tunnels, e.g. African lungfishes	Estivation
Chemical communication in animals	Releaser pheromones trigger immediate action, primer pheromones cause developmental/physiological changes; in ants, releaser pheromones used to mark trails to food, primer pheromones released by queen to prevent workers from developing reproductive ability
Types of communication in animals (&amp; examples)	Chemical (ants' pheromones), visual (silverback gorillas), auditory (whales' songs), tactile (bees' dancing)
Foraging behaviors in animals	Herds, flocks, and schools provide concealment, vigilance, and defense; packs enable members to corner and attack large prey; search images help animals find favored or plentiful food
Agonistic behavior	Aggression and submission; usually ritualized, e.g. combat in deer
Aggression and submission; usually ritualized, e.g. combat in deer	Agonistic behavior
Dominance hierarchies	Indicate power and status relationships to minimize fighting, e.g. pecking order in chickens
Indicate power and status relationships to minimize fighting, e.g. pecking order in chickens	Dominance hierarchies
Territoriality	Active possession and defense of territory to ensure adequate food and a place to mate and rear young
Active possession and defense of territory to ensure adequate food and a place to mate and rear young	Territoriality
Eusociality&nbsp;	Members divided into castes with different roles; found in many insects
Members divided into castes with different roles; found in many insects	Eusociality&nbsp;
Altruistic behavior	Individual fitness sacrificed for inclusive fitness (fitness of individual plus relatives); occurs through kin selection, e.g. Belding's ground squirrels&nbsp;
Individual fitness sacrificed for inclusive fitness (fitness of individual plus relatives); occurs through kin selection, e.g. Belding's ground squirrels&nbsp;	Altruistic behavior
RuBisCO	Fixes carbon dioxide by using its carbon atoms to manufacture PGA; however, when no CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;is available, such as when the plant's stomata are closed, may fix oxygen instead (photorespiration), creating potentially dangerous compounds the cell has to catabolize with peroxisomes (would not have been a dancer in early Earth atmosphere w/o oxygen)
Fixes carbon dioxide by using its carbon atoms to manufacture PGA; however, when no CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;is available, such as when the plant's stomata are closed, may fix oxygen instead (photorespiration), creating potentially dangerous compounds the cell has to catabolize with peroxisomes (would not have been a dancer in early Earth atmosphere w/o oxygen)	RuBisCO
Fluorescence	Light emitted due to electrons falling back down to lower energy levels
Light emitted due to electrons falling back down to lower energy levels	Fluorescence
Chlorophyll	Porphyrin ring (light catching array; contains electrons that jump to next energy level when struck by light of right wavelength) centered around Mg atom&nbsp;
Porphyrin ring (light catching array; contains electrons that jump to next energy level when struck by light of right wavelength) centered around Mg atom&nbsp;	Chlorophyll
Photosystems	<div>Energy from a photon of light&nbsp;boosts an electron in a pigment molecule to the next&nbsp;higher energy level, where falling back to its original level releases energy that causes an electron in a neighboring&nbsp;pigment to be boosted to a higher level; eventually passed to chlorophyll A molecule that passes electrons to primary electron acceptor</div>
<div>Energy from a photon of light&nbsp;boosts an electron in a pigment molecule to the next&nbsp;higher energy level, where falling back to its original level releases energy that causes an electron in a neighboring&nbsp;pigment to be boosted to a higher level; eventually passed to chlorophyll A molecule that passes electrons to primary electron acceptor</div>	Photosystems
C3 plants	Evolved in temperate climates; in hot dry conditions, partially or completely shut stomata, making Calvin cycle half as efficient&nbsp;
Evolved in temperate climates; in hot dry conditions, partially or completely shut stomata, making Calvin cycle half as efficient&nbsp;	C3 plants
C4 plants	Largely grasses, spatial separation of carbon fixation and Calvin cycle; in hot dry conditions, open stomata briefly to admit CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;that is moved to bundle sheath cells without oxygen; Calvin cycle requires more ATP &nbsp;
Largely grasses, spatial separation of carbon fixation and Calvin cycle; in hot dry conditions, open stomata briefly to admit CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;that is moved to bundle sheath cells without oxygen; Calvin cycle requires more ATP &nbsp;	C4 plants
CAM plants	Succulentss and cacti, temporal separation of carbon fixation and Calvin cycle; stomata open at night to admit CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;then converted to malic acid and stored in vacuoles until daytime, when stomata close and malic acid converted back to CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;to manufacture PGA
Succulentss and cacti, temporal separation of carbon fixation and Calvin cycle; stomata open at night to admit CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;then converted to malic acid and stored in vacuoles until daytime, when stomata close and malic acid converted back to CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;to manufacture PGA	CAM plants
Types of survivorship curves	Type I - Most members survive until old age, then rapidly decline due to age-related problems, e.g. humans<div>Type II - Death is random and may occur at any stage of life, e.g. rodents</div><div>Type III - Many offspring are produced that will not survive to maturity, but those that do tend to survive until old age, e.g. oysters</div>
ZPG	Zero population growth
Biotic potential	Maximum growth rate of population under ideal conditions, dependent on age at reproductive maturity, clutch size, frequency of reproduction, reproductive lifeime, and survivorship of offspring to reproductive maturity
Maximum growth rate of population under ideal conditions, dependent on age at reproductive maturity, clutch size, frequency of reproduction, reproductive lifeime, and survivorship of offspring to reproductive maturity	Biotic potential
Limiting factors	Prevent population from attaining biotic potential; density-dependent (parasites, disease, competition, predation) or independent (natural disasters, climate)
Prevent population from attaining biotic potential; density-dependent (parasites, disease, competition, predation) or independent (natural disasters, climate)	Limiting factors
Reproductive rate&nbsp;	r = (births—deaths)/N
Population cycles	Fluctuations in population size in response to limiting factors; exponential growth takes population above initial carrying capacity, causing either population crash or decline to sustainable levels (possibly fluctuating around new carrying capacity)
Fluctuations in population size in response to limiting factors; exponential growth takes population above initial carrying capacity, causing either population crash or decline to sustainable levels (possibly fluctuating around new carrying capacity)	Population cycles
R-selected vs. k-selected species	Opportunistic species exhibiting exponential growth vs species exhibiting logistic growth with mature population size remaining constant at carrying capacity of K
Opportunistic species exhibiting exponential growth vs species exhibiting logistic growth with mature population size remaining constant at carrying capacity of K	R-selected vs. k-selected species
Gause's Principle	No two species can sustain coexistence if they occupy the same niche when resources are limiting, e.g. paramecium&nbsp;
No two species can sustain coexistence if they occupy the same niche when resources are limiting, e.g. paramecium&nbsp;	Gause's Principle
Resource partitioning	Minimization of competition by using slightly different resources, e.g. five warbler species in one tree
Minimization of competition by using slightly different resources, e.g. five warbler species in one tree	Resource partitioning
Realized niche&nbsp;	In presence of competitors, species only occupies part of fundamental niche where competition is absent, e.g. barnacles&nbsp;
In presence of competitors, species only occupies part of fundamental niche where competition is absent, e.g. barnacles&nbsp;	Realized niche&nbsp;
Character displacement	Selection for characteristics that enable resource partitioning more efficiently, e.g. Galapagos finches&nbsp;
Selection for characteristics that enable resource partitioning more efficiently, e.g. Galapagos finches&nbsp;	Character displacement
Forms of predation	True predator, parasite (most of life in other organism), parasitoid (lays eggs in host to consume tissues), herbivore (grazer/browser)
True predator, parasite (most of life in other organism), parasitoid (lays eggs in host to consume tissues), herbivore (grazer/browser)	Forms of predation
Mutualism	+,+; e.g. trees and mycorrhizae
+,+; e.g. trees and mycorrhizae	Mutualism
Commensalism	+, 0; e.g. birds nesting in trees
+, 0; e.g. birds nesting in trees	Commensalism
Parasitism	+,-; e.g. tapeworms
+,-; e.g. tapeworms	Parasitism
Secondary compounds	Toxic chemicals produced in plants to discourage herbivores, e.g. nicotine&nbsp;
Toxic chemicals produced in plants to discourage herbivores, e.g. nicotine&nbsp;	Secondary compounds
Camouflage	Color, pattern, shape or behavior that enables animal to blend in with surrounding, e.g. birdshit moths&nbsp;
Color, pattern, shape or behavior that enables animal to blend in with surrounding, e.g. birdshit moths&nbsp;	Camouflage
Aposematic coloration	Color or pattern warns predators of danger, e.g. bees' black and yellow stripes
Color or pattern warns predators of danger, e.g. bees' black and yellow stripes	Aposematic coloration
Müllerian mimicry	Several animals with common defense mechanism use same coloration, e.g. bees, yellowjackets, and wasps
Several animals with common defense mechanism use same coloration, e.g. bees, yellowjackets, and wasps	Müllerian mimicry
Batesian mimicry	Animal lacking special defense mechanisms mimics coloration of animal that possesses them, e.g. flies with yellow and black markings
Animal lacking special defense mechanisms mimics coloration of animal that possesses them, e.g. flies with yellow and black markings	Batesian mimicry
Pollination	Coevolution of traits benefits both organisms, e.g. hummingbirds and red, tubular flowers&nbsp;
Coevolution of traits benefits both organisms, e.g. hummingbirds and red, tubular flowers&nbsp;	Pollination
Primary Succession	Colonization by plants of formerly barren substrate&nbsp;
Colonization by plants of formerly barren substrate&nbsp;	Primary Succession
Secondary Succession	Recolonization by plants of substrate partially or entirely destroyed (may originate in seed bank)
Recolonization by plants of substrate partially or entirely destroyed (may originate in seed bank)	Secondary Succession
Succession on rock or lava	1. Lichens hold moisture and secrete acids to erode rock into soil<div>2. Bacteria, protists, fungi, and mosses appear, followed by insects</div><div>4. Nitrogen-fixing bacteria introduce nutrients into soil&nbsp;</div><div>3. R-selected species eventually replaced by k-selected species</div>
Succession on sand dunes	1. Grasses adapted to taking root in shifting sand stabilize dunes over about six years&nbsp;<div>2. Rooting of shrubs, followed by cottonwoods, then pines and black oaks, finally culminating in beech-maple climax community&nbsp;</div>
Old-field succession	Germination of r-selected species from seed bank, followed by region-specific trees
Succession in lakes and ponds&nbsp;	1. Sand, silt, and decomposed vegetation transform body of water into marsh<div>2. Submerged vegetation followed by emergent vegetation</div><div>3. Grasses, rushes, cattails take root at perimeter</div><div>4. Lake fills with sediment and vegetation, becoming meadow or part of coniferous forest</div>
Five trophic levels&nbsp;	Primary producers -&gt; primary consumers -&gt; secondary consumers -&gt; tertiary consumers -&gt; detritivores/decomposers&nbsp;
Primary producers -&gt; primary consumers -&gt; secondary consumers -&gt; tertiary consumers -&gt; detritivores/decomposers&nbsp;	Five trophic levels&nbsp;
Primary productivity	Amt of organic matter produced through photosynthetic activity per unit of time; NPP = GPP -- R
Amt of organic matter produced through photosynthetic activity per unit of time; NPP = GPP -- R	Primary productivity
Why do certain species have a disproportionate impact on the health of the community?	Dominant species contributes the most biomass; keystone species regulate numbers of other species, e.g. grey wolf in Yellowstone; invasive species displace native species without natural limiting factors, e.g. kudzu
Factors influencing number and size of trophic levels in ecosystem	Size of bottom trophic level, efficiency of energy transfer between levels, stability of levels, requirements of top predators
Size of bottom trophic level, efficiency of energy transfer between levels, stability of levels, requirements of top predators	Factors influencing number and size of trophic levels in ecosystem
Bottom-up vs top-down models	Describe how changes in structure of trophic levels are regulated by changes in the bottom vs top trophic level
Describe how changes in structure of trophic levels are regulated by changes in the bottom vs top trophic level	Bottom-up vs top-down models
Carbon cycle	Reservoirs in atmosphere as CO<sub>2</sub>, bodies of water as bicarbonate, fossil fuels, peat, and durable organic materials; assimilated through use in photosynthesis by plants and consumption of plants by animals; released through respiration, decomposition, and burning of organic matter
Phosphorus cycle	Reservoirs in rocks and ocean sediments, assimilated through absorption of inorganic phosphate (PO<sub>4</sub>) by plants and consumption of plants by animals, released through decomposition and excretion
Nitrogen cycle	"<img src=""Nitrogen.JPG"" />"
Transmission Electron Microscope	Electrons passed through specimen on slide, objective lens, projector lens, and imprints image on fluorescent screen
Electrons passed through specimen on slide, objective lens, projector lens, and imprints image on fluorescent screen	Transmission Electron Microscope
Scanning Electron Microscope	Electrons passed through lenses and beam deflector before bouncing off specimen and hitting detector, producing image on viewing screen
Electrons passed through lenses and beam deflector before bouncing off specimen and hitting detector, producing image on viewing screen	Scanning Electron Microscope
Epistasis	One gene being dependent upon genetic background, e.g. hair color gene depends upon baldness gene&nbsp;
One gene being dependent upon genetic background, e.g. hair color gene depends upon baldness gene&nbsp;	Epistasis
Pleiotropy	One gene influences two or more seemingly unrelated phenotypic traits, e.g. albinism
One gene influences two or more seemingly unrelated phenotypic traits, e.g. albinism	Pleiotropy
Reaction equilibrium	Forward reaction proceeds at same rate as reverse reaction
Forward reaction proceeds at same rate as reverse reaction	Reaction equilibrium

Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle fibers are easily fatigued	Type <span class=cloze>II</span> muscle fibers are easily fatigued<br> 
Type II muscle fibers are <span class=cloze>[...]</span> fatigued	Type II muscle fibers are <span class=cloze>easily</span> fatigued<br> 
Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle fibers store energy in the form of triglycerides	Type <span class=cloze>I</span> muscle fibers store energy in the form of triglycerides<br> 
Type I muscle fibers store energy in the form of <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Type I muscle fibers store energy in the form of <span class=cloze>triglycerides</span><br> 
Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle fibers store energy in the form of ATP and creatine phosphate	Type <span class=cloze>II</span> muscle fibers store energy in the form of ATP and creatine phosphate<br> 
Type II muscle fibers store energy in the form of <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Type II muscle fibers store energy in the form of <span class=cloze>ATP and creatine phosphate</span><br> 
Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle fibers have weak contractile power	Type <span class=cloze>I</span> muscle fibers have weak contractile power<br> 
Type I muscle fibers have <span class=cloze>[...]</span> contractile power	Type I muscle fibers have <span class=cloze>weak</span> contractile power<br> 
Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle fibers have strong contractile power	Type <span class=cloze>II</span> muscle fibers have strong contractile power<br> 
Type II muscle fibers have <span class=cloze>[...]</span> contractile power	Type II muscle fibers have <span class=cloze>strong</span> contractile power<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle contracts the fastest and <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle contracts the slowest (relative speeds)	<span class=cloze>Skeletal</span> muscle contracts the fastest and <span class=cloze>smooth</span> muscle contracts the slowest (relative speeds)<br> 
Skeletal muscle contracts the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> and smooth muscle contracts the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> (relative speeds)	Skeletal muscle contracts the <span class=cloze>fastest</span> and smooth muscle contracts the <span class=cloze>slowest</span> (relative speeds)<br> 
Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle fibers are also called slow twitch	Type <span class=cloze>I</span> muscle fibers are also called slow twitch<br> 
Type I muscle fibers are also called <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Type I muscle fibers are also called <span class=cloze>slow twitch</span><br> 
Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle fibers are also called fast twitch	Type <span class=cloze>II</span> muscle fibers are also called fast twitch<br> 
Type II muscle fibers are also called <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Type II muscle fibers are also called <span class=cloze>fast twitch</span><br> 
Type I and Type II muscle are subtypes of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle	Type I and Type II muscle are subtypes of <span class=cloze>skeletal</span> muscle<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> muscle are subtypes of skeletal muscle	<span class=cloze>Type I and Type II</span> muscle are subtypes of skeletal muscle<br> 
A cross bridge is formed by <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	A cross bridge is formed by <span class=cloze>the attachment of myosin head to an actin filament</span><br> 
A <span class=cloze>[...]</span> is formed by the attachment of myosin head to an actin filament	A <span class=cloze>cross bridge</span> is formed by the attachment of myosin head to an actin filament<br> 
The <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of a sarcomere is the section with only myosin (in the middle between two Z lines)	"The <span class=cloze>""H"" zone</span> of a sarcomere is the section with only myosin (in the middle between two Z lines)<br> "
"The ""H"" zone of a sarcomere is <span class=cloze>[...]</span>"	"The ""H"" zone of a sarcomere is <span class=cloze>the section with only myosin (in the middle between two Z lines)</span><br> "
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> molecules in a sarcomere are bound to the Z line	<span class=cloze>Actin</span> molecules in a sarcomere are bound to the Z line<br> 
Actin molecules in a sarcomere are bound to <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Actin molecules in a sarcomere are bound to <span class=cloze>the Z line</span><br> 
The M line of a sarcomere is the <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	The M line of a sarcomere is the <span class=cloze>thin line in the very middle between two Z lines (in the middle of the H zone)</span><br> 
The <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of a sarcomere is the thin line in the very middle between two Z lines (in the middle of the H zone)	The <span class=cloze>M line</span> of a sarcomere is the thin line in the very middle between two Z lines (in the middle of the H zone)<br> 
In skeletal muscles, calcium binding to troponin triggers a conformational change in <span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;to uncover actin so <span class=cloze>[...]</span> heads can bind	In skeletal muscles, calcium binding to troponin triggers a conformational change in <span class=cloze> tropomyosin</span>&nbsp;to uncover actin so <span class=cloze>myosin</span> heads can bind<br> 
all amino acids exist as ___	zwitterions
what is cortisol?	stress hormone
as acidity increases, HgB's affinity for O2 ___	decreases
centrosomes CONTAIN	centrioles, composed of microtubules
the citric acid cycle produces GTP, T/F	T
Calcium released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum binds to	troponin
how does competitive inhibition work?	binding reversibly to the active site
what happens to the Km and Vmax in competitive inhibition?	Vmax unchanged, Km increases
what does an uncompetitive inhibitor bind?	the E-S complex
what happens to the Vmax and Km of uncompetitive inhibition?	Lowers Vmax and Lowers Km
where do noncompetitive inhibitors bind?	at a location other than the active site
what happens to the Km and Vmax during noncompetitive inhibition?	Km remains the same, decreases Vmax
gut flora are found mostly in the __	Large Intestine
what is the function of DNA ligase?	joining strands of DNA together (Okazaki fragments)
what is the equation for osmotic pressure?	Pi (osmotic pressure) =<i>i*</i>MRT<div>where i= # of solute particles and R is ideal gas constat</div>
what is beta oxidation?	cleaving the beta carbon next to the COOH group
<sup>what does chymotrypsin do?</sup>	cleaves peptide bonds preferentially near hydrophobic amino acids (think aromatic benzene rings)
What's the central Dogma of Biology?	DNA--&gt;RNA--&gt;protein.
What describes the process of DNA becoming RNA?	Trancsription.
What describes the process of RNA becoming protein?	Translation
What enzyme turns DNA into RNA?	RNA polymerase 2
A chromosome in G1 made up of how many chromatids per chromosome?	1&nbsp;
What does N=3 mean?	3 types of chromosomes
What is ploidy?	the number of copies of a chromosome
What are the 4 stages of the cell cycle	G1, S, G2, M
What is S?	Period of DNA synthesis
Gap between Mitosis and S	G1
Gap between S and Mitosis	G2
How many chromatids in G2	2
How many chromatids per chromosome after S? Name?	2, sister
What are the phases of Interphase?	G1, S, G2
What connects sister chromatids?	Centromere
Two chromosome of the same type are:	homologs
Karyotopes stop mitosis in:	metaphase of mitosis
The stage when the nucleus begins to break down and the chromosomes become observable	prophase
The stage when the chromosomes align in mitosis	metaphase
The stage in meiosis when homologs begin to seperate	anaphase I
What pulls the chromosomes apart?	Spindle fibers
Banding pattern is the same for:	Homologs
Cells with the 'normal' amount of chromosomes are	euploid
What term describes cells with missing or additional chromosomes?	aneuploid
Crossing over happens in which stage of meiosis?	Prophase I
What % of the DNA remains in the daughter cell after meiosis?	50%
The DNA content of N chromosomes with one chromatid per chromosome is:	C
When does crossing over take place?	Prophase I of meiosis
What does a karyotype identify?	chromosomes
How does a karyotype identify chromosomes?	Size and shape (position of centromere)
A cell that undergoes mitosis after meiosis is a	spore
What is a Barr body	an inactive X chromosome
A ___ cell undergoes meiosis to generate gametes	germ
Homologs are paired up in meiosis or mitosis?	Meiosis. NOT Mitosis
A karyotype is unique to a:	species
pyruvate is converted to acetyl CoA in the	mitochondrial matrix
pyruvate is converted to acetyl CoA by (and where)	pyrvuate dehydrogenase, found inside mitochondrial matrix
what are prosthetic groups?	nonprotein components of enzymes required for enzymatic activity. NOT part of original AA sequence of protein
what is an enoyl?	carbonyl with a double bond between alpha and beta carbons
each FADH2 produces __ ATP	1.5
each NADH produces __ ATP	2.5
can viral budding occur in bacteria?	no, because prokaryotes have a cell wall
what is thyroxine?	associated with thyroid, responsible for regulating metabolism. Aka t4
what is the founder effect?	phenomenon where certain areas of world show higher allele frequency than others
does salinity affect enzyme rate?	yes
where is oxytocin made?	hypothalamus
what are pseudopodia made of?	microfilaments (actin polymerization)&nbsp;
actin polymerizes to form	microfilaments
where is the mitral valve located?	between the left atrium and left ventricle
what is an apoenzyme?	enzyme lacking its cofactor
what is a holoenzyme?	enzyme+coenzyme
what lipid is the component of myelin?	sphingomyelin
which channel repolarizes the membrane to its resting potential?	K+ (potassium)
"a cell that isn't dividing but metabolically ""active"" is in what stage of the cell cycle?"	G0 or G1.
what does the diaphragm do during inspiration	contracts
what do the intercostal (rib) muscles do during inspiration?	contract, pulling ribs together, elevating rib cage
what happens to the pupil during the sympathetic response	DILATES
when are primary oocytes made?	between fertilization and birth
glomerular filtration rate is *mostly* dependent on	blood pressure
what do the kidneys do in response to decreased blood pressure?	<div>Decreased blood pressure on juxtoglomerular cells in afferent arteriole of kidney result in release of renin. Renin acts on angiotensinogen in bloodstream, converts it to angiotensin. Angiotensin acts on adrenal cortex to stimulate release of aldosterone, which&nbsp;increases sodium and water reabsorption, increasing blood volume and pressure</div>
what is adaptive radiation?	divergence of one species into multiple different species which can occur when the original species is geographically isolated
what causes a neuronal depolarization?	sodium ions moving IN
what does calcitonin do?	DECREASE blood calcium<div><br></div>
what does parathyroid hormone do?	INCREASE blood calcium
what are sertoli cells?	provide nourishment for developing sperm cells
what are the steps in spermatogenesis?	spermatogonium--&gt;primary spermatocyte--&gt;secondary spermatocyte--&gt; spermatid--&gt;spermatozoan
what is unique about exocrine glands?	secrete through ducts
what does the pancreas produce? What is it signaled by ?&nbsp;	Endocrine: insulin, glucagon<div>Exocrine (signaled by gastrin): proteolytic enzymes (chymotrypsin), lipases, amylases, nucleases, bicarbonate&nbsp;</div>
what is the function of ADH?	anti-diuretic hormone, fxns to increase water reabsorption and urine concentration
what is the function of myoglobin?	STORAGE of O2, no transport
what direction does RNA polymerase travel in? what direction does it synthesize in?	travels: 3--&gt;5<div>synthesized: 5--&gt;3</div>
what kind of polymerase is found in a retrovirus?	RNA dependent DNA polymerase (reverse transcriptase)
what is the function of the leaky potassium channels?	maintainence of resting membrane potential
what is a zymogen?	inactive form of protein
are shorter wavelengths(higher freq) more likely or less likely to be absorbed by body tissue?	more likely
how many phosphates are attached to each nucleotide in DNA?	2
what property of the lipid sphingomyelin makes it important for action potentials?	its conductivity(or lack thereof), as conductivity and insulation are related
error bars are a measure of___	Precision: how far from the true value is it?
what is an ideal control group?	has all the factors of the test group except the thing being tested
what are T cells activated by?	antigen presenting cells
what are antigen presenting cells?	B cells, macrophages, dendritic cells
what do antigen presenting cells do?	display a MHC
neutrophils and macrophages are part of the	innate immune system
what is a spliceosome?	Molecular machine that splices from RNA not DNA
what does DNA methylation do?	suppress transcription by condensing chromatin
how many ATP are produced in glycolysis?	2 total. 4 in, 2 out.
what are the 3 stop codons on DNA?	TGA, TAA, TAG
what does a kinase do?	transfer phosphate from high energy molecule (GTP or ATP), to substrate
what does a phosphatase do?	removes phosphate group from substrates
what is the function of a fibroblast?	produce ECM
what does prolactin do?	stimulate breast milk PRODUCTION
what does oxytocin do?	stimulate breast milk RELEASE (as well as uterine contractions, etc)
what is the function of VLDL? (very low density lipoprotein)	carry fatty acids AWAY FROM liver
what does HDL do?	carries stray fatty acids and triglycerides TO liver
what is the ploidy of a secondary spermatocyte? and of a primary spermatocyte?	n, 23/ 2n, 46. Chromosome # gets halved at Meiosis I. Loss of sister chromatids at Meiosis II
what direction does DNA polymerase READ in?	3--&gt;5
what direction does DNA polymerase SYNTHESIZE in?	5--&gt;3
what is the function of lutenizing hormone?	stimulate leydig cells to promote testosterone--&gt;make sperm. In females, luteal surge results in ovulation.&nbsp;
what is the function of CD8 cells?	detect and kill INTRACELLULAR pathogens
what is the function of CD4 T cells?	helper cells, release cytokines and help suppress or regulate immune response
what is the function of B cells?	releasing antibodies
maltose is the product of?	amylase breaking down starch
what connects the cells in cardiac muscle?	GAP JUNCTIONS (aka electrical synapses)
what do tight junctions do?	TIGHT joining of cells, prevent movement of shit
what does the sodium potassium pump do?	pumps 3 Na+ out and 2 K+ in. Net output of 1+ out of cell, maintains negative potential INSIDE CELL
what do cytotoxic T cells do?	kill cancer cells or infected/damaged cells
what is the function of a dendritic cell?	process antigen material, and present it to T cells. act as messengers between adaptive and innate immune system
what is the difference between a coenzyme and a cofactor?	a coenzyme is ORGANIC, while a cofactor is not (usually a metal ion or something)
what event precedes the release of opening of Na+ channels on the motor end plate, resulting in depolarization of muscle fibers?	binding of acetylcholine to postsynaptic membrane of sarcolemma&nbsp;
what do reducing conditions do in gel electrophoresis?	disrupt disulfide bonds
what do denaturing conditions do during gel electrophoresis	disrupt interactions between monomers allowing primary structure to be analyzed
what is the significance of the hill coefficient?	higher than 1 meants enzyme exhibits cooperativity. Sigmoidal shape of O2-hemoglobin curve means hill coefficeint &gt; 1&nbsp;
what is the G1/S checkpoint?	checkpoint before DNA replication takes place
what is kD?	dissociation constant
is pressure lower or higher in the lower extremities?	HIGHER
the GLUT4 does what, and where is it found?	insulin-regulated glucose transporter allows diffusion of glucose down its concentration gradient into cells. Found in adipose tissue and muscle.&nbsp;
what is a chaotropic agent?	disrupts H bonding networks by solubizing hydrophobic residues (destroys proteins)
at a pH below the isoelectric point, a protein will have a net	POSITIVE charge
how do you find the pI of an amino acid without any acidic/basic side chains?	take the averages of the amino and carboxy pKas. w
what is the pKa of the carboxy terminus?	2
what is the pka of the n-terminus?	~10
what ribsomal subunit type is associated with eukaryotes?	80s
what ribosomal subtype is associated with prokaryotes?	70s
how many reading frames does prokaryotic mRNA have?	multiple
a large kD means	low binding affinity
the GI tract is derived from	endoderm
what is opsonization?	when antibodies bind to antigens on a pathogen
what happens to insulin levels after a meal?	increase
what are the fat soluble vitamins?	DEAK
where can lipid peroxides be found in the cell, and why?	Oxygen is needed for lipid peroxidation (breakdown via addition of O2), and thus takes place in mitochondrial membrane.&nbsp;
what is trisomy 21?	downs syndrome
what is trisomy 14?	DEATH! why? because it has more genes
how does SDS page separate proteins? (Form of gel electrophoresis)	based on mass
glucose 6-phosphatase plays a role in	gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis
how do you calculate kcat/ what is kcat?	Vmax/[Etotal]. Turnover number- number of substrate molecules the enzyme produces per unit time
what are some starting materials for gluconeogenesis?	lactate, glycerol, alanine. Three carbons!
what happens to the Galpha subunit of a GPCR when a ligand is bound?	exchanges bound GDP for a GTP. GTP, associated with alpha subunit, activates downstream pathway&nbsp;
what enzyme catalyzes the rate limiting step in glycogenolysis?	glycogen phosphorylase
phosphogluconate is involved in	the pentose phosphate pathway
what is the product of the pentose phosphate pathway?	NADPH and five carbon sugars (ribose)<div><br></div>
what primarily composes the secondary structure of proteins?	H bonding between backbones
alpha helix and beta sheets are an example of	secondary structure
disulfide bridges are what level of protein structure?	tertiary
trypsin and lipase function in what part of the body?	small intestine
cytokinesis is possible because of what protein structure?	microFILAMENTS
prokaryotic flagella are made from ___	flagellin, different from eukaryotes, where it is made of 9+2 microTUBULE arrangement.&nbsp;
what are the stages of interphase?	G1--&gt;S--&gt;G2
the y intercept in a linweaver-burke plot represents	1/vmax
how many electrons does cytochrome c carry?	ONE
ideal PCR primers have	a high G-C content, increasing the melting temperature. Stronger h bonds.
when does nondisjunction occur?	anaphase 1 or 2
which amino acids are used to make proteins? (Chirality)	only L
what is euchromatin?	loose, easily accesible to transcription machinery
what is the vasculature schema?	Arteries--&gt;arterioles--&gt;capillary bed--&gt;venules--&gt;veins
the lower the Kd, the higher the	binding affinity
what does a protease do?	hydrolytic cleavage of proteins
Ectoderm	Nervous system, epidermis, sense organs, mouth
what does lipase do?	hydrolyze fatty acids/fats
proteins destined for the cell membrane have a&nbsp;	signal sequence to bind to rough ER
what does calcium do in the context of muscle movement?	after AP propogates from sarcolemma to T tubule to sarcoplasmic reticulum, Ca2+ store is released to sarcomere. Binds troponin--&gt;pulls tropomyosin away from actin-myosin binding site which allows myosin to bind actin
where is glomerular filtrate the most concentrated?	Bottom of loop of Henle, which is in medullary collecting duct
what are ABC transport proteins?	ATP-binding cassette transporters. Utilize energy of ATP to energize translocation of substances across membrane, either for uptake or export.&nbsp;
what is a lipid raft?	cholesterol rich domain in plasma membrane. Cholesterol holds phospholipids together at an appropriate distance.&nbsp;
the initial filtration step in the kidney occurs due to	pressure difference in bowman's capsule
nucleotides are bonded to eachother by	Phosphodiester bond
is loss of appetite a Sx of DM?	No. Low blood sugar is common (due to medication), thus sensation of increased appetite results.
is glycolysis exergonic or endergonic?	exergonic overall. Some steps are endergonic.
what is the fate of pyruvate / electron carriers in gluconeogenesis?	reduced to glucose and NADH oxidized to NAD+
what is the function of NADPH produced by the pentose phosphate pathway?	NADPH helps build molecules. Able to donate its electrons to compounds that fight dangerous oxygen molecules. Gives antioxidants their constant flow of electrons to fight oxygen radicals.&nbsp;
vesicle exocytosis does what to membrane surface area?	INCREASES it
what does aldosterone do?	increases sodium reabsorption, which increases blood osmolarity, which increases ADH production--&gt;more water reabsorpton--&gt;increase in blood volume and pressure
what does the krebs cycle produce for each acetyl CoA?	1 FADH2, 3 NADH, 1 GTP, 2 CO2&nbsp;
what does the movement of Cl- ions into an neuron do?	hyperpolarizes it and prevents it from firing an action potential
hyperpolarization of a neuron prevents its ability to	release neurotransmitters
a frameshift mutation affects	translation
what are the assumptions for hardy-weinberg?	No mutations, large population, no net migration, no natural selection, random mating
a low Km indicates	higher binding affinity between enzyme and substrate
what controls the anterior pituitary?	factors released by the hypothalamus
what controls the posterior pituitary?	neuronal stimulus from the hypothalamus
what is a proto-oncogene?	a gene that, when mutated, becomes an oncogene
what is endothelium?	simple squamous cells that line blood and lymphatic vessels
epi and nor-epi are produced by	the adrenal medulla
where do epi and nor-epi bind?	the cell surface because they are derived from amino acids and are polar
what happens during prophase?	spindle apparatus forms, centrioles move to poles, nuclear membrane disintegrates, chromatin condenses
what is produced in oogenesis?	1 ovum after 2 divisions
what is the 16 or more cell stage called?	morula&nbsp;
what is the ~64 cell stage called?	blastula
what is the 1 cell stage called?	zygote
what does the parasympathetic nervous system do to blood vessels?	contracts blood to skeletal muscle, dilates blood to GI muscles&nbsp;
what is IgA?	immunoglobulin (antibody) that protects against toxins, bacteria, and free floating viral cells
what does ACTH do?	stimulate adrenal cortex to produce cortisol&nbsp;
how many carbons are in pyruvate?	3
how many carbons in oxaloacetate?	4
what does a positive deltaH mean	rxn requires input of heat
ketogenesis uses ___ as substrates	Acetyl CoA or amino acids&nbsp;
a decreased Km indicates	increased substrate affinity/increased velocity
can noncompetitive inhibition be overcome with increased substrate concentration?	NO
competitive inhibition can be overcome with	greater [S]
what kind of sugar does NADPH contain?	ribose(pentose) because it is a nucleotide derivative
fatty acid oxidation occurs in the _____; synthesis occurs in the ______	mitochondrial matrix; cytoplasm&nbsp;
pyrvuate is converted to acetyl coA in the	mitochondrial matrix
increasing pKa of side chains means the isoelectric point	also increases
when pH is less than pKa	protonated
G Cells produce what, and respond to what?	Produce gastrin in response to peptides in stomach/distension/parasympathetic input. Gastrin stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.&nbsp;
how do you calculate recombination frequency?	# of recombinants/total # of offspring
what happens to the allele frequency in hardy weinberg?	remains the same
are actin filaments polymerized in muscle contraction?	NO
what happens to FSH levels after menstruation?	They are high
what hormone increases to instigate ovulation?	LH
what does aldosterone do to blood K levels?	decreases them because of increased K secretion
what do exonucleases do?	Cleaves nucleotides from end of polynucleotide chain.&nbsp;
the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate requires	Pyruvate carboxylase, CO2 and ATP
what is a missense mutation?	one AA substituted for another
what is a nonsense mutation?	leads to a premature termination
A segment of DNA coding for a protein is a	gene
Non-identical copies of chromosomes are	homologs
Non-identical versions of a gene are	alleles
A person carrying two different alleles at a given locus is a&nbsp;	heterozygote
If an allele is expressed regardless of what the second allele is, it is&nbsp;	dominant
When the phenotype is expressed as a blended mix of two alleles it is referred to as	incomplete dominance
If two alleles are both expressed and not blended it is	co-dominance
how do you measure catalytic efficiency?	kcat/Km
The effects of mutation in one gene alters many seemingly unrelated aspects of an organism's phenotype is called	pleiotropism
Many genes that influence one trait are called	Polygenism
The likelihood that a person with a given genotype will express &nbsp;the expected phenotype is called	penetrance
Expression of alleles for one gene is dependent on a different gene is called	Epistasis
A recessive allele on the X chromosome in a male will be (expressed/not expressed)	Expressed
anion exchange columns bind:	negatively charged anions
A group of organisms capable of reproducing sexually is a&nbsp;	species
Two types of reproductive isolation are&nbsp;	pre and post-zygotic
Repr. Isolation that prevents formation of a zygote, such as ecological, temporal, behavioral are called	Prezygotic&nbsp;
Barrers that prevent the development survival and reproduction of a hybrid individual are called	Postzygotic barriers
The creation of a new species is called	speciation
Shared physical structures resulting from a common ancestor are	Homologous features
Features that serve the same function in different species but that are not due to a common ancestor	Analogous Features
When two different species come to possess many analogous features	Convergent Evolution
When two species result from a common ancestor	Divergent Evolution
Branching speciation caused by divergent selection is&nbsp;	cladogenesis (Clado-greek for branch)
Two species that go through similar evolutionary changes	parallel evolution
Spontaneous polymerization of monomers with enzymes (early Earth) is called	abiotic synthesis
Polypeptides made through abiotic synthesis	proteinoids
how do you calculate Vmax given [Etotal] and kcat?	Vmax=kcat[Etotal]
when both substrates occupy an active site, what kind of complex is formed?	ternary complex
Electrochemical signals of the nervous system are	action potentials
The body of the neuron	soma
Neurons with one dendrite are termed	bipolar
neurons with many dendrites are termed	multipolar
Dendrites ___ signals and axons ____ signals	receive, carry away
Axons terminate in&nbsp;	synaptic knobs
When an action potential reaches a synaptic knob it is realeased across the	synaptic cleft
The electric potential across the plasma membrane	resting membrane potential
Enzyme that pumps sodium out and potassium into the cell with the hydrolysis of one ATP Molecule	Na+/K+ ATPase
Channels that allow the ions to leak across the membrane according to their gradient	Leak Channels
Sodium ions are pumped __ of the cell and Potassium ions are pumped ___ the cell, during the resting state	Out/ Into
As a result of the gradient and Na/K ATPase the inside of the neuron is ___ relative to the outside	Negative
A disturbance of the membrane potential that causes a wave of depolarization to travel along the axon	Action Potential
After depolarization, the process of___ returns the membrane to the normal resting potential	Repolarization
once the ____ is reached 'voltage gated sodium channels' are opened	Threshold potential
The resting membrane potential is at ___ volts and the threshold potential is at ___ volts	-70, -50
The process of returning to its resting membrane potential is	repolarization
During repolarization Sodium channels are ___ and Potassium channels are ___	Closed, Opened
Axons are wrapped in ___	myelin
in Nerve cells, ion channels are concentrated at the ____, where there are breaks in the myelin sheath.&nbsp;	Nodes of Ranvier
The rapid jumping conduction in myelinated axons	Saltatory conduction
Action potentials are sped up due to the myelin sheath as the action potential is forced to jump from __ to __	node to node
Na ions are driven ___ the cell by their concentration gradient and ___ the cell by the electrical gradient	Into, Out of
K ions are driven ___ the neuron by their concentration gradient and ___ neuron by the electrical gradient	Out of , In to
Recovery period for a neuron after depolarization is called the&nbsp;	Refractory period
In the ___ ____ period, no amount of depolarization will induce an action potential	Absolute
In the ___ ___ period the amount of depolarization required for an action potential is much greater than normal	relative refractory
The junction between the axon of one neuron and the dedrites of a second neuron or an organ	Synpase
___ synapses are used in the nervous system	chemical
When an action potential reaches the end of the axon ___ &nbsp;are opened on the presynaptic neuron	Calcium channels
Calcium influx causes ___ of neurotransmitter stored in vesicles from the presynaptic cell	exocytosis
The receptor cells in the postsynaptic membrane are ion channels that open/close upon the capture of a&nbsp;	neurotransmitter
"The adding of the effects of all the synapses impinging on the neuron which allows the postsynaptic neuron to ""decide"" whether to fire an action potential"	Summation
___ neurotransmitters induce the postsynaptic neuron to fire	Excitatory
___ neurotrasmitters further polarize (hyperpolarize) the postsynatic neuron	Inhibitory
Motor neurons carry messages to muscles and glands known as __	effectors
Motor neurons are known as	Efferent Neurons (to Effectors)
Sensory neurons are known as&nbsp;	afferent neurons
The portion of the PNS that is concerned with conscious sensation and voluntary movement	Somatic Division
Portion of PNS concerned with involuntary processes	Autonomic Division
The efferent portion of the Autonomic division is dividided into two subdivisions:&nbsp;	sympathetic and parasympathetic
Fight or Flight	Sympathetic
Rest and Digest	Parasympathetic
CNS is composed of&nbsp;	brain and spinal chord
Cell bodies bunched together in the CNS are called	nuclei
Cell bodies of neurons bunched together outside the CNS are called	ganglia
Recombination Frequency =	# recombinants/ total # of progeny
Spinal cord is involved in	simple reflexes, primitive behaviors (urination, walking, sex)
Hindbrain is composed of&nbsp;	medulla, pons, cerebellum
This region of the CNS controls antigravity posture and balance and connects the medulla to the upper regions of the brain	pons
This region of the CNS coordinates complex movement, balance, posture and spatial equilibrium	cerebellum
brainstem includes	medulla, pons, midbrain (ascending order)
Two general components of forebrain	Diencephalon and telencephalon
Diencephalon parts	thalamus and hypothalamus
Ascending order from spinal cord to cortex	spinal cord-&gt;medulla-&gt;pons-&gt;midbrain-&gt;thalamus-&gt;cortex
Thalamus function	relay and processing sensory info
hypothalamus function	emotions, controls endocrine
Telencephalon parts	cerebral hemispheres and corpus callosum
what connects the two hemispheres	corpus callosum

a sigmoidal shape indicates	cooperative binding
how does a blood pressure reading occur?	constrict until no flow is heard. the first point at which it is heard is systolic, the point at which it is no longer heard again is diastolic
where are the bonds occuring in the secondary structure of a protein?	between backbone amide protons and carbonyl oxygens
pyrimidines are	CUT<div><br /></div><div>6 member rings</div>

what is ubiquitination?	targeting a protein for degradation by proteasomes
what does glyceraldehyde-3phosphate-dehydrogenase do?	catalyze conversion of G3P to 1,3-biphosphoglycerate. NAD+, Pi --&gt; NADH, H+
what does vasopressin do?	exact same thing as ADH, because it is ADH. Always drilling holes in the collecting duct for water uptake.&nbsp;
what are schwann cells?	myelin producing cells of PNS
what are oligodendrocytes?	myelin producing cells of central nervous system

what do proteases do?	digest proteins into smaller fragments

why is ATP required for muscle contraction?	required to break myosin-actin bond

The purpose of the middle ear bones is to	amplify the sound waves

beneath the sclera	choroid
Just behind the cornea is the	anterior chamber

Behind the anterior chamber is a membrane called the	iris
The opening in the iris is called the&nbsp;	pupil
Behind the iris is the&nbsp;	posterior chamber
In the back part of the posterior chamber is the	lens
Its job is to focus the incoming light on the retina at the right angle	lens
The curvature of the lens is varied by which muscle?	ciliary muscle
Light passes through the ___ on its way from the lens to the retina	Vitreous chamber

the terminal electron acceptor in alcoholic fermentation is	NADH cannot be oxidized in ETC, and thus donates its electrons elsewhere. Pyruvate loses CO2 to form acetaldehyde. NADH donates electrons to acetaldehyde, forms ethanol and NAD+. &nbsp;&nbsp;

A form of summation in which the rapid firing of action potentials causes the EPSPs or IPSPs to pile up	temporal summation
A form of summation in which EPSPs and ISPS's from all of the synapses on the postsynaptic membrane are summed at a given moment in time	spatial summation
Excitatory neurotransmitters cause postsynaptic depolarization. This is called	Excitatory Post Synaptic Potentials (EPSPs)
Inhibitory neurotransmitters cause postsynaptic polarization, also referred to as	Inhibitory Post-Synaptic Potentials (IPSPs)
When the sympathetic system is activated the digestive system is (inhibited OR stimulated)	inhibited
When the parasympathetic nervous system is activated the urinary system is (stimulated OR inhibited)	stimulated
When the parasympathetic nervous system is activated the bronchial smooth muscle is (constricted OR relaxed)	constricted (airways closed)
When the sympathetic nervous system is activated heart rate and blood flow is (decreased OR increased)	increased

Mature gametes are 1N is good in meiosis because...&nbsp;	(1 complete set of chromosome)&nbsp;<div>Union of sperm nucleus and ovum nucleus will only produce the right amount of sets of chromosomes (2N) in the <b>gamete</b></div>
The purpose of sexual reproduction is so that the offspring will...	have the same number of chromosomes as the parents (23+23=46)
Steps in Meiosis:	Meiosis I:<div><b>(1) Interphase (2N)</b></div><div>(2) Prophase 1</div><div><b>(3)--&gt;Prometaphase 1</b></div><div><b>(4) Metaphase 1 (4N)</b></div><div>(5) Anaphase 1</div><div>(6) Telophase</div><div><b>(7) Cytokinesis 1</b></div><div>Meiosis II:</div><div>(7)&nbsp;Prophase 2</div><div><b>(8) Metaphase 2</b></div><div>(9)&nbsp;Anaphase 2</div><div><b>(5) Cytokinesis 1</b></div>
Process:&nbsp;g1, s, g2	interphase
<div>How is genetic information passed on from cell to cell within an organism​?</div>	Mitosis
How is genetic information passed on from organism to organism within a species?​	Meiosis
The cell cycle only applies to	eukaryotic cells
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> contain the blueprint for a cell​	<span class=cloze>Chromosomes</span> contain the blueprint for a cell​<br> 
In the Interphase phase, the cell is not <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	In the Interphase phase, the cell is not <span class=cloze>dividing</span><br> 
Stages within Interphase are <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Stages within Interphase are <span class=cloze>G1, Restriction point, S, and G2</span><br> 
Interphase: <b>G1</b>	Phase where cell just divided so now it builds membranes to get to a size the same as parent, builds more mitochondria (divided from parent to two)&nbsp;<div>Some cells stay in this phase like neurons</div>
Phase where cell just divided so now it builds membranes to get to a size the same as parent, builds more mitochondria (divided from parent to two)&nbsp;<div>Some cells stay in this phase like neurons</div>	Interphase: <b>G1</b>
Example of cells that are always in the G1 phase	neurons
Interphase: <b>Restriction Point</b>	"Phase where cell stops rebuilding ""new"" organelles. Like an internal clock. As the cell senses its environment, it may receive a chemical signal that tells it to stay or move on to the S-phase"
"Phase where cell stops rebuilding ""new"" organelles. Like an internal clock. As the cell senses its environment, it may receive a chemical signal that tells it to stay or move on to the S-phase"	Interphase: <b>Restriction Point</b>
Interphase: <b>S phase</b>	Phase in interphase where the cell makes copies of DNA (chromosomes). Accomplished by the DNA Polymerase 2 enzyme that replicates.&nbsp;
Phase in interphase where the cell makes copies of DNA (chromosomes). Accomplished by the DNA Polymerase 2 enzyme that replicates.&nbsp;	Interphase: <b>S phase</b>
Interphase: <b>G2 phase</b>&nbsp;(3 events)	Phase in interphase in which:<div><div>(1) Chromosomes become condensed​</div><div>​(2)&nbsp;Centrosome splits &nbsp;releasing two Centrioles​</div><div>​&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;---&gt; a Centriole (microtubule organizing center)​</div><div>​(3)&nbsp;Each centriole moves to the opposite side of a cell</div></div>
Phase in interphase in which:<div><div>(1) Chromosomes become condensed​</div><div>​(2)&nbsp;Centrosome splits &nbsp;releasing two Centrioles​</div><div>​&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;---&gt; a Centriole (microtubule organizing center)​</div><div>​(3)&nbsp;Each centriole moves to the opposite side of a cell</div></div>	Interphase: <b>G2 phase</b>&nbsp;(3 events)
"Steps in Mitosis or ""M-Phase"" are (5):"	<div>Prophase​</div><div>​</div><div>Prometaphase​</div><div>​</div><div>Metaphase​</div><div>​</div><div>Anaphase​</div><div>​</div><div>Telophase</div>
<div>Prophase​</div><div>​</div><div>Prometaphase​</div><div>​</div><div>Metaphase​</div><div>​</div><div>Anaphase​</div><div>​</div><div>Telophase</div>	"Steps in Mitosis or ""M-Phase"" are (5):"
In G2, the&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> separate and move to opposite ends of the cell​	In G2, the&nbsp;<span class=cloze>Centrosomes</span> separate and move to opposite ends of the cell​<br> 
In prometaphase,&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> dissolves; Spindle Apparatus forms​	In prometaphase,&nbsp;<span class=cloze>Nuclear Envelope</span> dissolves; Spindle Apparatus forms​<br> 
In prometaphase,&nbsp;Nuclear Envelope dissolves; <span class=cloze>[...]</span> forms​	In prometaphase,&nbsp;Nuclear Envelope dissolves; <span class=cloze>Spindle Apparatus</span> forms​<br> 
<div>Nuclear Envelope dissolves; Spindle Apparatus forms​</div><div>(diagram)​</div>	Prometaphase
"Phase in which replicated <font color=""#0a00f6"">chromosomes pair with corresponding homologous chromosomes</font>, forming tetrads, undergo crossing over to create new allele combos"	Prophase 1
Prophase 1	"Phase in which replicated <font color=""#0a00f6"">chromosomes pair with corresponding homologous chromosomes</font>, forming tetrads, undergo crossing over to create new allele combos"
"<div>Phase in which spindle fibers attach to tetrads, homologous chromosomes line up <b>side to side</b>&nbsp;(aka <font color=""#0a00f6"">synapse</font>)</div>"	metaphase 1
metaphase 1	"<div>Phase in which spindle fibers attach to tetrads, homologous chromosomes line up <b>side to side</b>&nbsp;(aka <font color=""#0a00f6"">synapse</font>)</div>"
"Phase in which homologous chromosomes are pulled apart by spindle fibers, the <font color=""#0a00f6"">tension breaks the centromere and chromatids separate and pulled to the centrosomes</font>"	anaphase 1
anaphase 1	"Phase in which homologous chromosomes are pulled apart by spindle fibers, the <font color=""#0a00f6"">tension breaks the centromere and chromatids separate and pulled to the centrosomes</font>"
"Phase in which separated chromosomes cluster at opposite ends, membrane forms<font color=""#0a00f6"">, cytokinesis occurs</font>"	telophase 1
telophase 1	"Phase in which separated chromosomes cluster at opposite ends, membrane forms<font color=""#0a00f6"">, cytokinesis occurs</font>"
Phase within telophase in which cell membrane pinches	cytokinesis
cytokinesis	Phase within telophase in which cell membrane pinches
"Phase in which chromosomes (2N) line up head to toe in the ""equator"" of the nucleus"	metaphase II&nbsp;
metaphase II&nbsp;	"Phase in which chromosomes (2N) line up head to toe in the ""equator"" of the nucleus"
Phase in which sister chromatids are pulled apart/separated, then cell pinches in the middle, producing four grandaughter cells	(Anaphase II) Telophase II / Cytokinesis II
(Anaphase II) Telophase II / Cytokinesis II	Phase in which sister chromatids are pulled apart/separated, then cell pinches in the middle, producing four grandaughter cells
In prometaphase, <span class=cloze>[...]</span> has dissolved, duplicate sets of chromasomes and spindle paratus&nbsp;are visible, each macrotubule attaches to the homologous duplicated chromosome	"In prometaphase, <span class=cloze>nuclear envelope</span> has dissolved, duplicate sets of chromasomes and spindle paratus&nbsp;are visible, each macrotubule attaches to the homologous duplicated chromosome<br> <img src=""prometaphase I.png"">"
In prometaphase, nuclear envelope has dissolved, duplicate sets of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> and <span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;are visible, each macrotubule attaches to the homologous duplicated chromosome	"In prometaphase, nuclear envelope has dissolved, duplicate sets of <span class=cloze>chromasomes</span> and <span class=cloze>spindle paratus</span>&nbsp;are visible, each macrotubule attaches to the homologous duplicated chromosome<br> <img src=""prometaphase I.png"">"
In prometaphase, nuclear envelope has dissolved, duplicate sets of chromasomes and spindle paratus&nbsp;are visible, each <span class=cloze>[...]</span> attaches to the homologous duplicated chromosome	"In prometaphase, nuclear envelope has dissolved, duplicate sets of chromasomes and spindle paratus&nbsp;are visible, each <span class=cloze>macrotubule</span> attaches to the homologous duplicated chromosome<br> <img src=""prometaphase I.png"">"
In prometaphase, nuclear envelope has dissolved, duplicate sets of chromasomes and spindle paratus&nbsp;are visible, each macrotubule attaches to the <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"In prometaphase, nuclear envelope has dissolved, duplicate sets of chromasomes and spindle paratus&nbsp;are visible, each macrotubule attaches to the <span class=cloze>homologous duplicated chromosome</span><br> <img src=""prometaphase I.png"">"
As we proceed to<b> prometaphase</b>, each pair of homologous duplicated chromosome is becoming associated with microtubule from only <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b>	"As we proceed to<b> prometaphase</b>, each pair of homologous duplicated chromosome is becoming associated with microtubule from only <b><span class=cloze>one centriole</span></b><br> <img src=""prometaphase I.png"" />"
What is a unique feature in meiosis?	synapse
In <b>Metaphase I</b>, the large duplicated chromosome (<span class=cloze>[...]</span> origin) is on the left side and the&nbsp;large duplicated chromosome (<span class=cloze>[...]</span> origin) is on the right... but usually <i>random!!!</i>	"In <b>Metaphase I</b>, the large duplicated chromosome (<span class=cloze>paternal</span> origin) is on the left side and the&nbsp;large duplicated chromosome (<span class=cloze>maternal</span> origin) is on the right... but usually <i>random!!!</i><br> <img src=""Metaphase 1.png"" />"
In metaphase I, cells undergoing meiosis are at <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span> </b>stage	In metaphase I, cells undergoing meiosis are at <b><span class=cloze>4N</span> </b>stage<br> 4 complete sets of chromosomes
"homologous sets of duplicated chromosomes line up <span class=cloze>[...]</span> not <span class=cloze>[...]</span> in <b>metaphase I</b>, also known as <font color=""#0a00f6""><b>synapse</b></font>"	"homologous sets of duplicated chromosomes line up <span class=cloze>side by side</span> not <span class=cloze>head to tail</span> in <b>metaphase I</b>, also known as <font color=""#0a00f6""><b>synapse</b></font><br> <img src=""Metaphase 1.png"" /><div>large to large; small to small</div>"
Precursor cells in interphase are in <span class=cloze>[...]</span> stage	Precursor cells in interphase are in <span class=cloze>2N</span> stage<br> 
By the end of <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span>,</b>&nbsp;we are left with 2 cells with 2 complete sets of chromosomes	"By the end of <b><span class=cloze>Meiosis I</span>,</b>&nbsp;we are left with 2 cells with 2 complete sets of chromosomes<br> <img src=""End of Meiosis I.png"" />"
By the end of <b>Meiosis I,</b>&nbsp;we are left with <span class=cloze>[...]</span> with <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"By the end of <b>Meiosis I,</b>&nbsp;we are left with <span class=cloze>2 cells</span> with <span class=cloze>2 complete sets</span> of <span class=cloze>chromosomes</span><br> <img src=""End of Meiosis I.png"" />"
Crossing over only exchanges <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of chromosomes	Crossing over only exchanges <span class=cloze>fragments</span> of chromosomes<br> 
In Meiosis II (Prophase/Prometaphase): each duplicated chromosome (<b>daughter cell</b>) will now connect to a <span class=cloze>[...]</span> from each centriole.&nbsp;	In Meiosis II (Prophase/Prometaphase): each duplicated chromosome (<b>daughter cell</b>) will now connect to a <span class=cloze>microtubule fiber</span> from each centriole.&nbsp;<br> 
In Meiosis II (<span class=cloze>[...]</span>): each duplicated chromosome (<b>daughter cell</b>) will now connect to a microtubule fiber from each centriole.&nbsp;	In Meiosis II (<span class=cloze>Prophase/Prometaphase</span>): each duplicated chromosome (<b>daughter cell</b>) will now connect to a microtubule fiber from each centriole.&nbsp;<br> 
In Metaphase II: Chromasome sets are now lined up&nbsp;&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"In Metaphase II: Chromasome sets are now lined up&nbsp;&nbsp;<span class=cloze> head to toe in equator of cell</span><br> <img src=""Meiosis II.png"">"
For sperms the precursor cell is called...	primary spermatocyte&nbsp;
For ovum, the precursor cell is called...	primary oocyte
As soon as a precursor cell enters meiosis 1 it is destined to become a&nbsp;	gamete
Are the new 1N cells at end of Meiosis I mature gametes?	It depends on the organism, if modifications are needed for function&nbsp;
After Anaphase II and Cytokinesis II, we are left with <span class=cloze>[...]</span> cells with one complete set<div>&nbsp;of chromosomes...</div>	"After Anaphase II and Cytokinesis II, we are left with <span class=cloze>four</span> cells with one complete set<div>&nbsp;of chromosomes...</div><br> <img src=""Meiosis II.png"" />"
After Anaphase II and Cytokinesis II, we are left with four cells with <span class=cloze>[...]</span><div>&nbsp;of chromosomes...</div>	"After Anaphase II and Cytokinesis II, we are left with four cells with <span class=cloze>one complete set</span><div>&nbsp;of chromosomes...</div><br> <img src=""Meiosis II.png"" />"
The goal of meiosis is to&nbsp;produce <span class=cloze>[...]</span> &nbsp;from one precursor (diploid)	"The goal of meiosis is to&nbsp;produce <span class=cloze>4 gamete cells (1N each; haploid)</span> &nbsp;from one precursor (diploid)<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 7.11.16 AM.png"" />"
The goal of meiosis is to&nbsp;produce 4 gamete cells (1N each; haploid) &nbsp;from <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"The goal of meiosis is to&nbsp;produce 4 gamete cells (1N each; haploid) &nbsp;from <span class=cloze>one precursor (diploid)</span><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 7.11.16 AM.png"" />"

spermatogenesis vs oogenesis	"<img src=""paste-73946451936016.jpg"" />"
The precursor cell of sperm is <span class=cloze>[...]</span> and originates in the 3rd trimester of fetal development&nbsp;	The precursor cell of sperm is <span class=cloze>spermatogonium</span> and originates in the 3rd trimester of fetal development&nbsp;<br> testes fully formed (mitosis) and gametes &nbsp;
In theory, a male can <span class=cloze>[...]</span> spermatogonial cells through <span class=cloze>[...]</span> until that male dies.	In theory, a male can <span class=cloze>continue to produce</span> spermatogonial cells through <span class=cloze>mitosis</span> until that male dies.<br> 
At the end of spermatogenesis we're left with <span class=cloze>[...]</span> that are <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"At the end of spermatogenesis we're left with <span class=cloze>4 spermatozoa</span> that are <span class=cloze>1N</span><br> <div><img src=""paste-74384538600208.jpg"" /></div>"
In order for a <b>spermatid </b>to be functional/viable, it must be able <span class=cloze>[...]</span> so it needs to mature and make a <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	In order for a <b>spermatid </b>to be functional/viable, it must be able <span class=cloze>to move</span> so it needs to mature and make a <span class=cloze>flagelum</span><br> takes 75 days
The precursor cell of ovum is <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, originates from 3rd trimester of human development and stops undergoing mitosis&nbsp; so that&nbsp;	The precursor cell of ovum is <span class=cloze>oogonium</span>, originates from 3rd trimester of human development and stops undergoing mitosis&nbsp; so that&nbsp;<br> 
The precursor cell of ovum is oogonium, originates from 3rd trimester of human development and <span class=cloze>[...]</span> so that&nbsp;	The precursor cell of ovum is oogonium, originates from 3rd trimester of human development and <span class=cloze>stops undergoing mitosis&nbsp;</span> so that&nbsp;<br> 
When a female human is born she has a <span class=cloze>[...]</span> amount of oogonium to reproduce	When a female human is born she has a <span class=cloze>finite</span> amount of oogonium to reproduce<br> 
After meiosis I in oogenesis, the secondary oocyte is <span class=cloze>[...]</span> than the first polar body	"After meiosis I in oogenesis, the secondary oocyte is <span class=cloze>larger in size</span> than the first polar body<br> <img src=""paste-74835510166288.jpg"" />"
After meiosis I in oogenesis, the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> is larger in size than the <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"After meiosis I in oogenesis, the <span class=cloze>secondary oocyte</span> is larger in size than the <span class=cloze>first polar body</span><br> <img src=""paste-74835510166288.jpg"" />"
One of the unique features of oogenesis is&nbsp;	As we move through meiosis I and meiosis II the offspring cells are disproportionate in size (volume of cytoplasm)
At the end of Meiosis II of oogenesis, one ovum is larger than the other three (<span class=cloze>[...]</span>)	"At the end of Meiosis II of oogenesis, one ovum is larger than the other three (<span class=cloze>polar bodies</span>)<br> <img src=""436866036_1280x1442.jpg"" />"
In the cytoplasm of the ovum (viable oocyte) is the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> (used as metabolic fuel for developing embryo)	In the cytoplasm of the ovum (viable oocyte) is the <span class=cloze>yolk protein</span> (used as metabolic fuel for developing embryo)<br> 
Polar bodies are <span class=cloze>[...]</span> in <span class=cloze>[...]</span> making them nonviable	Polar bodies are <span class=cloze>deficient</span> in <span class=cloze>yolk protein</span> making them nonviable<br> 
When can you see the difference between mitosis and meiosis?	"at Metaphase (I)<img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 8.09.56 AM.png"" />"
"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 8.13.36 AM.png"" /></div>When duplicated homologous chromosomes synapse, they are much closer to each other, and so when they touch a <b>break</b>&nbsp;occurs then an <b>exchange of region</b>&nbsp;of chromasome happens and finally <b>re-anneal</b>. This process is called..."	Crossover during Meiosis<div><br /></div>
Crossover during Meiosis<div><br /></div>	"<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 8.13.36 AM.png"" /></div>When duplicated homologous chromosomes synapse, they are much closer to each other, and so when they touch a <b>break</b>&nbsp;occurs then an <b>exchange of region</b>&nbsp;of chromasome happens and finally <b>re-anneal</b>. This process is called..."
Crossing over during meiosis causes&nbsp;	variation
"After crossover, it <b>is</b> possible for chromosome to not ""re-anneal"" so this means that"	Have a broken chromosome and so missing fragments... causing problems later on
Non-Disjunction Mutation (example)	"In an oocyte during synapse, an offspring cell at end of meiosis I is carying an <b>extra</b> homologous chromosome (pulled from anaphase).&nbsp;<div>In&nbsp;</div><div><b>This causes confusion when allele tries to communicate.... causes imbalances in the embryo and subsequent newborn</b>.</div><div><br /></div><div><b>Chromosome 21 has an excess like in Down Syndrome:</b></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 8.17.51 AM.png"" /><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 8.20.53 AM.png"" /></div>"
"In an oocyte during synapse, an offspring cell at end of meiosis I is carying an <b>extra</b> homologous chromosome (pulled from anaphase).&nbsp;<div>In&nbsp;</div><div><b>This causes confusion when allele tries to communicate.... causes imbalances in the embryo and subsequent newborn</b>.</div><div><br /></div><div><b>Chromosome 21 has an excess like in Down Syndrome:</b></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 8.17.51 AM.png"" /><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 8.20.53 AM.png"" /></div>"	Non-Disjunction Mutation (example)
More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div><br /></div><div>XXX</div>	sterile female = reproductive system does not develope properly
More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div>XXY</div>	Sterile male (Klinefelter Syndrome) - reproductive system does not develop properly
More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div>OY</div>	nonviable - no X chromosome, which has abundance of genes... so embryo will not develop to maturity
nonviable - no X chromosome, which has abundance of genes... so embryo will not develop to maturity	More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div>OY</div>
More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div>XO</div>	"<div>Sterile Female, ""<b>Turner Syndrome</b>""</div>Externally female, but internally female reproductive system will not be functionaly"
"<div>Sterile Female, ""<b>Turner Syndrome</b>""</div>Externally female, but internally female reproductive system will not be functionaly"	More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div>XO</div>
Sterile male (Klinefelter Syndrome) - reproductive system does not develop properly	More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div>XXY</div>
sterile female = reproductive system does not develope properly	More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div><br /></div><div>XXX</div>
More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div>XYY&nbsp;</div>	"Sterile Male ""<b>Jacob Syndrome</b>""<div>Causes neurological disfunctions</div>"
"Sterile Male ""<b>Jacob Syndrome</b>""<div>Causes neurological disfunctions</div>"	More examples of Non-Disjunction Mutations (sex chromosomes):<div>XYY&nbsp;</div>
Fallopian Tube when open is in close contact with the&nbsp;	ovary
"Day 15 of 28 cycle: Ovary releases a gamete ""<span class=cloze>[...]</span>"" that'll be caught by the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> and move down by small hairlike extensions on its walls (5 days approx.) to the uterus.<div><br /></div><div>If fertilizaiton hasn't happened, then <span class=cloze>[...]</span> occurs</div>"	"Day 15 of 28 cycle: Ovary releases a gamete ""<span class=cloze>primary oocyte</span>"" that'll be caught by the <span class=cloze>fellopian tube</span> and move down by small hairlike extensions on its walls (5 days approx.) to the uterus.<div><br /></div><div>If fertilizaiton hasn't happened, then <span class=cloze>menses</span> occurs</div><br> "
"If on day 15, during ovulation, sperm is present in the fellopian tube (introduced 72 hours prior), the oocyte touches the sperm and so <span class=cloze>[...]</span> occurs. This <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b> is dividing through mitosis and moves down to the uterus. The <span class=cloze>[...]</span> implants in the wall of uterus and releases a lot of the ""protein signal"" <span class=cloze>[...]</span> (HCG) &nbsp;that indicates to the ovary to not begin <span class=cloze>[...]</span>."	"If on day 15, during ovulation, sperm is present in the fellopian tube (introduced 72 hours prior), the oocyte touches the sperm and so <span class=cloze>fertilization</span> occurs. This <b><span class=cloze>zygote</span></b> is dividing through mitosis and moves down to the uterus. The <span class=cloze>embryo</span> implants in the wall of uterus and releases a lot of the ""protein signal"" <span class=cloze>human chorionic gonadotropin</span> (HCG) &nbsp;that indicates to the ovary to not begin <span class=cloze>menses</span>.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-29 at 8.27.59 AM.png"" />"
How much human chorionic gonadotropin hormone does the embryo produce?	so much that it is present in urine (pregnancy test)
