Region between the Cornea and the Iris	Anterior Chamber
Region behind the iris	posterior chamber
This type of hormone targets enzyme activity	peptide
This type of hormone affects transcription	steroid
Homologs line up in ___ of (meiosis/mitosis)	metaphase I of meiosis
"Lived in the 1800s. An Austrian Monk who is the ""Father of Genetics,"" observed the trends in transfer of traits among plants."	Gregor Mendel
the study of inheritance of biological traits passed on from generation to generation	genetics
genetics	the study of inheritance of biological traits passed on from generation to generation
Observation: within a species offspring tend to resemble the parents.&nbsp;<div>Initial theories (2) to why this was included:</div>	Blending and Particulate Inheritence
Theory:&nbsp;<div>gametes had hereditary determinants that blend together in the offspring</div>	Blending
Blending	Theory:&nbsp;<div>gametes had hereditary determinants that blend together in the offspring</div>
Blending is a theory in which gametes had <span class=cloze>[...]</span> that blend together in the offspring	Blending is a theory in which gametes had <span class=cloze>hereditary determinants</span> that blend together in the offspring<br> 
Theory:<div>Each determinant had a physiologically distinct nature.&nbsp;</div>	particulate inheritance
particulate inheritance	Theory:<div>Each determinant had a physiologically distinct nature.&nbsp;</div>
Mendel observed in his experiments with pea plants that&nbsp;some pea plants produced <span class=cloze>[...]</span> seeds​. While other pea plants have <span class=cloze>[...]</span> seeds	"Mendel observed in his experiments with pea plants that&nbsp;some pea plants produced <span class=cloze>smooth round</span> seeds​. While other pea plants have <span class=cloze>wrinkled round</span> seeds<br> <img src=""16162_pea4.jpg"" />"
Mendel's hypothesis:<div>If blending is correct then the seeds of the offspring should be a <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of patches of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> areas and <span class=cloze>[...]</span> areas​</div>	"Mendel's hypothesis:<div>If blending is correct then the seeds of the offspring should be a <span class=cloze>mix</span> of patches of <span class=cloze>smooth</span> areas and <span class=cloze>wrinkled</span> areas​</div><br> <img src=""Gregor-Mendel-examines-peas.jpg"" />"
Mendel's Results:<div>After cross polination, he observed the first generation and found that&nbsp;all the seeds are <span class=cloze>[...]</span>; <span class=cloze>[...]</span>.</div><div>He cross polinates the <b>F1</b>&nbsp;generation and found that <span class=cloze>[...]</span> seeds is wrinkled&nbsp;</div>	"Mendel's Results:<div>After cross polination, he observed the first generation and found that&nbsp;all the seeds are <span class=cloze>smooth</span>; <span class=cloze>no apparent &nbsp;blending​</span>.</div><div>He cross polinates the <b>F1</b>&nbsp;generation and found that <span class=cloze>1 of every 4</span> seeds is wrinkled&nbsp;</div><br> <img src=""mendel.png"" />"
Mendel's conclusion:<div>The hypothesis is <span class=cloze>[...]</span>. There is <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of characteristics and a recessive trait can <span class=cloze>[...]</span></div>	"Mendel's conclusion:<div>The hypothesis is <span class=cloze>rejected</span>. There is <span class=cloze>no irreversible blending</span> of characteristics and a recessive trait can <span class=cloze>reappear in succeeding generations</span></div><br> <img src=""mendel.png"" />"
"What Mendel observed between his pea plants was a <font color=""#0a00f6""><b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b>&nbsp;</font>in which the plants were <font color=""#0a00f6"">diploid</font>"	"What Mendel observed between his pea plants was a <font color=""#0a00f6""><b><span class=cloze>monohybrid cross</span></b>&nbsp;</font>in which the plants were <font color=""#0a00f6"">diploid</font><br> <img src=""peas.jpg"" />"
"What Mendel observed between his pea plants was a <font color=""#0a00f6""><b>monohybrid cross</b>&nbsp;</font>in which the plants were <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>"	"What Mendel observed between his pea plants was a <font color=""#0a00f6""><b>monohybrid cross</b>&nbsp;</font>in which the plants were <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>diploid</span></font><br> <img src=""peas.jpg"" />"
In a <b>monohybrid cross, </b>there should be a trait of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> origin and a trait of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> origin	In a <b>monohybrid cross, </b>there should be a trait of <span class=cloze>paternal</span> origin and a trait of <span class=cloze>maternal</span> origin<br> 
In a monohybrid cross, one trait is <span class=cloze>[...]</span> while the other is <span class=cloze>[...]</span>. In Mendel's pea plant experiment, smooth surface was <span class=cloze>[...]</span> while wrinkled surface was <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"In a monohybrid cross, one trait is <span class=cloze>dominant</span> while the other is <span class=cloze>recessive</span>. In Mendel's pea plant experiment, smooth surface was <span class=cloze>dominant</span> while wrinkled surface was <span class=cloze>recessive</span><br> <img src=""peas.jpg"" />"
Genotype is&nbsp;the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of an individual organism.	Genotype is&nbsp;the <span class=cloze>genetic constitution</span> of an individual organism.<br> Ss, SS, or ss
Phenotype is the set of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of an individual resulting from the interaction of its genotype with the environment.	Phenotype is the set of <span class=cloze>observable characteristics</span> of an individual resulting from the interaction of its genotype with the environment.<br> smooth, wrinkled
How were the genes for seed shape sorted?	by the <b>Law of Segregation</b>
Alternative versions of genes account for variations in inherited traits	alleles
"Alleles are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> of genes that account for <font color=""#0a00f6"">variations</font> in inherited traits"	"Alleles are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>&nbsp;alternative versions</span></font> of genes that account for <font color=""#0a00f6"">variations</font> in inherited traits<br> "
"Alleles are <font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;alternative versions</font> of genes that account for <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> in inherited traits"	"Alleles are <font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;alternative versions</font> of genes that account for <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>variations</span></font> in inherited traits<br> "
allele pairs separate during gamete formation, and randomly unite at fertilization.	The Law of Segregation
The Law of Segregation	allele pairs separate during gamete formation, and randomly unite at fertilization.
"The Law of Segregation:<div>• For each character, an organism inherits <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> of a gene, one from each parent .</div><div>•&nbsp;If two alleles at a locus differ, then one, the <b>dominant</b> allele<font color=""#0a00f6""> determine</font> the organism’s appearance; the other , the <b>recessive</b> allele, has <font color=""#0a00f6"">no noticeable</font> effect on the organism’s appearance. ​</div><div>​•&nbsp;The two alleles for a heritable character <font color=""#0a00f6"">segregate</font> during gamete formation and end up in <font color=""#0a00f6"">different</font> gametes​</div>"	"The Law of Segregation:<div>• For each character, an organism inherits <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>two copies</span></font> of a gene, one from each parent .</div><div>•&nbsp;If two alleles at a locus differ, then one, the <b>dominant</b> allele<font color=""#0a00f6""> determine</font> the organism’s appearance; the other , the <b>recessive</b> allele, has <font color=""#0a00f6"">no noticeable</font> effect on the organism’s appearance. ​</div><div>​•&nbsp;The two alleles for a heritable character <font color=""#0a00f6"">segregate</font> during gamete formation and end up in <font color=""#0a00f6"">different</font> gametes​</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 10.42.51 AM.png"" />"
"The Law of Segregation:<div>• For each character, an organism inherits <font color=""#0a00f6"">two copies</font> of a gene, one from each parent .</div><div>•&nbsp;If two alleles at a locus differ, then one, the <b>dominant</b> allele<font color=""#0a00f6""> <span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> the organism’s appearance; the other , the <b>recessive</b> allele, has <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> effect on the organism’s appearance. ​</div><div>​•&nbsp;The two alleles for a heritable character <font color=""#0a00f6"">segregate</font> during gamete formation and end up in <font color=""#0a00f6"">different</font> gametes​</div>"	"The Law of Segregation:<div>• For each character, an organism inherits <font color=""#0a00f6"">two copies</font> of a gene, one from each parent .</div><div>•&nbsp;If two alleles at a locus differ, then one, the <b>dominant</b> allele<font color=""#0a00f6""> <span class=cloze>determine</span></font> the organism’s appearance; the other , the <b>recessive</b> allele, has <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>no noticeable</span></font> effect on the organism’s appearance. ​</div><div>​•&nbsp;The two alleles for a heritable character <font color=""#0a00f6"">segregate</font> during gamete formation and end up in <font color=""#0a00f6"">different</font> gametes​</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 10.42.51 AM.png"" />"
"The Law of Segregation:<div>• For each character, an organism inherits <font color=""#0a00f6"">two copies</font> of a gene, one from each parent .</div><div>•&nbsp;If two alleles at a locus differ, then one, the <b>dominant</b> allele<font color=""#0a00f6""> determine</font> the organism’s appearance; the other , the <b>recessive</b> allele, has <font color=""#0a00f6"">no noticeable</font> effect on the organism’s appearance. ​</div><div>​•&nbsp;The two alleles for a heritable character <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> during gamete formation and end up in <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> gametes​</div>"	"The Law of Segregation:<div>• For each character, an organism inherits <font color=""#0a00f6"">two copies</font> of a gene, one from each parent .</div><div>•&nbsp;If two alleles at a locus differ, then one, the <b>dominant</b> allele<font color=""#0a00f6""> determine</font> the organism’s appearance; the other , the <b>recessive</b> allele, has <font color=""#0a00f6"">no noticeable</font> effect on the organism’s appearance. ​</div><div>​•&nbsp;The two alleles for a heritable character <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>segregate</span></font> during gamete formation and end up in <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>different</span></font> gametes​</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 10.42.51 AM.png"" />"
If the two alleles don't seperate as instructed in the Law of Segregation, this will result in a <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	If the two alleles don't seperate as instructed in the Law of Segregation, this will result in a <span class=cloze>nondisjunction mutation</span><br> 
"Mendel had to do a test cross to establish that he had a <b>homozygous dominant parent​</b>:<div><u>Hypothesis:</u> The <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span> </font>can reveal whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous. Cross it with <font color=""#0a00f6""><b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b>.</font></div><div><u>Results</u>: If SS x ss then all offspring show {<font color=""#0a00f6"">{c1::the dominant phenotype.}}</font></div><div>If Ss x ss<font color=""#0a00f6""> <span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> of the offspring will show <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></div>"	"Mendel had to do a test cross to establish that he had a <b>homozygous dominant parent​</b>:<div><u>Hypothesis:</u> The <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>progeny of a test cross</span> </font>can reveal whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous. Cross it with <font color=""#0a00f6""><b><span class=cloze>homozygous recessive</span></b>.</font></div><div><u>Results</u>: If SS x ss then all offspring show {<font color=""#0a00f6"">{c1::the dominant phenotype.}}</font></div><div>If Ss x ss<font color=""#0a00f6""> <span class=cloze>half</span></font> of the offspring will show <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>dominant phenotype.</span></font></div><br> <img src=""progency test.png"" />"
<span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;is a cross between two different lines (varieties, strains) that differ in two observed traits.&nbsp;<div>In the Mendelian sense, between the alleles of both these loci there is a relationship of complete dominance - recessive.</div>	<span class=cloze>Dihybrid Cross</span>&nbsp;is a cross between two different lines (varieties, strains) that differ in two observed traits.&nbsp;<div>In the Mendelian sense, between the alleles of both these loci there is a relationship of complete dominance - recessive.</div><br> 
How do you combine gametes for dihybrid cross?	First, outside, inside, last
when two or more characteristics are inherited, individual hereditary factors assort independently during gamete production, giving different traits an equal opportunity of occurring together	law of independent assortment&nbsp;
"<b>law of independent assortment </b>- when <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> characteristics are inherited, individual hereditary factors assort independently during gamete production, giving different traits an <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> opportunity of occurring together.<div>A</div><div><b>allows for <font color=""#0a00f6"">variability</font> in an offspring</b></div>"	"<b>law of independent assortment </b>- when <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>two or more</span></font> characteristics are inherited, individual hereditary factors assort independently during gamete production, giving different traits an <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>equal</span></font> opportunity of occurring together.<div>A</div><div><b>allows for <font color=""#0a00f6"">variability</font> in an offspring</b></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 10.59.35 AM.png"" />"
"<b>law of independent assortment </b>- when <font color=""#0a00f6"">two or more</font> characteristics are inherited, individual hereditary factors assort independently during gamete production, giving different traits an <font color=""#0a00f6"">equal</font> opportunity of occurring together.<div>A</div><div><b>allows for <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> in an offspring</b></div>"	"<b>law of independent assortment </b>- when <font color=""#0a00f6"">two or more</font> characteristics are inherited, individual hereditary factors assort independently during gamete production, giving different traits an <font color=""#0a00f6"">equal</font> opportunity of occurring together.<div>A</div><div><b>allows for <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>variability</span></font> in an offspring</b></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 10.59.35 AM.png"" />"
<div>Example of dihybrid cross:</div><b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b> traits in humans –&nbsp;<div>The ability for blood to clot quickly is a dominant​.&nbsp;The inability for blood to clot quickly is a recessive (Hemophilia)​.&nbsp;Consider the possibilities for females​. ​Consider the possibilities for males​.​&nbsp;Now look at Queen Victoria’s Grandchilden</div>	"<div>Example of dihybrid cross:</div><b><span class=cloze>Sex-linked</span></b> traits in humans –&nbsp;<div>The ability for blood to clot quickly is a dominant​.&nbsp;The inability for blood to clot quickly is a recessive (Hemophilia)​.&nbsp;Consider the possibilities for females​. ​Consider the possibilities for males​.​&nbsp;Now look at Queen Victoria’s Grandchilden</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 11.02.52 AM.png"" />"
Mendel's 2 Laws:<div>Law of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> &amp; Law of <span class=cloze>[...]</span></div><div>Both are based on principles of <span class=cloze>[...]</span></div>	Mendel's 2 Laws:<div>Law of <span class=cloze>Segregation</span> &amp; Law of <span class=cloze>Independent Assortment</span></div><div>Both are based on principles of <span class=cloze>meiosis</span></div><br> 
	<br> 
Example of cross:<div><div>A rooster with gray feathers and a hen of the same phenotype produce 15 gray, 6 black, and 8 white chicks. ​</div><div>​What is the simplest explanation for the inheritance of these colors in chickens? ​</div><div>​What phenotypes would you expect in the offspring of a cross between a gray rooster and a black hen?&nbsp;</div></div>	Example of blending... black pigment + white pigment = gray&nbsp;<div>Any organism that is gray is heterozygous.&nbsp;</div><div>Phenotypes of&nbsp;Bb + BB: All black</div>
Muscle below heart	diaphragm
The area that includes your lungs, heart and diaphragm	thorax
The two veins leading to the heart	Superior and Inferior Vena Cava
Main artery leaving heart	Aorta
Before blood leaves heart it goes through the ___ to gain oxygen	lungs&nbsp;
These blood vessels serve the heart muscle	coronary blood vessels
The heart is involved with two types of flow:	Systemic Flow, Pulmonary Flow
Flow of blood in the heart	RA-&gt;Tricuspid-&gt;RV-&gt;Pulmonary Valve-&gt;PA-&gt;Lungs-&gt;PV-&gt;LA-&gt;Mitrial Valve-&gt;LV-&gt;Aortic Valve-&gt;Aorta
Valve between RA and RV	Tricuspid
Valve between LA and LV	Mitrial Valve
Cords that keep valve from flipping backwards (flowing in wrong direction)	Chordae Tendinae
Muscles that attach the chordae tendinae to valves	Papillary Muscles
Wall between the RV and LV	Intreventricular Septum
The Atrium is (above/below) the ventricle	above
Interventricular Septum is composed of two parts:	Membraneous and Muscular
Defect when blood flows between the LV to RV	Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
Most internal layer of heart muscle	endocardium
Intermediate layer of heart muscle	Myocardium
This layer of heart muscle does most of the work	myocardium
Outermost layer of heart muscle	Pericardium
There is a gap in between the two layers of this layer of heart muscle	pericardium
Layer of the pericardium closer to heart	visceral pericardium
Outer layer of pericardium	partietal
The fetus heart starts pumping at week ___	6
Superior Vena Cava collects blood from ___	arms and head
Superior and Inferior Vena Cava flow into the	Right Atrium
This valve connects the RV to the R&amp;L Pulmonary Arteries	Pulmonary Valve
Pulmonary Circuit	RV-&gt;Pulmonary Valve-&gt;Pulmonary Trunk-&gt;PA-&gt;Lungs-&gt;PVeins-&gt;LA
Valve between LV and Aorta	Aortic Valve
Systemic Circuit	LV-&gt;Aortic Valve-&gt;Aorta-&gt;Body-&gt;Inferior and Superior VC-&gt;RA
Cells that carry oxygen to rest of the body	RBC
RBC's (Need Or Don't Need) Oxygen	DON'T!! (no mitochondria or nucleus)
The first organ to get blood flow from systemic circulation	Heart
These arteries bring oxygenated blood to lungs	bronchial arteries
As Mitrial and Tricuspid valves are open the ____ valves are closed	Pulmonary and Aortic
The first heart sound (S1) is the ___ valves snapping shut	Tricuspid &amp; Mitrial
The second heart sound (S2) is the ___ valves snapping shut	Pulmonary &amp; Aortic
The gap between S1 and S2 is called&nbsp;	systole
Between S1 and S2 which valves are open?	Pulmonary &amp; Aortic
Between S2 and the next S1 (i.e. ______)which valves are open?	diastole Tricuspid &amp; Mitrial
The gap between S2 and the next S1 is called	diastole
Diastole is longer than Systole (T/F)	True!!! T &amp; M are open for longer&nbsp;
Surface surrounding endothelial cells	basement membrane (basal lamina)
Basement Membrane + Endothelial Cells =	Tunica Intima
Three layers of blood vessels (starting from lumen)	Tunica Intima-&gt;Tunica Media-&gt;Tunica Externa
Tunica Media is composed of	smooth muscle
Little blood vessels in Tunica Externa	Vasa Vasorum
These blood vessels have a larger tunica media and an elastic protein (elastin) for high pressures	Large Arteries
These blood vessels have large tunica media with only muscle and no elastin	Small arteries/arterioles
These blood vessels have very small lumens and their walls are made of a single cell layer	capillaries
These blood vessels transport blood from arteries to veins	capillaries
Pulmonary Arteries carry (Oxygenated Or Deoxygenated) blood to the lungs	Deoxygenated
Arteries typically carry (Oxygenated or Deoxygenated) blood to the tissues	Oxygenated
The pressure in the arteries is typically (higher or lower) than the veins	Higher
65% of our blood is in our ____ at any point in time	veins
The blood vessel system that is low pressure and high volume	veins
This blood vessel system has no valves	arteries
The radius is (proportional OR inversely proportional) to resistance in flow through a tube	Inversely proprotional
When the smooth muscles of arterioles are relaxed we call this	vaso-dilation
During Vasodilation resistance to blood flow is (high OR low)	low
When the muslces surrounding the arterioles are constricted we call this&nbsp;	vaso-constriction
During Vaso-constriction, resistance to blood flow is (high OR low)	HIGH!!!!
A small branch of an artery leading to capillaries	arterioles
During (diastole or systole) the heart muscle relaxes as the chambers fill with blood	diastole
DeltaP=	Q*R
In the equation P=Q*R, Q is	blood flow (volume/ min)
R (Resistance) is proportional to&nbsp;	1/radius^4
Capillary Beds allow exchange of ___ between the blood and tissue	oxygen
When its hot out and our body wants to get rid of heat, our capillaries (dilate or constrict)	dilate (capillaries act as vents)
It was in the 19th and Early 20th Centuries that major observations were made to contribute to figuring out the origin of life.<div>Chemists figured out that <b>all life forms are <span class=cloze>[...]</span></b></div>	It was in the 19th and Early 20th Centuries that major observations were made to contribute to figuring out the origin of life.<div>Chemists figured out that <b>all life forms are <span class=cloze>carbon based</span></b></div><br>

<b>Archaeans</b> are prokaryotes that have plasma membrane and cytoplasm, but also special because they have large ribosomes (like in eukaryotes) and <span class=cloze>[...]</span> similar to eukaryotes	<b>Archaeans</b> are prokaryotes that have plasma membrane and cytoplasm, but also special because they have large ribosomes (like in eukaryotes) and <span class=cloze>structure of RNA Polymerase</span> similar to eukaryotes<br> 
Eukaryotes can be <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, and membrane-bound subcompartments	Eukaryotes can be <span class=cloze>uni and multicelluar</span>, and membrane-bound subcompartments<br> 
Eukaryotes can be uni and multicelluar, and <span class=cloze>[...]</span> subcompartments	Eukaryotes can be uni and multicelluar, and <span class=cloze>membrane-bound</span> subcompartments<br> 
Unicelluar eukaryotes are in Kingdom <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Unicelluar eukaryotes are in Kingdom <span class=cloze>Protista</span><br> 
Examples of organisms in Kingdom Protista: <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Examples of organisms in Kingdom Protista: <span class=cloze>Photosynthetic autotrophs and heterotrophs</span><br> 
Some organisms in Kingdom Protista can have a <span class=cloze>[...]</span> covering on their surface&nbsp;	Some organisms in Kingdom Protista can have a <span class=cloze>hard mineral</span> covering on their surface&nbsp;<br> 
Some organisms in Kingdom Protista&nbsp;can be <span class=cloze>[...]</span> - Trypanosom	Some organisms in Kingdom Protista&nbsp;can be <span class=cloze>nasty parasites</span> - Trypanosom<br> 
All organisms in Kingdom Protista are <span class=cloze>[...]</span>; but some join together to be <span class=cloze>[...]</span>. But can survive by itself so no true multicellular life forms	All organisms in Kingdom Protista are <span class=cloze>unicellular eukaryotes</span>; but some join together to be <span class=cloze>colonial life forms</span>. But can survive by itself so no true multicellular life forms<br> 
All organisms in Kingdom Protista are unicellular eukaryotes; but some join together to be colonial life forms. But can survive by itself so <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	All organisms in Kingdom Protista are unicellular eukaryotes; but some join together to be colonial life forms. But can survive by itself so <span class=cloze>no true multicellular life forms</span><br> 
All organisms in Kingdom Protista are&nbsp;no true multicellular life forms have&nbsp;highly <span class=cloze>[...]</span> development	All organisms in Kingdom Protista are&nbsp;no true multicellular life forms have&nbsp;highly <span class=cloze>sophisticated organelle</span> development<br> 
All organisms in Kingdom Protista are both <span class=cloze>[...]</span> trophs	All organisms in Kingdom Protista are both <span class=cloze>hetero- and auto-</span> trophs<br> 
Kingdom Protista first appeared in the age between <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"Kingdom Protista first appeared in the age between <span class=cloze>2 and 1 billion years ago</span><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 4.18.24 PM.png"" />"
Kingdom Fungi include organisms like&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Kingdom Fungi include organisms like&nbsp;<span class=cloze>Single-celled yeast or multicellular mushrooms</span><br> 
Kingdom Fungi are <span class=cloze>[...]</span>-<span class=cloze>[...]</span> <span class=cloze>[...]</span>;&nbsp;	Kingdom Fungi are <span class=cloze>non</span>-<span class=cloze>photosynthetic</span> <span class=cloze>heterotrophs</span>;&nbsp;<br> 
organisms in Kingdom Fungi have a <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, but the primary component is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;	organisms in Kingdom Fungi have a <span class=cloze>cell wall</span>, but the primary component is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>a protein/carbohydrate <b>chitin</b></span>&nbsp;<br> Chitin makes it be in the Kingdom Fungi!!!!
organisms in Kingdom Fungi&nbsp;play&nbsp;a vital role in the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of organic matter – <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b>	organisms in Kingdom Fungi&nbsp;play&nbsp;a vital role in the <span class=cloze>decomposition</span> of organic matter – <b><span class=cloze>saprophytes&nbsp;</span></b><br> 
"<b>Kingdom Animalia</b> are composed of <span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;<img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 4.30.53 PM.png"" />"	"<b>Kingdom Animalia</b> are composed of <span class=cloze>multi-cellular heterotrophs</span>&nbsp;<img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 4.30.53 PM.png"" /><br> "
<div>Kingdom Plantae are composed of <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, including (4): <span class=cloze>[...]</span></div>	"<div>Kingdom Plantae are composed of <span class=cloze>multi-cellular, photosynthetic autotrophs</span>, including (4): <span class=cloze>moss, fern, evergreens, and flowering plants</span></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-01-31 at 4.32.30 PM.png"" />"
Basic features of organisms in Kingdom Plantae include its <span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;	Basic features of organisms in Kingdom Plantae include its <span class=cloze>phylum</span>&nbsp;<br> 
The three layers of heart muscle (from inner to outer):	Endocardium-&gt;Myocardium-&gt;Epi(peri)cardium
Specialized epithelial cells that line blood vessels' lumens	endothelial
The non-reactivity of the immune system to self particles	tolerance
The proteins that pathogens make are called	antigens
moleculs used for cell signaling	cytokines
A type of cytokines released by infected cells to initiate an immune response	chemokines
Viruses, bacteria, parasites and fungi that the immune system responds to are called	pathogens
Physical Barriers, Defense Mechanisms and General Immune Responses make up the	Innate Immune System
Skin, GI tract, Resp. Tract are examples of this part of the Innate Immune System	Physical Barriers
Secretions, Mucuous, Bile, Gastric Acid are examples of what component of the Innate Immune System?	Defense Mechanisms
Inflammation and complement are examples of this part of the Innate Immune System	General Immune Responses
Non-Specific Part of Immune System	Innate Immune System
Part of the Innate Immune System, these cells envelop a pathogen	phagocytes
Phagocytes perform a version of endocytosis called	phagocytosis
a 'vesicle' or membrane inside the phagocyte that contains the pathogen is called a	phagosome
This protein attaches to the broken down pathogen's protein inside the phagocyte or B-Cell and brings it to the surface	Major Histocompatibility Complex II (MHC II)
Phagocytes and B-Cells are also called ____ because of the MHCII's actions	Antigen Presenting Cells
Three types of Phagocytes	Neutrophils, Macrophages, Dendritic Cells
Barriers, Inflammatory responses and phagocytes are all part of the&nbsp;	Innate Immune System
White blood cell name	leukocyte
Another name for the specific immune system	Adaptive Immune System
Phagocytes and Lymphocytes are both	White Blood Cells
Main cells in Adaptive Immune System	lymphocytes
These lymphocytes are produced in Bone Marrow	B-lympohcytes
These lymphocytes are produced in Thalamus	T-Lymphocytes
These cells of the adaptive immune system produce a humoral response (pathogens in fluid/humor, not inside cells)	B-cells
Membrane Bound Antibodies	Immunoglobulins
These cells have membrane bound antibodies	B-Lymphocytes
Antibody binds to this part of pathogen	epitope
When a B-Lymphocyte's antibody binds to a pathogen the cell does two things:	replicates &amp; presents MHC II complexes
B-cells replicate and differentiate into these two types of cells when they attach to an antigen:	memory cells &amp; effector cells
These activated B-cells are 'antibody factories'	Effector B Cells
the process whereby antibodies produced by effector B cells attach themselves to a pathogen and 'tag them' for phagocytes to 'eat them up'	opsonization
Tagged cells are 'eaten up' by ___	phagocytes
MHC II are found in both ___ and ___	phagocytes and B cells
T cells that kill other cells	cytoxic T cells
B and T cells are all what kind of cells?&nbsp;	lymphocytes
A subtype of WBC in the immune system	Lymphocyte
B-Cells main function	produce antibodies
While both phagocytes and B-cells endocytose antigens and produce MHCII complexes, Phagocytes are part of the ___ Immune System while B-Cells are part of the ___ Immune System	Innate (non-specific), Adaptive (specific)
Immune Cells that have never been activated are termed	'naive'
When a Helper T Cell is activated it replicates and produces these two types of Helper T cells	Effector and Memory T Cells
Helper T cells are activated when they attach to a ___ on a phagocyte	MHC II complex
Effector Helper-T cells release these proteins that 'raise the alarm':	cytokines
Cytokines tell these cells to 'get in gear' and divide more often	Cytoxic T Cells and activated B cells
T cell receptors are (specific OR general)?	Specific!!
B Cells have (Specific OR General) antibody receptors?	Specific
In order for a B cell to become activated a ____ cell must attach to the MHCII complex	Helper T Cell
Once the B cell attaches to an antigen and produces the MHCII complex it becomes activated (T/F)	FALSE!! Needs Helper T cell to attach to activate
Phagocytes have (Specific OR General) receptors	GENERAL
These lymphocytes produce a humoral (non-cell mediated) response	B cells
These lymphocytes produce a cell mediated response	T cells
These two adaptive-immune-system cell types are lymphocytes	B and T cells
The cell mediated response of the Adaptive Immune System involves these cells:	Helper T cells and Cytoxic T cells
Red blood cells have a spectrin web (True or False)	TRUE!
Red Blood Cells contain tubulin (T/F)	FFFF
All nucleated cells, including B cells, have a major histocompatibility complex called ___	MHC I
The only cells that don't have MHC I complexes (don't have a nucleus) are ___	RBC's
These cells bind to MHC I complexes	Cytoxic T-cells
Cytoxic T-cells are (General OR Specific) to the MHC I complexes they bind to	SPECIFIC
When cytoxic T-cells attach to a MHC I complex they replicate into these two types of cells:	Helper and Effector Cytoxic T Cells
When antibodies produced by B-cells attach to their specfic antigen they can either render them ineffective or 'tag' them for ____	phagocytosis
Effector B cells commonly called	Plasma Cells
In addition to membrane bound receptors Helper T cells also have ____ that bind to MHC II complexes	CD4
In addition to membrane bound receptors Cytoxic T cells also have ____ receptors that bind to MHC II complexes	CD8
When activated cytoxic T cells ____	kill bad cells
Helper T cells release ____ when activated	cytokines
The daughter cells of B and T cells will have antibodies that are identical to its parent (T/F)	False!!! They each develop UNIQUE antibodies
B &amp; T cells migrate to and 'wait' in the _____ for the antigen presenting dendritic cells	lymph nodes
Once B&amp;T cells are activated in the lymph nodes, they replicate and their daughter cells are (Identical or Different) than their parent cells	IDENTICALLL
The process: differentiation of lymphocytes-&gt; Activation-&gt; Non-differentiation of daughter cells, is called	clonal selection
each B &amp; T cell produces unique antibody/receptors through ____	genetic shuffling
B cells don't respond to 'self' proteins, because those that do respond to 'self' proteins are ___ during early stages of develpment in the Bone Marrow or Thymus&nbsp;	killed off
The necessity for activation of B cells by ____ is a defense mechanism against B-cells producing antibodies to 'self' proteins	Helper T cells
diseases where the immune system responds to 'self' as if it were 'non-self'	auto immune disease
This autoimmune disease results in the inability to activate muslce fibers&nbsp;	Myasthenia Gravis
a type of phagocyte that engulfs an antigen and alerts endothelial cells to alert the Neutrophils in the blood	Macrophage
These phagocytes circulate in the blood, enter the tissue and after they 'eat' pathogens they die and become pus	Neutrophils
Macrophages reach the B and T cells by circulating through the body in the blood (T/F)	FALSE! They can't pass through endothelial cells to get into the blood
Neutrophils can squeeze through endothelial cells to get to macrophages in tissue (T/F)	TRUE! COOL
Macrophages reach B&amp;T cells through passge in ___	Lymphatic Vessels
Macrophages both alert Neutrophils to come 'eat' antigens and travel to the ____ to present their antigen to B &amp; T cells	lymph nodes
upon being activated, T cells and antibodies from B cells leaving the lymph nodes = enter the bloodstream through the ___&nbsp;	thoracic duct
This Stem Cell in our bone marrow that can make all 10 types of blood cells	Multipotent Hematopoietic Stem Cells
The two lineages of the Pluriopotent Hematopoetic Stem Cell are	Myeloid &amp; Lymphoid
Lymphoid Cells can make these 3 types of cells	B, T, NK cells
This descendant of the Myeloid cell makes this cell that makes platelets	Megakaryocyte
Macrophages are descendent of ___ which are descendant of Myeloid Cells	Monocyte
Dendritic cells descend from both Lymphoid and Myeloid lines (T/F)	TRUE! They are weird!!!
Neutrophils present antigens on their surface (T/F)	False!! Mainly dendritic cells and macrophages
Are plants multicellular or unicelluar? prokaryotes or eukaryotes?	multicellular eukaryotes
Organisms in Kingdom Plantae are <b>aerobic</b>, meaning	they use the mitochondria and utilize oxygen to metabolize glucose
Are&nbsp;Organisms in Kingdom Plantae anaerobic or aerobic?	aerobic
Organisms in Kingdom Plantae&nbsp;use <span class=cloze>[...]</span> as their <b>primary organic metabolite</b> for aerobic metabolism&nbsp;	Organisms in Kingdom Plantae&nbsp;use <span class=cloze>Glucose</span> as their <b>primary organic metabolite</b> for aerobic metabolism&nbsp;<br> But there are some plants that can use amino acids for metabolism
"Organisms in Kingdom Plantae are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>, because they can make glucose from CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and H<sub>2</sub>O (<span class=cloze>[...]</span> sources)"	"Organisms in Kingdom Plantae are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>photosynthetic autotrophs</span></font>, because they can make glucose from CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and H<sub>2</sub>O (<span class=cloze>inorganic</span> sources)<br> "
Kindom Plantae makes their own <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Kindom Plantae makes their own <span class=cloze>glucose</span><br> 
"All cells of the&nbsp;organisms in <b>Kingdom Plantae</b> are surrounded by a <b>cell wall made up of the protein/carbohydrate complex,<font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>.</font></b><div>This is different to the cell wall surrounding <b>fungi</b>, made up of chitin</div>"	"All cells of the&nbsp;organisms in <b>Kingdom Plantae</b> are surrounded by a <b>cell wall made up of the protein/carbohydrate complex,<font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;<span class=cloze>cellulose</span>.</font></b><div>This is different to the cell wall surrounding <b>fungi</b>, made up of chitin</div><br> "
"All cells of the&nbsp;organisms in <b>Kingdom Plantae</b> are surrounded by a <b>cell wall made up of the protein/carbohydrate complex,<font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;cellulose.</font></b><div>This is different to the cell wall surrounding <b>fungi</b>, made up of <span class=cloze>[...]</span></div>"	"All cells of the&nbsp;organisms in <b>Kingdom Plantae</b> are surrounded by a <b>cell wall made up of the protein/carbohydrate complex,<font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;cellulose.</font></b><div>This is different to the cell wall surrounding <b>fungi</b>, made up of <span class=cloze>chitin</span></div><br> "
"Plant <b>cell walls</b> are like chain link fence... they are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span> but <span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>"	"Plant <b>cell walls</b> are like chain link fence... they are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>ridgid</span> but <span class=cloze>pourous</span></font><br> "
"There are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> and <font color=""#0a00f6"">terrestrial </font>plants... some spend in or under water (fresh/salt), but most are on the surface of planet"	"There are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>aquatic</span></font> and <font color=""#0a00f6"">terrestrial </font>plants... some spend in or under water (fresh/salt), but most are on the surface of planet<br> "
"There are <font color=""#0a00f6"">aquatic</font> and <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span> </font>plants... some spend in or under water (fresh/salt), but most are on the surface of planet"	"There are <font color=""#0a00f6"">aquatic</font> and <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>terrestrial</span> </font>plants... some spend in or under water (fresh/salt), but most are on the surface of planet<br> "
All plants are <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span>, </b>meaning once they germinate and become multicellular, they don't move around	All plants are <b><span class=cloze>sedentary</span>, </b>meaning once they germinate and become multicellular, they don't move around<br> 
All plants are <b>sedentary, </b>meaning once they germinate and become multicellular, they <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	All plants are <b>sedentary, </b>meaning once they germinate and become multicellular, they <span class=cloze>don't move around</span><br>

"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">plasma membrane</font></b>&nbsp;(below the cell wall) is a <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> protein complex that has the standard <font color=""#0a00f6"">asymetric</font> distribution of phospholipids:&nbsp;</div><div>Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">choline</font> predominately is on the extracellular side. Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">inositol</font> and Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">serine</font> are on the cytoplasmic side.</div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">plasma membrane</font></b>&nbsp;(below the cell wall) is a <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>phospholipid bilayer</span></font> protein complex that has the standard <font color=""#0a00f6"">asymetric</font> distribution of phospholipids:&nbsp;</div><div>Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">choline</font> predominately is on the extracellular side. Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">inositol</font> and Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">serine</font> are on the cytoplasmic side.</div><br> "
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">plasma membrane</font></b>&nbsp;(below the cell wall) is a <font color=""#0a00f6"">phospholipid bilayer</font> protein complex that has the standard <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> distribution of phospholipids:&nbsp;</div><div>Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> predominately is on the extracellular side. Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> and Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> are on the cytoplasmic side.</div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">plasma membrane</font></b>&nbsp;(below the cell wall) is a <font color=""#0a00f6"">phospholipid bilayer</font> protein complex that has the standard <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>asymetric</span></font> distribution of phospholipids:&nbsp;</div><div>Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>choline</span></font> predominately is on the extracellular side. Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>inositol</span></font> and Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>serine</span></font> are on the cytoplasmic side.</div><br> "
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b> is composed mainly of water and similar to the cytoplams of many other life forms. The <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> pathway is in the <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, to begin performing aerobic metabolism.</div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>cytoplasm</span></font></b> is composed mainly of water and similar to the cytoplams of many other life forms. The <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>glycolysis</span></font> pathway is in the <span class=cloze>cytoplasm</span>, to begin performing aerobic metabolism.</div><br> "
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b>&nbsp;are scattered throughout the cytoplasm to <font color=""#0a00f6"">translate mRNA</font> and/or <font color=""#0a00f6"">make polypeptide&nbsp;</font></div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>ribosomes</span></font></b>&nbsp;are scattered throughout the cytoplasm to <font color=""#0a00f6"">translate mRNA</font> and/or <font color=""#0a00f6"">make polypeptide&nbsp;</font></div><br> "
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">ribosomes</font></b>&nbsp;are scattered throughout the cytoplasm to <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> and/or <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;</font></div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">ribosomes</font></b>&nbsp;are scattered throughout the cytoplasm to <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>translate mRNA</span></font> and/or <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>make polypeptide</span>&nbsp;</font></div><br> "
What size are the ribosomes in the cytoplasm?	large
Plant cells with <b>large type of ribosomes</b>&nbsp;is the result of ... making it a <b>cousin</b> to animals.	endosymbiosis
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b>&nbsp;(below the cell wall) is a <font color=""#0a00f6"">phospholipid bilayer</font> protein complex that has the standard <font color=""#0a00f6"">asymetric</font> distribution of phospholipids:&nbsp;</div><div>Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">choline</font> predominately is on the extracellular side. Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">inositol</font> and Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">serine</font> are on the cytoplasmic side.</div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>plasma membrane</span></font></b>&nbsp;(below the cell wall) is a <font color=""#0a00f6"">phospholipid bilayer</font> protein complex that has the standard <font color=""#0a00f6"">asymetric</font> distribution of phospholipids:&nbsp;</div><div>Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">choline</font> predominately is on the extracellular side. Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">inositol</font> and Phosphotidyl<font color=""#0a00f6"">serine</font> are on the cytoplasmic side.</div><br> "
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">cell wall</font></b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>. It is not a barrier to the movement of&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>, all&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>, and some&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>. It IS a barrier to&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>&nbsp;to physically impede (i.e.&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>).</div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">cell wall</font></b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>ridgid but porous</span></font>. It is not a barrier to the movement of&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>gases</span></font>, all&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>small organic molecules</span></font>, and some&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>macromolecules</span></font>. It IS a barrier to&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>large organisms</span></font>&nbsp;to physically impede (i.e.&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>bacteria</span></font>).</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 6.33.23 PM.png"" />"
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">ridgid but porous</font>. It is not a barrier to the movement of&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">gases</font>, all&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">small organic molecules</font>, and some&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">macromolecules</font>. It IS a barrier to&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">large organisms</font>&nbsp;to physically impede (i.e.&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">bacteria</font>).</div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>cell wall</span></font></b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">ridgid but porous</font>. It is not a barrier to the movement of&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">gases</font>, all&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">small organic molecules</font>, and some&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">macromolecules</font>. It IS a barrier to&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">large organisms</font>&nbsp;to physically impede (i.e.&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">bacteria</font>).</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 6.33.23 PM.png"" />"
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The<font color=""#0a00f6""> <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b></font>&nbsp;has <font color=""#0a00f6"">double membrane complex</font> and contains the <font color=""#0a00f6"">genetic material/chromosomes</font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The<font color=""#0a00f6""> <b><span class=cloze>nucleus</span></b></font>&nbsp;has <font color=""#0a00f6"">double membrane complex</font> and contains the <font color=""#0a00f6"">genetic material/chromosomes</font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 6.33.23 PM.png"" />"
"In a typical plant cell:<div>The<font color=""#0a00f6""> <b>nucleus</b></font>&nbsp;has <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> and contains the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>The<font color=""#0a00f6""> <b>nucleus</b></font>&nbsp;has <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>double membrane complex</span></font> and contains the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>genetic material/chromosomes</span></font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 6.33.23 PM.png"" />"
"In a typical plant cell:<div>In the nuclues is the <b>nucleolus, </b>which is a site condensed with <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>In the nuclues is the <b>nucleolus, </b>which is a site condensed with <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>chromosomes transcribing rRNA</span></font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 6.33.23 PM.png"" />"
"In a typical plant cell:<div>In the nuclues is the <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span>, </b>which is a site condensed with <font color=""#0a00f6"">chromosomes transcribing rRNA</font></div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>In the nuclues is the <b><span class=cloze>nucleolus</span>, </b>which is a site condensed with <font color=""#0a00f6"">chromosomes transcribing rRNA</font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 6.33.23 PM.png"" />"

"In a typical plant cell:<div>Continuous with the <u><b>nuclear envelope</b></u>&nbsp;is the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;</font>(rough is closer) and can be divided into 2:</div><div><font color=""#0a00f6"">Rough</font> - has <font color=""#0a00f6"">ribosomes</font> and is the site of<font color=""#0a00f6""> protein synthesis</font></div><div><font color=""#0a00f6"">Smooth</font> - lacks <font color=""#0a00f6"">ribosomes</font> and is the site of <font color=""#0a00f6"">lipid synthesis</font></div>"	"In a typical plant cell:<div>Continuous with the <u><b>nuclear envelope</b></u>&nbsp;is the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze><b>endoplasmic reticulum</b>&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;</font>(rough is closer) and can be divided into 2:</div><div><font color=""#0a00f6"">Rough</font> - has <font color=""#0a00f6"">ribosomes</font> and is the site of<font color=""#0a00f6""> protein synthesis</font></div><div><font color=""#0a00f6"">Smooth</font> - lacks <font color=""#0a00f6"">ribosomes</font> and is the site of <font color=""#0a00f6"">lipid synthesis</font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 6.33.23 PM.png"" />"

Photosynthesis (process and balanced chemical equation)	The process where light energy is converted into chemical energy. In which carbon dioxide and water processed to become <b>glucose</b><div><br /></div><div>CO<sub>2</sub> + 6H<sub>2</sub>O ------&gt; C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub> + 6O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;<sup>Sunlight energy</sup></div>
The process where light energy is converted into chemical energy. In which carbon dioxide and water processed to become <b>glucose</b><div><br /></div><div>CO<sub>2</sub> + 6H<sub>2</sub>O ------&gt; C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub> + 6O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;<sup>Sunlight energy</sup></div>	Photosynthesis (process and balanced chemical equation)
Because photosynthesis is done in the <b>chloroplast</b>, <span class=cloze>[...]</span> is also released from here.&nbsp;	Because photosynthesis is done in the <b>chloroplast</b>, <span class=cloze>oxygen</span> is also released from here.&nbsp;<br> 
Why would a plant cell need a <b>lysosome</b>&nbsp;when there's really no need for the intake of macromolecules for intracellular digestion?	The mitochondria and chloroplast will tend to break down (will be replaced). When they do, they need to be completely broken down.&nbsp;<div>So, the lysosome takes non-functional organelles to break them down into their building blocks. This process is called <b>autophagy</b>.&nbsp;</div>
<b>autophagy</b>	The process that the<b> lysosome </b>performs, in which it takes non-functional organelles to <b>break them down into their building blocks</b>.&nbsp;

"Because of the <font color=""#0a00f6""><b>vacuole</b>'s size</font> (due to how much water is int it), it will exert <span class=cloze>[...]</span> onto the cytoplasm, which exerts pressure on <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, which is pushing onto the <span class=cloze>[...]</span>. This is called <b>""<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>"".</b>&nbsp;It is what gives the plant cell its 'puffed-out' shape"	"Because of the <font color=""#0a00f6""><b>vacuole</b>'s size</font> (due to how much water is int it), it will exert <span class=cloze>pressure</span> onto the cytoplasm, which exerts pressure on <span class=cloze>plasma membrane</span>, which is pushing onto the <span class=cloze>cell wall</span>. This is called <b>""<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>turgor pressure</span></font>"".</b>&nbsp;It is what gives the plant cell its 'puffed-out' shape<br> <img src=""cell_vacuole1.jpg"" /><img src=""35-1.jpg"" />"

This is called <b>""<font color=""#0a00f6"">turgor pressure</font>"".</b>&nbsp;It is what gives the plant cell its '<span class=cloze>[...]</span>"	"Because of the <font color=""#0a00f6""><b>vacuole</b>'s size</font> (due to how much water is int it), it will exert pressure onto the cytoplasm, which exerts pressure on plasma membrane, which is pushing onto the cell wall. "<div><b>Orientation of plant cells</b>: <span class=cloze>[...]</span></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 8.33.34 PM.png"" /><div>In between the cell walls, there is <font color=""#0a00f6"">fluid (extracelluar space).</font></div><div>The cell walls are connected to each other through <font color=""#0a00f6"">complexes</font> that act like ""<font color=""#0a00f6"">rivets</font>"", so the whole network comes together.&nbsp;</div><div><b>This is what gives plants its form</b>; through the <font color=""#0a00f6"">adjecent rivets that allow fluid to move around...</font></div>"	"<div><b>Orientation of plant cells</b>: <span class=cloze>connect to each other via the cell walls</span></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-04 at 8.33.34 PM.png"" /><div>In between the cell walls, there is <font color=""#0a00f6"">fluid (extracelluar space).</font></div><div>The cell walls are connected to each other through <font color=""#0a00f6"">complexes</font> that act like ""<font color=""#0a00f6"">rivets</font>"", so the whole network comes together.&nbsp;</div><div><b>This is what gives plants its form</b>; through the <font color=""#0a00f6"">adjecent rivets that allow fluid to move around...</font></div><br> "

Physiological challenges for plants:<div><br /></div><div>In order to <u>perform photosynthesis</u>&nbsp;plants need access to (3):</div><div><b>– <span class=cloze>[...]</span>: </b>Need to live in aquatic zones where this penetrates and on land they need to be exposed to for some amount of time.</div><div><b>–&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>:&nbsp;</b>For terrestrial organism, need to obtain this in the atmosphere or the soil. They can't move directly, so need networks to branch out (<b>roots)</b></div><div><b>–&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>:</b>&nbsp;not much of a problem, plenty in oceans and atmosphere.</div>	Physiological challenges for plants:<div><br /></div><div>In order to <u>perform photosynthesis</u>&nbsp;plants need access to (3):</div><div><b>– <span class=cloze>light</span>: </b>Need to live in aquatic zones where this penetrates and on land they need to be exposed to for some amount of time.</div><div><b>–&nbsp;<span class=cloze>H<sub>2</sub>O</span>:&nbsp;</b>For terrestrial organism, need to obtain this in the atmosphere or the soil. They can't move directly, so need networks to branch out (<b>roots)</b></div><div><b>–&nbsp;<span class=cloze>CO<sub>2</sub></span>:</b>&nbsp;not much of a problem, plenty in oceans and atmosphere.</div><br>

They can't move directly, so need networks to branch out (<b>roots)</b></div><div><b>–&nbsp;CO<sub>2</sub>:</b>&nbsp;not much of a problem, plenty in oceans and atmosphere.</div>	Physiological challenges for plants:<div><br /></div><div>In order to <u>perform photosynthesis</u>&nbsp;plants need access to (3):</div><div><b>– light: </b><span class=cloze>Need to live in aquatic zones where this penetrates and on land they need to be exposed to for some amount of time.</span></div><div><b>–&nbsp;H<sub>2</sub>O:&nbsp;</b>For terrestrial organism, need to obtain this in the atmosphere or the soil. They can't move directly, so need networks to branch out (<b>roots)</b></span></div><div><b>–&nbsp;CO<sub>2</sub>:</b>&nbsp;not much of a problem, plenty in oceans and atmosphere.</div><br> 
Physiological challenges for plants:<div><br /></div><div>In order to <u>perform photosynthesis</u>&nbsp;plants need access to (3):</div><div><b>– light: </b>Need to live in aquatic zones where this penetrates and on land they need to be exposed to for some amount of time.</div><div><b>–&nbsp;H<sub>2</sub>O:&nbsp;</b>For terrestrial organism, need to obtain this in the atmosphere or the soil. Mostly around the<b> equator</b> and south hemisphere where humidity was high.</div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 12.10.48 PM.png"" />"
"The <b>Alternation of Generations for Bryophytes</b>&nbsp;starts with a <b>multicellular bryophyte</b> (moss or hornwort) that are <span class=cloze>[...]</span>.&nbsp;<div>There are 2 specialized cell types in these:</div><div>– <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b>&nbsp;which is <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N </font>and develops a gamete that<font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;</font>is the<font color=""#0a00f6""> egg</font></div><div>– <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b>&nbsp;which is <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N&nbsp;</font>and develops a gamete that<font>&nbsp;</font>is the<font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;sperm</font></div><div>When sperm transfers to the egg when water transports it, it becomes a <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b>&nbsp;then&nbsp;<b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b>.&nbsp;</div>"	"The <b>Alternation of Generations for Bryophytes</b>&nbsp;starts with a <b>multicellular bryophyte</b> (moss or hornwort) that are <span class=cloze><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N gametophytes</font></span>.&nbsp;<div>There are 2 specialized cell types in these:</div><div>– <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>Archegonium</span></font></b>&nbsp;which is <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N </font>and develops a gamete that<font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;</font>is the<font color=""#0a00f6""> egg</font></div><div>– <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>Antheridium</span></font></b>&nbsp;which is <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N&nbsp;</font>and develops a gamete that<font>&nbsp;</font>is the<font color=""#0a00f6"">&nbsp;sperm</font></div><div>When sperm transfers to the egg when water transports it, it becomes a <b><span class=cloze>1N zygote</span></b>&nbsp;then&nbsp;<b><span class=cloze>fertilization begins</span></b>.&nbsp;</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 12.15.46 PM.png"" />"

<b>Bryophytes </b>are limited to where/how they can move on the surface of earth... so what <b>adaptations</b> must we consider for them to move from an aquatic to a terrestrial environment?	"They must be resistant to water lost... so comes in the <b>cuticle</b><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.40.41 PM.png"" />"
<b>cuticle</b>&nbsp;(not in bryophytes... only found in vascular plants)	"a waxy (heavy-duty lipid polymer) covering the surface of the organism.&nbsp;<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.40.41 PM.png"" /></div>"
"<div>Adaptations for Moving from an Aquatic to a Terrestrial Environment:</div><div>​</div><div>The <b>Cuticle</b> will <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> the <font color=""#0a00f6"">diffusion</font> of&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">H<sub>2</sub>0</font>&nbsp;into or out of the plant​.&nbsp;However, the Cuticle will also <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> the <font color=""#0a00f6"">diffusion</font> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">gases</font> such as CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>2​</sub></div><div>​</div><div>There is a need for an <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> on the <b>Cuticle</b> - solution: <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b></div><div>​</div>"	"<div>Adaptations for Moving from an Aquatic to a Terrestrial Environment:</div><div>​</div><div>The <b>Cuticle</b> will <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>block</span></font> the <font color=""#0a00f6"">diffusion</font> of&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">H<sub>2</sub>0</font>&nbsp;into or out of the plant​.&nbsp;However, the Cuticle will also <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>block</span></font> the <font color=""#0a00f6"">diffusion</font> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">gases</font> such as CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>2​</sub></div><div>​</div><div>There is a need for an <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>opening</span></font> on the <b>Cuticle</b> - solution: <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>Stomata</span></font></b></div><div>​</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.40.41 PM.png"" />"
"<div>Adaptations for Moving from an Aquatic to a Terrestrial Environment:</div><div>​</div><div>The <b>Cuticle</b> will <font color=""#0a00f6"">block</font> the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> of&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>&nbsp;into or out of the plant​.&nbsp;However, the Cuticle will also <font color=""#0a00f6"">block</font> the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> of <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> such as <span class=cloze>[...]</span></div><div>​</div><div>There is a need for an <font color=""#0a00f6"">opening</font> on the <b>Cuticle</b> - solution: <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">Stomata</font></b></div><div>​</div>"	"<div>Adaptations for Moving from an Aquatic to a Terrestrial Environment:</div><div>​</div><div>The <b>Cuticle</b> will <font color=""#0a00f6"">block</font> the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>diffusion</span></font> of&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>H<sub>2</sub>0</span></font>&nbsp;into or out of the plant​.&nbsp;However, the Cuticle will also <font color=""#0a00f6"">block</font> the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>diffusion</span></font> of <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>gases</span></font> such as <span class=cloze>CO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>2​</sub></span></div><div>​</div><div>There is a need for an <font color=""#0a00f6"">opening</font> on the <b>Cuticle</b> - solution: <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">Stomata</font></b></div><div>​</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.40.41 PM.png"" />"
small openings for gas exchange and water movement​ found in the surface of vascular plants cells	"<div><b>stomatas</b></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.40.41 PM.png"" />"
"<div><b>stomatas</b></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.40.41 PM.png"" />"	small openings for gas exchange and water movement​ found in the surface of vascular plants cells
<div>H<sub>2</sub>O can move in or out of the <b>Stomata</b> based on <span class=cloze>[...]</span> in the Plant interior​.&nbsp;</div><div><span class=cloze>[...]</span></div>	"<div>H<sub>2</sub>O can move in or out of the <b>Stomata</b> based on <span class=cloze>water content</span> in the Plant interior​.&nbsp;</div><div><span class=cloze>Higher concentration to lower concentration</span></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.48.40 PM.png"" />"
<div><div>CO<sub>2</sub> is drawn in through the <b>stomata</b> for <span class=cloze>[...]</span>.&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span></div></div>	"<div><div>CO<sub>2</sub> is drawn in through the <b>stomata</b> for <span class=cloze>Photosynthesis​</span>.&nbsp;<span class=cloze>High CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;content to Low CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;content</span></div></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.48.40 PM.png"" />"
O<sub>2</sub> tends to move <span class=cloze>[...]</span> through the <b>stomata</b> as a result of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> ​	O<sub>2</sub> tends to move <span class=cloze>out</span> through the <b>stomata</b> as a result of <span class=cloze>Photosynthesis</span> ​<br> 
<div><div>CO<sub>2</sub> is <span class=cloze>[...]</span> through the <b>stomata</b> for Photosynthesis​.&nbsp;High CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;content to Low CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;content</div></div>	"<div><div>CO<sub>2</sub> is <span class=cloze>drawn in</span> through the <b>stomata</b> for Photosynthesis​.&nbsp;High CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;content to Low CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;content</div></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.48.40 PM.png"" />"
<div>H<sub>2</sub>O can move <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of the <b>Stomata</b> based on water content in the Plant interior​.&nbsp;</div><div>Higher concentration to lower concentration</div>	"<div>H<sub>2</sub>O can move <span class=cloze>in or out</span> of the <b>Stomata</b> based on water content in the Plant interior​.&nbsp;</div><div>Higher concentration to lower concentration</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.48.40 PM.png"" />"

"<div>Adaptations for Moving from an Aquatic to a Terrestrial Environment: ​</div><div><br /></div><div>If Terrestrial plants want better exposure the Sun, the organisms need to grow <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span>.</font></div><div>​However, as they increase in size they will need a mechanism more efficient than <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> to<font color=""#0a00f6""> <span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>​</div><div>​</div><div>Solution:<font color=""#0a00f6""> <span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></div>"	"<div>Adaptations for Moving from an Aquatic to a Terrestrial Environment: ​</div><div><br /></div><div>If Terrestrial plants want better exposure the Sun, the organisms need to grow <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>vertically​</span>.</font></div><div>​However, as they increase in size they will need a mechanism more efficient than <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>diffusion between cells</span></font> to<font color=""#0a00f6""> <span class=cloze>transport water</span></font>​</div><div>​</div><div>Solution:<font color=""#0a00f6""> <span class=cloze>Xylem and Phloem​</span></font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.40.41 PM.png"" />"
xylem	"series of tubes/vessels within vascular plants that carries water and minerals <b>one-way only</b><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.01.17 PM.png"" />"
"series of tubes/vessels within vascular plants that carries water and minerals <b>one-way only</b><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.01.17 PM.png"" />"	xylem
phloem	"a series of tubes/vessels in vascular plants that carry water <b>and glucose</b>&nbsp;(<font color=""#0a00f6"">food produced at the leaves to transport throughout cells</font>) and have a <b>two-way flow</b><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.01.17 PM.png"" /></div>"
"a series of tubes/vessels in vascular plants that carry water <b>and glucose</b>&nbsp;(<font color=""#0a00f6"">food produced at the leaves to transport throughout cells</font>) and have a <b>two-way flow</b><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.01.17 PM.png"" /></div>"	phloem
The <b>xylem</b> don't have <span class=cloze>[...]</span> between the cells. Their walls are <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"The <b>xylem</b> don't have <span class=cloze>end walls</span> between the cells. Their walls are <span class=cloze>stiffened with lignin</span><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.01.17 PM.png"" />"
The&nbsp;<b>phloem</b>&nbsp;have <span class=cloze>[...]</span> between the cells.	"The&nbsp;<b>phloem</b>&nbsp;have <span class=cloze>end walls with perforations</span> between the cells.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.01.17 PM.png"" />"
Xylem and Phloem cells have <span class=cloze>[...]</span> that allows the cell its <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"Xylem and Phloem cells have <span class=cloze>ridgid structures</span> that allows the cell its <span class=cloze>structure to grow vertically</span><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 1.40.41 PM.png"" />"
Xylem and Phloem are made up of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> that are <span class=cloze>[...]</span> to form a tubular vessel.	"Xylem and Phloem are made up of <span class=cloze>individual cells</span> that are <span class=cloze>linked head to tail</span> to form a tubular vessel.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.07.16 PM.png"" />"

"<div>Adaptations for Moving from an Aquatic to a Terrestrial Environment: ​</div><div>​</div><div>Must have strategies for <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">gametes and spores​</font></div><div>​</div><div>Look at <span class=cloze>[...]</span> – <font color=""#0a00f6"">Seedless Vascular Plants​</font></div>"	"<div>Adaptations for Moving from an Aquatic to a Terrestrial Environment: ​</div><div>​</div><div>Must have strategies for <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>dispersal</span></font> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">gametes and spores​</font></div><div>​</div><div>Look at <span class=cloze>Ferns</span> – <font color=""#0a00f6"">Seedless Vascular Plants​</font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.14.45 PM.png"" />"

<b>Ferns</b> (aka seedless vascular plants) first appeared &nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> years ago. The world had&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> (looked like). The dominant plant type were ferns	"<b>Ferns</b> (aka seedless vascular plants) first appeared &nbsp;<span class=cloze>300 million</span> years ago. The world had&nbsp;<span class=cloze>continental land masses</span> (looked like). The dominant plant type were ferns<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.15.56 PM.png"" /><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.17.07 PM.png"" /><div>Carboniforious forest = carbon beds for fuel</div>"

"<b>Fern Life Cycle:</b><div>Begins with a mature multicellular&nbsp;<b><span class=cloze>[...]</span>.</b>&nbsp;It has '<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>' structures whose underside has <font color=""#633511"">brown spots</font>, which are chambers called the <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Inside the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> are <font color=""#0a00f6"">precursor</font> cells that are undergoing <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">meiosis</font></b> to make thousands of&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">spores</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>These <font color=""#0a00f6"">spores</font> are <u>spread out</u> by the <font color=""#0a00f6"">wind</font> or just <font color=""#0a00f6"">drops down at the base of the original sporophyte</font>.&nbsp;Once it settles down it'll undergo <font color=""#0a00f6"">mitosis</font> and <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinates</font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinate spores</font> becomes a multicellular '<font color=""#0a00f6"">heart-shaped</font>' structure which is the&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N gametophyte</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The gametophyte cells makes the archegonium (yield 1N egg) and antheridum (yield 1N sperm).&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fertilization</font></b> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">sperm to egg</font> is <b>still <font color=""#0a00f6"">water</font> dependent</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div><b>Fertilization</b> produces a&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><b>2N</b>&nbsp;<b>embryo</b></font>&nbsp;that <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">emerges</font> from the&nbsp;</b>1N <b>gametophyte</b>&nbsp;to become another&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">2N&nbsp;</font></b><b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporophyte</font></b>.</div>"	"<b>Fern Life Cycle:</b><div>Begins with a mature multicellular&nbsp;<b><span class=cloze>2N sporophyte</span>.</b>&nbsp;It has '<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>leaf-like</span></font>' structures whose underside has <font color=""#633511"">brown spots</font>, which are chambers called the <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>sporangia</span></font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Inside the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>sporangia</span></font> are <font color=""#0a00f6"">precursor</font> cells that are undergoing <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">meiosis</font></b> to make thousands of&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">spores</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>These <font color=""#0a00f6"">spores</font> are <u>spread out</u> by the <font color=""#0a00f6"">wind</font> or just <font color=""#0a00f6"">drops down at the base of the original sporophyte</font>.&nbsp;Once it settles down it'll undergo <font color=""#0a00f6"">mitosis</font> and <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinates</font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinate spores</font> becomes a multicellular '<font color=""#0a00f6"">heart-shaped</font>' structure which is the&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N gametophyte</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The gametophyte cells makes the archegonium (yield 1N egg) and antheridum (yield 1N sperm).&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fertilization</font></b> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">sperm to egg</font> is <b>still <font color=""#0a00f6"">water</font> dependent</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div><b>Fertilization</b> produces a&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><b>2N</b>&nbsp;<b>embryo</b></font>&nbsp;that <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">emerges</font> from the&nbsp;</b>1N <b>gametophyte</b>&nbsp;to become another&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">2N&nbsp;</font></b><b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporophyte</font></b>.</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.18.12 PM.png"" />"
"<b>Fern Life Cycle:</b><div>Begins with a mature multicellular&nbsp;<b>2N sporophyte.</b>&nbsp;It has '<font color=""#0a00f6"">leaf-like</font>' structures whose underside has <font color=""#633511"">brown spots</font>, which are chambers called the <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporangia</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Inside the <font color=""#0a00f6"">sporangia</font> are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> cells that are undergoing <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b> to make thousands of&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>These <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> are <u>spread out</u> by the <font color=""#0a00f6"">wind</font> or just <font color=""#0a00f6"">drops down at the base of the original sporophyte</font>.&nbsp;Once it settles down it'll undergo <font color=""#0a00f6"">mitosis</font> and <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinates</font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinate spores</font> becomes a multicellular '<font color=""#0a00f6"">heart-shaped</font>' structure which is the&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N gametophyte</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The gametophyte cells makes the archegonium (yield 1N egg) and antheridum (yield 1N sperm).&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fertilization</font></b> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">sperm to egg</font> is <b>still <font color=""#0a00f6"">water</font> dependent</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div><b>Fertilization</b> produces a&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><b>2N</b>&nbsp;<b>embryo</b></font>&nbsp;that <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">emerges</font> from the&nbsp;</b>1N <b>gametophyte</b>&nbsp;to become another&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">2N&nbsp;</font></b><b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporophyte</font></b>.</div>"	"<b>Fern Life Cycle:</b><div>Begins with a mature multicellular&nbsp;<b>2N sporophyte.</b>&nbsp;It has '<font color=""#0a00f6"">leaf-like</font>' structures whose underside has <font color=""#633511"">brown spots</font>, which are chambers called the <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporangia</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Inside the <font color=""#0a00f6"">sporangia</font> are <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>precursor</span></font> cells that are undergoing <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>meiosis</span></font></b> to make thousands of&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>spores</span></font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>These <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>spores</span></font> are <u>spread out</u> by the <font color=""#0a00f6"">wind</font> or just <font color=""#0a00f6"">drops down at the base of the original sporophyte</font>.&nbsp;Once it settles down it'll undergo <font color=""#0a00f6"">mitosis</font> and <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinates</font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinate spores</font> becomes a multicellular '<font color=""#0a00f6"">heart-shaped</font>' structure which is the&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N gametophyte</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The gametophyte cells makes the archegonium (yield 1N egg) and antheridum (yield 1N sperm).&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fertilization</font></b> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">sperm to egg</font> is <b>still <font color=""#0a00f6"">water</font> dependent</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div><b>Fertilization</b> produces a&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><b>2N</b>&nbsp;<b>embryo</b></font>&nbsp;that <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">emerges</font> from the&nbsp;</b>1N <b>gametophyte</b>&nbsp;to become another&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">2N&nbsp;</font></b><b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporophyte</font></b>.</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.18.12 PM.png"" />"
"<b>Fern Life Cycle:</b><div>Begins with a mature multicellular&nbsp;<b>2N sporophyte.</b>&nbsp;It has '<font color=""#0a00f6"">leaf-like</font>' structures whose underside has <font becomes a multicellular '<font color=""#0a00f6"">heart-shaped</font>' structure which is the&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N gametophyte</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The gametophyte
