"<b>Fern Life Cycle:</b><div>Begins with a mature multicellular&nbsp;<b>2N sporophyte.</b>&nbsp;It has '<font color=""#0a00f6"">leaf-like</font>' structures whose underside has <font color=""#633511"">brown spots</font>, which are chambers called the <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporangia</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Inside the <font color=""#0a00f6"">sporangia</font> are <font color=""#0a00f6"">precursor</font> cells that are undergoing <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">meiosis</font></b> to make thousands of&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">spores</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>These <font color=""#0a00f6"">spores</font> are <u>spread out</u> by the <font color=""#0a00f6"">wind</font> or just <font color=""#0a00f6"">drops down at the base of the original sporophyte</font>.&nbsp;Once it settles down it'll undergo <font color=""#0a00f6"">mitosis</font> and <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinates</font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinate spores</font> becomes a multicellular '<font color=""#0a00f6"">heart-shaped</font>' structure which is the&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N gametophyte</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The gametophyte cells makes the archegonium (yield 1N egg) and antheridum (yield 1N sperm).&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fertilization</font></b> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">sperm to egg</font> is <b>still <font color=""#0a00f6"">water</font> dependent</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div><b>Fertilization</b> produces a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;that <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> from the&nbsp;</b><span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;to become another&nbsp;<b><span class=cloze>[...]</span>.</div>"	"<b>Fern Life Cycle:</b><div>Begins with a mature multicellular&nbsp;<b>2N sporophyte.</b>&nbsp;It has '<font color=""#0a00f6"">leaf-like</font>' structures whose underside has <font color=""#633511"">brown spots</font>, which are chambers called the <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporangia</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Inside the <font color=""#0a00f6"">sporangia</font> are <font color=""#0a00f6"">precursor</font> cells that are undergoing <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">meiosis</font></b> to make thousands of&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">spores</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>These <font color=""#0a00f6"">spores</font> are <u>spread out</u> by the <font color=""#0a00f6"">wind</font> or just <font color=""#0a00f6"">drops down at the base of the original sporophyte</font>.&nbsp;Once it settles down it'll undergo <font color=""#0a00f6"">mitosis</font> and <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinates</font>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <font color=""#0a00f6"">germinate spores</font> becomes a multicellular '<font color=""#0a00f6"">heart-shaped</font>' structure which is the&nbsp;<b><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N gametophyte</font></b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The gametophyte cells makes the archegonium (yield 1N egg) and antheridum (yield 1N sperm).&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fertilization</font></b> of <font color=""#0a00f6"">sperm to egg</font> is <b>still <font color=""#0a00f6"">water</font> dependent</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div><b>Fertilization</b> produces a&nbsp;<span class=cloze><font color=""#0a00f6""><b>2N</b>&nbsp;<b>embryo</b></font></span>&nbsp;that <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>emerges</span></font> from the&nbsp;</b><span class=cloze>1N <b>gametophyte</b></span>&nbsp;to become another&nbsp;<b><span class=cloze><font color=""#0a00f6"">2N&nbsp;</font></b><b><font color=""#0a00f6"">sporophyte</font></b></span>.</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-05 at 2.18.12 PM.png"" />"
In ferns:<div>The <span class=cloze>[...]</span> is the dominant multicellular life form in the fern’s alternation of generations.&nbsp;The <span class=cloze>[...]</span> is multicellular, but is much smaller than the <span class=cloze>[...]</span></div><div><br /></div><div>Compared to bryophytes (whoe &nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> were dominant.</div>	In ferns:<div>The <span class=cloze>Sporophyte</span> is the dominant multicellular life form in the fern’s alternation of generations.&nbsp;The <span class=cloze>Gametophyte</span> is multicellular, but is much smaller than the <span class=cloze>Sporophyte</span></div><div><br /></div><div>Compared to bryophytes (whoe &nbsp;<span class=cloze>gametophytes</span> were dominant.</div><br>

In ferns:&nbsp;Dispersal of Spores is via <span class=cloze>[...]</span> or <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	In ferns:&nbsp;Dispersal of Spores is via <span class=cloze>wind</span> or <span class=cloze>water​</span><br> 
In ferns:&nbsp;Dispersal of Gametes must occur in a <span class=cloze>[...]</span> (<span class=cloze>[...]</span> on the surface of the Gametophyte)&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>Similar to bryophytes</div>	In ferns:&nbsp;Dispersal of Gametes must occur in a <span class=cloze>water environment</span> (<span class=cloze>moisture</span> on the surface of the Gametophyte)&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>Similar to bryophytes</div><br> 
Filtrate that gets forced through spaces in the endothelial cells of capillary beds	lymph
As blood travels through capillaries the concentration of solutes in capillaries (increases or decreases)	Increases (lymph diffuses out)
Osmotic pressure (increases OR decreases) as blood travels through capillaries	Increases (less lymph)
Hydrostatic Pressure is (greater or lower) in latter part of capillaries	Lower
Lymphatic vessels dump their content back into blood circulation (T/F)	TRUE.&nbsp;
The location where lymph enters back into circulation	End of venous (vein) circulation. LOW PRESSURE
Lymph drains into (Low OR High) pressure portion of circulatory stystem	LOWWW
Lymphs have ___ to prevent backward flow	valves
Lymph vessels has smooth muscle to help direct forward flow (T/F)	True&nbsp;
Lymph vessels pick up materials at the ___	capillary beds
lymph re-enters at the ____ veins	subclavian
Lymph vessels take advantage of ___ muscle to move the lymph around the body	skeletal&nbsp;
Fluids in the lymph vessels are filtered in the ____ before entering back into the bloodstream	lymph nodes
Chylomicrons enter the (bloodstream OR lymphatic system)&nbsp;	Lymphatic!!- too big to enter capillaries
Chylomicrons are synthesized in the epithelial cells in our ___	small intestine
The lymphatic vessels of our small intestine are called ___	lacteals
Chylomicrons enter these lymphatic vessels	lacteals
Molecules that cannot diffuse directly into capillaries, enter ____ to then enter the bloodstream	lymphatic circulation
Lymphatic Vessels collect fluid forced out of the capillaries due to the high pressure in the arteries, and bring it back to bloodstream (T/F)	TTTTTTTT
The lymph has more proteins than blood &nbsp;(T/F)	False!!!!
As blood travels through the capillary the hydrostatic pressure (inc or dec) and the osmotic pressure (inc or dec)	Decreases, Increases
The measure of the tendency of a solution to take water in by osmosis	Osmotic Pressure
How much lymph do we make per day?	3 Liters!! (20 comes out of blood and 17 reenters through osmotic pressure)
Lymph has how much protein compared to blood?	1/2 - 1/3
Lymph has a greater ratio of smaller:larger proteins than blood (T/F)	TRUE, higher ratio of small!
The waste products in our blood are filtered by our kidneys and removed as&nbsp;	urine
smallest functional unit of kidney	nephron
Two main jobs of kidney:	Filtration (urine) and Collection (Reabsportion of Nutrietnts)
Outside portion of kidney	Renal Cortex
Internal part of kidney	Renal Medulla
Urine is first present in the&nbsp;	renal calyx
Renal calyces meet at the renal ___	pelvis
The renal artery, vein and ureter all emerge from this location:	hilum
Afferent arterioles lead to this (first) section of the nephron	glomerulus
Portion of the arteriole leaving the glomerulus	efferent arteriole
Glomerulus collects filtrate from blood and leaks the filtrate into the&nbsp;	Bowman's Capsule
Types of tubular cells emerging from Bowmans Capsule that hug the arterioles of the Bowmans Capsule	Podocytes
Path from Glomerulus to Bowmans Capsule	Diffusion through: Endothelial cells-&gt;Basal Lamina-&gt;Epithelial cells (tubular/podocytes)&nbsp;
Increases in the diameter of the afferent arteriole will (inc OR dec) the filtration rate?	Increase
Decreasing the diamter of the efferent arteriole will (inc OR dec) filtration rate&nbsp;	Increase!! can't leave!!! o no.
The nephron dips in and out of the renal medulla from the cortex (T/F)	True!
These types of molecules are filtered by the glomerulus	Ions, glucose, amino acids, SMALL MOLECULES
From Bowman's capsule the filtrate enters the&nbsp;	Proximal Convoluted Tubule
After the&nbsp;Proximal Convoluted Tubule, the filtrate enters the ____	Loop of Henle
Salts are pumped out of the ascending Loop of Henle into the:	renal medulla
What gets reabsorbed in the descending Loop of Henle	Water!
From the ascending Loop of Henle the filtrate enters the	Distal Convoluted Tubule
The Distal Convoluted Tubule exits into the ____ once all the reabsportion has taken place and only waste is left	collecting ducts
The collecting ducts travel through the _____, which is 'super salty	renal medulla
This hormone determines how porous the collecting ducts are as they pass through the medulla	ADH
If ADH makes the collecting ducts very porous more water will (Enter OR Exit) the collecting ducts into the medulla, making the urine more concentrated	EXIT. SUPER CONC URIne
Capillaries surrounding Convoluted Tubules that bring the reabsorbed nutrients back into the bloodstream	Peritubular Capillaries
Na/K pumps are on the ____ side of cells	basolateral&nbsp;
Sodium is transported into epithelial cells in the kidney through via (this protein) and (this kind of transport)	SGLT, Secondary Active Transport
This portion of the nephron reabsorbs 65% of the nutriets (Salts, Glucose, H2O) from the filtrate	Proximal Convoluted Tubule
The descending limb of the Loop of Henle is impermeable to ___ and&nbsp;ascending limb is impermeable to ___	ions, water
The processes governing the passive reabsorption of water in the descending limb of the Loop of Henle via Active Transport in the ascending limb	Countercurrent Multiplication
Part of nephron that controls blood pressure	Juxtaglomerular apparatus
This waste component is reabsorbed by the medulla to drive water reabsorption in the loop of Henle through osmolarity	urea (urea recycling
Peeing	Micturition
Path of urine starting from collecting ducts	collecting ducts-&gt; renal callyses -&gt; Renal pelvis -&gt; ureter -&gt; bladder-&gt; urethra
The ureters have ___ that prevent backflow	valves
This cell layer allows our bladder to expand	transitional epithelium
Bladder leads to&nbsp;	Urethra
Muslce below bladder that ensures bladder doesn't leak out urine	Internal Urethral Sphincter
Females have the _____ below the Internal Urethral Sphicter, that then leads to outside	External Urethra Sphincter
Men have the ___ region after the Internal Urethra Sphincter	Prosthetic Urethra
The three sections of the male urethra (in order from bladder)	Prosthetic-&gt;Membraneous-&gt; Spongy (in penis)
The membraneous region of the urethra contains this skeletal muslce in both men and women	External Urethra Sphincter
Females have only the Membraneous Region of the Urethra which makes their urethra much shorter than mens (T/F)	TRUEEE
Females have a greater chance for urinary tract infections due to their smaller urethra (T/F)	TRUEEE
This hormone induces aquaporin channels to enter the membrane of the collecting duct cells, promoting H20 reabsportion	ADH
Erythrocytes:	RBCs
Leukocytes:	WBCs
RAAS stands for:	Renin Angiotensin Aldosterone System
These cells release the renin hormone	Juxta Glomerular cells
The three triggers of renin release:	1) low bp 2) sympathetics 3) low Na+ in distal tubule
endothelial cells throughout the body convert Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II via THIS enzyme	Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE)
Aldosterone acts on kidney cells by increasing ___ reabsportion which leads to an increase in stroke volume	Na+
Angiotensin II works on these two glands:&nbsp;	Posterior Pituitary and Adrenal Gland
Angiotensin II targets 4 cell types:	Posterior Pituitary, Adrenal Gland, Kidney, Smooth Muscle
Juxta glomerular cells are outside the endothelial cells of the ____ of the kidney	affterent arteriole
Renin is a protein (t/f)	Ttttttttt
ADH increases ___ reabsportion whereas aldosterone increases ___ reabsportion in the kidneys&nbsp;	H2O, Na+
Where the nephron is water permeable ___ reabsorption leads to water reabsportion through osmosis	Na+
Where the nephron is impermeable to water ___ acts to create channels	ADH
Angiotensin II stimulates the cells in the adrenal cortex to convert cholestorol into ___	Aldosterone
High concentration of ____ stimulates cholestorol to be converted into aldosterone and be entered into the bloodstream	K+
The cells surrounding the collecting ducts are called:	Principal cells
Aldosterone's effect on the urine is an (inc OR dec) of K+ AND an (inc or dec) of Na+	Inc, dec
Increasing Na+ in blood, increases ____ concentration in the blood	H2O
Increased Water reabsorption leads to increased ___ which leads to increased bp	Stroke Volume
These cells of the collecting duct system &nbsp;help remove acid from the blood by sending HCO3- into the blood to bond with an H+	Alpha Intercalated Cells
HCO3- is converted into ___ in the blood when it bonds with an H+	CO2 and H2O
The H+ that is created with HCO3- from CO2 in the principal cells is transported into the URINE via Primary and Secondary Active Transports (T/F)	TRUEEE, (and there are even two types of Primary Active Transport!!!)
Aldosterone works to boost the transport of H+ out of the intercalated cell via these two transporters	Primary H+ &amp; Secondary H+/Na+
Another name for ADH	vasopressin
ADH is made in the ___ and secreted by the ___	hypothalamus, Posterior Pituitary
varo (Pressure) receptors collect information from this part of the cirulatory system	arteries
Volume receptors collect information from this part of the cirulatory system	Veins
The 4 triggers for ADH release:	1)High Osmolarity (Blood Concentration/ High Saltiness) 2) Low Blood Volume 3) Low Blood Pressure 4) Angiotensin II
ADH's two organ targets to raise bloop presssure:	Smooth Muscle (vaso-constriction), Kidneys (increase Stroke Volume)
As urine travels down collecting ducts, Osmolarity (inc OR dec)	INCC!!! MORE SALTY
ADH stimulates insertion of ___ into the collecting duct cell membranes, allowing H2O to enter the bloodstream	aquaporins
The ability of an extracellular solution to make water move into or out of a cell by osmosis	tonicity
On a basic level, &nbsp;Aldosterone increases H2O in blood by&nbsp;	increasing Na+ in blood

First place bile hits the GI tract:	duodenum
Pancreas sits in the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> (back of abdomen)	Pancreas sits in the <span class=cloze>retroperitoneum</span> (back of abdomen)<br>

Exocrine pancreas releases HCO3 to neutralize <span class=cloze>[...]</span> from stomach	Exocrine pancreas releases HCO3 to neutralize <span class=cloze>gastric acid/ HCl</span> from stomach<br> 
Endocrine Pancreas has islet cells that sit on <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Endocrine Pancreas has islet cells that sit on <span class=cloze>islands</span><br> 
Endocrine Pancreas has <span class=cloze>[...]</span> cells that sit on islands	Endocrine Pancreas has <span class=cloze>islet</span> cells that sit on islands<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> islet cells release glucagon which break down glycogen into glucose	<span class=cloze>Alpha</span> islet cells release glucagon which break down glycogen into glucose<br> 
Alpha islet cells release <span class=cloze>[...]</span> which break down glycogen into glucose	Alpha islet cells release <span class=cloze>glucagon</span> which break down glycogen into glucose<br>

Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> diabetes miletus is due to a problem with insulin production	Type <span class=cloze>I</span> diabetes miletus is due to a problem with insulin production<br> 
Type I diabetes miletus is due to a problem with insulin <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Type I diabetes miletus is due to a problem with insulin <span class=cloze>production</span><br> 
Type <span class=cloze>[...]</span> diabetes Miletus is a problem with insulin receptors	Type <span class=cloze>II</span> diabetes Miletus is a problem with insulin receptors<br> 
Type II diabetes Miletus is a problem with insulin <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Type II diabetes Miletus is a problem with insulin <span class=cloze>receptors</span><br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> Islet cells release somatostatin whose job it is to stop other hormones&nbsp;	<span class=cloze>Delta</span> Islet cells release somatostatin whose job it is to stop other hormones&nbsp;<br> 
Delta Islet cells release <span class=cloze>[...]</span> whose job it is to stop other hormones&nbsp;	Delta Islet cells release <span class=cloze>somatostatin</span> whose job it is to stop other hormones&nbsp;<br> 
Small intestine ends in <span class=cloze>[...]</span> valve&nbsp;	Small intestine ends in <span class=cloze>ileocecal</span> valve&nbsp;<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> ends in ileocecal valve&nbsp;	<span class=cloze>Small intestine</span> ends in ileocecal valve&nbsp;<br> 
Large Intestine is responsible for absorbing <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Large Intestine is responsible for absorbing <span class=cloze>water</span><br> 
Too little water being absorbed by LI results in diarrhea and too much leads to <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Too little water being absorbed by LI results in diarrhea and too much leads to <span class=cloze>constipation</span><br> 
Too little water being absorbed by LI results in <span class=cloze>[...]</span> and too much leads to constipation	Too little water being absorbed by LI results in <span class=cloze>diarrhea</span> and too much leads to constipation<br> 
The disease, <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, involves bacteria affecting the LI and can lead to death by dehydration	The disease, <span class=cloze>Cholera</span>, involves bacteria affecting the LI and can lead to death by dehydration<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> is rich source of microorganisms, which assist in digestion	<span class=cloze>LI</span> is rich source of microorganisms, which assist in digestion<br> 
LI is rich source of <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, which assist in digestion	LI is rich source of <span class=cloze>microorganisms</span>, which assist in digestion<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> holds on to stool	<span class=cloze>Rectum</span> holds on to stool<br> 
Anus is composed of two <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, one made of smooth and one made of skeletal muscle	Anus is composed of two <span class=cloze>sphincters</span>, one made of smooth and one made of skeletal muscle<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> Nervous System is the nervous system of the GI	<span class=cloze>Enteric</span> Nervous System is the nervous system of the GI<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> reflex pushes food in our colon further south when food enters the stomach	<span class=cloze>Gastrocolic</span> reflex pushes food in our colon further south when food enters the stomach<br> 
When food enters stomach, it releases <span class=cloze>[...]</span> which causes secretion of HCl by <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, pepsinogen by <span class=cloze>[...]</span> and increases stomach motility. Pepsinogen&nbsp;is turned into active <span class=cloze>[...]</span> by HCl and assists in the breakdown of <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	When food enters stomach, it releases <span class=cloze>Gastrin hormone</span> which causes secretion of HCl by <span class=cloze>parietal cells</span>, pepsinogen by <span class=cloze>chief cells</span> and increases stomach motility. Pepsinogen&nbsp;is turned into active <span class=cloze>pepsin</span> by HCl and assists in the breakdown of <span class=cloze>proteins</span><br>

Pepsinogen&nbsp;is turned into active pepsin by <span class=cloze>HCl</span> and assists in the breakdown of proteins<br>

Pepsinogen&nbsp;is turned into active pepsin by HCl and assists in the breakdown of proteins	When food enters stomach, it releases Gastrin hormone which causes secretion of HCl by parietal cells, <span class=cloze>pepsinogen</span> by chief cells and increases stomach motility. Pepsinogen&nbsp;is turned into active pepsin by HCl and assists in the breakdown of proteins<br>

When stomach acid reaches pH 3 <span class=cloze>[...]</span> secretion is stopped	When stomach acid reaches pH 3 <span class=cloze>gastrin</span> secretion is stopped<br>

It also stimulates the pancreas to release lipase. The HCl in our chyme causes <span class=cloze>secretin</span> to be released which inhibits <span class=cloze>gastrin</span> release from the <span class=cloze>stomach</span> and stimulates release of <span class=cloze>HCO3</span> by <br> 
What is the significance of the evolution of stomata?	Stomata are opening on the surface of plants that are not covered by cuticle. They provide a site for the movement of water into and out of the plant, and provide a site for gas exchange.
Do sporophytes develop from zygotes through mitosis or meiosis? Explain.	<div>Mitosis. The sporophyte is derived from the 2N zygote. The zygote is the result of the union of a</div><div>sperm (N) and an ovum (N). &nbsp;The zygote divided by mitosis to develop into a multicellular 2N sporophyte. &nbsp;</div>
<div>Why wouldn't a scientist automatically place a photosynthetic organism into the same</div><div>clade as land plants?</div>	Photosynthesis occurs in many other organisms. Like Algae
Why do nonvascular plants grow so close to the ground?	They lack the support structures (xylem and phloem) that allow vascular plants to grow vertically.
<div>Which of the following is a characteristic of a nonvascular plant?&nbsp;</div><div>Select one:</div><div>• xylem and phloem</div><div>• complex root systems&nbsp;</div><div>•&nbsp;photosynthetic structures</div><div>•&nbsp;flowering reproductive structures&nbsp;</div><div>•&nbsp;thick, waxy cuticle&nbsp;</div>	photosynthetic structures
<div>Mosses have a thin cuticle that offers very little protection against dehydration. Why is this a</div><div>beneficial trait for the moss?</div>	A thin cuticle allows mosses to absorb moisture from their environment.
What life cycle phase dominates the life of a nonvascular plant?	gametophyte
<div>During what phase of its life cycle does a seedless vascular plant spend most of its life?</div>	sporocyte
Gymnosperm diversity evolved in a geologic period marked by changing climate conditions. Why would anthropogenic climate change be a threat to gymnosperms now?	The changes to the environment being introduced by anthropogenic factors are happening at such a rapid rate: much faster than environmental changes that occurred in past geological time periods. If gymnosperms lack the adaptations to adjust to these rapid changes, those organism may suffer loses. &nbsp;
<div>Which innovations gave gymnosperms a selective advantage over the&nbsp;nonvascular and seedless vascular plants during the Permian period? (4)</div>	bark, seeds, needle-shaped leaves, greatly reduced gametophyte stage
Which structure of a pine is the immature male gametophyte?	one prothallial cell, one generative cell, and two tube cells...<div><br /></div><div>NOT:&nbsp;cone, seed, pollen grain, or the tree</div>
<div>By what mechanism is gymnosperm pollen usually carried from male pollen cones to the&nbsp;female ovule cones that contain the eggs?</div>	wind
Which trait has not contributed to the dominance of angiosperms in many ecosystems?	thick, desiccation-resistant leaves that persist year-round in temperate habitats
What is the most common function of an angiosperm's sepals?	They protect the petals and other organs during flower development.
Approximately when do scientists believe life originated on Earth?	4.2 Billion Years ago
<div>Which piece of evidence supports the idea that life originated in or near submarine hydrothermal</div><div>vents?</div>	Some of the microorganisms that appear to have evolved earliest still live in hydrothermal vents.
When the Murchison meteorite that landed in Australia was found to contain amino acids, how could scientists tell they had arrived with the meteorite rather than having contaminated it after it landed?	About half of the amino acids were D isomers and half were L isomers, whereas nearly all organic molecules on Earth are in the L configuration.
<div>Huntington's disease, a progressive nervous system disorder, is inherited as a dominant trait. The songwriter Woody Guthrie died of Huntington's disease. If he was heterozygous for the trait and his wife did not carry it, what was the probability that their</div><div>son would develop Huntington's disease? (make a punnet square)</div>	50%<div><br /></div>
If both parents are heterozygous for a trait, what is the probability that a given offspring of theirs will display the recessive trait? Assume the gene for the trait is not sex-linked. (make punnet square)	1/4
<div>For fruit flies, brown body color (B) is dominant to black body color (b). A brown fruit fly is crossed with a black fruit fly. Both flies are purebred. What will the offspring's</div><div>genotypes be? (make punnet square)</div>	all Bb
<div>During metaphase I, the tetrads are aligned at the metaphase plate. How does their arrangement influence genetic variation? What is this concept called?</div>	<div>The two sets of duplicated homologous chromosomes synapsis at metaphase I. The positioning of the two duplicated chromosomes on either side in the middle of the cell is independent assortment. The separation of the two sets of duplicated homologous chromosome is segregation. &nbsp; &nbsp;</div>
Explain how crossing over increases genetic variation.	Non-sister chromatids from homologous chromosomes exchange genetic information, usually at two or more locations per chromosome depending on the size.
Describe how independent assortment during meiosis increases genetic variation.	The random arrangement of chromosomes during metaphase I creates gametes that are genetically unique from one another.
Describe in order the four phases that occur during meiosis II.	prophase II, metaphase II, anaphase II, telophase II

"<b>Gymnosperm's Alteration of Generations (#3 aka Fertilization)</b>:&nbsp;<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">pollen grain</font></b> (also known as the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> and is <span class=cloze>[...]</span>) <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">enters</font></b> the <u>Megastrobalus</u> (which makes pollen and ovum) and the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> of the <font color=""#0a00f6"">pollen grain</font> <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fuses</font></b> with the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>&nbsp;which is also <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span>.</font></div>"	"<b>Gymnosperm's Alteration of Generations (#3 aka Fertilization)</b>:&nbsp;<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">pollen grain</font></b> (also known as the <span class=cloze><font color=""#0a00f6"">male gametophyte</font></span> and is <span class=cloze><font color=""#0a00f6"">1N</font></span>) <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">enters</font></b> the <u>Megastrobalus</u> (which makes pollen and ovum) and the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>nucleus</span></font> of the <font color=""#0a00f6"">pollen grain</font> <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fuses</font></b> with the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>Ovum nucleus</span></font>&nbsp;which is also <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>1n</span>.</font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 2.19.44 PM.png"" />"
"<b>Gymnosperm's Alteration of Generations (#3 aka Fertilization)</b>:&nbsp;<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b> (also known as the <font color=""#0a00f6"">male gametophyte</font> and is <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N</font>) <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">enters</font></b> the <u>Megastrobalus</u> (which makes pollen and ovum) and the <font color=""#0a00f6"">nucleus</font> of the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fuses</font></b> with the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">Ovum nucleus</font>&nbsp;which is also <font color=""#0a00f6"">1n.</font></div>"	"<b>Gymnosperm's Alteration of Generations (#3 aka Fertilization)</b>:&nbsp;<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>pollen grain</span></font></b> (also known as the <font color=""#0a00f6"">male gametophyte</font> and is <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N</font>) <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">enters</font></b> the <u>Megastrobalus</u> (which makes pollen and ovum) and the <font color=""#0a00f6"">nucleus</font> of the <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>pollen grain</span></font> <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">fuses</font></b> with the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">Ovum nucleus</font>&nbsp;which is also <font color=""#0a00f6"">1n.</font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 2.19.44 PM.png"" />"
"<b>Gymnosperm's Alteration of Generations (#3 aka Fertilization)</b>:&nbsp;<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">pollen grain</font></b> (also known as the <font color=""#0a00f6"">male gametophyte</font> and is <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N</font>) <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b> the <u>Megastrobalus</u> (which makes pollen and ovum) and the <font color=""#0a00f6"">nucleus</font> of the <font color=""#0a00f6"">pollen grain</font> <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></b> with the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">Ovum nucleus</font>&nbsp;which is also <font color=""#0a00f6"">1n.</font></div>"	"<b>Gymnosperm's Alteration of Generations (#3 aka Fertilization)</b>:&nbsp;<div>The <b><font color=""#0a00f6"">pollen grain</font></b> (also known as the <font color=""#0a00f6"">male gametophyte</font> and is <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N</font>) <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>enters</span></font></b> the <u>Megastrobalus</u> (which makes pollen and ovum) and the <font color=""#0a00f6"">nucleus</font> of the <font color=""#0a00f6"">pollen grain</font> <b><font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>fuses</span></font></b> with the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">Ovum nucleus</font>&nbsp;which is also <font color=""#0a00f6"">1n.</font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 2.19.44 PM.png"" />"

The <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of angiosperms undergo photosynthesis (respiration, and photorespiration) to convert light energy,&nbsp;O<sub>2</sub>, and&nbsp;CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;into&nbsp;sugars (C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>)&nbsp;and starch.	"The <span class=cloze>leaves</span> of angiosperms undergo photosynthesis (respiration, and photorespiration) to convert light energy,&nbsp;O<sub>2</sub>, and&nbsp;CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;into&nbsp;sugars (C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>)&nbsp;and starch.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 3.49.36 PM.png"" />"
The leaves of angiosperms undergo <span class=cloze>[...]</span> (<span class=cloze>[...]</span>, and <span class=cloze>[...]</span>) to convert <span class=cloze>[...]</span>,&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>, and&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;into&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;and <span class=cloze>[...]</span>.	"The leaves of angiosperms undergo <span class=cloze>photosynthesis</span> (<span class=cloze>respiration</span>, and <span class=cloze>photorespiration</span>) to convert <span class=cloze>light energy</span>,&nbsp;<span class=cloze>O<sub>2</sub></span>, and&nbsp;<span class=cloze>CO<sub>2</sub></span>&nbsp;into&nbsp;<span class=cloze>sugars (C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>)</span>&nbsp;and <span class=cloze>starch</span>.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 3.49.36 PM.png"" />"
In angiosperms, the sugars and water travel up and down networks inside the stem called the&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"In angiosperms, the sugars and water travel up and down networks inside the stem called the&nbsp;<span class=cloze>xylem and phloem</span><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 3.49.36 PM.png"" />"
In angiosperms, H<sub>2</sub>O vapor and O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;pass through membranes of the cells that make up its <b><span class=cloze>[...]</span></b>	"In angiosperms, H<sub>2</sub>O vapor and O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;pass through membranes of the cells that make up its <b><span class=cloze>leaves</span></b><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 3.49.36 PM.png"" />"
The&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> of angiosperms store starch, sugar, as well as the seeds for future reproduction.	"The&nbsp;<span class=cloze><b>fruit</b></span> of angiosperms store starch, sugar, as well as the seeds for future reproduction.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 3.49.36 PM.png"" />"
The&nbsp;<b>fruit</b> of angiosperms store <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, <span class=cloze>[...]</span>, as well as the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> for future reproduction.	"The&nbsp;<b>fruit</b> of angiosperms store <span class=cloze>starch</span>, <span class=cloze>sugar</span>, as well as the <span class=cloze>seeds</span> for future reproduction.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 3.49.36 PM.png"" />"
The&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> of angiosperms allow for respiration but no&nbsp;photorespiration. These absorb&nbsp;O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and H<sub>2</sub>O and minerals&nbsp;(4)&nbsp;	"The&nbsp;<span class=cloze>roots</span> of angiosperms allow for respiration but no&nbsp;photorespiration. These absorb&nbsp;O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and H<sub>2</sub>O and minerals&nbsp;(4)&nbsp;<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 3.49.36 PM.png"" />"
The&nbsp;roots of angiosperms allow for respiration but no&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>. These absorb&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;(4)&nbsp;	"The&nbsp;roots of angiosperms allow for respiration but no&nbsp;<span class=cloze>photorespiration</span>. These absorb&nbsp;<span class=cloze>O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and H<sub>2</sub>O and minerals</span>&nbsp;(4)&nbsp;<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 3.49.36 PM.png"" />"
<b>Gymnosperms vs Angiosperms</b>:<div>Compare both their sporophytes and gametophytes.</div>	Gymnosperms: have 2 different cones (female and male gametophytes), each containing the pollen and ovule.<div>Angiosperms: Both male and female gametophytes are inside the flower...</div><div><br /></div><div>BOTH Sporophytes and gametophytes are 2N and 1N (respectively)</div>

Angiosperms are capable of <span class=cloze>[...]</span> for reproduction.&nbsp;	Angiosperms are capable of <span class=cloze>contaning both the male and female parts</span> for reproduction.&nbsp;<br> 
Some angiosperms can be&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>-sex like an&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> or even sperately sexed	Some angiosperms can be&nbsp;<span class=cloze>single</span>-sex like an&nbsp;<span class=cloze>avocado tree</span> or even sperately sexed<br> 
Some angiosperms can be&nbsp;single-sex like an&nbsp;avocado tree or even <span class=cloze>[...]</span> sexed	Some angiosperms can be&nbsp;single-sex like an&nbsp;avocado tree or even <span class=cloze>sperately</span> sexed<br> 
"The&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> of angiosperms are&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">mega-gametophyte</font> chambers consisting of the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">ovule,&nbsp;megasporocyte</font> which is&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">2N</font>, and the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">megasporangium</font>.<div>Once it undergoes&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">meiosis</font>, it produces a surviving <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N megaspore</font></div>"	"The&nbsp;<span class=cloze>ovary</span> of angiosperms are&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">mega-gametophyte</font> chambers consisting of the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">ovule,&nbsp;megasporocyte</font> which is&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">2N</font>, and the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">megasporangium</font>.<div>Once it undergoes&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6"">meiosis</font>, it produces a surviving <font color=""#0a00f6"">1N megaspore</font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.27.36 PM.png"" />"
"The&nbsp;ovary of angiosperms are&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> chambers consisting of the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span>,&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span></font> which is&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>, and the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>.<div>Once it undergoes&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span></font>, it produces a surviving <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>[...]</span> <span class=cloze>[...]</span></font></div>"	"The&nbsp;ovary of angiosperms are&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>mega-gametophyte</span></font> chambers consisting of the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>ovule</span>,&nbsp;<span class=cloze>megasporocyte</span></font> which is&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>2N</span></font>, and the&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>megasporangium</span></font>.<div>Once it undergoes&nbsp;<font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>meiosis</span></font>, it produces a surviving <font color=""#0a00f6""><span class=cloze>1N</span> <span class=cloze>megaspore</span></font></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.27.36 PM.png"" />"
The ovary of angiosperms consists of&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> nuclei, very&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> quantity compared to ferns	The ovary of angiosperms consists of&nbsp;<span class=cloze>8</span> nuclei, very&nbsp;<span class=cloze>small</span> quantity compared to ferns<br> 
The stigma is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>.	The stigma is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>sticky</span>.<br> 
stigma	(a part of the pistil)<div>the site where pollen grains will attach to the ovary.</div>
(a part of the pistil)<div>the site where pollen grains will attach to the ovary.</div>	stigma
Once the pollen attaches to the stigma, it releases&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> that makes a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> aka&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> through the style to the ovary for <b>fertilization</b>.&nbsp;	"Once the pollen attaches to the stigma, it releases&nbsp;<span class=cloze>enzymes</span> that makes a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>channel</span> aka&nbsp;<span class=cloze>pollen tube</span> through the style to the ovary for <b>fertilization</b>.&nbsp;<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.04.23 PM.png"" />"
In order for fertilization to occur in angiosperms, <span class=cloze>[...]</span> must make it through the style to the ovary. ***UNIQUE CHARACTERISTIC***	"In order for fertilization to occur in angiosperms, <span class=cloze>2 pollen grains</span> must make it through the style to the ovary. ***UNIQUE CHARACTERISTIC***<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.04.23 PM.png"" />"
The anther has&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> and within these are&nbsp;microsporocyytes (diploid) that undergo <b>meiosis</b>&nbsp;to divide into 4 microspores (haploid) aka pollen.	"The anther has&nbsp;<span class=cloze>several chambers</span> and within these are&nbsp;microsporocyytes (diploid) that undergo <b>meiosis</b>&nbsp;to divide into 4 microspores (haploid) aka pollen.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.36.30 PM.png"" />"
The anther has&nbsp;several chambers and within these are&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> (<span class=cloze>[...]</span>) that undergo <b>meiosis</b>&nbsp;to divide into <span class=cloze>[...]</span> (<span class=cloze>[...]</span>) aka pollen.	"The anther has&nbsp;several chambers and within these are&nbsp;<span class=cloze>microsporocyytes</span> (<span class=cloze>diploid</span>) that undergo <b>meiosis</b>&nbsp;to divide into <span class=cloze>4 microspores</span> (<span class=cloze>haploid</span>) aka pollen.<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.36.30 PM.png"" />"
Angiosperm pollen do not have&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> like gymnosperms... but they are <span class=cloze>[...]</span> so they can still be carried by the <span class=cloze>[...]</span>.	Angiosperm pollen do not have&nbsp;<span class=cloze>wings</span> like gymnosperms... but they are <span class=cloze>round and small</span> so they can still be carried by the <span class=cloze>wind</span>.<br> 
Within the ovary of angiosperms, is an ovule that undergoes <b>meiosis</b>&nbsp;to produce <span class=cloze>[...]</span>... only&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> survives.&nbsp;	Within the ovary of angiosperms, is an ovule that undergoes <b>meiosis</b>&nbsp;to produce <span class=cloze> 4 diploid megasporocytes</span>... only&nbsp;<span class=cloze>one</span> survives.&nbsp;<br> 
Angiosperms are considered&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> because they produce both microspores and megaspores	Angiosperms are considered&nbsp;<span class=cloze>heterosporous</span> because they produce both microspores and megaspores<br> 
Angiosperms are considered&nbsp;heterosporous because they produce both <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Angiosperms are considered&nbsp;heterosporous because they produce both <span class=cloze>microspores and megaspores</span><br> 
Angiosperm Life Cycle:<div>Each microspore undergoes mitosis to produce a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>, this is a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> male gametophyte also known as a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span></div>	"Angiosperm Life Cycle:<div>Each microspore undergoes mitosis to produce a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>pollen grain</span>, this is a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>haploid</span> male gametophyte also known as a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>microgametophyte</span></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.50.07 PM.png"" />"
Angiosperm life cycle:<div>The surviving megaspore divides by&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> to produce&nbsp;seven (7) <b>haploid</b>&nbsp;cells: one large centered cell contains 2 nuclei (total of 8 within the megagametophyte (1N)</div>	"Angiosperm life cycle:<div>The surviving megaspore divides by&nbsp;<span class=cloze>mitosis</span> to produce&nbsp;seven (7) <b>haploid</b>&nbsp;cells: one large centered cell contains 2 nuclei (total of 8 within the megagametophyte (1N)</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.52.55 PM.png"" />"
Angiosperm life cycle:<div>The surviving megaspore divides by&nbsp;mitosis to produce&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> <b>haploid</b>&nbsp;cells: one large centered cell contains 2 nuclei (total of 8 within the megagametophyte (1N)</div>	"Angiosperm life cycle:<div>The surviving megaspore divides by&nbsp;mitosis to produce&nbsp;<span class=cloze>seven (7)</span> <b>haploid</b>&nbsp;cells: one large centered cell contains 2 nuclei (total of 8 within the megagametophyte (1N)</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.52.55 PM.png"" />"
Angiosperm life cycle:<div>The surviving megaspore divides by&nbsp;mitosis to produce&nbsp;seven (7) <b>haploid</b>&nbsp;cells: one large centered cell contains <span class=cloze>[...]</span> (total of 8 within the megagametophyte (1N)</div>	"Angiosperm life cycle:<div>The surviving megaspore divides by&nbsp;mitosis to produce&nbsp;seven (7) <b>haploid</b>&nbsp;cells: one large centered cell contains <span class=cloze>2 nuclei</span> (total of 8 within the megagametophyte (1N)</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.52.55 PM.png"" />"
The process when pollen lands on the stigma and forms the pollen tube is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>	The process when pollen lands on the stigma and forms the pollen tube is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>germination</span><br> 
2 pollen grains travel to the ovule: 1 <span class=cloze>[...]</span> an <b>egg</b> forming a 2N&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>; the other&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> a <b>polar nuclei</b>&nbsp;forming a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> which is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>.<div>This process is known as&nbsp;<b>double fertilization</b></div>	"2 pollen grains travel to the ovule: 1 <span class=cloze>fertilizes</span> an <b>egg</b> forming a 2N&nbsp;<span class=cloze>zygote</span>; the other&nbsp;<span class=cloze> fertilizes</span> a <b>polar nuclei</b>&nbsp;forming a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>triploid cell</span> which is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>3N</span>.<div>This process is known as&nbsp;<b>double fertilization</b></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.56.54 PM.png"" />"
2 pollen grains travel to the ovule: 1 fertilizes an <b>egg</b> forming a 2N&nbsp;zygote; the other&nbsp; fertilizes a <b>polar nuclei</b>&nbsp;forming a&nbsp;triploid cell which is&nbsp;3N.<div>This process is known as&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span></div>	"2 pollen grains travel to the ovule: 1 fertilizes an <b>egg</b> forming a 2N&nbsp;zygote; the other&nbsp; fertilizes a <b>polar nuclei</b>&nbsp;forming a&nbsp;triploid cell which is&nbsp;3N.<div>This process is known as&nbsp;<span class=cloze><b>double fertilization</b></span></div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.56.54 PM.png"" />"
The fertilization of the egg cell and the central cell (forming a 3N cell) is called&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>	"The fertilization of the egg cell and the central cell (forming a 3N cell) is called&nbsp;<span class=cloze>double fertilization</span><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.56.54 PM.png"" />"
<div>After double fertilization:</div>The <span class=cloze>[...]</span> develops into the embryo. The <span class=cloze>[...]</span> develops into the endosperm of the seed.&nbsp;	"<div>After double fertilization:</div>The <span class=cloze>zygote (2N)</span> develops into the embryo. The <span class=cloze>triploid cell (3N)</span> develops into the endosperm of the seed.&nbsp;<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.59.32 PM.png"" />"
<div>After double fertilization:</div>The zygote (2N) develops into the <span class=cloze>[...]</span>. The triploid cell (3N) develops into the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of the seed.&nbsp;	"<div>After double fertilization:</div>The zygote (2N) develops into the <span class=cloze>embryo</span>. The triploid cell (3N) develops into the <span class=cloze>endosperm</span> of the seed.&nbsp;<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 4.59.32 PM.png"" />"
Once the angiosperm seed germinates, the sporophyte matures to become a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>... the lifecycle begins again!	Once the angiosperm seed germinates, the sporophyte matures to become a&nbsp;<span class=cloze>seedling</span>... the lifecycle begins again!<br>

a plant that is eaten	vegetable
vegetable	a plant that is eaten
Examples of vegetables	tomato, potato, lettuce, cucumber, cabbage
The edible part of a plant consisting of seeds and pulpy surrounding tissue	Fruit

Is cucumber a fruit? or vegetable?	both
Are walnuts fruits or vegetables?	fruits
Why study biodiversity?	"To get a better understanding of how cells work and how we can use that to our benefit.. THERE ARE LESSONS TO BE LEARNED<b>..</b><div><b>I.E.&nbsp;</b><img src=""150.jpg"" /></div><div>how this can regenerate completely</div>"
"<img src=""Tardigrade-2.jpg"" /><div>what is this? why is it interesting</div>"	"<i>Tardigrade</i>&nbsp;or ""Water bear"" - doesn't die in 0 oxygen or absolute 0 environments... survives in <i>space</i>"
systematics	The science of cataloging (classifying) biodiversity (figuring how many kinds of organisms there are and how they relate to each other)
The science of cataloging (classifying) biodiversity (figuring how many kinds of organisms there are and how they relate to each other)	systematics
taxonomy	the science of naming the living organism
<i>scala naturae</i>	"<b>scale of nature </b>- originally derived by Plato/Aristotle<div>A hierarchal orginization of things in the environment (both living and nonliving).</div><div><img src=""6cee006b73a9f4c2b2ffb27e7ccf8507.jpg"" /></div>"
"<b>scale of nature </b>- originally derived by Plato/Aristotle<div>A hierarchal orginization of things in the environment (both living and nonliving).</div><div><img src=""6cee006b73a9f4c2b2ffb27e7ccf8507.jpg"" /></div>"	<i>scala naturae</i>
"The concept of ""scale of nature"" was adopted by the 18th Century Swiss Naturalist&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> who made his own version that ordered things/creatures/man by&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>,&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>, and <span class=cloze>[...]</span>"	"The concept of ""scale of nature"" was adopted by the 18th Century Swiss Naturalist&nbsp;<span class=cloze>Charle Bonnet</span> who made his own version that ordered things/creatures/man by&nbsp;<span class=cloze>anatomical complexity</span>,&nbsp;<span class=cloze> religious significance</span>, and <span class=cloze>practical usefulness</span><br> <img src=""ScaleNature-1-300 (1).jpg"" />"
"This thinking of ""scale of nature"" still persists today in the form of there being&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>.&nbsp;"	"This thinking of ""scale of nature"" still persists today in the form of there being&nbsp;<span class=cloze>lower and higher animals</span>.&nbsp;<br> "
"The concept of ""scale of nature"" is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> because it leads to wrong thinking of evolution. Every current living organism is here beause it is good enough that it survived in the current environment."	"The concept of ""scale of nature"" is&nbsp;<span class=cloze>WRONG</span> because it leads to wrong thinking of evolution. Every current living organism is here beause it is good enough that it survived in the current environment.<br> "
"The concept of ""scale of nature"" is&nbsp;WRONG because it leads to wrong thinking of evolution. Every current living organism is here beause it is <span class=cloze>[...]</span>"	"The concept of ""scale of nature"" is&nbsp;WRONG because it leads to wrong thinking of evolution. Every current living organism is here beause it is <span class=cloze>good enough that it survived in the current environment.</span><br> "
Everything that is alive today is here because its ancestors were&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Everything that is alive today is here because its ancestors were&nbsp;<span class=cloze>good enough to survive their environment</span><br> 
Everything that is alive today is here <span class=cloze>[...]</span>... ALL are the&nbsp;<b><span class=cloze>[...]</span> of&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>... just differently evolved</b>&nbsp;<div>NOT that&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> gave rise to&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span></div>	Everything that is alive today is here <span class=cloze>at the same time</span>... ALL are the&nbsp;<b><span class=cloze>end-products</span> of&nbsp;<span class=cloze>evolution</span>... just differently evolved</b>&nbsp;<div>NOT that&nbsp;<span class=cloze>simple animals</span> gave rise to&nbsp;<span class=cloze>complex animals</span></div><br> 
Baron Cuvier organized animals into 4 groups:	<b>Radiata </b>(circular animals; jellyfish and starfish), <b>articulata</b> (segmented animals; worms), <b>mollusca </b>(animals with shell and brain), and <b>vertebrata </b>(bony skeleton, muscular heart, red blood)
Baron Cuvier's organization has no hierchy... but also has no&nbsp;	relationship ... he didn't believe in evolution; was a creationist (:D)
Lamarck is credited with the theory of...; and the ...	inherited characteristics..&nbsp;<div>tree of life</div>
"Which scientist made this?<div><img src=""220px-Haeckel_arbol_bn.png"" /></div>"	19th Century German scientist Haeckel
Why does the tree analogy works (kind of) for evolution?	Twigs = species<div>Close proxymity = closely related</div><div>Branches = deeper relationships (phyla)</div><div><br /></div><div>All twigs and branches come from one ancestor</div>
plural of phylum	phyla
What makes something a part of Phylum Animalae? (has to have 4 things)	Notochord,<div>dorsal hollow nerve cord,</div><div>post anal tail,</div><div>pharyngeal gill slits</div><div><br /></div><div>all more evident during embryo stage</div>
A group of organisms that share a common body plan and evolutionary or phylogenic relationship	phylum
There are&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> animal phyla recognized today	There are&nbsp;<span class=cloze>30-35</span> animal phyla recognized today<br> 
Exceptions to categorizing phyla:<div>Some organisms with similar body plans are distantly relate so are in&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> phyla</div><div>Some organisms with different body plans are found closely related and are placed in&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> phylum</div>	Exceptions to categorizing phyla:<div>Some organisms with similar body plans are distantly relate so are in&nbsp;<span class=cloze>different</span> phyla</div><div>Some organisms with different body plans are found closely related and are placed in&nbsp;<span class=cloze>same</span> phylum</div><br> 
9 well known phyla are .. and 4 more common are	porifera, cnidaria, arthropoda, nematoda, annelida, mollusca, platyhelminthes, echinodermata;<div>bryozoa, nemertea, rotifera, tardigrada</div>
<b>What is an Animal?</b><div>Eukaryotes or prokaryotes?</div>	eukaryotes
<b>What is an Animal?</b><div>Cell wall or no cell wall (which has do /don't)</div>	lack a cell wall.<div>Plants and fungi do have cell wall</div>
<b>What is an Animal?</b><div>haploid or diploid?</div>	diploid body form (haploid gametes - product of meiosis)
<b>What is an Animal?</b><div>Stationary or mobile?</div>	mobile (usually)
<b>What is an Animal?</b><div>asexual or sexual reproduction?</div>	sexually reprodcuing (anisogamous) - usually
anisogamous	gametes: big eggs and small sperm
<b>What is an Animal?</b><div>Autotrophs or Heterotrophs? explain</div>	Heterotrophs that ingest food and digest it in an internal cavity
<b>What is an Animal?</b><div>What is the level of organization of the components that make up an animal..?</div>	(Cell)&nbsp;→ Tissue&nbsp;→ Organs&nbsp;→ Organ Systems (like nervous/sensory, motor, gas exchange, excretory, digestive, circulatory, reproductive)
___ are the closest single-celled relatives of animals	choanoflagellates&nbsp;
<b>choanoflagellates&nbsp;</b>form multicellular <span class=cloze>[...]</span> but lack <span class=cloze>[...]</span> cell types with a <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of labor	"<b>choanoflagellates&nbsp;</b>form multicellular <span class=cloze>colonies</span> but lack <span class=cloze>differentiated</span> cell types with a <span class=cloze>division</span> of labor<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 6.27.58 PM.png"" />"
Isogamy	"when gametes are roughly the same size to each other and mature cell<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 6.33.17 PM.png"" /></div>"
Anisogamy benefits	"Most animals - small sperm : easier to move (fast)<div>Large ovum - full of nutrients<img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 6.35.17 PM.png"" /></div>"
Not all animals <b>have sex!</b>&nbsp;Example?	"bdelloid rotiffers have secondarily lost sex!!!<div>Females reproduce through <b>parthenogenesis. males</b>&nbsp;have NEVER BEEN OBSERVED.</div><div>Genomics : 80 million years without sex&nbsp;<img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 6.37.06 PM.png"" /></div>"
female bdelloid rotifers reproduce through	parthenogenesis
bdelloid rotifers haven't had sex for (years)	80 million years

What are the three germ layers of a grastula (zygote that has cleavaged)	ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm
How is animal sexual reproduction and development similar to the relative choanoflagellates?	"colonial choanoflagellates resemble blastula stage<img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-12 at 8.27.26 PM.png"" />"
Air travels through the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> at the top of the trachea to the lungs	Air travels through the <span class=cloze>voice box</span> at the top of the trachea to the lungs<br> 
Air travels through the voice box at the top of the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> to the lungs	Air travels through the voice box at the top of the <span class=cloze>trachea</span> to the lungs<br> 
Right lung has <span class=cloze>[...]</span> lobes and left has 2&nbsp;	Right lung has <span class=cloze>3</span> lobes and left has 2&nbsp;<br> 
Right lung has 3 lobes and left has <span class=cloze>[...]</span>&nbsp;	Right lung has 3 lobes and left has <span class=cloze>2</span>&nbsp;<br> 
<span class=cloze>[...]</span> makes an indentation in the Left Lung	<span class=cloze>Cardiac Notch</span> makes an indentation in the Left Lung<br> 
Cardiac Notch makes an indentation in the <span class=cloze>[...]</span>	Cardiac Notch makes an indentation in the <span class=cloze>Left Lung</span><br>

Henry's Law	P/Kh=C&nbsp;<div>P= Partial Pressure of solute in gas above solution(gas going in)/ Kh (solubility of substance/ gas going out) = concentration of solute dissolved in solvent&nbsp;</div>
CO2 is (more OR less) soluble than Oxygen in blod	MUCH MOREEEE
CO2 has a (Greater OR Smaller) Kh than Oxygen in blood	Smaller!! (CO2 comfy in the blood)
Ficks Law	V=( (P1-P2)* A * D)/ T<div><br /></div><div>V=Rate of particles moving</div><div>A=Surface Area</div><div>Delta P= Change in Pressure</div><div>D=Diffusion Contstant&nbsp;</div><div>T= Thickness of wall</div>
D in Fick's Law	Diffusion Constant = (Solubility/ Sq root of Molec. Wt.) = (Henry's Law/Graham's Law)
Fick's Law in simplified version:	Flux=Gradient*Diffusion Constant<div><br /></div><div>Flux= Rate/Surface Area</div><div>Gradient=Delta Pressure/Distance</div>
Almost all animals have common development sequence:<div>The process of a zygote becoming an&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span>... dividing cells that are&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> identical.</div><div>The&nbsp;<span class=cloze>[...]</span> stage is ubiquitous among animals.</div>	"Almost all animals have common development sequence:<div>The process of a zygote becoming an&nbsp;<span class=cloze>embryo</span>... dividing cells that are&nbsp;<span class=cloze>genetically</span> identical.</div><div>The&nbsp;<span class=cloze><b>blastula</b></span> stage is ubiquitous among animals.</div><br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-13 at 10.48.53 AM.png"" />"
In Fick's Law, Flux is&nbsp;	Rate of particles/Surface Area
In Fick's Law, Gradient is	Delta Pressure/ Distance
In the blastula stage we have a ... of cells. that surround the ...	"<b>hollowed ball of cells </b>that ultimately gets produced after a series of divisions... you end up with a monolayer epithelial tissue shaped like a ball.&nbsp;<div><b>The cells (blastoecel) surround the blastocoele (fluid filled cavity of amino acids, proteins, growth factors, sugars, ions, and other components necessary for cellular differentiation.)</b></div><div><b><img src=""Blastula_(PSF).jpg"" /></b></div>"
fluid filled cavity of amino acids, proteins, growth factors, sugars, ions, and other components necessary for cellular differentiation	"blastocoel<img src=""Blastula_(PSF).jpg"" />"

what is the <b>blastospore</b>?	an opening into the archenteron (blastula--gastrula) during the gastrulation stages

In most animals, the endoderm germ layer will produce	digestive tract

When was there a shift in the fossil records showing animals that relate to those alive today and those we don't see anymore? What are the two animals called?	"542 million years ago (before: &nbsp;ediacaran biota – after: cambrian animals)<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-13 at 11.50.42 AM.png"" /></div>"
ediacaran biota who lived prior to 542 million years ago fed like	osmoheterotrophs - fed by diffusion of debris with bacteria
"<img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-13 at 11.56.26 AM.png"" /><div>Is this an animal? is it a new phyla?</div>"	No. Discovered in 1970s . Actually belongsin Cnidaria and is related to jellyfish.
Phyla that are <b>non-bilaterian </b>(4 and give animal examples)	"porifera (sponges), ctenophora (comb jelly), placozoa (basal form of invertebrate), cnidaria (sea anemone, jellyfish)<div><img src=""paste-16874926507065.jpg"" /></div>"
Phyla that are&nbsp;in&nbsp;<b>bilateria&nbsp;</b>(4 phyla and the minor phyla; and give animal examples)	– Xenacoelomorpha<div>– Ecdysozoa:&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; • Arthropods (insects, crustaceans, arachnids)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; • Nematodes (roundworms)</div><div>– Lophotrochozoa:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; •&nbsp;Molluscs (snails, oysters, squid)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; •&nbsp;Annelids (earthworms, centepedes, millipedes)</div><div>–&nbsp;Deuterostomia</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; • Gdinodomes (?) - lost bilateral &nbsp;symmetry</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; •&nbsp;Chordates (vertibrates; humans, frogs, monkeys, etc.)</div>
<b>Protostomes</b> are animals in <b>bilateria,</b>&nbsp;whose blastopore becomes the ... during embryonic development. These include phyla:	mouth - first opening of the digestive tract. (The anus develops from an opening later inn development)<div><br /></div><div>Arthropods, nematodes, molluscs, and annelids</div>
<b>Deuterostomes</b>&nbsp;are animals in&nbsp;<b>bilateria,</b>&nbsp;whose blastopore becomes the ... during embryonic development. These include phyla:	anus (mouth forms later)-<div><br /></div><div>Chordates (vertebrates, sea squirts), echinodermata (sea stars, sea urchins), &nbsp;hemichordata (acornworms)</div>
Sponges are in Phylum...	cnidaria
comb jellies are in phylum	placozoa
jellydish &nbsp;are in phylum	cnidaria
roundworms are in phylum	nematoda
corals are in phylum&nbsp;	cnidaria
grasshoppers&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	arthropoda
lobsters and crabs (crustaceans)&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	arhropoda
earthworms&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	annelida
snails&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	mollusca
leeches&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	annelida
squids&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	mollusca
clams&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	mollusca
vertebrates (mammals, amphibians, reptiles) are in phylum&nbsp;	chordata
sea urchins&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	echinodermata
acorn worms&nbsp;are in phylum&nbsp;	hemichordata
star fish are in phylum&nbsp;	echinodermata
Xenacoelomorpha	<div>basal <b>bilaterian</b> clade of small and very simple animals</div>
<div>Ecdysozoa</div>	bilateria - but also in protostomia<div>Includes arthropods and nematodes</div>
lophotrochozoa	are bilateria - and protosomia<div>Includes molluscs and annelids</div>
which group includes snails?	snails are molluscs;<div>Molluscs are Lophotrochozoans</div>
animals before the cambrian period (542 mya) are&nbsp;	ediacaran biota - fed by abosorbing bacteria in the debris
What could future animals look like?	canine transmissible &nbsp;venereal tumors - found in dogs (and tazmanian devils);&nbsp;<div>Has persisted for several hundred years.. unicellular</div>
Why is it not best to rely on a checklist of traits to determine if an organism is an animal? ... Because traits can... (give examples)	– Traits can evolve independently (epithelial tissue);<div>– Traits &nbsp;can be secondarily lost (gut in tube worms; or multicellularity CTVT/canine tumor)</div><div>– New animals might be &nbsp;found (dendrogramma)</div>
If animals cannot be reliably defined based upon the presence of specific traits, how can they be defined?	"by the <b>phylogenetic definition/approach ––</b>&nbsp;animals can be defined as the descendants of a specific ancestor on a phylogenetic tree<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-13 at 1.34.52 PM.png"" /></div>"
animals can be defined as the <span class=cloze>[...]</span> of a specific ancestor on a phylogenetic tree	"animals can be defined as the <span class=cloze>descendants</span> of a specific ancestor on a phylogenetic tree<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-13 at 1.34.52 PM.png"" />"
animals can be defined as the descendants of a <span class=cloze>[...]</span> on a phylogenetic tree	"animals can be defined as the descendants of a <span class=cloze>specific ancestor</span> on a phylogenetic tree<br> <img src=""Screen Shot 2017-02-13 at 1.34.52 PM.png"" />"
